fields.headline: Fulham draw little comfort
fields.trailText: QPR 0 - 0 Fulham
fields.body:
A night of frantic rivalry, high endeavour and a handful of scoring chances ended with no one really surprised at the blank stalemate, given both teams' recent failure to finish off opponents.

At least Fulham's point keeps them in touch with the play-off positions. Rangers own hopes have diminished considerably but it always looked a tall order anyway.

Although Rangers' last four outings had all ended in 1-1 draws, Stan Bowles, the Loftus Road dribbling wizard of the 70s and rarely shy when a good bet is at hand, advised punters that a 1-0 home win was where their money should be put.

He was clearly not impressed with Fulham's scoring record; 29 goals was truly a meagre return for a club who have forward riches in reserve. Barry Hayles decided to delay his transatlantic journey to link up with the Cayman Islands' squad and formed an alliance with Karlheinz Riedle.

Rangers began strongly and, if the ball had fallen kindly for Gavin Peacock (twice), Bowles might have been made to regret his caution before five minutes had elapsed. Hayles' strength and pace caused problems at the other end and Darren Ward had to tackle firmly to keep him out.

After Riedle had come close with a header Rangers went to the interval cursing two missed chances from glorious positions. Chris Kiwomya lunged in only to balloon his header over the bar; and the finish from Stuart Wardley was equally wasteful after Jermaine Darlington had found him in generous space with a clever dinked pass.

Darlington continued to find scope to show his skills down the right.

Richard Langley went galloping into the same space three minutes into the second half and a perfect cross gave Kiwomya the opportunity to make amends. This time he headed the ball down and it bounced over the bar once more.

Both attacks were menacing on the counter and a breakthrough always appeared no more than a mistake or an astute touch away. It might have fallen to Hayles but poor control was his enemy after Steve Finnan had ushered him through.

With a minute remaining the hardworking Bjarne Goldbaek launched another raid from the right and it eventually fell to Hayles whose close- in stab drew a find stop from Lee Harper.

Queens Park Rangers (5-3-2): Harper; Darlington, Ward, Ready, Rose, Baraclough; Wardley, Peacock, Langley; Kiwomya, Beck.

Fulham (5-3-2): Taylor; Goldbaek, Melville, Morgan, Coleman, Phelan; Finnan, Ball, Clark; Riedle, Hayles.

Referee: T Heilbron (Co Durham).

fields.headline: Marseille 1 - 0 Chelsea
fields.standfirst: Chelsea fall to French resistance
fields.trailText:
Marseille: Trevisan, Cyprien, Luccin, Abardonado, Blondeau, Dalmat, Brando, Pires, Leroy, Pouget, Bakayoko. Subs: Carasso, Issa, Martin, De La Pena, Keita, Martini, Moses.
Chelsea: De Goey, Harley, Desailly, Leboeuf, Ferrer, Poyet, Deschamps, Wise, Petrescu, Flo, Zola. Subs: Cudicini, Sutton, Di Matteo, Ambrosetti, Morris, Lambourde, Thome.
fields.body:
Marseille: Trevisan, Cyprien, Luccin, Abardonado, Blondeau, Dalmat, Brando, Pires, Leroy, Pouget, Bakayoko. Subs: Carasso, Issa, Martin, De La Pena, Keita, Martini, Moses.
Chelsea: De Goey, Harley, Desailly, Leboeuf, Ferrer, Poyet, Deschamps, Wise, Petrescu, Flo, Zola. Subs: Cudicini, Sutton, Di Matteo, Ambrosetti, Morris, Lambourde, Thome.

1 min After a brief hibernation, the Champions' League Second Phase resumes with Chelsea visiting a fragile Marseille side. Chelsea have named an attacking eleven with Poyet, Flo and Zola all starting.
2 Chelsea, after a positive start, are still asleep defensively. Bakayoko beats Harley with ease on the right and his cross is struck low towards Pouget. The Marseille forward had pulled well away from Leboeuf, but could only scuff his shot wide of De Goey's goal. A great chance and the home side should be one-up.
5 After their defensive lapse, Chelsea have settled into their rhythm well. Flo in particular looks very comfortable. The Norwegian international turns Blondeau inside-out on the left before thrashing the ball into the side netting from 15 yards as Zola waited on the penalty-spot.
7 Harley has his first chance to overlap and appears to relish the 'challenge' of Blondeau. The young Englishman beats the right-wing back with ease before delivering a cross to Flo at the far post. His nod-down is towards Zola, who shapes to hit a waist-high volley goalwards. His balance and shape are a little off and as a result his shot is too. Goal kick.
12 Free kick to Chelsea just inside their own half and everyone pushes up. The ball in is poorly hit but as the ball is cleared Flo is fouled on the centre-right 30 yards from goal.
13 It's Zola to take but his effort disappears straight into the wall. The rebound drops to Leboeuf, but his shot is charged down and the home side can break upfield.
16 GOAL Marseille 1 - 0 Chelsea Well that's a surprise. Pires with some space and time on the right, decides against the cross and cuts into De Goey's box. Spotting the Chelsea keeper a little distance away from his near post, he puts his head down and hits a perfect drive that clips the near post then shoots into the net off the far post. Silence reigns as even the home crowd can't believe this Goal of the Unexpected.
19 Flo finds half a yard on Luccin in a central position just outside the Marseille area. He tries his luck with his left foot but Trevisan covers well and palms the low shot wide of his right-hand post.
22 Chelsea keep possession well as Flo and Zola exchange crosses on from first the left, then the right. Eventually Trevisan comes and claims one. Some encouragement for Chelsea as they seem to be able to get behind the Marseille defence with ease.
25 Bakayoko conducts an attack with his back to the goal and his feet just outside the middle of the Chelsea box. After much interplay, he finally receives and tries to turn, only to be met by a strong challenge from Desailly which leaves him requiring some attention off the pitch.
27 De Goey will be thanking Harley after a timely block. A low square ball from Dalmat on the left scoots behind a retreating Chelsea back four, to be met by a thunderous drive by goalscorer Pires. His shot is deflected by a desperate lunge from Harley. Marseille win a corner and Chelsea manage to clear.
30 Chelsea on the rack as Pires, Bakayoko and Pouget combine with a succession of short passes. Pouget eventually latches onto a flicked header from Bakayoko and it's only a last-ditch challenge from Desailly that denies him a shot at De Goey.
34 Pires nutmegs Desailly and so big Marcel bundles him over. Nothing comes of the free kick.
38 Chelsea are simply being outplayed in every department, especially by the magnificent Pires on the Marseille right, who is really enjoying making Desailly's night as long and as miserable as possible. Dennis Wise has been virtually anonymous this half.
41 Again Flo finds some space on the right thanks to a searching pass from Petrescu. Poyet chests down to Zola outside of the Marseille area on the left. His volley is powerful but always rising. Goal kick.
42 More Chelsea pressure results in a free-kick on the left, about 45 yards out. Zola takes and his high, inswinging cross to the far post evades Flo, Desailly and Trevisan before going out of play just outside the keeper's left-hand post.
46 The referee brings a great half for the home side to a close. At this point Chelsea will do well to earn a draw, but Marseille look very capable of adding to their tally in the second half.

45 Chelsea restart the match after some 'motivational' words from Graham Rix and Ray Wilkins. Vialli has to call the shots via a mobile phone from the stand as he serves his touchline suspension from a previous game.
46 Marseille are up and at Chelsea straight away, again with Pires on the right making it to the byline and whipping in a low cross that De Goey does well to smother at the feet of Bakayoko.
48 Another foul from Desailly on Pires, this time flush on the right-wing touchline. The centre is cleared, but Chelsea lose possession and then concede a corner. The visitors clear, but surrender possession yet again. Finally De Goey hoofs it 70 yards upfield.
51 Pouget, Pires and Bakayoko combine again to slice apart this Chelsea defence with short, simple passes and excellent running off the ball. Bakayoko drifts into right the Chelsea area, lays it off to Pires who crosses to the far post where Pouget rises to head wide of De Goey's left post. Chelsea are doing well just to deny Marseille a second goal.
55 The seemingly tireless Leroy dispossesses Deschamps just 35 yards away from the Chelsea goal in a central position. The young Marseille player knows exactly where the goal is and launches one, but Desailly gains enough ground in the last moments to deflect Leroy's powerful shot.
58 Chelsea seem to be making small inroads into the home team's domination of this game. Dennis Wise has drifted out to the right and is finding more time and space. His centre this time is overhit and the Chelsea forwards trudge back and assume the position.
60 Wise pops up as a forward, running onto a pass from Flo. Abardonado shields the ball from the England midfielder, and as Wise is in mid-tumble the referee is already signalling play on.
61 Chelsea substitution: Di Matteo for Deschamps.
64 Desailly has suffered a gash on his left leg and may not last much longer. The Chelsea defence looks easy to penetrate - Bakayoko muscles his way past Leboeuf and Desailly and plays in Pouget on the right. The Marseille forward lashes the ball past De Goey and high into the net, but the verdict is offside.
67 Some time and space for Wise in central midfield and he uses it well, chipping the ball up to Flo on the centre-left edge of the Marseille area. His first touch is to chest the ball up, and his second touch is an ill-judged volley high into the night sky. A half-chance, at best.
70 Blondeau's confidence has increased exponentially since beginning of the match. now he feels up to spearheading a dangerous-looking counterattack on the right. His cross is overhit and straight at De Goey.
72 Marseille substitution: De La Pena for Pouget.
74 Chelsea, to their credit, are pressing further and further forward whilst still trying to pass the ball into attacking positions. The move breaks down between Wise and Zola and Marseille break quickly down the right with Bakayoko. Chelsea concede a corner.
76 The set-piece is well cleared by Leboeuf and falls to Zola. The diminutive Italian runs 60 yards but his final ball is weak and the home side can clear, but only as far as Di Matteo. His shot from the centre-right is scuffed and trickles off for a goal kick.
79 An excellent run from Dalmat on the left brings the crowd to its feet. His attempted cross with his left foot from the byline is blocked by Leboeuf, but the rebound falls back at the feet of Dalmat, who hits a low, curling drive just wide of the far post.
81 Chelsea substitution: Morris for Ferrer; Sutton for Flo.
83 Sutton controls well inside the left of the Marseille box. He lays off to Zola, who cannot hit the ball as hard as he wants. Trevisan sees it late but saves well. Sutton is already proving to be more of a handful for the Marseille defence than the departed Flo.
86 A small confrontation on the pitch as Chelsea go close. Sutton is played in by an excellent flick from Morris on the right. Sutton's shot is well saved by Trevisan and the keeper recovers well to smother the rebound at Morris' feet. Some of the home side didn't like Sutton's challenge on their keeper and tell him about it. He disagrees and tells them about it. It takes five Chelsea players and the ref. to halt the debate.
89 Marseille substitution: Moses for Bakayoko.
90 Dennis Wise is belatedly making things happen on the right. The Chelsea captain wins a corner which Poyet meets with a bullet header from 10 yards and somehow Trevisan turns it outside his left-hand post. The second corner is the keeper's as soon as it's kicked. Four minutes of added on time to go.
93 Chelsea launch long-ball after long-ball but to no avail as the home back four stand firm. The ball eventually makes its way out to Zola on the left, but his cross is too close to Trevisan, who collects despite having Dennis Wise launch himself at his chest at the precise moment the ball meets his gloves.
94 Full time: Marseille 1 - 0 Chelsea.

webTitle: Clubs could be compensated for international call-ups

fields.headline: Clubs could be compensated for international call-ups
fields.trailText: Fifa, the world game's governing body, admitted for the first time yesterday that there is nothing to stop national federations from paying clubs for releasing their players for international duty.
fields.body:
Fifa, the world game's governing body, admitted for the first time yesterday that there is nothing to stop national federations from paying clubs for releasing their players for international duty.

Its general secretary Michel Zen Ruffinen, speaking here at a Football Expo debate on players' wages, commented that there is nothing in the regulations to prevent the Football Association and other national federations from compensating clubs whenever players are called up, a scenario that is bound to inflame the build-up to Euro 2000.

Zen Ruffinen was replying to a statement by the chairman of the Professional Footballers' Association Gordon Taylor that the English FA had always resisted paying compensation as it is not permitted to do so. "Such a regulation does not exist," said Zen Ruffinen. "In fact it has never existed."

The general secretary said the world body was now prepared to debate the issue following informal talks with the so-called G14 group, an inde pendent body comprising Europe's most influential clubs, so long as one or more national federation makes an official approach. Taylor welcomed the apparent change of heart, describing it as a "watershed".

"It has always been said by the FA that they could not do a deal with the clubs because it was not allowed," Taylor said at the end of the first day of this annual forum for the sport's movers and shakers. "This is a very significant change."

In recent weeks leading clubs have intensified their opposition to releasing players for international duty, especially friendly matches.

Taylor has warned that unless something is done to stop federations having first call on players without sharing the costs, there is a danger of clubs finding excuses to stop them going. "The issue has to be resolved," he said. "It's a problem Fifa must deal with to achieve some harmony. It's becoming critical."

He acknowledged, however, that not all federations were as wealthy as England, Germany and Italy, and said that to get developing countries to pay compensation may be impossible. "If they find there is nothing left in the pot how are they expected to look after the grass roots? But the fact remains that as there are more and more international games, the tension is increasing."

Taylor said players should also be better provided for when playing for their national teams. "Countries ask players to help them qualify for the World Cup in order to earn them more money, then they say they won't pay for it."

In a separate debate Liverpool's manager Gérard Houl lier said football's leading players should be treated, and paid, like any other top entertainers.

"Footballers' wages may shock the man in the street, but they don't shock me," Houllier said. "They are artists and should be recognised as such. Frank Sinatra was still singing up to his death, but footballers' careers are very short.

"I'm against wage-capping because if you try to fix a ceiling the first thing that would happen would be illicit payments [would be made]. But there are other ways of keeping a lid on things." One of them, he said, was to add performance-related bonuses to fixed salaries, another is to provide a loyalty bonus to help offset the attractions of the Bosman ruling, and a third is to get players involved in the financial sides of their clubs, by offering stock options.

Houllier added that one way of keeping agents away from clubs is to give young players better deals. "We don't wait for players to become superstars before giving them salaries to reflect their talent," he said. "Clubs which do not soon have to learn their lesson."

fields.headline: Trio home to domestic strife
fields.standfirst: Chelsea's Frenchmen face a Marseille team in the depth of a crisis
fields.trailText: The heat is on as the Champions League restarts tonight. Chelsea visit the Stade Velodrome to take on Marseille. Marcel Desailly and Didier Deschamps won a European Cup for Olympique and Frank Leboeuf is back in his place of birth.
fields.body:
For Chelsea as a whole and three of their players specifically, tonight's game here is a case of coming home.

The resumption of the second group phase sees Gianluca Vialli's side back in the Champions League they negotiated far more comfortably than the Premier League at the beginning of this season.

Meanwhile, Marcel Desailly and Didier Deschamps return to the club they once graced and Frank Leboeuf is back in the place of his birth.

The three will possess fond memories of Marseille, but in contrast there is little love lost among current players at the Stade Vélodrome.

Olympique Marseille are struggling, positioned just above the relegation zone in the French league after a series of player defections and appalling results, and are not expected to pose the greatest threat to Chelsea's aspirations.

Indeed, such is their plight that four weeks ago they tried to tempt Leboeuf home, making an audacious bid for the Chelsea defender in an attempt to shore up their leaky back line.

But Leboeuf's response was as dismissive as he hopes the Chelsea team will be of Marseille's advances tonight.

"Because I was from Marseille they came in for me," explained the 32-year-old. "But I told them I had two years left on my contract at Chelsea and I was happy. To go back to France would be a step backwards as I don't think the French championship is better than the Premier League.

"I always said I would stop at the top so I hope to end my career at Chelsea. I don't want to be pitied at the age of 36 playing in the Second Division."

Since Marseille's qualification for this season's Champions League it seems that some of their players have had similar thoughts to Leboeuf on the subject of playing for the club.

The list of defectors includes Christophe Dugarry and Fabrizio Ravanelli and suspensions and injuries will deprive Marseille of even more players tonight. The team that Chelsea face will bear little resemblance to that which beat Manchester United 1-0 at home in October. Not least because they have a new coach, Bernard Casoni, playing a new system.

Of course Chelsea, who top Group D after beating Feyenoord and drawing at Lazio, will not be so unprofessional as to underestimate the threat of a wounded team. Especially without the ineligible George Weah to lead their attack.

But victory here would certainly put Vialli's team a long way down the road to the quarter-finals and even in with a shout of winning the trophy itself.

"I hope we can win the tournament but we have to be realistic," said Vialli. "We are one of the best teams left in the competition but perhaps not the best."

The manager really has only two problems to cope with in the build-up to the game. First, how best to communicate with the bench, given that he is banned from the touchline and dressing room after an al tercation with a linesman at Lazio. A mobile-phone link with Graham Rix is planned.

The second problem is whether to reinstate Celestine Babayaro at left-back now that the experienced Nigerian has deigned to return to the club after going awol after the African Nations Cup.

The odds are on Vialli keeping faith with the youngster who stood in during Babayaro's absence, Jon Harley, who has been hitting the headlines for the right reasons. Tore Andre Flo and Gianfranco Zola may continue their European partnership up front.

Marseille, 13th in the 18-team French First Division, will be without their goalkeeper Stéphane Porato, who is injured after falling off a ladder at home. Four of their defenders are also out, William Gallas with a broken leg, Sébastien Perez and Yannick Fischer through suspension and the former Newcastle centre-back Franck Dumas because he is ineligible. The international Robert Pires remains their best-known player but the midfielder's form has slipped so badly that Casoni has deprived him of the captaincy.

Desailly has warned his team-mates what to expect tonight. The defender said: "They are very passionate fans and the best in the world when they are winning. But if they are losing they let the players know how they feel, and they have had a frustrating season."

Vialli, meanwhile, has read reports that his midfielder Jody Morris has been involved in controversy off the pitch on a night out with friends, despite being warned by Chelsea's chairman Ken Bates this season to mend his ways or risk damaging his career.

The manager responded: "This seems to happen to lads from England, and I will talk to him if there are any problems and I will take action if I feel the need to. However, I don't think there is anything to worry about - at the moment."

fields.headline: Fewer Balls and more *!!**!, please
fields.trailText: Argues that England need disharmony in the dressing room to go forward much like Holland and Germany have done over the years.
fields.body:
It is hard to imagine that any confined space containing Kevin Keegan would ever be mistaken for a Buddhist retreat, yet such it seems is the current state of the England dressing room. According to the national team boss the place is quiet, too quiet.

As fans of Western movies will know, such unnatural silence can presage only one thing: total annihilation. To stave off such disaster Keegan last week introduced a secret weapon, Alan Ball, his new chatterbox-in-chief.

The England supremo is surely correct in believing that the atmosphere in the changing room is one of the keys to victory. The fear is that he may be misjudging what the best ambience for fostering success actually is. In an age when everyone from Sir Harrison Birtwistle to Nicolas Anelka has arrived at the conclusion that discord is the way forward, our coach is still seeking harmony.

As usual we lag far behind the rest of the world in this matter. On the continent the value of an unsettled, not to say downright fractious dressing room has long been well known. Like many radical coaching innovations the system was pioneered by the Dutch.

In the 1970s Holland gave us total football on the field and total disagreement off it. They reached consecutive World Cup finals while England, still endearingly attempting to be mates with one another, failed to qualify for the latter stages of either tournament.

Last Wednesday, while Keegan's men were being all chummy and failing to get a shot on target against Argentina, there were signs that Holland are getting things right again.

After a run of poor results Edgar Davids was entrusted with the captaincy. The Juventus midfielder gives the impression of being a bloke who could start a row in an empty barn. His influence was immediately clear as his team completely overran Germany.

The Germans rather seem to have lost their way recently. In the late 70s regional differences between Bayern players and the rest were added to an incendiary mix of major egos. The 1982 World Cup finals saw tempers twanging like untuned banjos. In the final it is alleged that the regal Karl-Heinz Rummenigge was so stung by half-time criticism of his performance by a team-mate that, rather in the manner of Henry II calling for deliverance from Thomas A'Becket, he encouraged someone to strike the culprit on his behalf.

By 1986 Rumenigge had calmed down, but Harald Schumacher more than compensated. The Cologne goalkeeper signalled his potential by attacking the legendary Bayern Maoist Paul Breitner for his heavy drinking, smoking and gambling.

Later, told that Germany's second-choice keeper was watching an international from high up in the stands, Schumacher remarked acidly: "He should remember that even when sitting on the loftiest Himalayan peak, a dwarf is still a dwarf."

The result of all this bad blood was three successive World Cup final appearances, including victory in 1990. England, with never a cross word between them, managed only a single semi-final appearance.

And such will remain the story, I am afraid, until we face up to the fact that communal spirit is getting us nowhere. Thankfully there is hope.

Andy Cole has apparently not spoken to Teddy Sheringham for years and he has slagged off Alan Shearer in print. Alone among his contemporaries he seems to understand that in the modern dressing room silence of the sullen, brooding sort is golden. Clearly it is his personality, not Alan Ball's, which England desperately need.

webTitle: Shearer keeps one strike ahead of the pack

fields.headline: Shearer keeps one strike ahead of the pack
fields.standfirst: The England captain explains a retirement that denies the media their kill
fields.trailText: Alan Shearer, by choosing the manner of his retirement from international football, has invited fresh carping from critics who, as his performances have waned, have been increasingly irritated by his unsullied reputation.
fields.body:
Alan Shearer, by choosing the manner of his retirement from international football, has invited fresh carping from critics who, as his performances have waned, have been increasingly irritated by his unsullied reputation. The charge of selfishness intensified yesterday as he rationalised his decision to retire as an England player after the European championship this summer.

Shearer, his detractors raged, is a man who wants everything on his own terms, a player whose overriding self-interest in naming the date of his England retirement has left Kevin Keegan in an invidious position, a fading national icon who in reality is as pure as the driven slush.

It was little wonder, therefore, that Shearer chose to expand on his decision yesterday not in a suspicious England environment but at Newcastle United's training ground in Chester-le-Street. Here the affection for him remains unqualified. "Kick a guy enough and he'll decide he's had enough," said one Geordie fan yesterday. Many in the north-east feel the same.

Shearer's loyalties to Newcastle have always been equally strong. "I love this football club," he said. "Hopefully Newcastle will benefit from this decision. I might not play in the next World Cup but maybe I can win an FA Cup final for Newcastle United.

"If I am to play my best for the next four years then I need to pace myself and that means having a summer break. Over the past 10 years I have been playing 11 months a year; I've never had more than three weeks off. I'm not complaining, because that is a measure of the success I have had, but it can't go on for ever.

"I want to stay sharp, fit and strong, both physically and mentally. I don't want anyone else telling me I am slowing down. I want to do it my way and I have done that."

When Shearer began to contemplate international retirement last October his clash of personalities with Rudd Gullit remained fresh in the mind and his rejuvenation under Bobby Robson had barely begun. Since then family matters have strengthened his resolve; his wife, Lainya, is expecting their third child in September.

His England career had lately been driven more by professional dedication and personal ambition than by any sense of passion. Too often, for supporters and players alike, England exists as a cluster of prejudices and affiliations.

As his England stature declined, accusations of self-interest fuelled the abuse and denunciation that he now routinely endures on virtually every Premiership ground outside St James' Park. In the derisive world of English football it is only a short journey from favourite to favouritism.

When they could not even find the energy to boo him at Hillsborough on Saturday it became clear that Sheffield Wednesday had accepted the inevitability of relegation.

He insists this malign atmosphere has not influenced his decision, as anyone so strong-willed and single-minded must - "I use it as a spur; they don't boo bad players" - but, had England given one of its finest servants of the past decade the respect and affinity he deserves, the decision would have been much harder to make.

Shearer's determination to decide his own future arises, in reality, not so much from selfishness as self-esteem. And that is the stuff that separates a good sportsman from an ordinary one, that supplies the fortitude to survive the bad times.

Why expect a player whose prime assets have included an ordered mind, a shrewd intent and a sense of empowerment not to map out his own future with the same rationale?

Shearer has expressed a willingness to play for England after Euro 2000 "in an emergency" - less a sign of vacillation than an attempt to avoid further charges of selfishness.

He has not planned his retirement so fastidiously in a scheming attempt to align himself as Robson's managerial successor at Newcastle United or to wrest control from Keegan's hands. He has done it now because he has too much self-respect to allow a voracious media to determine when he goes. The predictable sound of baying is from a pack that has been denied its kill.

webTitle: Reading winger tests positive for cocaine

fields.headline: Reading winger tests positive for cocaine
fields.trailText: Andy McLaren, the former Scotland Under-21 and Reading winger, has been charged with misconduct by the Football Association after failing a drugs test.
fields.body:
Andy McLaren, the former Scotland Under-21 and Reading winger, has been charged with misconduct by the Football Association after failing a drugs test.

McLaren tested positive for cocaine and cannabis last month after returning to the Second Division club from a spell in Scotland with Livingston. He was the second Reading player in nine months to fail a test; the midfielder Byron Glasgow was sacked by the club last May after testing positive for cocaine in a test at the end of last season.

The 26-year-old McLaren, who has also played for Dundee United, is the first player to fail a test as part of the FA's expanded drug-testing programme which will see 1,000 tests carried out this season. His contract at Reading has been terminated since the test and he is not contracted to any club.

 Crystal Palace supporters have formed a trust to give the cash-strapped First Division club extra finances.

The Football League may step in if it does not receive an assurance that Palace, who have debts in the region of £20m, can fulfil next season's fixtures. But the newly formed Crystal Palace Supporters Trust believes it has found an answer to the financial problems. The trust spokesman Paul Newman said: "We have 10,000 season-ticket holders, and if each one could invest £1,000 in the way of a loan to the trust that would be £10m automatically.

"We have given ourselves a March 31 deadline to act out our four-point plan. First we want all fans to join the trust for a £20 fee. We also want them to loan a minimum of £1,000 to the trust, which will be returnable if the idea does go through."

 Bury are preparing to sell 11 senior players before next month's transfer deadline. The Second Division club want to trim their wage bill by more than a third, having resigned themselves to failure in their campaign for an immediate return to the First Division.

 The Scottish Executive has pledged a further £600,000 to support the rescue package announced in December to save Queen's Park, the owners of Hampden Park, from financial ruin. Glasgow City Councillors will vote next week on whether to match that amount. Queen's Park went into administration after failing to reach an agreement over a £4.4m rescue package outlined in December. The project now has debts of £5.5m.

webTitle: Rae faces misconduct charge for elbow on Powell

fields.headline: Rae faces misconduct charge for elbow on Powell
fields.trailText: Alex Rae has been charged with misconduct by the Football Association for allegedly elbowing the Derby captain Darryl Powell in Saturday's Premiership match at Sunderland.
fields.body:
Alex Rae has been charged with misconduct by the Football Association for allegedly elbowing the Derby captain Darryl Powell in Saturday's Premiership match at Sunderland.

The referee, Alan Wiley, took no action over the incident but the FA has stepped in after viewing video evidence.

Aston Villa have invited PSV Eindhoven's Belgian international striker Luc Nilis to spend three days at Villa Park this weekend with a view to signing him on a Bosman free this summer. He is due to attend Villa's game against Arsenal on Sunday.

"His age does not concern me," said Villa's manager John Gregory. "He is 32 going on 27 and he has looked after himself superbly."

Nilis, who plays alongside the even more coveted Ruud van Nistelrooy at PSV, has attracted interest from several European clubs, including Sheffield Wednesday and Rangers.

"It's time for something new and I'd like to play in England," he said. "The contract is not yet signed but I'm convinced it will happen and that it will be a contract for two years.

"I know little about Villa or any of their players, but I am told they are a very ambitious club. I have spoken to the manager and he feels I can do a good job for him."

Germany's manager Erich Ribbeck has come under increasingly critical scrutiny since last Wednesday's 2-1 defeat at the hands of Holland.

Ribbeck has been accused of lacking authority. A German international who asked not to be named told Kicker magazine that the coach had "kept very much in the background" at half-time in Amsterdam while Jens Jeremies and Oliver Bierhoff had made "some very loud comments".

Jeremies implied that the coach was to blame. "There's something in our heads that is blocked," he said. "It does not come only from the players."

The fiercest critic has once again been Paul Breitner, who starred in Bayern Munich's formidable side of the 70s and lifted the World Cup in 1974.

"Every problem is dealt with in a naive, ridiculous and shortsighted manner," he said. "Since the World Cup disaster there has been a lot of talking but nothing has been learnt nor done. We are and remain the world champions in smooth talking."

webTitle: Owen and Yorke ready to rumble

fields.headline: Owen and Yorke ready to rumble
fields.trailText: Michael Owen and Dwight Yorke seem certain to be available for Saturday's crucial Premiership match between Manchester United and Liverpool at Old Trafford after overcoming their respective problems with injury and international commitments.
fields.body:
Michael Owen and Dwight Yorke seem certain to be available for Saturday's crucial Premiership match between Manchester United and Liverpool at Old Trafford after overcoming their respective problems with injury and international commitments.

Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier will assess Owen's fitness in a behind-closed-doors practice game this week in the belief that his young striker is ready for a senior recall after more than five weeks out with a hamstring injury.

Owen has not kicked a ball in anger since limping away from a game against Middlesbrough at Anfield on January 22 with his sixth hamstring- related injury in 14 months.

Meanwhile Yorke has been cleared to play for United and will miss Trinidad and Tobago's World Cup qualifier against the Dutch Antilles. The striker returned to Old Trafford yesterday after his country's Gold Cup semi-final defeat by Canada on Thursday and has decided not to return to the Caribbean at the weekend.

Yorke indicated last month that he would make himself available only for those World Cup qualifying games that he believed could not be won without his involvement. The Dutch Antilles are ranked the 167th-best team, 118 places below Trinidad and Tobago, in Fifa's world rankings.

"There are games that Trinidad can certainly win without me being there, and I'm sure they understand that," he said.

The Trinidadian FA could appeal to the world governing body to force United to release him, but its relationship with Old Trafford has been cordial so far and this course of action seems unlikely.

"Dwight is not going to play in the World Cup game and he has already told Trinidad and Tobago that," said United's manager Sir Alex Ferguson.

Yorke's participation in Saturday's match, which kicks off at 11.30am and could put United nine points clear in the Premiership, may still be hampered by a thigh strain which also makes him doubtful for tomorrow's Champions League game against Bordeaux at Old Trafford.

Owen's involvement would likewise be a gamble on the part of Houllier. A Liverpool win would leave them seven points behind United with a game in hand, but if Owen breaks down again he is likely to be ruled out for the remainder of the season and Euro 2000.

This outcome would intensify Liverpool's pursuit of Leicester's Emile Heskey. Such is their desire to land the England striker that they are believed willing to increase their offer to about £12.5m if the player is allowed to join them immediately.

Heskey's dilemma is simple: Liverpool would like to sign him - preferably this week - but Leicester are desperate that he extends his stay at Filbert Street at least until his current contract expires in 16 months' time.

Had Leicester succumbed to First Division Tranmere in the Worthington Cup final at Wembley on Sunday it is conceivable that the 22-year-old would have joined the Merseyside club within the next 24 hours.

But yesterday, as Martin O'Neill's men paraded their trophy through teeming streets, a diplomatic offensive was launched in the hope of delaying what, at Anfield, is regarded as inevitable.

"Emile is absolutely priceless so, believe me, I will move heaven and earth to keep him at this club," said O'Neill. "I would really love him to stay and so would the rest of the players.

"We have now qualified for European football next season so you never know what might happen."

Leicester have already accepted in principle a £10.75m bid from Liverpool, an offer which was submitted more than six months ago.

However, with both Liverpool's front-line strikers having suffered serious injuries - Robbie Fowler is still recovering from surgery after a long-term ankle problem - the Merseyside club have been attempting to bring forward a deal which was expected to be formally ratified in June.

fields.headline: Caymans launch World Cup trawl
fields.trailText: A small and disparate group of British footballers were last night preparing to become international mercenaries after being offered up to £70,000 each to represent the Cayman Islands in the World Cup.
fields.body:
A small and disparate group of British footballers were last night preparing to become international mercenaries after being offered up to £70,000 each to represent the Cayman Islands in the World Cup.

At least seven players are ready to represent the tax haven against Cuba in two qualifiers on March 5 and 19, leaving their managers back home cursing that Fifa rules allow them to play for a new-found national team rather than clubs to whom they are contractually tied.

It will be little consolation to the clubs that Fifa said yesterday they could get financial compensation from their own or overseas national federations for loss of players.

The Cayman Islands, a British crown colony, have recruited the players by taking advantage of the rule that allows them to play for any country inside Britain's jurisdiction. The incentive from the national FA is on offer to the players if they get the Caymans to the 2002 World Cup finals in Japan and Korea.

The most prominent players are Fulham's Barry Hayles, due to fly in today, and Motherwell's Ged Brannan, who arrived at the weekend. Other players include Jimmy Wood of Hull City, Martin O'Connor of Birmingham and Dominic Barclay of Bristol Rovers.

The Caymans also attempted to recruit the Watford defender Des Lyttle, but he declined the invitation after talks with his manager Graham Taylor.

"I got the invitation via my agent," said Brannan. "I realised some time ago that I would never be capped by England and this was an opportunity to become an international footballer."

"There's not a lot I can do if Fifa insist we have to release him," said Paul Bracewell, Hayles's manager at Fulham.

Two Ryman League players, Neil Sharpe of Boreham Wood and Alec Masson of Bognor Regis, are also going. The defender Masson has already played twice for the Caymans against Jamaica. He is currently on trial at Stoke City.

The Cayman Islands FA was less than forthcoming about its use of the rules: "I am in a meeting, thank you," said its president Geoffrey Webb. He refused to comment further.

The deal is believed to have been brokered by Barry McIntosh, who claims links with the Jamaican squad that went to France 1998. The Jamaicans included several British-based players specifically recruited for the tournament, including Marcus Gayle, Darryl Powell and Frank Sinclair.

The Cayman Islands (population 32,800) have no great sporting traditions. Their flag was once carried by a Fleet Street columnist at the start of a Commonwealth Games and the national sport in the 19th century - always on a Sunday - was crocodile shooting.

fields.headline: Vaas pressures Pakistan
fields.trailText: Sri Lanka's seamer Chaminda Vaas rounded off a great day at the office when he ended Saeed Anwar's defiant rearguard innings to leave Pakistan in deep trouble after the third day of the first Test in Rawalpindi.
fields.body:
Sri Lanka's seamer Chaminda Vaas rounded off a great day at the office when he ended Saeed Anwar's defiant rearguard innings to leave Pakistan in deep trouble after the third day of the first Test in Rawalpindi.

The hosts restart on 154 for four, still needing 17 runs to cancel Sri Lanka's first-innings lead, after the captain Anwar held out for more than 4 hours in making 84 and anchoring half-century stands with Aamir Sohail and Inzamam-ul-Haq.

But Vaas, who had earlier reached an unbeaten 53 as the tail wagged to 353, bowled the left-hander off an inside edge with only two overs left to play.

webTitle: Why does Shalina wish she was a boy?

fields.headline: Why does Shalina wish she was a boy?
fields.standfirst: The secretary general of the United Nations shows, in the life of one 13-year-old Bangladeshi girl, the tragedies and the lost potential caused by keeping her and around 90m of her peers out of school. Educating them would be a huge benefit to them and society
fields.trailText: The secretary general of the United Nations shows, in the life of one 13-year-old Bangladeshi girl, the tragedies and the lost potential caused by keeping her and around 90m of her peers out of school. Educating them would be a huge benefit to them and society
fields.body:
Shalina is a Bangladeshi girl who is about to finish school. But for Shalina, there will be no pre-exam jitters, no university applications, no diplomas, no career plans. There will not even be a graduation. Shalina is 13 and she is about to join 73m school-age girls around the world who are not in school.

For Shalina's parents, and millions of other parents like them, educating a daughter is a waste of time and money. They married off her older sister aged 15, having decided to use their scarce resources for their son's education at the expense of their daughters'. Shalina used to worry about lessons and tests, but she worries much more about having to get married and bear children while still a child herself. Shalina used to dream about being a doctor, but now faces a life of cleaning houses during the day and tutoring younger children at night. Shalina now wishes she were a boy.

Shalina and millions of her peers are denied something many of us take for granted. They are denied a fundamental human right spelled out in international instruments their governments have signed on to - such as the universal declaration of human rights and the convention on the rights of the child - the right to education. It is often said that education empowers girls by building up their confidence and enabling them to make informed decisions about their lives. For most of the world's girls, that means not being forced into a marriage while in your teens because you have no other choice; it is about managing pregnancies so that they do not threaten your health, your life or your livelihood; about seeking and obtaining medical care for your children and yourself when you need it; about child care and nutrition; about ensuring that your children attend at least primary school.

It is about being able to earn an income when women before you earned none; about knowing and enjoying rights which women before you never knew they had; about educating your children to do the same, and their children after them. It is about bringing to a close a previously never-ending spiral of poverty and powerlessness. It is, in short, about ensuring a decent life for an entire generation and succeeding generations.

Education is, quite simply, an investment that yields a higher profit than any other. It is what makes possible the development of entire communities, countries and continents. It is the most effective form of defence spending there is.

So why are so many millions of girls denied it? In many societies, women are systematically marginalised; and yet, when catastrophe strikes - whether it be in the form of illness, conflict or hardship - they bear the biggest burden. Nothing illustrates this more amply than the impact of HIV/Aids. Girls are most likely to care for a sick family member and help manage the household. Prevented from going to school, they are denied information about how to protect themselves against the virus. Deprived of an education, they risk being forced into early sexual relations with older men or into prostitution, and thereby becoming infected. They pay many times over the deadly price of not going to school.

If we are to change this cruel and unjust state of affairs, we need to do more than build new classrooms. We need to remove the constraints that lead parents to keep their daughters out of school. And once girls are in school, we must ensure that school prepares them for life, by developing curricula, textbooks and teaching attitudes that emphasize the life skills they will need. But societies must first recognise that educating girls is not an option; it is a necessity.

In the Middle East, a few countries have already eliminated the gender gap in primary schooling. Others in the region have come to recognise the need to educate girls, if only to ensure they have a better-trained and qualified labour force.

Some African countries, too, have made progress in reducing gender bias. Malawi has cut the direct costs of schooling by eliminating school fees and abolishing compulsory uniforms. Guinea has reduced the domestic burdens of girls, by digging wells and providing mechanical mills. It has introduced regulations to ensure that boys and girls share chores in school, and legislation that makes it illegal to force girls to marry before they have completed nine years of school.

These are welcome examples. But they are not nearly enough. The world needs a coordinated strategy on the scale of the challenge. We need all those with the power to change things to come together in an alliance for girls' education: governments, voluntary progressive groups and above all, local communities, schools and families. That is why this spring, the United Nations is launching a new global initiative to educate girls.

The 12th century Arab philosopher Ibn Rushd declared that "a society which enslaves its women is a society doomed to decay". Nine hundred years later, let us prove that a society which empowers its women is a society sure to succeed.

webTitle: Providing a chance to make up for lost learning

fields.headline: Providing a chance to make up for lost learning
fields.standfirst: Egypt:  Schooling devised to fit in with helping the family at home
fields.trailText: Egypt: Schooling devised to fit in with helping the family at home
fields.body:
Manal, a 12-year-old girl in the village of Abu Ghreir in the southern Egyptian province of Minya, would never have gone to school if her sister had not done well in literacy classes.

"I didn't go to school before because my family said girls shouldn't go to school," she said, adding that they changed their minds because of her sister's results in literacy classes.

Her school, a two-storey house on a dusty footpath in the middle of the village, is run by the Salama Moussa project, which provides basic education for children between nine and 13 who were never sent to school. In rural Egypt, most are girls.

Manal's story is typical of many girls in the poor areas of Egypt, which experts describe as pockets of resistance to the government's campaign for universal education.

According to Adolescents and Social Change in Egypt, a survey by the independent New York-based Population Council, school enrolment among girls has been increasing by about 1.25% a year. But there is a gap of about 10 percentage points between the enrolment of boys and girls.

This gap is most evident in Upper Egypt, the provinces south of Cairo, where the study says there are 71 girls per 100 boys enrolled in primary school (6-10 years of age), 64 per 100 in preparatory school (11-13 years of age) and 51 per 100 in secondary school.

There have been several initiatives to boost girls' education in recent years. They include community schools, run by Unicef, which were introduced in 1992 and now number over 200. The community schools inspired the government to launch "one classroom schools", which number about 3,000 in Upper Egypt. Community and one classroom schools are for girls only.

Manal's school in Abu Ghreir and its sister school in nearby Bani Ebeid were set up by one of the most innovative projects to address the needs of girls not attending school. The Salama Moussa project, named after a nineteenth century Egyptian literary figure, was launched in 1997 by Imad Sarawat.

"There are about four million children in Egypt between the ages of nine and 13 who are illiterate and out of school - the equivalent in number of the population of Jordan," Mr Sarawat said. Children between those ages have fallen through the cracks in Egypt's education system. The cut-off age for primary enrolment is eight and the minimum age for enrolment in government-run literacy classes is 14.

There are 32 children in the Abu Ghreir school and 28 in Bani Ebeid. They spend three to four hours a day learning not just reading, writing and mathematics but also the importance of their folklore heritage through songs, plays and painting. There is no school uniform and they wear brightly coloured village dress.

"We never said we wanted more boys or girls. As it happens, we have more girls than boys because many families need boys to work in the field. Girls work more at home so have a better chance to come to class," Mr Sarawat said.

The teaching methods in Abu Ghreir and Bani Ebeid reflect the new trend of activity-based learning. The curriculum evolved after Mr Sarawat and colleagues consulted the families about what they wanted the children to learn.

"One girl had a problem that she wanted us to solve for her. She said that when she went for a walk with her friend they always argued which of them the moon was following. She said she'd asked four teachers and none of them could answer her," Mr Sarawat said.

The children decide when classes will start according to when their families need them to help in the fields or with housework. Some will sit an examination in September to allow them to attend government-run preparatory schools.

Poverty and distance are the main reasons that girls do not attend school, researchers say.

"If a household has a penny, they will probably devote it to the boys' education, but if they have two pennies they will give equal opportunity for the girl and the boy," said Hind Wassif, a research assistant for the population council.

Although school and university education has been free in Egypt since the 1952 revolution, many families cannot afford extra expenses such as exercise books and stationery.

Malak Zaalouk, a Unicef education officer in Cairo, denied that there was a "cultural aversion" to girls' education in Egypt: "On the contrary, we have found openness and eagerness on the part of poor communities to send their girls to school if it is free of charge and close to home."

"There are about four million children in Egypt between the ages of nine and 13 who are illiterate and out of school - the equivalent in number of the population of Jordan," Mr Sarawat said. Children between those ages have fallen through the cracks in Egypt's education system. The cut-off age for primary enrolment is eight and the minimum age for enrolment in government-run literacy classes is 14. There are 32 children in the Abu Ghreir school and 28 in Bani Ebeid. They spend three to four hours a day learning not just reading, writing and mathematics but also the importance of their folklore heritage through songs, plays and painting. There is no school uniform and they wear brightly coloured village dress. "We never said we wanted more boys or girls. As it happens, we have more girls than boys because many families need boys to work in the field. Girls work more at home so have a better chance to come to class," Mr Sarawat said. The teaching methods in Abu Ghreir and Bani Ebeid reflect the new trend of activity-based learning. The curriculum evolved after Mr Sarawat and colleagues consulted the families about what they wanted the children to learn. "One girl had a problem that she wanted us to solve for her. She said that when she went for a walk with her friend they always argued which of them the moon was following. She said she'd asked four teachers and none of them could answer her," Mr Sarawat said. Malak Zaalouk, a Unicef education officer in Cairo, denied that there was a "cultural aversion" to girls' education in Egypt: "On the contrary, we have found openness and eagerness on the part of poor communities to send their girls to school if it is free of charge and close to home."

webTitle: Nowhere to go after classroom years end

fields.headline: Nowhere to go after classroom years end
fields.standfirst: Mexico: The system, starved of resources, is no passport to a better life
fields.trailText: Mexico: The system, starved of resources, is no passport to a better life
fields.body:
The girls and boys of Zacatecaz primary school in the Tepito district of Mexico City walk to school each day through the bustling heart of the thriving local industry: crime.

This is the part of the capital where cars that have been stolen at gunpoint are brought to be stripped and repainted ready to be sold on. This is home to many of the city's drug dealers, illegal gunsmiths and prostitutes, a kind of Fagin's cantina where higher education usually means the university of hard knocks.

Francisco Cabezas, 34, is about to start his second teaching shift of the day. To make ends meet and stretch his salary to around £95 a week, Mr Cabezas has to take on two teaching jobs, starting the first at crack of dawn and finishing the second long after sunset. It does not leave much time for his young family. While the children in his charge are lively and anxious to learn, they are doing so, he says, against great odds.

"There is a lot of delinquency round here," Mr Cabezas says. "Many of the parents are illiterate or have problems with drugs." The current state of Mexico's economy means that there is little money available for repairing and equipping schools; classes are held in small brick rooms.

Another teacher, Felipe Mercado - who also works in two different schools and has to travel across this city of 23m people to complete his second stretch of the day - says that one of the greatest problems is trying to persuade children that there is a point to an education when many who study hard and earn qualifications end up unable to find work, competing as they are with the 10% of the population who attend private schools.

The differences are multiplied in parts of Mexico with large indigenous populations. The index for educational deprivation - lack of facilities, schools, opportunities - is 20 times higher in areas where the indigenous population is more than 70% than it is in Mexico City. Illiteracy rates for indigenous people are five times the national average.

But if it is hard for all the children in the poorer parts of both urban and rural Mexico to achieve their potential, for girls in the education system the problem is magnified. In the last major survey of illiteracy, eight of every 100 men could not read or write; for women, the figure was 13.

"This is still a very macho society," says Malu Valenzuela of GEM (Grupo de Educacion Popular con Mujeres), an organisation campaigning to promote women in education. While girls do better than the boys at primary level, she says, they fall away afterwards for a variety of reasons.

Although 97% of Mexican children enter the primary school system, the drop-out rates thereafter are high and with more and more women entering the workforce - around 35% now - there is a greater need for someone to look after the small children; this usually means an older sister.

Officially, boys and girls are treated equally within the system, she says, but in fact, from an early age the girls find themselves standing very much second in line. To try to counter this, GEM has been distributing hundreds of copies of a special card game, The Game of Possibilities, it has devised to get children to challenge the stereotypes of men and women in Mexican society.

Gabriela Delgado, the director of Promujer, an organisation set up by the Mexico City government to advance the rights of women, said that while officially girls might receive the same education as boys in the capital, they had cultural and economic factors against them in that it was still traditional for men to be regarded as the main wage-earners. In a staunchly Catholic country, girls too often found themselves pregnant very young and having to leave school early.

"Women still don't have the same opportunities as men," she said. But she added that serious attempts were being made to encourage girls to see wider prospects for themselves in education. New textbooks were introduced nationally in 1996 to try to break the stereotypical view of girls as simply deferential, caring mothers. Things are gradually changing: while in 1980, women made up only 37% of students studying the sciences, this has risen to about 45%.

Mexican education has always been a sharper political topic than in most other countries in the world: in 1933 President Abelardo Rodriguez enacted a constitutional reform that made public education "socialistic," which at the time meant that it was to be secular and rational as opposed to religious.

In a recent opinion poll asking people who were the most respected and least respected professions in the country, the results put politicians, police officers and journalists at the bottom while the top three were doctors, priests and - teachers. Often from the working class, dedicated and committed, teachers enjoy a respect that can be missing in Europe.

Yet many teachers still have to work double shifts or moonlight as taxi drivers to make ends meet. The National Union of Education Workers (SNTE) whose million-strong membership - 70% of it female - makes it one of the largest unions in Latin America, took national action in 1998 to press for a living wage.

If the rougher areas of the capital are short of many of the necessities of education, the poorer rural areas with large indigenous populations are far worse served.

At the time of the Zapatista uprising in Chiapas state in 1994, it emerged that only a quarter of the Indian children there attended school.

In his recent book Mexico's Hope, James D Cockcroft, a former professor at the National Autonomous University of Mexico (UNAM) in the capital writes: "Indians repeatedly demanded reforms in what little education they did receive: more schools, more teachers from the Indians' own linguistic communities and an end to teachers beating children who did not understand or speak Spanish adequately." In a country with 50 dialects, this is a big problem.

Education has again been in the forefront of the national debate over the last few weeks in Mexico with the ending of a long strike by a group of students at the vast and sprawling UNAM, the biggest university in Latin America.

It is a measure of how education is regarded that the strike - initially in protest against the introduction of fees that poorer students could not afford - received widespread public support. That backing dissipated after the authorities conceded on the fees issues and the strike went on, becoming more complex and intractable.

But among the questions that the students were asking were: what is the point of higher education if there are no jobs for those graduating with their new qualifications, and how do the poor advance through education if what jobs there are go to the wealthy and the well connected?

Back in the classroom in Tepito, Francisco Cabezas calls his young class to order. "Ready, kids?" he asks.

Clearly at the moment they are. But it will need more than the enthusiasms of such teachers to ensure that education holds its attractions for the girls and boys who know that immediately outside the gates of their cramped playground the simplest way to make money needs no academic qualification at all.

webTitle: An island where girls now fly high

fields.headline: An island where girls now fly high
fields.standfirst: Mauritius: Two decades of free schooling have sent women surging into the work force
fields.trailText: Mauritius: Two decades of free schooling have sent women surging into the work force
fields.body:
When she's not playing Monopoly, 11-year-old Khurty dreams of being an actress. She wants to sing and dance on the big screen, just like her favourite Bollywood stars. But Khurty's dream offers a rare glimmer of fantasy among those of her friends squatting in a shady corner of the playground. The rest of these girls have more serviceable expectations. One wants to be a teacher, another a doctor, a third an engineer like her father.

Since Mauritius introduced free education in 1977, girls have enjoyed increasing equality of opportunity in the island's education system, as families were no longer forced to concentrate their resources on the male children they believed would benefit more from schooling.

The Mauritian population is now highly literate (97% according to the most recent figures). At primary level, there is almost 100% enrolment, while at secondary level - where enrolment hovers around 60% - the gender difference is negligible. But a competitive scholastic environment, coupled with the demands of a growing economy, have created other concerns.

"The problem now is that every parent wants their child to be a high-flyer," says Kurty's head teacher, Kamla Bansoodeb. She insists that there is no difference in performance between girls and boys at Sir Veerasamy Rangadoo government school, in Quatre Bornes, a suburb of the capital city Port Louis.

"In the past in Asian households, girls weren't encouraged to get an education, but now that doesn't happen so much. We have a mixture of children here, and we don't differentiate between the child of a maidservant and the child of an office worker. All are ambitious to get into the top secondary colleges, and then go on to tertiary education."

Khurty and her friends are studying for their certificate of primary education (CPE) examinations. At the end of the primary cycle, there is a desperate scramble for places in good secondary schools, commonly referred to as "star schools". Only the top 4,000 out of 30,000 who take part in the CPE exams are admitted to the best schools on the basis of the rank they attain.

Inevitably, many parents are turning to private tuition to boost their children's chances, putting added pressure on the young.

"It used to be the case that lower income families preferred their children to fail the CPE so that they could send them out to work," says Ms Bansoodeb. "But now the law says that children can't work until they reach the age of 15."

There is no safety net for the 30% of schoolchildren who fail the CPE. Vocational training is limited, and there is growing concern that these chidlren will be roaming the street or being employed illegally.

At Stanley government school in the neighbouring suburb of Rose Hill, the head teacher, Kailashandra Rajcoomar, is similarly adamant that no gender difference exists in the classroom. Stanley has been identified as a "project school" under a scheme that was started in 1994 to provide problem schools with special grants, extra teacher training and counselling sessions for parents and children.

"There is no difference between boys and girls. That idea vanished a long time ago. They are equal throughout primary and secondary education. Girls want to get a good education and to go out to work, in white-collar jobs rather than agriculture." Like Kamla Bansoodeb, Mr Rajcoomar relies heavily on parental involvement. "Many of our children come from broken families. They grow up in poverty, their parents have alcohol or drug problems, many are illiterate, and we have children who don't want to learn because they aren't disciplined at home. We spend a lot of time talking to parents, encouraging them to send their children to school."

As more and more girls enter education, and stay in it for longer, there has been a resultant surge in women entering the labour force, especially the island's thriving textile industry. Mauritius currently ranks first among sub-Saharan countries according to the Gender Related Development Index published by the UN Development Programme, which measures gender disparities in life expectancy, educational attainment and income.

But as job opportunities open up for them, working women's burdens have grown. They remain largely responsible for household chores and there are concerns that the younger generation is not psychologically equipped to cope with the increased freedom that economic independence brings.

The education minister, Kadress Pillay, points to the recently released results of the higher school certificate, taken at the end of secondary school, in which girls enjoyed a 75% pass rate, compared with 70% for boys. "It is still a very conservative society, highly Indianised, but it is fairly liberal from an educational point of view.

"We're far from the situation where a 16-year-old girl can have her own life, but the mentality is changing. The judiciary is now female-dominated, and it's an evolutionary process that we need to encourage.

"In a society that is changing so quickly, I believe less in skills and knowledge that will become obsolete and more in values and perennial knowledge - the capacity to understand others in a mixed culture, to be broad-minded, to think creatively and critically."

The education system is still highly elitist, he says. "We create a few captains of industry and leave the rest to work in their factories. Society is highly classified, and the whole purpose of an education system should be to reduce the gap between rich and poor. The only way to create a balanced society is to create a balanced individual. Who is the nation if not the individual? That's why education is the driving force."

fields.headline: ITN denies Bosnia report 'fabrication'
fields.standfirst: Magazine sued over claim that TV journalists used camera angles and editing to 'fool the world' over Balkan camps
fields.trailText: The news organisation ITN yesterday denied fabricating images of Muslim refugees in a Bosnian detention camp during its coverage of the Balkan conflict.
fields.body:
The news organisation ITN yesterday denied fabricating images of Muslim refugees in a Bosnian detention camp during its coverage of the Balkan conflict.

The accusation, published in Living Marxism magazine, had been "highly damaging" to ITN, its lawyers told the high court in London.

Living Marxism is being sued by ITN and two reporters over an article titled The picture that fooled the world, which questioned the credibility of a 1992 report from two camps run by Bosnian Serbs.

Footage from the camps at Trnopolje and Omarska, which were at the centre of persistent allegations of torture and executions, captured world attention and prompted numerous commentators, including the US president, George Bush, to liken the scenes to those seen in Nazi death camps.

At the centre of the case is the image of an emaciated Bosnian Muslim prisoner, Fikret Alic, who was seen standing behind a barbed wire fence at the Trnopolje camp.

ITN says Living Marxism's February 1997 article, written by a German journalist, Thomas Deichmann, was wrong to claim that the image was created by "camera angles and editing" and that there was no barbed wire fence surrounding the camp.

Tom Shields QC, for ITN, said the criticism of the broadcasts and the journalists involved had been a "highly damaging attack upon their respective reputations and professional integrity".

The libel case, due to last three weeks, is expected to have far-reaching implications for the credibility of news coverage around the world.

ITN and two reporters, Penny Marshall and Ian Williams, are claiming damages from the magazine's editor, Michael Hume, and its publishers over the article, an editorial and a press release. The magazine denies libel and pleads justification.

The judge, Mr Justice Morland, and the jury were shown several hours of unedited footage shot in Bosnia in August 1992, as well as the final bulletins which were broadcast that month.

Mr Shields told the jury of 10 men and two women: "You will see footage of the appalling physical conditions of some of those men, of the armed guards who were there, and you will also see how all those who visited both those camps were shocked by what they saw.

"Among the sights to greet them was that of an emaciated man stripped to the waist in the heat, standing behind barbed wire."

The footage showed Ms Marshall and Mr Williams - who were accompanied by an armed Serb escort - visiting the detention camps in an attempt to verify allegations that Bosnian Serbs were interning Bosnian Muslims in concentration camps.

The journalists, who had been invited by the Serb leader Radovan Karadzic to see the camps for themselves, were also handed an undeveloped reel of film, secretly taken by an inmate, which showed images of emaciated men with severe bruising.

Mr Shields said: "Judgments have to be made about what should be broadcast. Their task as they saw it was to report back what they had seen."

The jury was then shown the Living Marxism press release sent to the media in January 1997 detailing the claims made in the article, which said the "misleading" picture had provoked an international outcry.

The court heard that the magazine had refused to withdraw the defamatory allegations in the press release, to withdraw the article or to apologise for its contents.

The press release claimed that Mr Deichmann, an expert witness at the Bosnian war crimes tribunal, had seen unbroadcast ITN footage which showed that barbed wire did not surround the camp but a small enclosure beside it from which the news team filmed.

Mr Hume had also argued in the press release that "taking sides cannot be an excuse for taking liberties with the facts".

Mr Shields told the court: "Anyone reading that would have understood it to mean that the claimants had fabricated and broadcast distorted footage which deliberately misrepresented and sensationalised the treatment of the Bosnian Muslims at Trnopolje.

"They also allege that they kept quiet about this for four and a half years."

The case continues today.

Mr Shields told the court: "Anyone reading that would have understood it to mean that the claimants had fabricated and broadcast distorted footage which deliberately misrepresented and sensationalised the treatment of the Bosnian Muslims at Trnopolje. "They also allege that they kept quiet about this for four and a half years." The case continues today.

fields.headline: Opportunity costs
fields.standfirst: Donald MacLeod  and Lee Elliot Major report on an erupting fees row
fields.trailText: Donald MacLeod and Lee Elliot Major report on an erupting fees row
fields.body:
Student loans are deterring young people from poor families from applying to higher education and threaten to reverse the progress of the past 20 years, says a detailed study of sixth formers.

As heads of the elite Russell group of universities met last week to discuss the possible phased introduction of top-up fees after the next election, a Lincolnshire and Humberside university report threw the issue of student funding into sharp relief. Fees and loans now look certain to be a major political issue which threatens to divide the Labour party in the run-up to the election. Student leaders from the Russell group universities pledged to take their campaign against top-up fees into schools to mobilise parents as well as young people against the measure. Meanwhile, the government announced the basic undergraduate tuition fee would be raised to £1,050 a year.

More than half of working-class youngsters questioned in a survey of Hull schools said they were less likely to apply for university or college because of the introduction of loans and fees, reported researcher John Knowles. Nearly 80% felt this had limited their choice of institution.

Quoting the father of a bright 15-year-old who said "No daughter of mine is getting into debt just for education," Knowles said funding changes seemed to be accentuating the barriers facing people from low-income families. "The real impact of funding changes may be to reverse the trends of the past 20 years and return higher education to its former role of being only for those from relatively affluent and educated family backgrounds."

The Russell group universities which have been most vocal in calling for more resources - including student fees - in order to compete with the best of the world are also anxious not to exclude students from disadvantaged backgrounds by erecting higher financial barriers. The dilemma continues to dog them. Meeting at Warwick last week, their vice-chancellors agreed to commission a report from four distinguished economists to explore options ranging from bigger grants to the more radical idea of student vouchers. Deregulation of fees - permitting the most popular universities to charge higher fees and for others to attract students by cutting prices - is likely to be a key part of the report in May.

Sir Colin Campbell, Nottingham's vice-chancellor, said there had been a "horrendous reduction" in resources per student. "The social composition of the student body is no better than when we started the expansion in relative terms."

Sir Brian Follett, vice-chancellor of Warwick, commented: "I can't see in my lifetime frankly going across to the private American university model. Much closer would be a model you find in states like Michigan or California, where they tolerate differential fees between certain universities, but where the state is still putting in a substantial amount of the total. Where it goes 20 years on I do not know."

The Aldwych group of student representatives from Russell group universities said they were fundamentally oppose to top-up fees which would introduce two-tier education and increase the cost of a degree to tens of thousands of pounds.

 Pity the Poor Students by John Knowles, £6.50, from Policy Studies Research Centre, University of Lincolnshire and Humberside, Brayford Pool, Lincoln LN6 7TS.
