He was among the scholars and justice ministry officials who decided on Sunday night that the diary should be made public immediately to aid in Ms Lipstadt’s defence on a libel suit arising from a book published in 1993 that calls Mr Irving a “Nazi partisan” for denying the organised murder of Europe’s Jews. Ms Lipstadt’s defence team is believed to have been keen to have the diaries before the court to test arguments by Mr Irving for which he has cited Eichmann as evidence. In court 37 of the high court, it is the interpretation of the new historical documents that will matter. Mr Irving is understood to be one of the few people to have detailed knowledge of Eichmann’s account. According to his website, he was handed two packets containing 426 pages of Eichmann typescripts by a member of the senior Nazi’s family in Buenos Aires during a lecture tour of Argentina in 1991. He has used parts of this account to back up his arguments that there was no systematic genocide and that Hitler had no knowledge of any mass killings of Jews. In a 1997 letter to Robert Jan van Pelt, a Canadian Holocaust historian, Mr Irving cited the memoirs to cast doubt on the existence of gas chambers. The letter, published on his internet site, claims that while Eichmann, the architect of the extermination programme, makes reference to witnessing an “experimental” truck gassing, he was never shown a gas chamber at Auschwitz. While the Eichmann memoir seeks to deny the Nazi officer’s responsibility for mass murder, it does not disclaim the systematic murder of millions. “There is nothing there that would lead anyone to the conclusion that this did not happen,” Mr Bach said. Eichmann begins his record in his childhood and writes about his entry into the SS and his oath of allegiance. “He wanted his family to see it, and to see his role. Maybe he wanted to convince his family he did not take a central part in the Final Solution,” Mr Bach said. But after Eichmann was hanged in 1962 - the only time Israel has carried out the death penalty - and his ashes scattered over the Mediterranean, the manuscript lay forgotten in the Israeli national archives in Jerusalem. “Nobody was aware of this document,” said Ido Baum, a spokesman for the justice ministry. No one was aware of the fact that the notes were in the archives until last August when Dieter Eichmann, Eichmann’s son, approached the attorney general and requested the manuscript. According to Mr Bach, the prevailing sentiment in Israel at the time was against the immediate publication of the memoir, but there was never any intention to bury it in the archives indefinitely. “We always knew that sooner or later the diaries would be published,” he said. Typewritten versions of the manuscript could be made available to scholars and journalists as early as tomorrow. Although Israel does not intend general publication of the manuscript, it is unclear what Eichmann’s sons envisage. Mr Baum said last night that the copyright remained with the Eichmann family.

webTitle: The Leap Day in cricket history

fields.headline: The Leap Day in cricket history
fields.standfirst: An Ask Steven special: February 29 through the ages
fields.trailText: Younis Khan, the 22-year-old Habib Bank batsman making his Test debut at Rawalpindi, today became only the fourth player to score a Test century on Leap Year Day. His hundred was part of a strong Pakistan rearguard action in the first Test against Sri Lanka.
fields.body:
Younis Khan, the 22-year-old Habib Bank batsman making his Test debut at Rawalpindi, today became only the fourth player to score a Test century on Leap Year Day. His hundred was part of a strong Pakistan rearguard action in the first Test against Sri Lanka.

There haven't been many internationals played on this bonus day, but the last time there was it threw up one of the biggest shocks in cricket history: Kenya clobbered West Indies by 73 runs at Pune in the 1996 World Cup. In a good omen for Pakistan, one of their players scored a century against Sri Lanka in the other match that day - Aamir Sohail, with 111 at Karachi. But he won't be repeating that feat this time, as he's already been dismissed.

The first Test scheduled to include play on Feb 29 didn't actually have any, because it rained. That was the fourth Test of the 1903-04 Ashes series, at Sydney. And the same happened at the SCG in 1912 - no play because of rain in the final Ashes Test. England went on to win both those games, so perhaps they should try Leap Year play more often.

The first Test which actually included play on Feb 29 was in 1932. It was the second day of the inaugural South Africa-New Zealand Test, at Christchurch. Replying to New Zealand's 293, Jim Christy (103) and Bruce Mitchell (113) put on 196 and notched up the first two Leap Year Day centuries. South Africa won by an innings.

It was another 32 years before it happened again, and again it was New Zealand v South Africa, this time at Dunedin. NZ reached 114 for 6 on a curtailed second day (the first day had been rained off), and the match was eventually drawn.

In 1968 two Tests started on Leap Year Day; the drawn third match between West Indies and England at Bridgetown, where Pat Pocock made his debut after Fred Titmus's horrific boating accident, which cost him four toes. At Wellington, New Zealand took on India in the third Test of a four-match series. India won that one by eight wickets.

Fast-forward 20 years to 1988, and the first Test to end on Feb 29, as New Zealand drew with Mike Gatting's England at Auckland. Mark Greatbatch became the fourth Kiwi to score a century on debut - and the third to make a Leap Year Day hundred.

That's the whole story for Test matches, but there have been three one-day internationals apart from that '96 World Cup shock. In 1984 Desmond Haynes thumped 133 not out at Berbice, in Guyana, as West Indies overhauled Australia's 231 with two overs to spare. And two matches in the 1992 World Cup were extra-day specials: New Zealand beat South Africa by seven wickets at Auckland, despite Peter Kirsten's 90, and West Indies hammered Zimbabwe by 75 runs at Brisbane, where Dave Houghton became the first man to score a one-day fifty on Leap Year Day after breaking a toe early in his innings.

One famous player who was born on Feb 29 is Alf Gover, now England's oldest surviving Test player at 92 (or 23 actual birthdays). The only other Test player born on the big day is Gavin Stevens, the South Australia opener who played four matches for Australia in 1959-60.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. Additional research by Dominic Graham

fields.headline: Role reversal in the Caribbean
fields.trailText: Fast bowlers, who used to burn out at 30, are getting older. Coaches, who used to be old men (if they existed at all), are getting younger. These two trends have now reached a logical conclusion. The West Indies' new coach, Roger Harper, is not 37 until March 17; their veteran opening bowler, Courtney Walsh, turned 37 last October.
fields.body:
Fast bowlers, who used to burn out at 30, are getting older. Coaches, who used to be old men (if they existed at all), are getting younger. These two trends have now reached a logical conclusion. The West Indies' new coach, Roger Harper, is not 37 until March 17; their veteran opening bowler, Courtney Walsh, turned 37 last October.

Meanwhile, West Indies are stuck for a captain. They ought to go for Jimmy Adams, who is a fighter, a quick thinker and an excellent communicator, but he has been short of runs. West Indies are so bereft of decent batting that it would actually cost them nothing to keep him in the side, but if that sort of logic was likely to prevail, West Indies wouldn't be in their present mess.

So whom can they appoint? Step forward Harper himself. He is one of the all-time great fielders, he is probably the only double-centurion available to bat at No 8, and his springy off breaks will be able to tie down an end, which is more than some Caribbean spinners have achieved in recent years. The days when West Indies had to pick four fast bowlers - because they had eight who were worth a place - have long gone. Sometimes they struggle to find a third seamer.

Harper can be player-manager, marshalling the troops in a way the late Malcolm Marshall never managed, and minding the shop until Adams finds his form or another leader emerges (or Brian Lara, a gifted tactician, gets his appetite back). Two heads are better than one, but that's not a problem, because the new assistant coach, Jeffrey Dujon, will be there to bounce ideas off. Harper is noted for taking care in everything he does. In other words, he's a natural caretaker.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly

fields.headline: Jeanne fait son cinma
fields.standfirst: The new film about Joan of Arc is soon to hit our screens. How have French youngsters received it?
fields.trailText: The new film about Joan of Arc is soon to hit our screens. How have French youngsters received it?
fields.body:
Sainte ou guerrière, mystique ou anarchiste, Jeanne d'Arc continue à intriguer les historiens. Le cinéma aussi a exploré les visages contradictoires de cette femme qui a vécu au 15e siècle.

Le cinéaste Luc Besson s'est aussi inspiré de son histoire dans son dernier film. Il prétend que 80 % des dialogues et des situations sont vraies, et que le reste est un mélange de déduction et d'imagination.

À partir du 10 mars, le film sera sur les grands écrans britanniques. Mais les jeunes français l'ont déjà vu. Voici les impressions et les critiques de Sara, 15 ans, Michel, 22 ans et Marianne, 18 ans.

Quel est le passage du film qui t'a le plus frappé ?

Michel: J'ai trouvé que les scènes où Besson essayait d'exprimer la foi religieuse de Jeanne d'Arc faisaient pub de mode ou de shampooing - des très belles images sans profondeur ni spiritualité réelles. C'est très juvénile dans le sens où c'est très superficiel.

Marianne: Les scènes de combat étaient impressionnantes. De voir tous ces acteurs suivre cette chorégraphie en armure, incroyable ! Ça a dû leur prendre des heures d'entranement.

Qu'as-tu pensé du film ?

Sara: Je l'ai bien aimé, mes copines aussi. J'aime bien l'actrice qui joue Jeanne d'Arc et j'ai trouvé que tout le reste s'accordait bien aussi. Je ne connaissais pas du tout l'histoire de Jeanne d'Arc et j'ai eu l'impression d'apprendre.

Michel: Je l'ai trouvé très mauvais. Les images sont très belles mais il n'y a rien derrière.

Marianne: J'ai adoré. Sauf que j'ai trouvé ça dommage qu'il n'y ait pas d'histoire d'amour. À mon avis, c'est le meilleur film de Besson depuis Le Grand Bleu .

Qui sont les méchants ?

Sara: On ne peut pas dire qu'il y ait des méchants et des gentils, chaque côté est méchant pour l'autre.

Michel: Les Anglais, mais aussi en général, "les grands". Jeanne est très puérile et innocente. En fait, tous les bons sont des jeunes, tous les méchants sont des adultes.

Marianne: C'est pas vraiment ça l'histoire. En fait, ce qui est important, c'est Jeanne, son personnage. C'est tout de même incroyable qu'une femme tellement courageuse et déterminée ait existé au 15e siècle.

Le film se rapproche de l'histoire de Jeanne d'Arc ?

Sara: Je ne sais pas, je ne suis pas trop au courant, sauf à travers le film. Dans le film, elle a l'image d'une guerrière. On peut bien y croire.

Michel: On connaît très peu l'histoire de Jeanne d'Arc. Ce que l'on sait est tellement un mélange de mythe et de réalité qu'on ne peut pas vraiment faire une reconstruction de sa vie. On ne sait pas si elle était vraiment quelqu'un d'extraordinaire ou non.

Marianne: Je pense que oui. Je sais que Besson a fait beaucoup de recherches sur l'histoire de Jeanne d'Arc avant de réaliser son film.

Est-ce qu'un film basé sur l'histoire doit respecter les faits historiques ?

Sara: Ça dépend de ce que tu sais de l'histoire. Après, il faut préciser si c'est fictif ou réel. Chez Walt Disney, ils font souvent ça - ils prennent une base et après ils inventent pour que ça soit plus amusant pour les petits.

Michel: Non, pas du tout. Parce qu'un film, c'est artificiel. De toute façon, c'est tellement dur, il y a tellement de faits qui sont contestés, il y en a très peu qui sont très nets ou clairs.

Marianne: Oui, c'est très important. Sinon, à quoi ça sert ? La seule question, c'est est-ce qu'on peut toujours faire confiance aux réalisateurs ?

Et le fait qu'un film français soit réalisé en anglais ?

Sara: Je n'y ai même pas pensé. Ça ne m'a pas surprise car la plupart des films sont en anglais. En plus, Milla Jovovich (Jeanne), était la femme de Besson à l'époque. En plus, elle joue souvent des rôles comme ça. Du coup, ça ne m'a pas trop choquée qu'il l'ait choisie et qu'il ait tourné le film en anglais.

Michel: Je trouve ça ironique parce que Jeanne d'Arc est le symbole du Front national en France. Je trouve que c'est une façon de faire un pied de nez aux nationalistes.

Marianne: C'est vrai que c'est toujours plus agréable d'aller voir un film qu'on comprend tout de suite sans lire les sous-titres. Mais ça ne m'a pas vraiment dérangée.

Glossaire/Glossary

la guerrière warrior
le grand écran the big screen, cinema
la foi religieuse religious faith
la pub (coll.) advertisement
c'est dommage it's a pity
les méchants the baddies
les grands (coll.) adults
son personnage his/her character
être au courant to know about
y croire to believe in
faire un pied de nez to cock a snook

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Nicolas Cage files for divorce, Wes Bentley looks for blood, Oliver Stone criticised over Doors, Disney to film in US military installations, and Michael Caine reveals Oscar superstition
fields.body:
 Nicolas Cage has filed for divorce from his wife of five years Patricia Arquette (pictured) citing "irreconcilable differences". Surprisingly, Cage has declared on the divorce petition that the couple have actually been separated since January 1996 - just eight months after they were married. Cage and Arquette both hail from Hollywood families (her father was an actor in The Waltons, his uncle is Francis Coppola) and first met in 1987. When they were reunited eight years later, she set him a series of tasks which included finding her a black rose and obtaining the autograph of reclusive author JD Salinger. To outsiders, the relationship between the Oscar-winning actor from Leaving Las Vegas and the breathy, engrossing star of True Romance, Lost Highway and Flirting with Disaster appeared to be one of Hollywood's more healthy liasons. This time last year the couple were acting together for the first time, playing an ambulance driver and a recovering drug addict in the Martin Scorsese movie Bringing Out the Dead. Now it appears that their marriage was on the life-support machine itself.

 Fresh from his success as a drug-pushing suburban teen in American Beauty, 20 year-old Wes Bentley is reported to be in final negotiations to star in Warner Bros' Queen of the Damned, based on the third book in Anne Rice's vampire series. Bentley would take on Lestat, the role played by Tom Cruise in Neil Jordan's Interview With the Vampire six years ago. Slated to begin shooting in Australia in April, Queen of the Damned looks to be shaping up as a sort of Velvet Goldmine with fangs. It has the bloodsucking Lestat finding fame and fortune as a rock singer until his music awakens the queen of the vampires. The little-known Michael Rymer will direct the project.

 Ray Manzarek, the former rock keyboard player, has hit out at director Oliver Stone's portrayal of he and cohort Jim Morrison in the 1991 movie The Doors. Speaking at the Santa Monica Film Festival, Manzarek dismissed 1991's pseudo-biopic The Doors as "way off" and "innacurate" and a romanticised, over-the-top version of what "Oliver probably would have been like if he was a rock star". If being in The Doors was as crazed as Stone painted it, Manzarek added, he would have quit the band straight away.

 The Los Angeles County Sheriff's office has confirmed that it is investigating a reported car accident involving actress Halle Berry. The accident occurred on the morning of February 23 in West Hollywood and involved a rented Chevrolet believed to be driven by Berry. A woman in another car suffered a broken arm and Berry - who co-starred in last year's political satire Bulworth - was later treated for undisclosed injuries. The police are said to be treating the accident as a hit and run.

 The Pentagon has given permission for Disney to film sections of their World War Two epic Pearl Harbour on US military installations in the Pacific. The makers of the $135m epic, which focuses on America's entry into the war, now plan to shoot several action setpieces on Ford Island in Hawaii, which was bombed by Japanese forces on December 7, 1941. The mega-budget production begins shooting on April 10, with Michael Bay directing.

 Michael Caine may find himself fluffing his lines if he wins an award at next month's Oscar ceremony. The British star, nominated as Best Supporting Actor for his role in The Cider House Rules, told GMTV yesterday that he would not be preparing a victory speech in case it jinxed his chances. "I think it would be bad luck to prepare a speech," said Caine, speaking from the East End set of his latest film, Shiner. "I see people go up there and get [out] a piece of paper and I think 'Jesus, you must be confident'."

The makers of the $135m epic, which focuses on America's entry into the war, now plan to shoot several action setpieces on Ford Island in Hawaii, which was bombed by Japanese forces on December 7, 1941. The mega-budget production begins shooting on April 10, with Michael Bay directing.  Michael Caine may find himself fluffing his lines if he wins an award at next month's Oscar ceremony. The British star, nominated as Best Supporting Actor for his role in The Cider House Rules, told GMTV yesterday that he would not be preparing a victory speech in case it jinxed his chances. "I think it would be bad luck to prepare a speech," said Caine, speaking from the East End set of his latest film, Shiner. "I see people go up there and get [out] a piece of paper and I think 'Jesus, you must be confident'."

webTitle: Blair's vision for the NHS - full text

fields.headline: Blair's vision for the NHS - full text
fields.standfirst: Speech at St Thomas' Hospital, London, on modernisation of accident and emergency facilities
fields.trailText: I am delighted to be here today to open formally this million pound upgrading of St Thomas' Accident and Emergency facilities - completed on time and to budget.
fields.body:
I am delighted to be here today to open formally this million pound upgrading of St Thomas' Accident and Emergency facilities - completed on time and to budget.

As a result of the modernisation, this hospital now has new areas for receiving and assessing patients and for treating minor conditions. It also has improved facilities for treatment, resuscitation, mental health assessment and - I am pleased to see - staff. It also has an impressive state of the art digital radiology system. And later this year a new medical assessment unit for GP admissions will be built.

It will provide the people of this part of south London with the modern high class A&E services they need and deserve. The facilities you have here rank alongside the best Emergency Rooms in the US.

As important is the fact that what is happening here is happening elsewhere in the country. The £115 million modernisation programme which we announced last year is now producing results. Over a quarter of the 244 Accident and Emergency modernisation schemes in 182 hospitals are now complete. Half will be finished by the end of April and all bar a handful will be done and dusted by the end of the year.

This is a huge achievement. Every casualty department that needed it - that's three-quarters of the total - modernised. NHS casualty departments in their history have never had the benefit of a programme on this scale.

Like the scheme here the projects elsewhere include new special areas for children, better links between A&E and primary care, improved safety and security for staff and patients, faster access to diagnostic facilities and more assessment and observation wards.

This is real money spent on real projects to benefit real patients. You can touch it. You can see it.

Don't believe all that you read in the papers or hear on the radio about health care. I know there is a long way to go - but there is a real change and improvement in many parts of the NHS.

The NHS is building more new hospitals than it has ever done. 20 are under construction and 17 more are in the pipeline. The first ones open later this year. Another big achievement that will start to transform the face of the NHS.

It's the same with cancer equipment. With money from the NHS and the National Lottery we are funding over the next three years nearly 500 items of the most modern equipment to diagnose and treat cancer - mammography and ultrasound machines, linear accelerators and scanners.

And we are getting in more staff too. Yesterday Alan Milburn announced the results of the latest nurse census. There were 4,500 more qualified midwives and nurses in 1999 than there were in 1998 - equivalent to an extra 3,000 full-time nursing and midwifery staff.

It is the second year running that the numbers have risen and it is the biggest recorded rise for seven years. And since we came into government the number of full-time nurses has increased by over 4,000. Nurses are returning to the NHS - some of them are here today.

There are more nurse training places - over 4,000 of them. More doctors - over 2,000 of them. And there will be more medical students - 1,000 of them.

I could go on. True figures. Not invented statistics.

The extra money that we have put into the health service is beginning to make a difference.

But extra investment and more staff are not by themselves enough. We need modernisation too. Money and modernisation are two sides of the same coin. In this government's reform of the public services you cannot separate them. Modernisation requires money. But money without modernisation is money not well spent.

Take A&E as an example. We are getting the modern facilities. Now we need the modern ways of working to go with the modernised departments.

I was pleased to hear that as part of designing your new A&E department you examined your working practices to see what changes were needed to make the most of the new investment and to improve things for patients.

So now you are making more use of emergency nurse practitioners in the minor treatment areas. You have someone to oversee the way beds are allocated and managed so that patients get into the right bed more quickly. And you have improved your working arrangements with social services so that when patients who are ready to go home but need some support they can be discharged without delay.

That is exactly what I mean by money for modernisation.

We now need to go further. We have to address the frustration that people feel when they come and wait for hours to be seen in casualty in what, if we are honest, have all too often been crowded chaotic conditions.

The Department of Health's A&E Modernisation team will be reporting within the next couple of months. It will be recommending a big overhaul in how A&E works. A revolution in casualty care. Their recommendations will be wide-ranging.

For example, slashing waiting times by doing as you have done and separating the treatment of minor injuries and illnesses from major injuries and conditions. And using NHS Direct assessment procedures to help do this.

Giving appropriately trained nurses greater powers to order x-rays, blood tests and other diagnostic procedures, to interpret the results, give medication and discharge patients.

Fast-tracking of patients directly to the appropriate speciality - for example, to orthopaedics for patients with fractured hips direct to orthopaedics.

Training and empowering physiotherapist, radiographer and paramedics to take on new and extended roles.

Focusing experienced and skilled consultants on the most complex cases.

I know that you have anticipated many of these changes. But one of the challenges we face is to make the good things happen not just in isolated hospitals but everywhere.

We do not want a lottery of care depending on how efficient your local hospital is. All patients wherever they live are entitled to prompt, convenient quality when they need.

So modernisation is not something you opt in or opt out of. Of course, it will take time. But modernisation is not an optional extra. It is a 'must do'.

Those Trusts that embrace change and modernisation will increasingly find that we leave them to get on and provide local people with a good service. We will not only get off your back, we will reward your effort. But those few that cannot or will not change can expect support and intervention - and, where necessary, someone else running the show.

So modernisation and investment go together.

And this investment and modernisation is for a purpose. It is investment and modernisation to build a new NHS. A different sort of health service. The new buildings, the modernised facilities, the modern equipment, the extra staff and the new ways of working are part of a concerted plan to renew the NHS for a new century.

The health service we are creating effectively has four stages of care.

Easy access into the Health Service through NHS Direct, through walk-in centres and through more convenient opening times in doctors' surgeries, through modern well run A&E departments. That is point number one.

Point number two: the doctors and nurses locally grouped into Primary Care Groups that can drive forward innovation in health care in their areas - providing a wide range services on one site. Far better and more efficient than the two-tier system that we inherited.

The third stage is then for social services and community hospitals to work together to provide community and what are sometimes called step-down or intermediate services. Particularly for elderly people, who may initially need hospital care but then require intensive rehabilitation and support in a more appropriate setting. Care which as Alan Milburn put it the other week is care that is a bridge between home and hospital.

Fourthly, an acute hospital sector, where we have the doctors and nurses and specialists and the critical care beds that we need to care for people properly. And with proper inspection and accountability in the way those hospitals are run and managed.

The four stages or levels of care working to provide the right and convenient care for each and every patient. Modern IT systems used to connect the various levels together. So appointments can be booked from the GP surgery. Test results sent and patients' records available quickly and instantly through the latest technology.

So, our program for the Health Service requires extra investment, which we are getting. And it requires real reform and modernisation, which we are carrying out.

And since the NHS means so much to Britain, and the people who work in it, I do think it important that the media give a sense of balance about this issue. To read and hear some of the coverage in the past few weeks you would think no-one is being cared for; that it's hopeless, beyond repair. This is alarmist nonsense. Ninety-nine per cent of people do not get their operations cancelled on the day they are due. The vast majority get good NHS treatment. There are real problems, some of a deep and long-term nature which will require time and money and change to put right.

But there are millions of people every year in Britain getting superb healthcare from the NHS. They are the norm not the exception. We will put right what is wrong. But don't tell people it is all wrong. It isn't. The NHS is a brilliant conception and with that time and money and change, its reality will once again match the vision behind it.

It will take time, however. I repeat this point constantly, because it is the truth. But let no-one say that the NHS can not be re-built. It can be re-built. It will be re-built.

Yes, you will always get situations which should never happen. Yes, you will sometimes get people who are treated badly when they shouldn't be.

But the NHS is a fine institution, that given the resources and the changes necessary will once again be the pride of Britain and the envy of the rest of the world. Taking time is obvious, but it is worth taking the time to get it right. And I am confident that we will get it right.

fields.headline: Augenzeuge
fields.standfirst: Lilo is an arts journalist and film fan. Here she reports on her 11th visit to the Berlinale
fields.trailText: Lilo is an arts journalist and film fan. Here she reports on her 11th visit to the Berlinale
fields.body:
Ich war jetzt zum elften Mal auf der Berlinale. Ich mache das, um einmal im Jahr im Übermaß Kultur zu genießen, so wie ich sie mag. Für mich ist das eine Art Auftanken. Ich gehe dann ins Theater und natürlich auch ins Kino.

Übrigens: Ich leide heute noch darunter, daß ich auf der Berlinale Leonardo DiCaprio nicht gesehen habe... Nein, mal im Ernst: Ganz Berlin war im Leo-Fieber. Eine Zeitung hat getitelt: "Wer Leo küßt, kriegt 1000 Mark." Die Stimmung wurde richtig angeheizt: als er in Berlin war, standen die Kiddies schon Stunden vorher Schlange, um ihn zu sehen. Auch ich bin ja eigentlich DiCaprio-Fan. Ich habe ihn als Romeo geliebt, als Gilbert Grape bewundert, aber als Paradiessucher in "The Beach" hat er mich ehrlich gesagt abgetörnt.

Dieser Film ist einer der schlechtesten, die diesmal im Wettbewerb starteten. Es ist eine schlecht erzählte Geschichte und ein Wischi-Waschi-DiCaprio. Man nimmt ihm seine Rolle einfach nicht ab. Dagegen fand ich "Magnolia" wirklich gut. Ich habe ihn in der Spätvorstellung gesehen, und obwohl der Film ziemlich lang ist, bin ich nicht müde geworden. Und Wim Wenders "The Million Dollar Hotel" hat meiner Meinung nach zu Recht den silbernen Bären bekommen. Mir hat er sehr gut gefallen. Er ist überhaupt kein typisch deutscher Film.

Was das Umfeld betrifft, war diesmal sicherlich der Potsdamer Platz ein Thema. Und da vor allem der Berlinale-Palast mit seinen Stufen. Da gingen die Leute reihenweise in die Knie, sind also gestolpert, weil die Treppen eine so komische Höhe haben, viel niedriger, als man es gewohnt ist. Viele sind gefallen, ein Berlinale-Mitarbeiter hat sich sogar den Arm gebrochen.

Echte, große Stars habe ich natürlich keine getroffen.

Glossar/Glossary

abtörnen (coll.) to lose interest

auftanken to win new power

in die Knie gehen to fall

reihenweise one after the other

stolpern to stumble

die Stufe step

titeln to make a headline

wischi-waschi (coll.) wishy-washy

webTitle: Heather Graham to star in French comedy remake

fields.headline: Heather Graham to star in French comedy remake
fields.trailText: Heather Graham is to take the lead role of a lonesome New Yorker in a remake of a 1996 French film about a woman hunting her lost cat through the city
fields.body:
Heather Graham is to take the lead role of a lonesome New Yorker in a remake of a 1996 French film about a woman hunting her lost cat through the city.

Written and directed by the talented Gallic film-maker Cedric Klapisch, Chacon Cherche son Chat (When the Cat's Away) was a typically French creature - an airy urban comedy-drama alive with well-observed details and robustly eccentric characters. The proposed Miramax remake, to be directed by Brad Anderson (creator of Next Stop Wonderland), has been shrewdly Americanised, with the central location shifted from Paris to New York and an apple-pie star in Ms Graham. It is the latest in a growing line of American remakes of recent French pictures. A Hollywood rejig of last year's madcap Parisian comedy Le Diner de Cons is already on the cards.

For Graham, too, the Miramax signing reflects her burgeoning reputation. Since her comedic sex-kitten turn in last summer's Austin Powers picture, the 30 year-old actress has scarcely stopped working. As a result, When the Cat's Away will have to be shoe-horned into an increasingly frenetic schedule. The production is due to begin shooting as soon as Graham completes her work on the Farrelly Brothers-produced comedy Say it Ain't So which starts production on March 6.

fields.headline: Otello Martelli dies
fields.standfirst: Master of cinematography behind great Italian movies
fields.trailText: One of the great craftsmen of Italian cinematography, Otello Martelli, who has died aged 96, photographed some of the most famous postwar films, from Rossellini's Paisà to De Santis's Bitter Rice. He worked on seven Fellini films, most notably La Strada and La Dolce Vita
fields.body:
One of the great craftsmen of Italian cinematography, Otello Martelli, who has died aged 96, photographed some of the most famous postwar films, from Rossellini's Paisà to De Santis's Bitter Rice. He worked on seven Fellini films, most notably La Strada and La Dolce Vita.

Born in Rome, he became an assistant cameraman at 14, and worked on silent films. He was signed up as a cameraman by the state newsreel company Istituto Luce, and in 1928 was sent to film the tragic airship expedition to the North Pole by Umberto Nobile. After working as assistant cameraman, his first important credit was in 1934, for Alessandro Blasetti's Vecchia Guardia (Old Guard), a blatantly fascist film which, however, was "saved" for its plastic values even by leftwing critics of post-fascist Italy.

After the war, Martelli was chosen by Rossellini to join him on the adventurous journey up the Italian peninsula that resulted in Paisà. His experience as a newsreel cameraman helped to give the film a feeling of authenticity in this reconstruction of the struggles for the liberation from the Nazi-Fascists, even in sequences that were not always filmed on the real locations (such as the opening episode in Sicily).

During the shooting in Florence, Martelli was a first-person witness to the debut of the future director with whom he would later work, Federico Fellini, who was then Rossellini's assistant and co-scriptwriter. One day, Rossellini was sick, and Fellini was instructed to shoot the scene in a country lane, where a wine cart trundles by under fire from snipers. "Sor Otello", as Martelli was known (Sor being a respectful Roman term of address), had planned to shoot the scene from as high an angle as possible, but the brazen young assistant gave orders for the action to be filmed from ground level, which Martelli contemptuously called "a mouse's point of view". Fellini got his way, and was congratulated warmly by Rossellini when the rushes were seen.

Martelli photographed two of Rossellini's most famous films, the equally adventurous Stromboli, with Ingrid Bergman, and the film that François Truffaut once described as "the most beautiful film ever seen", Francis, God's Juggler - its exquisite visual aspect being very much to the credit of the cinematographer.

When, in 1950, Alberto Lattuada and Federico Fellini decided to produce, write and co-direct a film about Italian provincial music-halls, Luci del varietà (Variety Lights), it was Fellini who suggested Martelli as cinematographer. And three years later, Fellini chose him to photograph his second feature, I Vitelloni. The two men continued to bicker affectionately, but when the first choice for cinematographer of La Strada had to pull out, it was Sor Otello who took over - and the world was to acclaim him as well as the director.

He worked again with Fellini on Il Bidone (1955), and, though uncredited, took over from Aldo Tonti to finish Le Notti di Cabiria in 1956. With Tonti, he went round the world scouting locations for René Clement's The Sea Wall (1958), for which, in the end, he, rather than Tonti, was cinema- tographer.

He photographed many of the great cinematic beauties of those years, among them Silvana Mangano, Sophia Loren and Melina Mercouri, but Martelli himself said that the most photogenic of all was Anita Ekberg, immortalised by Fellini (with Martelli's help) in La Dolce Vita. Martelli's contribution to this film was his most creative achievement in later life. In spite of continuing disagreements with Fellini over camera angles, there was great mutual respect.

Martelli maintained that "it was not true that Federico knew nothing about camera technique. He just had his own ideas. For example, he wanted to use a lens for panoramic shots which is normally used only for close-ups. I told him there was a risk of flickering, but he said it didn't matter. He was absolutely right."

But after Fellini's episode of Boccaccio '70 (1962), The Temptations Of Dr Antonio, the director said he was tired of hearing Sor Otello continuously complain, "It can't be done." For the film 8, he entrusted the cinematography to a new emerging master of lighting, Gianni Di Venanzo. But Di Venanzo, like many other emerging cinematographers, admitted that Sor Otello had been their maestro. The chore which induced Martelli into retirement was working on one of the episodes of The Three Faces (1965), the film directed by Antonioni and others which producer Dino De Laurentiis had hoped would launch the then Empress Soraya of Iran as an actress.

He is survived by two daughters and a son, Luigi, who is a television director.

fields.bodyText: One of the great craftsmen of Italian cinematography, Otello Martelli, who has died aged 96, photographed some of the most famous postwar films, from Rossellini's Paisà to De Santis's Bitter Rice. He worked on seven Fellini films, most notably La Strada and La Dolce Vita. Born in Rome, he became an assistant cameraman at 14, and worked on silent films. He was signed up as a cameraman by the state newsreel company Istituto Luce, and in 1928 was sent to film the tragic airship expedition to the North Pole by Umberto Nobile. After working as assistant cameraman, his first important credit was in 1934, for Alessandro Blasetti's Vecchia Guardia (Old Guard), a blatantly fascist film which, however, was "saved" for its plastic values even by leftwing critics of post-fascist Italy. After the war, Martelli was chosen by Rossellini to join him on the adventurous journey up the Italian peninsula that resulted in Paisà. His experience as a newsreel cameraman helped to give the film a feeling of authenticity in this reconstruction of the struggles for the liberation from the Nazi-Fascists, even in sequences that were not always filmed on the real locations (such as the opening episode in Sicily). During the shooting in Florence, Martelli was a first-person witness to the debut of the future director with whom he would later work, Federico Fellini, who was then Rossellini's assistant and co-scriptwriter. One day, Rossellini was sick, and Fellini was instructed to shoot the scene in a country lane, where a wine cart trundles by under fire from snipers. "Sor Otello", as Martelli was known (Sor being a respectful Roman term of address), had planned to shoot the scene from as high an angle as possible, but the brazen young assistant gave orders for the action to be filmed from ground level, which Martelli contemptuously called "a mouse's point of view". Fellini got his way, and was congratulated warmly by Rossellini when the rushes were seen. Martelli photographed two of Rossellini's most famous films, the equally adventurous Stromboli, with Ingrid Bergman, and the film that François Truffaut once described as "the most beautiful film ever seen", Francis, God's Juggler - its exquisite visual aspect being very much to the credit of the cinematographer. When, in 1950, Alberto Lattuada and Federico Fellini decided to produce, write and co-direct a film about Italian provincial music-halls, Luci del varietà (Variety Lights), it was Fellini who suggested Martelli as cinematographer. And three years later, Fellini chose him to photograph his second feature, I Vitelloni. The two men continued to bicker affectionately, but when the first choice for cinematographer of La Strada had to pull out, it was Sor Otello who took over - and the world was to acclaim him as well as the director. He worked again with Fellini on Il Bidone (1955), and, though uncredited, took over from Aldo Tonti to finish Le Notti di Cabiria in 1956. With Tonti, he went round the world scouting locations for René Clement's The Sea Wall (1958), for which, in the end, he, rather than Tonti, was cinema- tographer. He photographed many of the great cinematic beauties of those years, among them Silvana Mangano, Sophia Loren and Melina Mercouri, but Martelli himself said that the most photogenic of all was Anita Ekberg, immortalised by Fellini (with Martelli's help) in La Dolce Vita. Martelli's contribution to this film was his most creative achievement in later life. In spite of continuing disagreements with Fellini over camera angles, there was great mutual respect. Martelli maintained that "it was not true that Federico knew nothing about camera technique. He just had his own ideas. For example, he wanted to use a lens for panoramic shots which is normally used only for close-ups. I told him there was a risk of flickering, but he said it didn't matter. He was absolutely right." But after Fellini's episode of Boccaccio '70 (1962), The Temptations Of Dr Antonio, the director said he was tired of hearing Sor Otello continuously complain, "It can't be done." For the film 8, he entrusted the cinematography to a new emerging master of lighting, Gianni Di Venanzo. But Di Venanzo, like many other emerging cinematographers, admitted that Sor Otello had been their maestro. The chore which induced Martelli into retirement was working on one of the episodes of The Three Faces (1965), the film directed by Antonioni and others which producer Dino De Laurentiis had hoped would launch the then Empress Soraya of Iran as an actress. He is survived by two daughters and a son, Luigi, who is a television director. Otello Martelli, cinematographer, born May 19 1903; died February 20 2000

fields.headline: Leap years
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about 29 February on the net
fields.trailText: 1. Today is leap day, the extra day we get once every four years.
fields.body:
1. Today is leap day, the extra day we get once every four years.

2. Traditionally it's the time when women can propose marriage to men.

3. But in this fast-moving, wired world February 29 is also the date that 1,200 Japanese cash dispensers fail to register the extra day and crash.

4. Years ending in "00" (such as 1900 or 2100) are only leap years if - like 2000 - they are also divisible by 400. Many computers did not know this.

5. The leap year was established by Julius Caesar in 46BC. His Julian calendar collected the six hours at the end of every 365.25 day year and tacked them on to February.

6. Before Caesar, the Romans' lunar calendar had an extra 22-day month every few years to maintain the correct seasonal changes.

7. The leap year has consequences: actor Joss Ackland, like others born on this day, only gets to celebrate his birthday once every four years, making him a sprightly 17.

8. Stranger still, on this day in 1504 Christopher Columbus used a lunar eclipse to terrify the native Tainos he encountered in Jamaica.

9. And in 1692 the Salem witch trial began when warrants were put out for the arrest of Tituba, Sarah Goode and Sarah Osborne on suspicion of witchcraft.

10. You won't get the chance for another four years so go on, send your leap year greetings card today.

webTitle: American Psycho cut to appease censors

fields.headline: American Psycho cut to appease censors
fields.trailText: The makers of the controversial American Psycho have removed parts of a central sex scene to ensure the picture qualifies for an R rating from the US censors
fields.body:
The makers of the controversial American Psycho have removed parts of a central sex scene to ensure the picture qualifies for an R rating from the US censors.

The film had been slapped with a prohibitive NC17 rating by the Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA) who were concerned over a section in which the tale's serial-killing anti-hero (played by Christian Bale) has sex with two prostitutes. A spokesman for the independent distribution company Lions Gate Entertainment now confirms that "a few seconds" have been cut from the offending section and that the MPAA has now passed the film as an R-rated picture.

This last-minute change of fortunes spells good news for American Psycho at the US box-office. The NC-17 is still widely regarded as a kiss of death for all but the lowest budget movies. Many cinema chains refuse to exhibit NC-17 pictures, the Blockbuster video chain refuses to stock them and many newspapers and magazines will not carry adverts promoting them. R-rated productions, by contrast, occupy a hefty slice of Hollywood's traditional output.

Based on the 1990 novel by Bret Easton Ellis, American Psycho tells the tale of a status-obssessed yuppie murderer in Manhattan. Directed by Mary Harron, a former BBC film-maker who made her feature debut with 1996's I Shot Andy Warhol, the picture premiered in its uncut version to an enthusiastic reception at last month's Sundance International Film Festival.

 American psycho goes on general release across America on April 14.

fields.headline: Woman is cross
fields.standfirst: Last month Vaneisa Baksh wrote about her failed attempt to become a member of the Queen's Park Cricket Club in Trinidad and Tobago. Now she reveals the sort of attitudes she was up against
fields.trailText: If I were a member of the Queen's Park Cricket Club, I would have known about their calypso competition, Oh Kaiso Boy, and I would have been present to hear two calypsoes which dealt with me firmly. As it is, my entry into the calypso world would have passed unknown to me had my neighbour, Carlos, not seen it fit to tell me about it.
fields.body:
If I were a member of the Queen's Park Cricket Club, I would have known about their calypso competition, Oh Kaiso Boy, and I would have been present to hear two calypsoes which dealt with me firmly. As it is, my entry into the calypso world would have passed unknown to me had my neighbour, Carlos, not seen it fit to tell me about it.

The QPCC's annual calypso competition had nine entrants this year, and two chose to sing on women. Curious about the content, I made several enquiries at the QPCC, and eventually tracked down both composers.

Kirk McGyver, who sings under the name Shakes, returned my call with some trepidation. He was expecting me to be "negative," he said, and was surprised that I seemed more curious in collecting his lyrics than in castigating him. I had to explain that when I applied for membership to the QPCC nearly three years ago, I knew it would meet opposition, and it is only now, after my application was rejected at the end of last year, that I have heard some indication that the matter was being ventilated at the Club. I felt that in the same way I had raised my side of the discussion in my columns over the years, I should allow some space to the opposing views.

Shakes was not comfortable. His song, "Woman is Cross," which won him second place behind Roger Galt's "Caribbean Woes," was a bit "crude", he said, and he wouldn't want me to publish the lyrics. He'd rather I came and heard him perform it. He did tell me what the song was about, though:

"Too much man-bashing going on and is time for men to hit back, is time for you all to take some jamming too. Women are trying too hard to be like men, it is not their place."

No matter how I tried to persuade him to tell me the lyrics, he wouldn't, insisting that it was too crude, and only the last verse was publishable:

If you stand beside me and fight,
I will help you in your struggle for equal rights,
I will be a little more equal of course,
But is only when a woman stays a woman,
I will be man and say woman is boss.

I asked him what he thought would be the negative effects of women becoming members of the QPCC, and he faltered; not finding a reason, he offered that he thought it might actually be a positive thing. Then he blurted out a question: do you really want to join the Club? I told him I did, and I told him how I feel about cricket. I told him I was as committed a supporter of West Indian cricket as there has ever been. The Queen's Park Cricket Club is the only Test ground in our country - doesn't that give it a wider mandate than just being a gentleman's club? Shouldn't I have the right to be there?

Shakes still did not agree, though he was appeased that I seemed to really be committed to the game (and there I was, having to extend some kind of credentials again), but he still felt that the QPCC ought to remain something of "a male comfort zone" where the guys could have the "freedom to carry on as you want," without having to say pardon me to the ladies.

I was more fortunate with George Wilcox, who sang as Pappy that night, complete with wig and make-up. His lyrics for "I want to be a Member" I reproduce hereunder, with his permission, of course.

Every day I read the newspaper
Is only complaints from Vaneisa
All over the paper,
Is pressure from Vaneisa
East, west, north and south
The woman only running she mouth
Like the woman have no gender,
But she want to be a member

Chorus
Dear Willie, forget about Vaneisa
Dear Joey, away with Vaneisa
This so-called cricket fan, this maccomere woman
I can't understand, ah only hope she could ketch a stand, Vaneisa
Vaneisa Baksh, Baksh, Baksh
Vaneisa mash, mash mash,
Vaneisa Baaaaksh

Even big-time lawyer, like Allum, she bring in this confusion
At the last ballot meeting, he and Denzil representing
Willie say, bring the lady to me
Let me stop this controversy
Then take she to St Clair Medical and I will give she a physical

Chorus
Dear Willie, Forget about Vaneisa
Dear Joey, away with Vaneisa
This so-called cricket fan, this maccomere woman
I can't understand, ah only hope she could find a man,

The last Test against Australia
I bounce up with Vaneisa
The Test was in Barbados
And the woman take off she clothes
She say she's in love with Brian Lara
And she want he to be she sponsor
But Joey say if he do sponsor she
He sure to lose the captaincy

(Chorus)

Now you heard the story
about Vaneisa versus Pappy
Go and get married quickly and forget about QPCC
Or go and join the nunnery and keep your virginity
A Parkite means men, you must know
We don't want no woman to spoil we show.

Shortly after I had written (on New Year's Day) of my rejection by the QPCC, Wisden's website (wisden.com) had carried my column under the heading, "QPCC making the MCC look good," referring to how the MCC had finally capitulated and let women in. I felt it was enough to run the lyrics of these calypsoes so we could have an idea of how the "guys" have arrived at their position. Keith Nexar, one of the organisers of the competition, had supported my application. "I hope one day you are with the boys," he said. I don't know, Keith, they might make me look too good.

Vaneisa Baksh writes a weekly column, Firefly, for the Express Newspapers in Trinidad and Tobago

webTitle: Wavell Hinds inspires Jamaica to Busta Cup glory

fields.headline: Wavell Hinds inspires Jamaica to Busta Cup glory
fields.trailText: West Indies
fields.body:
West Indies

Jamaica have won the first-class Busta Cup, beating the Leeward Islands in the final at Sabina Park by virtue of their first-innings lead. Jamaica were indebted to their young opener Wavell Hinds, 23, who hit 127 in their first innings total of 333. It was enough to win the match as the Leewards then collapsed to 142 all out; Courtney Walsh took 3-37, and Laurie Williams 3-21. The Leewards fought back in Jamaica's second innings, with Curtly Ambrose returning figures of 16-9-18-4, but Jimmy Adams made 51 to help set an improbable victory target of 353. The Leewards closed on 114 for 2.

Jamaica 333 and 161 for 9 decl.
Leeward Islands 142 and 114 for 2
Jamaica win by virtue of first-innings lead

Australia

A stunning collapse by the Queensland Bulls handed the Mercantile Mutual Cup to hosts Western Australia in the final at Perth. Set a mammoth 302 to win (that's right, it's not just the national side that's running up 300 in one-dayers), Queensland were romping home at 186 for 0 in the 27th over. They needed to score at five an over, but WA took the Bulls by the horns, and picked up all ten wickets for just 70. It meant James Maher's 90-ball 102 was in vain. Earlier, WA had totalled 301 for 6, with opener Ryan Campbell hitting 108 and adding 140 for the second wicket with Justin Langer (42) in just 19.5 overs. Adrian Dale, usually a model of economy, returned figures of 10-0-65-2.

Western Australia 301 for 6 in 50 overs
Queensland 256 in 45.2 overs (Martin Love 73)
Western Australia won by 45 runs

New Zealand

Seamer Chris Martin had career-best match figures of 12-55 as Northern Districts moved to the top of the first-class Shell Trophy with a crushing innings victory over close rivals Auckland in Taupo. Martin followed up first-innings figures of 5-22 with 7-33 (another career best) as Auckland twice subsided for less than 150. Northern Districts began the match with 345; Mark Bailey made 100.

Northern Districts 345
Auckland 131 and 149
Northern Districts won by an innings and 65 runs

Matthew Horne struck 141 to help Otago thrash Central Districts, also by an innings, in Palmerston North. He was assisted by 140* from Chris Gaffaney as Otago amassed a huge 505. This was in reply to CD's first innings of 165, in which Mathew Sinclair made 102; the next best score was 20. Medium-pacer Glenn Jonas took 6-39. Test left-arm seamer Shayne O'Connor was the destroyer second time round, claiming 5-52 as CD were dismissed for 215.

Central Districts 165 and 215 (Mark Douglas 64*)
Otago 505
Otago won by an innings and 125 runs

Test batsman Gary Stead led a superb rearguard as Canterbury salvaged a draw with hosts Wellington. Stead scored 125 as Canterbury were forced to follow on, 208 behind, and received support from Jarrod Englefield (76) and opener Brad Doody (72). Wellington's first innings of 390 was based around 143 from Jason Wells.

Wellington 390
Canterbury 182 and 384 for 5
Drawn

India

Vinod Kambli continues to nudge India's Test selectors. He made 88 and 114 as Mumbai hammered Delhi by 310 runs in the super league stage of the Ranji Trophy. In Mumbai's second-innings 453 for 8 declared, Jatin Paranjpe blasted 185, including 16 fours and five sixes. Mumbai moved top of group A.

Mumbai 247 and 453 for 8 decl.
Delhi 200 (Ashu Dani 74) and 190
Mumbai won by 310 runs

Utpal Chatterjee took 10-160 for Bengal but Rajasthan still had the better of a drawn game in Calcutta. Chatterjee toiled away in the first innings for an analysis of 51.1-20-76-5, but Anshu Jain hit 115 and put on 254 for the second wicket with Rahul Kannat (143). Chatterjee then took 5-84 as Rajasthan declared their second innings to leave Bengal a target of 310. They never got close, despite 67 from Test batsman Devang Gandhi to go with his first-innings 89, and 56 from S Kalyani to add to his earlier knock of 83*.

Rajasthan 377 and 216 for 8 decl.
Bengal 284 and 179 for 5
Drawn

Mihir Diwakar weighed in with 12-121 but still finished on the losing side as Bihar suffered a narrow defeat at the hands of Railways. Diwakar started with 7-47 to skittle Railways for 130, but Bihar did even worse in reply, folding to 105; medium-pacer Zakir Hussain took 5-36, while off spinner Kulamani Parida claimed 4-29. Diwakar then took 5-74 as Railways, held together by 82* from captain Yere Goud, reached 216, setting Bihar 242 to win. They were dismissed for 201, Parida adding four more wickets.

Railways 130 and 216
Bihar 105 and 210 (Parida 4-52)
Railways won by 40 runs

It was the Ricky Martin show in Chandigarh where Punjab drew with Baroda. Ravneet Ricky made 83 for Punjab, before Jacob Martin replied with 118 to give Baroda a first-innings lead of 139. But 114* from India Under-19 World Cup star Reetinder Singh Sodhi helped Punjab escape with a comfortable draw.

Punjab 245 and 274 for 4
Baroda 384
Drawn

Sridaran Sriram maintained his outstanding form with 177 as Tamil Nadu went top of group C with an easy win over Haryana in Gurgaon. Sriram guided TN to a huge 486 in response to Haryana's 208, an innings that was rescued by an eighth-wicket partnership of 102 between Pradeep Jain (57) and Pankaj Thakur (53). In Haryana's second innings, only Jitender Singh (100) put up much resistance.

Haryana 208 and 238
Tamil Nadu 486 (Jain 5-143)
Tamil Nadu won by an innings and 40 runs

There were 12 wickets for another bowler who ended up on the losing side, in the game between Orissa and Saurashtra at Rajkot. Odedra took 6-117 and 6-52 for Saurashtra but couldn't prevent Orissa making a matchwinning 372 in their first innings; opener Shiv Das struck 101. Saurashtra got to 238 in reply, but made a hash of chasing 316 to win, stumbling to 106 all out, with Debashish Mohanty (two Test caps) picked up 5-28, and Sanjay Satpathy 5-65 with his off-breaks.

Orissa 372 and 181
Saurashtra 238 (Hitesh Parsana 76, Manoj Parmar 71*) and 106
Orissa won by 209 runs

South Africa

Gauteng sneaked to a two-wicket victory over Griqualand West in the latest round of the one-day Standard Bank Trophy. Set 147 to win, Gauteng got into trouble against West Indian Otis Gibson (3-29) but scraped home with a ball to spare. Griquas had been restricted to 146 for 9, as Derek Crookes took 3-25. Gauteng moved third.

Griqualand West 146 for 9 in 45 overs
Gauteng 147 for 8 in 44.5 overs
Gauteng won by 2 wickets

An opening stand of 125 between Peterus Botha and Kreusch laid the foundations for a rare Border win, over KwaZulu-Natal. Botha hit 55 and Kreusch 59 as Border, one place off the bottom of the 11-team league, registered 221 for 7. Natal lost regular wickets in reply, and when John Kent was eighth out for 71 with the score on 167, the game was all but over.

Border 221 for 7 in 45 overs
KwaZulu-Natal 204 in 42.3 overs
Border won by 17 runs

The other match played on Sunday was ruined by the rain, with North West batting for just 10.2 overs of their reply against Free State.

Free State 194 for 9 in 45 overs
North West 26 for 0 in 10.2 overs
Match abandoned

Phil Simmons inspired Easterns to victory over Griqualand West at Kimberley and first place in the table in the round of matches played last Friday. Simmons hit 52* to accompany Derek Brand's 81 as Easterns scored 233 for 3, and then picked up 2-37 as Griquas crumbled to 149. Mark Conyers claimed 2-28 to go with the 55 he made earlier.

Easterns 233 for 3 in 45 overs
Griqualand West 149 in 40.4 overs
Easterns won by 84 runs

Henry Williams, who made his international debut for South Africa in the recent triangular tournament, had figures of 3-24, but his Boland side missed the chance to go top after going down to a 51-run defeat against Boland at Centurion. Former Surrey overseas player Rudi Bryson took 3-33 to help humble Boland for 125.

Northerns 176 for 8 in 45 overs
Boland 125 in 38.2 overs
Northerns won by 51 runs

webTitle: Big idiots, Big defender and Big trouble

fields.headline: Big idiots, Big defender and Big trouble
fields.trailText: BIG CUP, BAD BEHAVIOUR
fields.body:
BIG CUP, BAD BEHAVIOUR

Not a very nice welcome back for the returning Big Cup. Tonight, Chelsea play Marseille in Group W of Round 27 in the top half of the first sixteenth of the draw, but instead of looking forward to a great game, we have to report the latest bother involving English fans travelling abroad to "support" their team. Bah.

French police have detained seven Chelsea supporters for questioning following an alleged racial assault in Lyon. It has been reported that the fans spent last night in the town before preparing to travel south to Marseille, whose residents are surely hoping for a re-run of those crazy japes some of the more excitable English fans got up to before the Tunisia game during the last World Cup.

Reports suggest four people were first racially abused and then physically attacked in the Lyon metro station. A security person who tried to intervene was also attacked.

BIG CUP SPECIAL

Marseille v Chelsea. It's a European game full of European players. So why not follow a live minute-by-minute match report at that top European web site Football Unlimited? It'll be written entirely in a European language as well (probably English).

TAHAR VERY MUCH

He's only been back in a managerial position for two minutes but he's already decided he needs some more of them players. Yes, the man with the consistent transfer track record (Ruud Gullit, Paul Furlong) is at it again - Southampton boss Glenn Hoddle is about to spend £500,000 on Benfica centre-back Tahar El-Khalej.

Hod has been trying to strengthen the Saints' defence - ie. get someone in who is not Claus Lundekvam - ever since he took over from Dave Jones, but his attempts to buy Colin Hendry, who signed for Coventry, and Alan Stubbs, who did not, ended in failure. As a result, he has turned his attentions to 31-year-old El-Khalej, who eagerly came over to the Dell to spend a week trying to look fancy.

"I expect to sign soon," said the physically imposing Moroccan international today, clearly impressed with his own week's work. "English soccer demands more physical attributes but I do not have any problems in this area," Tahar continued, quietly but firmly, as the Fiver made a mental note not to mess him about in any way.

It's a tactic we advise Saints' chairman Rupert Lowe to use as well. "I do not know where this story came from," Lowe rashly denied. "If the manager decides the player is worth pursuing, then we will take it on from there. However, that has not yet been established." So Rupert, are you going to tell him personally if it all falls through, then?

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"In some of those penalty shoot-outs between England and Germany over the years it has been difficult to keep the score. I think Franz must have forgotten the World Cup score too. He must have forgotten that Germany last staged the World Cup eight years after England. If the World Cup comes to Europe in 2006, it's clearly England's turn." - Bobby Charlton misjudges the length of one of those new-fangled soundbites, bless him.

SLAP UNHAPPY

Tranmere's very own brawling-scouser-who-is-not-Clint-Hill - John Aldridge - has been charged with misconduct by the FA after another weekend of soccer shame (copyright: the nation's tabloids). Aldo is alleged to have slapped Leicester's Theo Zagorakis for applauding the referee's decision to red card Hill in the annual Leicester Challenge (sponsored by Worthington).

But what other option was open to the manager of a team boasting the most red and yellow cards in the league? A polite "Excuse me, Mr Zagorakis, but your applause is just not cricket" is not really the sort of response we've come to expect from a man who would struggle to get his Mersey tonsils around "calm down, calm down" (or even "keep it short this time, Challinor" come to think of it...).

Even after the match Aldo couldn't quite bring himself to attempt to pronounce Theo's surname. "A certain player," he told the post-match press conference, "was applauding as our player was sent off and that hurt me." Unfortunately for Aldo, a couple of FA jobsworths lurking nearby claim they got a grandstand view of him allegedly giving a hands-on demonstration of just how hurt he was. Wounded Aldo now has 14 days to respond to the charge and request a personal hearing.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Newcastle winger Nolberto Solano has agreed to join Real Madrid for £5m at the end of the season.

Everton are the latest club linked with £3m Arsenal misfit Stephen Hughes.

Benito Carbone will demand £38,000 a week to stay at Aston Villa. Villa would also have to pay Sheffield Wednesday £1m to sign the player permanently.

Newcastle and West Ham are interested in Eintracht Frankfurt winger Marco Gebhardt. The 27-year-old would cost £500,000.

Liverpool are interested in Queen of the South's Scotland under-21 keeper David Mathieson along with midfielder Denis Boyle.

Wigan will sign Bradford midfielder Neil Redfearn on loan later this week.

Jordi Cruyff is discussing a move to Espanyol in the summer.

According to Teamtalk, ex-Wimbledon chairman Sam Hammam has been approached by Swindon and asked to invest in the struggling First Division club.

Leeds are among a host of clubs following the progress of Matlock Town defender James Lukic, the nephew of John.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Dwight Yorke is fit for Manchester United's Big Cup clash with Bordeaux tomorrow at Old Trafford.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match (10pm, 2am)
Sideshow Bob presents some bits and bobs of Marseille v Chelsea, and later on he does it again, with extra time for more bits (but no extra time for more Bob).

Football Extra (3.35am)
At least five goals missed by lazy/inept cameramen - and that's guaranteed!

Channel 4: Football Italia (2am)
Italians quite like it. Italians are quite good at it.

Channel 5: Argentinian Football (4.45am)
Viewing figures should rocket after last week's Wembley wonder show, eh?

Sky Sports 1: Inside Scottish Football (6.30pm, 11pm)
Including Henrik Larsson's magic new leg.

You're On Sky Sports! (10.15pm, 4.15am)
Don't rub against him. He will erode your will to live.

Sky Sports 2: Football Special (8pm, 12midnight)
Something so special that it's a surprise. How dare you accuse us of not having the faintest idea what it is!

Sky One: Dream Team (6.30pm, 11pm)
A bit like Murphy's Mob, but for a more childish audience.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm)
A bit like any other football commentary, but with much more moaning.

webTitle: Many are called but few are chosen for Cayman's World Cup campaign

fields.headline: Many are called but few are chosen for Cayman's World Cup campaign
fields.trailText: Several British players have been left bitterly disappointed because all the vacant places in the Cayman Islands' squad have been filled.
fields.body:
Several British players have been left bitterly disappointed because all the vacant places in the Cayman Islands' squad have been filled.

In a bold attempt to reach the 2002 World Cup finals, the Cayman Islands have taken full advantage of the Fifa-ratified ruling that allows any British player to turn out for any country that operates inside Britain's jurisdiction.

In the hope of attracting the interest of eight players, the Caymans made formal approaches to 24 players - and were astonished to receive 22 positive replies.

"I thought that maybe I would get one out of every three players I approached," said the Cayman Islands Football Association's overseas representative, Barry McIntosh. "I wanted eight men so I contacted 24. I was amazed to receive 22 responses. In the end I had to disappoint several players."

One of only two players to have declined the offer was the Manchester United defender David May. Of those who have taken up the invitation the most celebrated is arguably Wayne Allison, the captain of Tranmere Rovers.

Allison was scheduled to depart for the tiny crown colony tomorrow after playing for the Worthington Cup finalists in their First Division game at Portsmouth tonight.

Seven other players arrived in the Caymans on Monday and featured in a friendly match against the American club side DC United last night.

Those who have already pulled on the Caymans shirt are Ged Brannan of Motherwell, David Barnett of Lincoln City, Martin O'Connor of Birmingham City, Dwayne Plummer of Bristol City, Barry Hayles of Fulham, Neville Roach of Southend United and Neil Sharpe of Boreham Wood.

All eight players are expected to play in Sunday's World Cup qualifying fixture against Cuba in Havana, the first of 22 games that the Caymans will have to negotiate if they are to realise their dream of matching Jamaica's achievement and appearing on world football's biggest stage.

Several of the players' club managers are known to be angry at the prospect of losing key personnel at such a crucial point in the season. But the Cayman Islands yesterday launched a stout defence of their recruitment policy.

"These players have agreed to join up with us not for the money but simply because they wish to play international football," said McIntosh. "They will not be earning anything like the sort of money which some people have been suggesting; to say they will pick up £70,000 if they were to reach the finals is ridiculous.

"We are doing nothing wrong and, perhaps most importantly, we are doing nothing new. The United States has taken players from Puerto Rico under the same system, as has Jamaica from England.

"The Cayman Islands is a British dependency. We use the same passports; we have the Queen's face on our currency. When you have something new in life it does take time for people to appreciate what the benefits can be."

The Tranmere manager John Aldridge, who will lose Allison for games against Blackburn on Saturday and West Bromwich next Tuesday, was rather less enthusiastic.

"It really is far from ideal but you cannot stand in the way of a player progressing to the international stage," he said.

The general secretary of the Cayman Islands FA, Costas Takkas, insisted that the players should not be condemned as sporting mercenaries.

"We are looking to build a Cayman Islands team in its own right, not a second England side," he said. "These players have been very warmly welcomed; the local public is very excited by the idea."

webTitle: Prince to see Trench Town poverty

fields.headline: Prince to see Trench Town poverty
fields.trailText:
From the Iwokrama rainforest in Guyana to the
foothills of the Blue Mountains in Jamaica, Prince
Charles has visited some of the most spectacular
corners of the Commonwealth during his Caribbean tour.
fields.body:
From the Iwokrama rainforest in Guyana to the foothills of the Blue Mountains in Jamaica, Prince Charles has visited some of the most spectacular corners of the Commonwealth during his Caribbean tour.

Today, however, he has left behind rural tranquility for the urban grit of downtown Kingston, to experience for himself the poverty and deprivation of the Trench Town streets as chronicled in Bob Marley classics such as No Woman, No Cry.

It is from these close-knit communities that the reputation of Jamaica as a haven of international drug crime and gun running has emerged. Here, families are crowded in to tiny shacks, grouped around the yards that give their name to the Caribbean gangs operating in Britain.

But these 'Yardies' are far from the gun-toting drug rivals of London. While crime rates are high and the threat of violence is never far from the surface, these are ordinary people fighting against the ravages of hunger and poverty.

The Trench Town community is highly sensitive to its portrayal abroad. It believes that the yardie label is an unfair slur concocted by the elements of the British media, which distorts the reality of their lives. They have been concerned about the effects of the prince's entourage descending upon them, so while Prince Charles will see a yard for himself, residents have resolutely refused to admit the media.

Indeed, royal aides are so nervous about the visit that they have refused even to identify the location of the yard to be visited by the prince. They are particularly worried about the size of his entourage: local protocol has dictated that he be accompanied by a gaggle of minor public officials.

Today's visit to Trench Town allows the prince to see the difficulties faced by many in Jamaica, but he was confronted with social problems of a different kind when he toured the rainforest regions deep in the interior of Guyana. At the weekend, the prince was taken to the Kaieteur Falls - the biggest waterfalls in the world. At the moment, it is a part of the planet known only to locals and the most hardened of eco-tourists, and Guyana's native population is deeply worried about the encroachment of the 21st century.

After he had a few private moments taking in the spectacular view, he met a group of native Amerindians who had travelled for miles to make their concerns known to him. Some told how they had trekked through the rainforest for three days and canoed for nine hours to reach this remote point. Around 20 of them lined up at the airstrip by the falls - the only connection between here and the outside world - holding banners bearing messages of welcome.

As he chatted to the Amerindians, the prince thanked them for travelling so far. But as he moved away to his plane, they turned their banners around. New slogans showed the Amerindians' anger at what they see as the Guyanese government's failure to honour promises about land rights and future development.

Social issues have dominated the prince's 10-day tour of Commonwealth territories in the Caribbean. Yesterday, he visited a school in inner Jamaica that is pioneering environmental education among its pupils and their parents. Educational standards in many parts of Jamaica are low, but at Mount Rosser, a dedicated principal has turned his school around, with a curriculum firmly rooted in environmental issues.

He later toured an EU-funded agricultural education project on the other side of the island, and was introduced to a stud-ram whose impressive fertility is such that he has sired 150 offspring. The prince appeared far more concerned with the animal's personal hygiene than his bodily functions: "Goats always smell the same, wherever you are in the world," he said.

fields.headline: Euro sinks to new low
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The European Central Bank will come under increasing pressure to raise interest rates this week after the euro plumbed new lows on foreign exchanges.
fields.body:
The European Central Bank will come under increasing pressure to raise interest rates this week after the euro plumbed new lows on foreign exchanges.

The euro crashed 3.5% in Tokyo on Sunday night to 94 cents (59p) before recovering in European trading to 96.5 cents.

European finance ministers and the head of the ECB, Wim Duisenberg, were tight-lipped yesterday, sticking to the line that the euro would appreciate as growth in the single-currency zone picked up.

But analysts were more wary about the outlook for the single currency. "It may be that the sell-off was overdone but people are still going to be cautious about moving back into [the euro] in a hurry," said Jeremy Hawkins, chief economic adviser at Bank of America in London.

Though there was little news to explain the single currency's latest fall - it has lost around 20% of its value against the dollar since its launch last year - one factor is thought to be a further reaction to better-than-expected US economic figures on Friday.

webTitle: Spreading religious violence leaves 50 dead in Nigeria

fields.headline: Spreading religious violence leaves 50 dead in Nigeria
fields.trailText: At least 50 people were killed in riots in south-east Nigeria yesterday in a reaction to the deaths of hundreds of people in religious bloodshed in northern Nigeria last week, witnesses said.
fields.body:
At least 50 people were killed in riots in south-east Nigeria yesterday in a reaction to the deaths of hundreds of people in religious bloodshed in northern Nigeria last week, witnesses said.

Residents of the southeastern city of Aba said the violence pitted local Christian Ibos against Hausa-speaking immigrants from Muslim northern Nigeria.

"In Aba itself I counted over 50 bodies. Many were burned in the street and angry youths were chanting war songs and dancing round the city," one witness said.

The violence has uncomfortable parallels with the run up to civil war in 1967, when the killing of thousands of Ibos in northern Nigeria and the sub sequent flight of tens of thousands more helped trigger the south-east's bid to secede.

An estimated 1m people died before the breakaway state of Biafra was defeated by forces from the rest of the diverse West African country.

An upsurge of ethnic and religious conflict since President Olusegun Obasanjo took office last May to end 15 years of military rule has again thrown doubt over the future of the country, which, with a population of 108m, is Africa's most populous.

Security forces have been hard pressed to deal with the killings. Residents said the riots were a direct response to the violence in the north, which erupted last Monday at a protest by Christians against Muslim demands for the introduction of Islamic sharia law in the state of Kaduna.

"There was a meeting last night among the traders and it was said that Ibo traders were killed in the Kaduna riots. So this morning they summoned the Hausa community to leave the city, saying that they could not guarantee their safety," one southeastern resident said.

Rumours of deaths in Aba triggered panic in the north's biggest city, Kano, where there is a large Ibo community. Shops and markets closed and residents said hundreds of southerners took refuge in military barracks.

Roman Catholic bishops warned yesterday that Nigeria was headed for "national suicide" over the introduction of sharia law by several northern states and called on the government to act quickly to stop it. - Reuters
