fields.headline: Multicultural reading
fields.trailText: Prompted by the disturbing evidence on racism in our society that followed the Stephen Lawrence enquiry, Books for Keeps has produced a third edition of its invaluable guide to multicultural books.
fields.body:
Prompted by the disturbing evidence on racism in our society that followed the Stephen Lawrence enquiry, Books for Keeps has produced a third edition of its invaluable guide to multicultural books.

"In our age of exile, migration, dispossession and global travel, our children cross borders every day, even if it is only from the safety of television screens or the pages of the books they read," says editor Rosemary Stones.

New categories include the excellent 16-plus list of fiction, biography and poetry, including authors such as Jackie Kay, Ben Okri and Hanif Kureishi, and a non-fiction section on Racism, Rights and Self-Esteem.

Multicultural publishing is changing constantly. In 1984, books were deemed multicultural for including a non-white child; now they stress cultural diversity. Among picture books, the heroine of Mary Hoffman's Amazing Grace (£14.99) wants to play Peter Pan in the school panto - to the consternation of her classmates. A black girl as Peter Pan? With encouragement from mother and grandmother, Grace gets the part - Caroline Binch's delightful illustrations show her playing Joan of Arc, Dick Whittington and Mowgli.

In Sarah Hayes's Eat Up, Gemma (£4.99), the little girl in a black family will do anything with her food except eat it, until her brother takes a hand. An increasing number of picture books show foreign settings such as Niki Daly's The Boy on the Beach (£9.99), a lively tale about a South African family outing with a post-apartheid air of freedom about it, or Caroline Pitcher's The Time of the Lion (£5.99) in which an east African village boy develops a close relationship with a lion.

Books like these give very young readers an awareness that there is a world outside their own where children live very different kinds of lives. The enormous number of beautifully illustrated retellings of myths and folk tales also offer an introduction to diverse cultural background.

In fiction, multiculturalism is developing more slowly. Non-white characters are rarely shown on book jackets (hence the delighted support given to Malorie Blackman's Pig-Heart Boy ages 10-12, £3.99 by many of the children "shadowing" the 1997 Carnegie Medal). Cameron, a black boy, will die without a transplant but the offer of a pig's heart from a pioneering doctor throws his family into turmoil.

And, while there are now novels with any number of different family backgrounds, such as Ann Strugnell's The Julian Stories (ages 5-8, £3.99) and Gene Kemp's The Hairy Hands (ages 10-12, £4.99), there are still few stories for any age group that reflect the multicultural realities made clear after the Stephen Lawrence enquiry.

As with picture books, the most exciting development in fiction is the dramatic increase in books with contemporary foreign settings such as Indonesian-occupied East Timor in James Watson's Justice of the Dagger (£4.99). Muyu, the son of a chief, and Lyana, the survivor of a massacre, endure nights of terror against a background of violence in this story for teenagers. Elizabeth Laird's Kiss the Dust (also for ages 12-16, £5.99) follows a Kurdish family forced to flee Iraq to Iran and then Britain.

 A Multicultural Guide to Children's Books 0-16+ , at £7.50, is available directly from Books for Keeps. Tel: 0181-852 4953. Fax: 0181-3187580. Email: booksforkeeps@btinternet.com

fields.headline: Livingstone bid in balance
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone's long-awaited bid to stand as an independent in London's mayoral elections hung in the balance last night after a two-hour meeting with John Prescott produced an unexpected joint statement saying the pair had had a "very comradely discussion".
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone's long-awaited bid to stand as an independent in London's mayoral elections hung in the balance last night after a two-hour meeting with John Prescott produced an unexpected joint statement saying the pair had had a "very comradely discussion".

Both sides refused to elaborate on what had taken place at the House of Commons encounter, which had been trailed as marking a final parting of the ways between the former Greater London council leader and the Labour leadership.

But the uncertain outcome of the talks between the deputy prime minister and the Brent East MP raised speculation about a possible accom modation in Labour's mayoral crisis, after a day in which the two camps had manoeuvred to blame the other for the anticipated failure of the meeting.

A senior Labour spokesman earlier revealed that the party hierarchy had now all but given up on any prospect of reconciliation and "assumed" that Mr Livingstone would declare his candidacy later this week.

Mr Livingstone, meanwhile, said he wanted to use the meeting to "do everything in my power to avoid my party finding itself in confrontation with the wishes of the great majority of Londoners" over its plans to part-privatise the tube system.

He added that he wanted to allow Londoners to "vote for the candidate and the policy backed by the majority of Labour members". Labour's Millbank headquarters had insisted there would be no horse-trading with the MP at the meeting, where Labour's general secretary and Mr Livingstone's adviser Simon Fletcher were also present.

"Last week we were happy to be conciliatory, but now the mood has changed," Labour's spokesman said. "There can be no question of asking Frank Dobson to stand down, or of ripping up plans for the tube. Our intelligence is that he is likely to announce he will run, on Wednesday or Thursday. If he does stand as an independent, we're going to hit him hard. The campaign will be tough and unrelenting."

webTitle: Baby tested for CJD link to mother

fields.headline: Baby tested for CJD link to mother
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: An investigation was under way yesterday into the possibility that a baby girl may have contracted the human form of mad cow disease from her mother.
fields.body:
An investigation was under way yesterday into the possibility that a baby girl may have contracted the human form of mad cow disease from her mother.

A department of health spokesman confirmed that tests were being carried out and that the possibility of maternal transmission of new-variant CJD was being investigated.

It is understood the baby girl, who has been ill since birth last year, is being treated in a Midlands hospital with her mother, who has been confirmed as suffering from new-variant CJD.

The passing of new-variant CJD from mother to baby was previously thought to be very unlikely.

The spokesman said: "We understand that all the necessary investigations are under way by the NHS trust involved and the appropriate specialists."

It was reported late last month that a 24-year-old mother of a young baby was in a serious condition in Walsgrave hospital, Coventry, suffering from a suspected case of new variant CJD.

The hospital added that the woman's daughter, aged three months at the time, was also seriously ill, but that it was not thought the child had the same illness.

Hospital staff would not comment yesterday on whether the cases were linked.

webTitle: £400 carrot to help unemployed into work

fields.headline: £400 carrot to help unemployed into work
fields.trailText: Grants of up to £400 are to be offered to about 250,000 unemployed people in an attempt to lure them back into work, in plans expected to be announced in next month's budget.
fields.body:
Grants of up to £400 are to be offered to about 250,000 unemployed people in an attempt to lure them back into work, in plans expected to be announced in next month's budget.

The "employment grants", proposed by chancellor Gordon Brown, will give lump sum payments to those who have been out of work for more than 12 months.

Payments of between £300 and £400 will help provide a "bridge" to cover living costs between people losing their social security benefits and re ceiving their pay packets. Though bound by pre-budget purdah, Mr Brown will today indicate where he is heading in a speech in Newham, east London.

"Our programme is about getting unemployed people into businesses, not into benefit offices. It is not about dependence, it is about dynamism. It is not about subsidies, it is about success. It is a 'get up and go' approach, not a Giro approach."

Mr Brown's move is designed to extend the government's carrot-and-stick approach to unemployment benefits.

fields.headline: Haider quits as party chief
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Jörg Haider, whose rise to power put Austria in turmoil, last night resigned as leader of the country's far-right Freedom party at its leadership meeting.
fields.body:
Jörg Haider, whose rise to power put Austria in turmoil, last night resigned as leader of the country's far-right Freedom party at its leadership meeting.

The move was seen as an attempt to take the heat off the controversial new coalition government, which has attracted international opprobrium and large demonstrations at home. Mr Haider told the party leadership meeting that he was stepping down because he did not want "to stand in the way" of the work of the new government.

The newspaper Die Presse said that Mr Haider's decision could be a shrewd tactical move that would enable him to distance himself from unpopular government decisions such as tax increases and to position himself for the next election.

The 50-year-old populist told the magazine Format in an interview published yesterday that he still aimed to become chancellor. "That has become even more probable," he said. The 14 other EU members have downgraded relations with Austria because of the presence of Mr Haider's party in the government. The resignation is also thought to give him more freedom to remake his tainted image.

Mr Haider, who gained notoriety in the past for pro-Nazi remarks, was not a member of the federal government and remains governor of the southern province of Carinthia. He had been portrayed as the puppet master of the new administration, despite his promises that he would not interfere in its work.

Speaking to reporters before the meeting yesterday, Peter Sichrovsky, the Freedom party's EU representative, said Mr Haider had mentioned stepping down at the weekend. His resignation is being viewed as a bizarre turn of events, considering the huge political gains Mr Haider made in October election.

It is thought that Mr Haider could remain in charge of the party as its spiritual leader. As provincial leader, he would have more room to prepare for his life-long ambition to become chancellor.

Another reason thought to have spurred Mr Haider's resignation was wages. Five years ago, Freedom party members signed a contract with the Austrian state saying that if they came into government, they would claim a maximum monthly salary of 60,000 Schillings (about £2,700). But since entering government, its cabinet members have said they wish to be exempt from the pledge. In fact the justice minister, Michael Kruger, has said he wanted to have a Jaguar instead of a BMW, which is the car usually given to cabinet ministers.

Mr Haider was highly critical of the threats to backtrack, saying that it would go against the spirit for which the Freedom party stands. The issue was said to be at the top of the agenda at last night's party meeting. Other political insiders indicated that Mr Haider's resignation may be a panic reaction to allegations within the party that he is a homosexual, which he has denied.

The leader of the opposition Social Democratic party, Alfred Gusenbauer, described the resignation as "one of Haider's many tactical feints". In the early 90s he resigned as governor of Carinthia after making comments praising Hitler 's unemployment policies and made a dramatic comeback a year ago.

Fall, rise and retreat of a maverick

1991 Resigns as governor of Carinthia after controversial remarks praising employment policies of Hitler. Claims it was a smear campaign by opponents

Mid-90s His attendance at a meeting of Waffen SS veterans is revealed

1999 Makes dramatic comeback when he is re-elected governor. He is seen to be using the regional post as a stepping stone to national government

October His party makes dramatic gains and takes 27% of vote in national elections, breaking consensus politics for first time in 50 years. In the campaign the slogan Überfremdung (over- foreignisation) was used, a phrase used by Nazi propaganda minister Josef Goebbels

January 2000 Talks between People's party and Social Democrats break down. Haider and People's party begin negotiations

February Agreement signed

Haider expresses anger at criticism from the EU, saying: 'The fox has not even entered the chicken pen yet.'

He criticises Brussels as a land of paedophiles, and the French prime minister, Jacques Chirac, for his 'mistakes'

In a surprise move he steps down, but is tipped to make a rapid comeback to fulfil his chancellorship dream

webTitle: 17 dogs and a cat ride into history

fields.headline: 17 dogs and a cat ride into history
fields.standfirst: Campaigners celebrate as first 'pet passport' passengers arrive in Britain
fields.trailText: Digby, a two-year-old Polish lowland shepherd dog, is clearly in an uncertain mood as he waits at Calais to become one of the first dogs to enter Britain for almost a century without undergoing quarantine.
fields.body:
Digby, a two-year-old Polish lowland shepherd dog, is clearly in an uncertain mood as he waits at Calais to become one of the first dogs to enter Britain for almost a century without undergoing quarantine.

"Don't worry," smiles Carolyn Menteith fixedly, as she stuffs him with biscuits to mollify him. He drools; the smile becomes more rigid. "He's just a little over-excited."

But if Digby is salivating, it is as nothing compared to the reaction of the posse of dog lovers who have campaigned for some six years for this moment: the introduction of pet passports and the relaxation of Britain's strict quarantine rules.

As they wait to board the first pet train - a Eurotunnel Shuttle carrying 17 dogs and one cat - there is an almost-tangible sense of triumphalism among the campaigners, for whom the £200 cost and lengthy bureaucratic process involved in proving their animals are rabies-free has been well worth it.

"This is a historic day," cries Lady Fretwell, the formidable force behind the pressure group Passports for Pets, as she hugs the pet-loving Tory MP Roger Gale and Dennis, her daughter's chocolate labrador.

"I just say: Thank God the United Kingdom has moved with modern science and we now have a system worthy of our country."

And how will she be celebrating? "I shouldn't really say this," she confides from beneath her Passports for Pets baseball cap. "But I was pissed once when I was 21 and I should think I might be again tonight."

For Lady Fretwell, a former ambassador's wife who formed the group after her bassett hound Bertie died six months after quarantine, yesterday's change in the rules will mean she can take his replacement, Claude, to the family's house in Normandy. But for many of her supporters the effect will be more profound.

Bill Whitehouse, a 31-year-old telecoms manager, will be able to end a peripatetic European lifestyle - prompted by his refusal to put Ximo, a five-year-old Rhodesian ridgeback he bought while working in Majorca, into quarantine - and join his wife Lynn and 18-month-old daughter Holly, at home in Solihull

Corporal Colin Binge, of the Queen's Royal Hussars, and his wife Nicola, were yesterday able to move from their home in Germany to Tidworth, Hampshire, without leaving behind their 13-year-old munsterlander, Ivan.

But perhaps the greatest benefit will be felt by the likes of Professor Rodney Harris, a retired and profoundly deaf medical geneticist who yesterday made the historic crossing with his 10-year-old hearing dog Jodie.

He has previously felt very isolated on his trips to Europe where he lectures regularly. "When I stay in hotels she's my ear for things like the alarm clock, telephone and fire alarm. Besides, she's normally with me 24 hours a day - and it's a real wrench to be separated from her."

The pet travel scheme - currently being piloted by the Shuttle and five ferry companies - is cumbersome at present, involving each pet being fitted with an identification microchip, vaccinated against rabies and blood-tested before being issued with a "passport".

Six months later, they can travel but must be treated by a vet for ticks and worms before they enter the UK.

"This is a momentous occasion," proclaimed Lady Fret-well, as the dogs arrived on British soil.

"To me, it's a miracle. My dog is getting in the car and coming home with me - and that's as it should be."

webTitle: World greets Haider resignation with caution

fields.headline: World greets Haider resignation with caution
fields.trailText: Governments around the world reacted with a mixture of caution and scepticism today to the resignation of Jörg Haider as leader of the far-right Freedom party in Austria.
fields.body:
Governments around the world reacted with a mixture of caution and scepticism today to the resignation of Jörg Haider as leader of the far-right Freedom party in Austria.

In London, a foreign office spokesman said: "We will continue to watch the actions and statements of the new Austrian government and will be assessing the reasons for Haider's resignation. We need to know the full facts."

Simon Murphy, leader of the Labour group of Euro MPs, said he did not believe that last night's announcement by Mr Haider meant that he was bowing out of politics, or ceasing to be an influential figure in the Freedom party.

"He's not going to go away and clearly we have to keep monitoring the situation," cautioned Mr Murphy. "The head may have gone but clearly there are still extreme right-wing hearts beating in the Austrian government. Noting that several of Mr Haider's colleagues still had their ministerial portfolios, Mr Murphy said: "They really are much the same as Haider. One or two may be even more extreme than him."

In Austria, most commentators saw Mr Haider's resignation as a tactical ploy in a grand design of eventually becoming chancellor. Die Presse newspaper said Mr Haider's decision was a shrewd move to distance himself from unpopular government decisions such as planned tax increases and to position himself for the next election, due within four years.

Mr Haider, who will remain governor of Carinthia province, said he would remain in politics. "I want to make clear that I am not running away from national politics, just making a new constellation in our party leadership." Asked if he still hoped to be chancellor one day, he replied: "I do not exclude it."

The opposition Social Democrats dismissed the resignation as a sham. "It is quite clear that Haider is only giving up his office but will continue to set the tone," said new Social Democratic leader Alfred Gusenbauer.

Portugal, which currently holds the EU presidency, said it saw no quick restoration of normal links between Austria and its EU partners, which were frozen after a coalition including the Freedom party took power three weeks ago. Antonio Guterres, Portugal's prime minister, said: "For the moment our position remains the same. The key question is not the personality of Haider. It is the nature of the party."

The US said it would continue to keep a close eye on Austria but viewed Mr Haider's resignation as positive if it allowed the Freedom party to work better with its coalition partner.

"We will react swiftly and firmly to any statements or actions suggesting sympathy with Nazi-era policies, or that express racism, xenophobia or anti-semitism," the US state department spokesman, James Rubin, said.

Mr Haider, best-known for controversial remarks playing down the crimes of the Nazis for which he has repeatedly apologised, did not take a post in the Austrian government. But despite pledging not to interfere with its work, Mr Haider constantly courted controversy. He said he held many common positions with Tony Blair, a comparison that infuriated Downing Street.

Mr Haider strongly criticised foreign governments and described the euro as a "miscarriage". He had nearly tripled his party's share of the vote since becoming leader in 1986 by campaigning against immigration, the "cronyism" of the established parties and pledging to put Austria's interests first.

The Freedom party won 27% of the vote in the October 3 election, edging ahead of the People's party to come second behind the Social Democrats. Recent opinion polls have suggested the Freedom party could become the largest party in the next election.

fields.headline: Hare today
fields.trailText: Cheshire
fields.body:
Cheshire

For years now the brown hare has suffered a steady decline in numbers, like so much of our wild fauna and flora. Amongst the reasons for this state of affairs has been a loss of living space due to the spread of new housing and industrial developments, and the associated growth of new roads and motorways. Changes in agricultural practices have also probably played a part in this, especially where the use of weedkillers has deprived the hare of many plants needed for a healthy diet. Certainly, in my corner of Cheshire, it is now a rare sight, so to have two in view at the same time was quite an event for the diary. I had chosen one of those days in the past fortnight when it wasn't raining, sleeting or snowing, to walk over the farmland outside the village in the hope of finding some elusive flocks of roosting lapwings or golden plovers, in an area where, in the past as many as 3,000 of these winter visitors would return each year to the same fields. Having walked alongside a mile or so of neatly clipped hawthorn hedgerows, many of which were already sprouting fresh green leaves of spring, and climbed over numerous farm gates, I found a field where a flock of disturbed birds flew up into a group of roadside oak trees. It was a mixed party of winter thrushes - redwings, and chaffinches who had left still more chaffinches feeding amongst the short turf along with some 15 or more meadow pipits. Up to that stage, I had taken what looked like two clumps of soil as part of the scenery, then I detected a slight movement and through the binoculars found a large, staring eye looking straight at me. It was a pair of brown hares hugging the ground with black tipped ears laid flat, and each darktopped tail pressed down into the grass. One stood up and loped unhurriedly to the far corner of the field, showing off the orange tinges of breast and flanks, leaving its mate still lying motionless on the ground. I stood watching them for a while longer, before moving on to continue my search for the lapwings, conscious of the fact that they lived their whole lives in a totally open habitat, where cold and wet weather must have been as much of a challenge to survival as avoiding predators.

webTitle: Black protesters occupy farmland in Zimbabwe

fields.headline: Black protesters occupy farmland in Zimbabwe
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: An organised wave of thousands of black protesters yesterday marched on to 13 white-owned farms across central Zimbabwe, where they built huts and where they intend to remain as squatters until they are allocated land elsewhere.
fields.body:
An organised wave of thousands of black protesters yesterday marched on to 13 white-owned farms across central Zimbabwe, where they built huts and where they intend to remain as squatters until they are allocated land elsewhere.

While peaceful thus far, the incidents follow speeches by President Robert Mugabe, key ministers, and articles in the state-controlled press that claimed the government would be justified in seizing white-owned land.

Mr Mugabe's critics claim that the new wave of squatting is an orchestrated ploy to distract public attention from recent widespread flooding, fuel shortages, and general economic decline.

The squatting began on Sunday in Norton on the outskirts of Harare, where a television crew from the state-run Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation, with prior notice of the squatters' plans, was able to film hundreds cheering and singing as they marched on to the farm.

"We fought for the land and would therefore like to warn those that might be thinking of fighting us off the land that we trained to be soldiers, and are still soldiers," said Joseph Chinotimba, a spokesman for the squatters who is also treasurer of the War Veterans Association. "Our tractors are moving on to the farm to prepare land for our people and we will not like to hear that any of our comrades has been moved."

He said the war veterans were angered by the recent rejection of a constitutional draft which would have authorised the government to seize white-owned farms without paying compensation. He warned white farmers to "cooperate or risk losing all their land".

For 20 years, Mr Mugabe has promised to give poor black peasants the white-owned farms, but his government has not delivered. Instead, many farms purchased for resettlement were turned over to cabinet ministers, generals and others with connections to the ruling Zanu-PF party.

Mr Mugabe tried to sell his constitutional draft by promising it would help him seize land to redistribute to poor peasants. With parliamentary elections due in April, Mr Mugabe intensified focus on the land issue in the hope that it will restore his party's flagging popularity.

fields.headline: WapWorld
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Life has become an awful lot easier for Naoyuki Hanyu since he signed up to the world's most advanced wireless internet service.
fields.body:
Life has become an awful lot easier for Naoyuki Hanyu since he signed up to the world's most advanced wireless internet service.

As translator and personal assistant to Steve Perryman, manager of one of Japan's top football teams, Mr Hanyu often has to look up English words, sterling-yen exchange rates and premier league football scores.

In the past that meant going to an office and using a PC to surf the web. But now with his i-mode cellphone, he is online 24 hours a day regardless of whether he is out on the training ground, in a press conference or at a pub.

"It's great for work," he said holding up the tiny 90-gram phone. "And I'm also just a few clicks away from travel information, weather forecasts and restaurant guides."

Half a million people are signing up to the i-mode service every month. In Europe, such Wap [wireless access protocol] services are in their infancy but they are well established in Japan. By the end of March there will be more than 5m subscribers, making it the most popular internet access platform in Japan. By the end of next year, that figure is expected to hit 20m, which would put i-mode on a par with AOL as the world's number one provider.

This has meant a bonanza for NTT Docomo, which created i-mode. Docomo's stock price has more than tripled in the past six months, making it one of the most valuable cellphone companies in the world.

With vast funds and a headstart in getting its service operational, Docomo is preparing to enter Europe and the United States, where it will take on Vodafone, BT and other large telecommunications groups. Like the web in its infancy, the existing service is exciting but far from perfect. Users are continuously connected, paying not for time but for the data they transmit. Sending an e-mail of 250 characters costs about 3p. Receiving it is half that price.

About 5,000 websites have been formatted for Wap use but many others cannot be downloaded on to mobile phone screens. At present users can only send and receive clear images if they buy an extra attachment.

Even so, Docomo is far ahead of its rivals and next year it will be the first to introduce the next generation of mobile internet services, which will offer connection speeds of 300kbps. By 2003, the company predicts that it will be able to provide broad-band transmissions at speeds about 40 times faster than existing modems.

Mr Hanyu will then be able to use his cellphone to watch live football broadcasts and do transfer deals by video conferencing. What will happen to his office PC is another question.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
Nicholas Tresilian celebrates the first centennial Leap Day in history by devoting the Evening Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM) to composers now remembered only as one-hit wonders. Allegri's Miserere might still be heard only within the Vatican had Mozart not secretly transcribed it. Paul Dukas hated all his output except The Sorceror's Apprentice. And whoever hears anything of Litolff's but his fourth piano concerto?

A Scottish psychologist, Dr David Weeks, has developed the idea of what he calls the Superyoung, whose outlook and energy belie their obviously advancing years. Barbara Myers (pictured) investigates the concept in The Ageing Game (9.0pm, Radio 4). Among her interviewees is the American heart surgeon Michael Debakey, now 88 years old and still wielding a wicked scalpel. The secret apparently lies not only in the genes but in the lifestyle - including an energetic and varied range of sexual encounters.

The secret apparently lies not only in the genes but in the lifestyle - including an energetic and varied range of sexual encounters.

fields.headline: Exchange expands despite £14m loss
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Exchange Holdings, the online financial information company, yesterday attempted to deflect attention from plunging pre-tax losses by announcing its first European acquisition and plans to spend millions on rebranding itself.
fields.body:
Exchange Holdings, the online financial information company, yesterday attempted to deflect attention from plunging pre-tax losses by announcing its first European acquisition and plans to spend millions on rebranding itself.

The company, which floated in August last year, reported an operating loss of £14m compared with a loss of £2m in 1998. Chairman Jan Loeber said this reflected "increased investment in product, service, people and brand to fuel the future growth of the business". Turnover rose 8% to £18m.

Exchange Holdings runs Moneyextra, one of the leading personal finance websites, which allows people to compare mortgages, savings accounts, loans and other products, and to monitor their investment portfolios.

After snapping up a number of other UK websites, including Moneyworld, Exchange yesterday took its first step abroad. It is buying Swedish online investment fund supermarket Fondex for an initial £21.65m, and said the deal "will be shortly followed by other announcements in Germany and Spain".

The company is to change its name to Moneyextra and plans to spend £18m on building up the brand this year. It intends to expand the main website to include an online home-buying centre, and comparative motor, home and travel insurance services.

Moneyextra and Moneyworld notched up almost 18m page views in January compared with 6.7m in September.

fields.headline: Volvo goes e-mobile with WirelessCar
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Three Swedish companies yesterday announced plans to bring the motor car into the internet age.
fields.body:
Three Swedish companies yesterday announced plans to bring the motor car into the internet age.

Telecommunications equipment maker Ericsson, truck and bus manufacturer Volvo and telecommunications services provider Telia are setting up WirelessCar which will offer mobile e-services ranging from roadside and emergency assistance to internet access for vehicle manufacturers and fleet operators. Drivers will be able to get expert analysis of faults from a remote diagnostics facility.

The companies have not given details of how much they plan to invest in WirelessCar. Initially they will be equal partners but expect to recruit other companies in the future. "So far advanced mobile e-services have been mere visions. WirelessCar will make them come true," president of the new venture, Jan Hellaker, said.

Jöran Hoff, vice president and general manager for new and special business operations at Ericsson, said WirelessCar was "a natural extension of our vision of anywhere, anytime communications".

Ericsson is involved in a similar link-up with Electrolux and telecoms provider TeleDanmark to bring the internet into the domestic appliance market aiming at creating "the networked home" - where the fridge could keep track of the number of eggs being used and provide advanced warnings of impending break-down.

webTitle: Smith tells BBC to show fewer repeats

fields.headline: Smith tells BBC to show fewer repeats
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC was urged yesterday by the culture secretary, Chris Smith, to spend some of its extra licence fee money on cutting the number of repeats it broacasts.
fields.body:
The BBC was urged yesterday by the culture secretary, Chris Smith, to spend some of its extra licence fee money on cutting the number of repeats it broacasts.

That was one of the improvements expected from promised annual licence fee rises of 1.5% over inflation, Mr Smith told the Commons.

"The measures that we have put in place over the course of the next six to seven years will provide the BBC with a modest and regular increase in their funding in order to enable them to maintain and improve on their position as our premier public service broadcaster," he said.

"That is one of the reasons why I am encouraging the BBC, for example, to ensure they make more new programmes and broadcast fewer repeats."

The request chimes with comments made by the BBC chairman, Sir Christopher Bland, when welcoming the government's licence fee announcement last week.

A BBC spokeswoman said the corporation's target was that 80% of programmes in peak time - 6pm to 10.30pm - would be original. Last year its main channels achieved this level 84% of the time and the BBC was always trying to increase that number.

"However, we have found a big appetite amongst our audience to have the chance to see our programmes again," she said, citing the popularity of the Sunday EastEnders omnibus and episodes of ongoing drama serials often repeated in the same week.

"The idea of all repeats being of necessity bad is something I want to get away from."

Repeats of popular sitcoms like One Foot in the Grave can scoop 10m viewers.

But the BBC has been criticised for showing a plethora of repeats on its new digital channel, BBC Choice, and is frequently attacked for the number of summer repeats.

Yesterday Mr Smith confirmed that pensioners over 75 would be able to get their free licences from November 1 this year. Eligible pensioners with a licence that expired after that date would be able to claim a partial refund.

webTitle: Take your partners for a dance to the music of whines

fields.headline: Take your partners for a dance to the music of whines
fields.trailText: What kind of mad world are MPs living in? Mr Tony McWalter asked a question at culture questions yesterday about training qualifications for people who teach dancing.
fields.body:
What kind of mad world are MPs living in? Mr Tony McWalter asked a question at culture questions yesterday about training qualifications for people who teach dancing.

"Dance is a hybrid activity," mused Mr McWalter, "sport at one end, and art at the other."

What could he mean? Do lovers of the terpsichorean arts discuss this kind of thing over caffé lattés? "Darcey's arty end is just divine," they say, "but her sporty end, well frankly, it's more Paul Gascoigne than John Curry ..."

I suspect that this is just another example of the drivelly jargon which government produces. Mr McWalter may have meant that, being both sporty and arty, dance doesn't qualify for handouts. Increasingly, question time consists of people who can talk the talk speaking to others who also know the patter.

For instance, the minister, Alan Howarth, replied: "Emma Goldman said to Lenin: 'If I can't dance, I don't want to be part of your revolution' - that is some thing New Labour should bear in mind." (Emma Goldman, the New York anarchist, was deported to the Soviet Union in 1919. No doubt it was the fact that Lenin preferred his artistes dancing on the end of a rope that brought about her final disillusion with the Soviet system.)

"Dance," continued Mr Howarth, "is the one field which I would most regret being heavily regulated by the state."

The notion of dance, that most ethereal expression of the human spirit, being heavily regulated by anyone was deeply depressing. But at least Mr Howarth means well. He is becoming Brian Sewell without the camp, Dale Winton with brains. At one point, asked about returning looted Nazi art treasures, he said he would refer this matter to "historians, aesthecists and art experts," causing the Tories to mock his use of the word "aesthecists" (try saying it) with so much sibilant hissing that they sounded like a a colony of bats bedding down for the day.

There were so many small mysteries. John Greenway now speaks for the Tories on culture. Kate Hoey, the sports minister, welcomed him yesterday by saying: "I know he and I have some things in common, which I won't go into at this stage."

What? we asked ourselves. Football? Fox-hunting? Surely they don't have a love-child, but then these days, who would be surprised? The culture ministers are coming to resemble the Spice Girls, each with their own soubriquet. Kate is Sporty Spice, Alan is Aesthecist Spice, and Janet Anderson is Yob Spice. Defending the Dome, she quoted a young person from Gwynedd, who, she said, had been "gobsmacked by the Dome". She quoted him in full. "I am gobsmacked. It absolutely blew me away." I cannot imagine the first arts minister, Jennie Lee, declaring: "People will leave the National Theatre gob-smacked. They will be blown away."

The new Plaid Cymru MP for Ceredigion, Simon Thomas, proved again my axiom - you can never trust anyone called Simon - when he too whinged about the Dome. He could find no evidence that anyone in Wales had ever bought a ticket (what, not one of the 870,000 visitors was Welsh? What a miserable lot they must be.) Furthermore, the loans could wipe out the NHS deficit in Wales.

And, he added in triumph, what were ministers doing to stop Welsh people who did want to visit the Dome "being penalised by distance?"

"Moving Wales to the Isle of Dogs" would have been a good answer to this ludicrous question, but would surely have produced yet more drizzling Cambrian complaint.

webTitle: Men prefer home cures to GP visits

fields.headline: Men prefer home cures to GP visits
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Young men have a cavalier approach to health, with nearly a third of them tolerating symptoms of ailments they consider to be non-serious rather than getting attention, according to a survey published yesterday.
fields.body:
Young men have a cavalier approach to health, with nearly a third of them tolerating symptoms of ailments they consider to be non-serious rather than getting attention, according to a survey published yesterday.

Just 30% of men under 40 would consider visiting a pharmacist for minor complaints, according to research conducted by the Royal Pharmaceutical Society.

More than half of all men questioned, 56%, would attempt to treat the symptoms themselves, with just 5% of under 40s saying they would visit a doctor or practice nurse.

The research revealed a cavalier approach, said Roger Odd, head of professional and scientific support at the RPS.

"The problem stems from the macho self-image many men have. They feel that they can tell why aches and pains have occurred and treat them themselves, but if you don't deal with some problems they can get considerably worse," he said.

"The message is go and see your pharmacist. They are highly trained, fully qualified healthcare professionals. If it's appropriate they will treat you and if it's not they'll send you on to the doctor," he added.

The results are likely to lead to a rethink in the way pharmacies are laid out, with chemists looking to present what Mr Odd described as a "more professional" approach to attract more men. It is thought that a large amount of cosmetics and other beauty products discourages men.

"Traditionally pharmacies are much more womens' shops but they are increasingly much more professional in appearance. Men would far rather go into a technophile shop, so pharmacies are much less showy than they used to be," Mr Odd added.

"There are more pharmacists now with areas dedicated to healthcare where you can sit down and get advice from a man or a woman."

The RPS survey revealed that 73% of men were generally unconcerned about whether the pharmacist was a man or a woman. However, when it came to advice on sexual health 22% of men preferred dealing with a man.

The survey also found that men who visit pharmacies do so because they are more convenient than visiting a doctor during surgery hours.

Some 66% said they visited a pharmacist for this reason, and 85% of those asked said pharmacists were giving a satisfactory service.

The message that the chemist should be a first point of contact for people suffering minor complaints was endorsed by the Royal College of General Practitioners.

"What you've got to remember is that pharmacists and doctors sprang from the same source, the apothecary, who was a doctor who also sold medicines. The fact the two are now split doesn't change the fact the pharmacists are highly skilled," said Catti Moss, a member of the college's patient group.

"Pharmacists are still the people who advise most accurately on medicines. GPs can't prescribe very many symptomatic remedies. That role now falls to the pharmacist in the interests of increasing availability.

"One should trust pharmacists' advice in the areas in which they are expert, and visit a GP when they advise you to do so. It's a very good idea to encourage people to see their pharmacist in the first instance as it will help ease the load on GPs," she said.

fields.headline: Livingstone ready to leap
fields.standfirst:
Labour loses hope of deal with mayoral renegade

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone was last night preparing to take the greatest gamble of his career and announce, possibly on Thursday, that he will stand as an independent in London's mayoral elections.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone was last night preparing to take the greatest gamble of his career and announce, possibly on Thursday, that he will stand as an independent in London's mayoral elections.

A Labour spokesman revealed before a meeting between Mr Livingstone and the deputy prime minister -expected to mark the final parting of the ways with the leadership - that the party hierarchy had now all but given up on a reconciliation with the former greater London council leader. The party "assumes" Mr Livingstone will declare his candidacy later this week.

Both sides had manoeuvred throughout the day to avoid blame for the expected failure of the planned face-to-face encounter between John Prescott and the Brent East MP.

Referring to Labour's controversial tube policy and mayoral selection fiasco, two statements from Mr Livingstone during the day emphasised his wish to use the meeting to "do everything in my power to avoid my party finding itself in confrontation with the wishes of the great majority of Londoners". With regard to his own opposition to plans for partly privatising the tube, he said he wanted to help the party resolve the crisis "by allowing Londoners to vote for the candidate and the policy backed by the majority of Labour members".

However, Downing Street and Labour's Millbank headquarters made clear there would be no horse-trading with the man who won most Labour party and trade union members' votes, but who narrowly lost to Frank Dobson in the electoral college.

"Last week we were happy to be conciliatory, but now the mood has changed," Labour's spokesman said. "There can be no question of asking Frank Dobson to stand down or ripping up plans for the tube. Nor is there any question of allowing him to use the meeting with Mr Prescott as an excuse to walk away from the party.

"If he does stand as an independent, we're going to hit him hard. His private life [is] out, but we will focus on what he has said and done - and the contradictions. We will also highlight the threat he poses to jobs, investment, taxation and debt to London and Londoners, and we'll see what happens to his opinion poll lead. The campaign will be tough and unrelenting".

The Labour machine's new stance, which amounts to a declaration of political war, follows days of communication between Millbank and Mr Livingstone's campaign office, much of it through an intermediary, Anne Harradine, a former Labour agent in Brent East. It is understood that Mr Livingstone and his advisers took the decision in principle yesterday to launch an independent campaign - which would only be reversed if the Labour leadership made a major concession on its plans for the tube.

Despite misgivings from his family and friends about the potential dirtiness of the campaign - and the opposition to a break with the party from leftwing Labour allies - Mr Livingstone has been buoyed by poll findings showing him as the runaway favourite for mayor among Londoners.

Meanwhile, Labour's Lord Whitty told the House of Lords yesterday that he believed there could be compromise over the deadlock on free-mail delivery for London's mayoral election, scheduled for 4 May. The issue, due to be debated tonight, has been a factor in Mr Livingstone's calculations, with fears that the government might use the row to postpone the election date.

fields.headline: Camelot promises the moon
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Camelot yesterday pledged to invest £1bn in technology that will allow people to play the national lottery via the internet, mobile phones and interactive television from 2002 in a final attempt to fend off a Microsoft-backed bid for its licence from Sir Richard Branson.
fields.body:
Camelot yesterday pledged to invest £1bn in technology that will allow people to play the national lottery via the internet, mobile phones and interactive television from 2002 in a final attempt to fend off a Microsoft-backed bid for its licence from Sir Richard Branson.

Camelot has also cut the salaries and bonuses of its directors by a third after heavy criticism for "fat-cat" payments. In an increasingly fraught public-relations war it has even committed to offer a prize of a trip to the moon if its contract is renewed.

A spokesman for the rival People's Lottery spokesman responded to the salary and profit pledges by saying: "Camelot has obviously recognised that people want to see a not-for- profit lottery, it's just a shame they have done it in such a half-hearted way."

Vodafone AirTouch, Nokia, Freeserve, NTL and ICL New Media had agreed to partner Camelot to deliver four new on-line games if the company wins the licence to operate the lottery for the next seven years, said chief executive designate Dianne Thompson.

Most of Camelot's £1bn will be spent on installing new terminals in retailers and branches of the Post Office. Camelot believes it would be able to generate £10bn for good causes by introducing the online games and cutting its profits by half.

Sir Richard, who is expected to unveil final details of his bid shortly before this morning's deadline for submissions, has attracted the support of advertising agency J Walter Thompson, Cisco, Energis, Compaq, KPMG, Kelloggs and US lottery operator AWI to his non-profit-making People's Lottery consortium. He claims his offering will generate £2bn more money for "good causes".

The national lottery commission is expected to announce in June which bidder has won the new licence which takes effect from October 2001.

Ms Thompson, who also has the support of the Post Office, said: "This is a compelling bid to win the next national lottery, based around our investment commitment of £1bn to be spent on technology, terminals, marketing and infrastructure. We want to deliver the best deal for good causes and the best opportunities and most fun for players."

Camelot has made much about its "social responsibility" and is cracking down on retailers who sell tickets to under-16s. Children, who are forbidden from playing by law, will also be prevented from buying tickets through their home computers by new software developed by GTech, which supplies to Camelot.

Freeserve's role will be to secure online sales of lottery tickets to internet users through a co-branded site within Freeserve's portal. Vodafone will initially focus on introducing a short messaging system that will send the winning numbers direct to mobile phone users, while NTL will lead the development of an interactive television gaming service.

Technological innovation has become a central theme of the lottery bid since Sir Richard described Camelot's offering as "stale and boring".

Ms Thompson said 65% of the adult population play the lottery, the highest level in Europe. Watford-based Camelot's shareholders include Cadbury-Schweppes, ICL, Racal and security printer De La Rue.

Vodafone AirTouch, Nokia, Freeserve, NTL and ICL New Media had agreed to partner Camelot to deliver four new on-line games if the company wins the licence to operate the lottery for the next seven years, said chief executive designate Dianne Thompson. Most of Camelot's £1bn will be spent on installing new terminals in retailers and branches of the Post Office. Camelot believes it would be able to generate £10bn for good causes by introducing the online games and cutting its profits by half. Sir Richard, who is expected to unveil final details of his bid shortly before this morning's deadline for submissions, has attracted the support of advertising agency J Walter Thompson, Cisco, Energis, Compaq, KPMG, Kelloggs and US lottery operator AWI to his non-profit-making People's Lottery consortium. He claims his offering will generate £2bn more money for "good causes". The national lottery commission is expected to announce in June which bidder has won the new licence which takes effect from October 2001. Ms Thompson, who also has the support of the Post Office, said: "This is a compelling bid to win the next national lottery, based around our investment commitment of £1bn to be spent on technology, terminals, marketing and infrastructure. We want to deliver the best deal for good causes and the best opportunities and most fun for players." Camelot has made much about its "social responsibility" and is cracking down on retailers who sell tickets to under-16s. Children, who are forbidden from playing by law, will also be prevented from buying tickets through their home computers by new software developed by GTech, which supplies to Camelot. Freeserve's role will be to secure online sales of lottery tickets to internet users through a co-branded site within Freeserve's portal. Vodafone will initially focus on introducing a short messaging system that will send the winning numbers direct to mobile phone users, while NTL will lead the development of an interactive television gaming service. Technological innovation has become a central theme of the lottery bid since Sir Richard described Camelot's offering as "stale and boring". Ms Thompson said 65% of the adult population play the lottery, the highest level in Europe. Watford-based Camelot's shareholders include Cadbury-Schweppes, ICL, Racal and security printer De La Rue.

webTitle: Teacher crisis - half plan to quit in 10 years

fields.headline: Teacher crisis - half plan to quit in 10 years
fields.trailText: Half of England's teachers expect to quit the profession within 10 years, according to a Guardian opinion poll that casts a shadow over Tony Blair's strategy for raising the quality of education.
fields.body:
Half of England's teachers expect to quit the profession within 10 years, according to a Guardian opinion poll that casts a shadow over Tony Blair's strategy for raising the quality of education.

It suggests that more than 200,000 teachers are planning to retire or seek alternative employment, mainly because they cannot stand the heavy workload, stress and bureaucracy that now accompanies a job in the classroom.

With more than 40% of teachers in their forties, and due to retire over the next 10-25 years, ministers were aware of an impending recruitment problem caused by a middle-aged bulge, but the ICM opinion survey commissioned by the Guardian suggests a disturbing level of disaffection among younger teachers. More than a third of those under 35 expect to quit within 10 years and 46% within 15 years.

The survey found the most serious problem was in primary schools which have undergone the biggest reforms during David Blunkett's tenure as education and employment secretary. Among primary staff, 31% do not expect to be teaching in five years, 56% in 10 years and 77% in 15 years.

But pessimism about long-term professional prospects spreads throughout the sector. In secondary schools, 26% do not expect to be in teaching in five years, 51% in 10 years and 71% in 15 years. University lecturers are slightly more inclined than secondary teachers to say they will quit.

Mr Blunkett may take comfort from a parallel ICM poll of parents with children in state education, showing 91% are happy with the quality of their own schools. But he has reason to worry that the mood of despondency among teachers does not look likely to be dispelled by the government's plans to spend £1bn over the next two years on introducing performance-related pay.

Workloads, stress and bureaucracy were the biggest factors in decisions to leave the profession, rather than poor pay, lack of job satisfaction or discipline problems.

When primary teachers were prompted with a list of reasons why they might quit, 75% said heavy workload was "very important", compared with 20% putting the same emphasis on poor pay.

A spokesman for the department for education and employment said comments about quitting in 10 or 15 years were not a reliable guide to eventual behaviour, as the number of teachers leaving the profession was stable and the number of entrants had been rising since 1996.

"Our reform of teachers' pay and proposals for their professional development will transform teaching and make it more attractive than ever."

Doug McAvoy, the general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said ministers should heed the message of the Guardian poll: "For the children's sake, we hope teachers won't leave the profession. But it is a measure of how far the government has ignored teachers' concerns that so many wish to do so."

Nigel de Gruchy, the general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said: "More and more teachers will quit unless the government acts to reduce workload with a contract protecting staff from unlimited hours and ever-increasing demands."

Peter Smith, the general secretary of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers, said: "Ministers have a potential crisis on their hands. Their challenge is to find a way of motivating the generation of teachers needed to replace those who can't wait to retire."

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 505 parents of primary and secondary schoolchildren, 501 primary and secondary schoolteachers and 101 university lecturers drawn from nationally representative samples. All interviews were conducted by telephone between February 8-15 2000.

webTitle: Poet attempts the ultimate in self-invention - patenting her own genes

fields.headline: Poet attempts the ultimate in self-invention - patenting her own genes
fields.standfirst: Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: A poet and casino waitress from Bristol, angered at the mass patenting of human genes by science and big business, is trying to become the first person to patent herself.
fields.body:
A poet and casino waitress from Bristol, angered at the mass patenting of human genes by science and big business, is trying to become the first person to patent herself.

Donna MacLean's application has been given a number - GB0000180.0 - by the patent office. In a letter, officials told Ms MacLean that they would check the legality and originality of the application if she sent them a £130 fee.

To patent an invention, the inventor has to prove it is novel and useful. In her application, Ms MacLean claimed she is both.

"It has taken 30 years of hard labour for me to discover and invent myself, and now I wish to protect my invention from unauthorised exploitation, genetic or otherwise," she wrote.

"I am new: I have led a private existence and I have not made the invention of myself public. I am not obvious."

Ms MacLean said she had many industrial applications. "For example, my genes can be used in medical research to extremely profitable ends," she wrote. "I therefore wish to have sole control of my own genetic material."

Companies and researchers all over the world have patented thousands of human genes under patent legislation which allows naturally occurring substances to be registered as "inventions" by their discov erers. But the latest European patent laws say that life itself, and individual human beings, cannot be patented.

Last week German environmental demonstrators occupied the offices of the European patent office in protest at the granting to Edinburgh university of what they said was a patent allowing the the fabrication of human beings.

Brain Caswell, assistant director of marketing at the UK patent office, would not rule out the possibility that a cunningly-worded patent application for a human being might be acceptable.

British law says a patent cannot be granted "for any variety of animal or plant, or any essentially biological process for the production of animals and plants, not being a microbiological process or the product of such a process".

Mr Caswell pointed out that the law also baldly forbade patenting of computer programmes - and yet by clever wording of patent claims, software did get patent protection.

Ms MacLean clipped four photos of herself and a copy of her passport to her applica tion. "It's quite a nice thing to know it's sitting there on the shelf next to applications for patents for pins and things," she said yesterday.

"There's a kind of unpleasant, grasping, greedy atmosphere at the moment around the mapping of the human genome ... I wanted to see if a human being could protect their own genes in law."

webTitle: Brady begs for the right to die

fields.headline: Brady begs for the right to die
fields.trailText: The Moors murderer Ian Brady arrived at court under armed police guard yesterday to plead with a high court judge for the right to starve himself to death.
fields.body:
The Moors murderer Ian Brady arrived at court under armed police guard yesterday to plead with a high court judge for the right to starve himself to death.

Brady, 62, who started a hunger strike five months ago, was taken from Ashworth hospital in Maghull, Merseyside, to the Queen Elizabeth II court complex in Liverpool city centre, where he entered a courtroom for the first time since his conviction for the sadistic murders of three children nearly 34 years ago.

In a four-day hearing behind closed doors, his lawyers will argue that the hospital has no legal right to force feed him by tube. He began his hunger strike when he was transferred from a relatively relaxed ward to a more secure ward for patients with severe personality disorders.

The thinking behind Brady's death wish emerged in a long letter he sent to the BBC. He expressed envy of his accomplice Myra Hindley, who is suffering from a life-threatening brain condition.

"Myra gets the potentially fatal brain condition, whilst I have to fight simply to die. I have had enough. I want nothing, my objective is to die and release myself from this once and for all," he wrote. "So you see my death strike is rational and pragmatic. I'm only sorry I didn't do it decades ago, and I'm eager to leave this cesspit in a coffin."

A leaked report of an independent investigation into Brady's complaints about his treatment by Professor David Sines of South Bank university in London, links his hunger strike with the way he was transferred to the new ward.

Managers feared he might commit suicide on the more low security ward, and that he might become a target for a sniper because it was on the edge of the hospital.

The report accuses the hospital authorities of mismanaging the transfer. He was marched without warning into the new ward by six members of the hospital's restraint and control team. Two were wearing shields, even though Brady has never been violent to staff.

As a general rule, adults who are capable of taking their own decisions- even those who are mentally ill - cannot lawfully be fed against their will. In 1994 a high court judge ruled that prisoners who were mentally competent were free to starve themselves to death.

But Brady is no longer in the prison system, having been transferred to Ashworth, a secure hospital, in 1985. The appeal court ruled in another case in 1994 case that an adult detained under the mental health act can be force-fed if self-starvation is a consequence or symptom of the mental disorder.

A psychiatrist who was asked by Ashworth for a second opinion said this applied in Brady's case, according to the report, in which Brady is diagnosed as having a psychopathic personality disorder.

But another psychiatrist who examined Brady at his lawyers' request says he is capable of deciding for himself and should be allowed to die.

Brady was jailed for life at Chester Assizes in May 1966 for the murders of Lesley Ann Downey, 10, Edward Evans, 17, and John Kilbride, 12. He later admitted killing Pauline Reade, 16 and Keith Bennett, 12.

His solicitor, Robin Makin, said Brady was very pleased to have reached a court hearing.

Apart from arguing that Brady is capable of deciding for himself, his lawyers are expected to contend that force-feeding him is a breach of his right to a private life under the European convention on human rights.

The judge, Mr Justice Maurice Kay, closed the court at Brady's lawyers' request and said his judgment, not expected this week, will be delivered in public.

In his letter to the BBC, Brady said: "My life is now over and the present hunger-thirst strike of four months duration is to the death. I have not the least interest in being kept artificially alive _ My main objective is to comprehensively expose this regime to public scrutiny and bring the force of law to bear on it."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
Ape-Man 9pm, BBC2
According to scientists, our ape-like ancestors may have evolved because they discovered the advantages of eating meat, which enlarged brain size. Their vegetarian counterparts, meanwhile, eventually became extinct. The information revealed by this absorbing series gives valuable insights into the origins of the human species; the dissatisfaction, however, comes from the special reconstructions which have been filmed through so many filters as to render them more irritating than illuminating. That, and the irritatingly histrionic music, detracts from an otherwise fascinating set of programmes.

Kids Alone 9pm, C4
In the last in the series forming part of C4's Adoption On Trial season, would-be adoptive parents come under scrutiny as they go through the often lengthy process of having their wishes matched to a very needy child. They're asked if they would accept a child with various afflictions or disabilities (strangely, a child with ginger hair falls loosely into these categories), and their struggle to be honest is plain to see. They realise that it's one thing to bear a child who is not "perfect", but to volunteer to adopt one puts them in a quandary.

The Fugitive: The Final Chapter 9.30pm, BBC1
Both David Janssen and Harrison Ford did very well out of playing Richard Kimball, the doctor wrongly accused of murdering his wife. But Hollywood didn't come up with the idea, of course. It was inspired by the case of Dr Sam Sheppard who, in 1954, said an intruder had murdered his wife; but this fell on the deaf ears of a hysterical media, and a judge who allowed the jury to read the press accounts. The film and TV versions of The Fugitive assumed the doctor was innocent; in real life, as usual, it isn't quite as cut and dried. The story has been in the public consciousness for almost half a century and it looks like it will hang around a bit longer, as Sheppard's son is now after damages for wrongful imprisonment.

webTitle: Drive for more NHS nurses launched

fields.headline: Drive for more NHS nurses launched
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The government is to create 1,000 nursing and midwife training places under a nationwide recruitment campaign launched last night as figures showed nurse numbers in the NHS increased by 4,500 last year.
fields.body:
The government is to create 1,000 nursing and midwife training places under a nationwide recruitment campaign launched last night as figures showed nurse numbers in the NHS increased by 4,500 last year.

At the start of a week in which the government will seek to emphasise a commitment to funding and reforming the health service, the health secretary, Alan Milburn, announced that £120m would be spent on funding the extra places and training more doctors, particularly in specialities where there is a recruitment crisis.

The money was being billed as new, but comes from cash already allocated for health under the comprehensive spending review.

The announcement coincided with the early publication of annual census figures showing that the number of nurses working in the NHS increased by 4,500, the equivalent of 3,000 full-time staff, to 304,560 last year.

An extensive recruitment campaign, on which the latest effort will build, has also seen applications for nursing and midwifery training rocket by 79% in 1999. A second campaign began last night with television and press advertising in areas where shortages are at their greatest.

Tony Blair will today highlight investment elsewhere in the NHS when he visits the accident and emergency department at St Thomas's hospital in south London, which was upgraded as part of a £115m nationwide programme of A&E modernisation.

Nurses' leaders last night welcomed the recruitment drive, but stressed any attempt to attract new staff and lure back trained nurses depended on pay and other initiatives such as training opportunities, reduction in violence and employee-friendly policies.

However, the Royal College of Nursing demanded clarification to determine whether the promised 1,000 "extra" training places would be enough to compensate for the 12,000 nurses it claims leave each year, either through retirement, career change or moving within the NHS.

The department of health calculates the annual loss of staff at 6,900, since it includes only vacancies unfilled after three months or more.

An RCN spokeswoman said: "When Frank Dobson was health secretary, he said the government would recruit 15,000 more nurses - about equal to the current vacancy rate. It is not clear whether the extra places will be over and above unfilled places."

In a speech to delegates at a conference in Birmingham, Mr Milburn pledged a radical overhaul of pay and work structures as part of the government's bid to modernise the health service. The health secretary said he planned to increase the number of nurses, doctors and consultants and create a new national pay framework.

New standards will also be introduced later this year which will judge every NHS body on the job flexibility they offer to staff, including family-friendly practices and modernised training. And he said the nurse recruitment campaigns would not be a one-off.

Opposition parties insisted the government would not crack the problem of nurse numbers until it tackled the problem of retention. The shadow health secretary, Liam Fox, said: "The government needs to address the problems of inflexible shift patterns, low staff morale and an ever-increasing burden of paperwork."

Liberal Democrat health spokesman, Nick Harvey, called on the government to cancel the penny cut in income tax due in April, and to spend the cash on the NHS.

fields.headline: Church split over section 28 repeal
fields.standfirst:
Bishops under fire at synod for not opposing government

Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The bishops of the Church of England came under heavy pressure from lay members last night for their "weakness" in not firmly opposing the government's plan to repeal section 28, which forbids local authorities from promoting homosexuality in schools.
fields.body:
The bishops of the Church of England came under heavy pressure from lay members last night for their "weakness" in not firmly opposing the government's plan to repeal section 28, which forbids local authorities from promoting homosexuality in schools.

A yawning gap appeared to be opening on the first day of the synod of the Church of England in London between senior clergy, anxious to influence the government's revised plans for sex education, and members, particularly from the church's evangelical wing which wants the section preserved.

In increasingly heated exchanges, the Rt Rev Alan Chesters, Bishop of Blackburn, who chairs the church's board of education, came close to agreeing that the section should be abandoned.

Asked by Archdeacon Peter Broadbent, a former Islington Labour councillor, why the "very badly designed and drafted" legislation should not be repealed, the bishop replied: "I would not demur from that."

Outside the synod, in Convocation Hall of Church House, under the stern gaze of a portrait of the former Archbishop of Canterbury, Cosmo Gordon-Lang - now thought to have been gay - opponents of repealing the section mounted an exhibition of literature which they claim would flood schools if the legislation was changed.

It included such famous works as the 1980s book Jenny Lives With Eric And Martin and more recent publications put out by health authorities.

Opponents of repeal claimed that the bishops should have supported Scotland's Roman Catholic Cardinal Thomas Winning in vociferously supporting the retention of the section, which was originally enacted in 1988.

Only four bishops voted at the end of the debate in the House of Lords earlier this month at which the repeal proposal was voted down. The bishops voted three to one against repeal.

Philip Gore, a lay member of the board of social responsibility, said: "Many members of the church are incensed.

"They feel let down by the perceived weakness of the bishops as opposed to the stronger stance of Cardinal Winning."

The Bishop of Blackburn appeared increasingly exasperated by the questioning he was subjected to by some synod members, insisting that as sex education in schools is now determined by governing bodies there was no question of local authorities interfering.

webTitle: Lawyer's challenge to US over GM safety claims

fields.headline: Lawyer's challenge to US over GM safety claims
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: The United States administration was challenged yesterday to explain the assumptions which had led it to claim that genetically modified foods were safe when documents produced by its own scientific advisers said its methods were fundamentally flawed.
fields.body:
The United States administration was challenged yesterday to explain the assumptions which had led it to claim that genetically modified foods were safe when documents produced by its own scientific advisers said its methods were fundamentally flawed.

Lawyer Steve Druker said the US food and drug administration (FDA) was guilty of a "deliberate ploy to deceive the world" by claiming that genetically engineered plants were substantially equivalent to normal plants.

Mr Druker issued his challenge at the GM food safety conference in Edinburgh, hosted by the British government, where some sceptics have been invited to take part but most speakers are in favour of the technology.

Documents which detailed scientific doubts about GM foods were obtained by Mr Druker as part of a court case against the FDA. He is hoping to force the FDA to have mandatory safety testing and labelling of genetically engineered foods.

He said yesterday that the 44,000 pages of documents showed that the FDA declared GM foods to be safe in the face of disagreement from its own experts. Eleven of the 17 experts on the GM task force to assess risks expressed disquiet but were overruled, he claimed.

The fears about GM food tests have begun to dominate the organisation for economic cooperation and development conference, GM Food Safety: Facts, Uncertainties and Assessment, attended by 400 invited delegates from 29 countries. The objectors to the technology say that without testing to see whether GM foods are toxic or cause allergies they should not be allowed on the market. The pro lobby say there is no need to test GM food because it is made from plants equivalent to those bred naturally.

Among the documents revealed by the court case was a memo dated January 8 1992 by Dr Linda Kahl, FDA compliance officer, summarising the objections of her colleagues. She wrote to James Maryanski, the FDA's biotechnology coordinator: "The processes of genetic engineering and traditional breeding are different, and according to the technical experts in the agency, they lead to different risks. There is no data that addresses the relative magnitude of the risks - for all we know, the risks may be lower for GM foods than for foods produced by traditional breeding."

The problem was that by holding to the view that normal plants and GM plants were substantially equivalent, "the acknowledgment that the risk was different was lost".

Dr Maryanski, in Edinburgh representing the FDA, said he could not comment on the documents because they were subject to court action but added "all possible angles on safety" had been considered before deciding that GM food was safe.

"We consider the differences between GM plants and ordinary plants, say an extra protein, and decide whether that extra ingredient makes a difference. If it might make a difference then we test for safety."

He was confident that all the GM products on the market in the US were safe and there was no evidence to the contrary.

The three-day conference began with a speech by Mo Mowlam, the minister for the cabinet office, who repeated the new softer line of Tony Blair that the government was "neither pro- nor anti-GM food".

"Above all we are pro-safety, pro-environment and pro-consumer choice. I believe it is in everyone's interests that the regulation of these new technologies has the maximum public trust and confidence."

webTitle: The man who came to symbolise an evil regime

fields.headline: The man who came to symbolise an evil regime
fields.trailText: As head of the Gestapo's department B4, Adolf Eichmann organised the "final solution" to the "Jewish problem" and in doing so he, perhaps more than any other Nazi, redefined our conception of evil.
fields.body:
As head of the Gestapo's department B4, Adolf Eichmann organised the "final solution" to the "Jewish problem" and in doing so he, perhaps more than any other Nazi, redefined our conception of evil.

But the man dragged into an Israeli courtroom and then executed in 1962 did not square with anyone's idea of a monster; he seemed neither a sadistic bully, nor a sinister intellectual. He claimed he had no stomach for the reality of genocide.

Sent to Chelmno in 1942 to report on the use of gas vans, he said, "I couldn't even look at it. All the time I was trying to avert my gaze from what was going on - the screaming and shrieking "

Eichmann did what he was told, even when the orders he received were inhumane. "I was a relatively young man and used to being led, in business and in everything else", he later said.

A failure at school and college, Eichmann drifted through a variety of jobs before being recruited into the SS in 1932 at a beer hall rally in Linz, his own, and Hitler's home town. He became the SS intelligence service's leading expert on Jewish issues. In 1938 got his first important post when he was put in charge of the deportation of Jews from Vienna.

There is evidence that, as late as the mid-1930s, Eichmann's own solution to the "Jewish problem" was essentially non-violent. "The Zionists wanted a territory where the Jewish people could finally settle in peace. And that was pretty much what the Nazis wanted," he said.

Yet the same man who had once applied for SS money to study Hebrew with a rabbi became someone who, in the closing stages of the second world war, could say of the mass graves: "I shall gladly jump into the pit, knowing that in that same pit there are 5m [sic] enemies of the state".

The imminent release of his memoirs is important because they promise an insight into one of the most disturbing minds of the Third Reich.
