fields.headline: Blunder patient loses second kidney
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: A pensioner who was left fighting for his life after the wrong kidney was removed in an operation has now lost the other one, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
A pensioner who was left fighting for his life after the wrong kidney was removed in an operation has now lost the other one, it emerged yesterday.

Graham Reeves, 70, of Llanelli, south Wales, was taken into surgery at Morriston hospital, Swansea, after developing septicemia.

The former soldier and power station worker has been in a coma on a dialysis machine since undergoing what should have been routine surgery at Prince Philip hospital, Llanelli, to remove a diseased kidney last month.

Mr Reeves' family refused to comment, but a hospital spokesman said he remained in a critical condition.

The Royal College of Surgeons is due to conclude its inquiry this week. Carmarthenshire NHS trust, which has also conducted an internal investigation, sent the surgeon, John Roberts, 58, home on leave.

It had been hoped that a close relative could be found to donate a kidney for transplant to replace the diseased organ the surgical team should have removed, but Mr Reeves had no brothers, sisters or children.

Consultant urologist Mr Roberts, the man ultimately responsible for the error, said the news had been "devastating" and added that in 30 years he had been responsible for more than 30,000 operations and had never been involved in anything remotely similar.

In a statement through the Medical Defence Union he said at the time: "I am devastated by what has happened.

Mr Reeves, a Korean war veteran, has been on a dialysis machine and receiving around the clock treatment.

All members of the surgical team involved in Mr Reeves' operation are still at work but have been stopped from carrying out similar duties.

Carmarthenshire NHS Trust could face a huge bill for compensation after the case. It has already admitted liability and said any claim would be settled quickly.

fields.headline: All in a day's work
fields.trailText: Police Investigations | Secrets Of The Incas
fields.body:
Even in programmes promising a gritty slice of reality in all its unpleasantness, we've come to expect a certain degree of collusion between the people behind the camera and the people in front of it - to assume that any genuinely illuminating level of access must come at a price. Perhaps this is the defining difference between the traditional fly-on-the-wall documentary and its runtish, fast-multiplying cousin, the docusoap: in the latter, we don't seriously expect to see the airline steward fooling around with the cabin doors mid-flight, the Ibiza tour guide poisoning the holidaymakers' paella.

Superintendent Kouassi, a senior police detective in the Ivory Coast capital, Abidjan, didn't seem to have grasped this development. A man with a bearing that smacked of reasonableness and plain dealing, Kouassi had amiably granted the makers of Police Investigations (Murder On The Ivory Coast, C4, 9pm) unfettered access to his force's investigation into the gunning down of one of their own men. He might, by this display of institutional openness, have been hoping to present himself as a paragon of modern policing - except that the superintendent also happened to preside over a team of officers so willing to batter and torture suspects arrested on the flimsiest of evidence that this astonishingly violent film was frequently difficult to watch without flinching.

French director Mosco Boucault's camera didn't flinch, though, but hung back, monitoring every stage of the farcical investigation, while an admirably sparse narration left the policemen's methods to speak for themselves. Kouassi's assistants rounded up alleged murderer after alleged murderer on the basis of "tip-offs" from informers who were, with embarrassing obviousness, inventing their stories on the spot. The suspects were hung by their feet, attacked with rubber pipes and kicked until, their limbs broken and bloody, they confessed to crimes they had clearly not committed. Kouassi, though, was a man evidently troubled by some vague sense that he ought to be unearthing the truth, and so laughingly rejected the violence-induced confessions, helpfully pointing out to the agonised suspects that they were, of course, making things up to avoid further beatings.

But the real insight of Boucault's film lay in the justifications Kouassi seemed only too happy to give directly to camera. "The police in Paris used to beat people up, but you've evolved to the point where you don't do that any more", he said, rehearsing arguments chillingly reminiscent of those deployed by the former colonial oppressors of his country.

The legacies of another colonialism hung heavy in the air of Secrets Of The Incas (Cracking The Code, C4, 8pm). The Spanish conquistadores brought the vast Inca civilisation to its knees in the mid-16th century. But there has always been something troubling about the ease with which the Incas were defeated. Even the conquistadores were bewildered by their lack of resistance. In the first confrontation, 170 marauding Spaniards faced 40,000 Incas, but finished off 4,000 of them in the first day's fighting; 50 years later, the pre-conquest population had been reduced to 2m, leaving little to show for past glories save a handful of folk myths. Dr William Sullivan, a maverick historian from Massachusetts, thinks he may have an explanation.

He claims that the Inca folktales recorded by the Spanish contain, in encrypted form, an advanced understanding of astronomy which had been used to draw a worrying conclusion. Whenever the Milky Way fell out of sight beneath the horizon, they noticed, disaster had struck them, in the shape of discord, civil war, and destruction. The final cataclysm was believed to be due sometime around 1532 - so that when the Spanish came ashore that year, the Incas had already decided that their empire was doomed.

In a programme notably starved of visual materials - an hour of slow pans across wilderness, even in the Andes, grew tedious, as did countless close-ups of arbitrary, unidentified South American people. Our softly-spoken, walrus-moustached hero spent much time gazing moodily from train and bus windows, presumably chewing over the evidence but, for all we knew, counting the passing llamas, of which there were many.

Fortunately, Sullivan's mesmerising research was enough to rescue the programme. This was history as gripping detective work; the next episode promises further exploration of Sullivan's engrossing findings - and, no doubt, plenty more llamas.

webTitle: Fans tackle club over 'broken' bond deal

fields.headline: Fans tackle club over 'broken' bond deal
fields.standfirst: Supporters thought they had guaranteed a seat - but Newcastle United had other ideas, court is told
fields.trailText: Newcastle United football club broke a promise to some of its most loyal fans when it told them they would have to move to another part of the ground to watch matches because their seats were being sold to corporate clients, a court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Newcastle United football club broke a promise to some of its most loyal fans when it told them they would have to move to another part of the ground to watch matches because their seats were being sold to corporate clients, a court was told yesterday.

The fans had each paid £500 as part of a bond scheme launched in 1994 which they claimed should have guaranteed them the same seat at Newcastle's home ground, St James' Park, for the next 10 years. As well as buying the bond, fans also had to pay around £400 for their season tickets.

Newcastle high court was told that in promotional material and interviews given by club officials about the bond scheme, fans were promised a guaranteed seat. Thousands took up the option as a way of ensuring they could watch their team.

In a unique test case which could have implications for the way clubs treat their fans, six people are challenging Newcastle United after they received a letter from the club last October telling them that they would have to move to another part of the ground to make way for high-paying corporate guests.

The fans, who are bringing the case on behalf of 2,000 other bond holders affected by the club's plans, claim Newcastle United has no right to move them and is in breach of a promise it made to them when the bonds were sold.

Jonathan Crystal, representing the fans, said: "A guaranteed seat was a constant theme in interviews and publicity. The application form asked you to identify your particular seat. Anybody who filled in that form would have concluded that they were bonding that particular seat."

Mr Justice Blackburne heard that bonds were taken up by just over 7,000 fans, generating £3.6m for the club.

The club is attempting to move fans who have seats in the middle sections of two stands. These seats are considered to have some of the best views in St James' Park.

The bond holders were told last October that they could either pay £1,350 per season to join an exclusive bar, known as 1892, or £900 per season to join another bar, called the Sports Bar, as a way of keeping their seats. If they rejected either option they would have to give up their seats.

The court heard that while there was limited demand for corporate facilities, more than 15,000 "ordinary" fans were on the waiting list for Newcastle United season tickets.

Mr Crystal said: "With more than 15,000 on the waiting list, that is where the demand is. Most people go to watch a match and the hospitality is an addition. This club is taking the position that you go to the ground for hospitality and the seat is an addition."

The court was told that Newcastle United fans were among the most loyal in the country, and the north-east as a whole was passionate about football. However, the club's directors had misled fans.

Chief executive Freddie Fletcher, who resigned in 1998 following newspaper reports in which he made disparaging remarks about the people of Newcastle, is to give evidence. Mr Fletcher returned to his post last year, much to the dismay of many Newcastle fans.

Newcastle United claims it has the right to move bond holders because of a clause in the bond agreement which does not guarantee them the same seat for 10 years.

The club claims it did not mislead fans and that it made its position clear at the start of the bond scheme.

The fans have the backing of the England manager, Kevin Keegan, who was the Newcastle manager when the scheme was launched. A statement from him will form part of the fans' case. Jane Duffy, a leader of the Save Our Seats campaign, told the court that she had not missed a Newcastle home fixture since 1976 and that she bought a bond as a way of guaranteeing the same seat.

Ms Duffy said: "I was led to believe that I would be securing my seat for the next 10 years. The club does not have the right to take that seat away from me."

The case continues.

webTitle: Brown's jibe at jobless greeted with contempt

fields.headline: Brown's jibe at jobless greeted with contempt
fields.trailText: The vacancy notices in Pontypool's jobcentre tell two stories. One is that chancellor Gordon Brown's claim that there are many opportunities for Britain's jobless to take up paid work is true. The other is that few of the jobs are thought worth having.
fields.body:
The vacancy notices in Pontypool's jobcentre tell two stories. One is that chancellor Gordon Brown's claim that there are many opportunities for Britain's jobless to take up paid work is true. The other is that few of the jobs are thought worth having.

"Tell him to come down here and have a look for himself," said lorry driver Stephen Davies.

"There is a queue of people in there waiting to sign up for work. I've been in there for two hours and there was only one job there for me."

In the south Wales town that grew up around the iron, coal and Japanware industries, those looking for work yesterday were contemptuous on hearing a Labour chancellor seemingly echoing the "get on your bike" philosophy of the Thatcher era.

Unemployment in Pontypool is around 5%, well above the average for the area, and the town centre bears the scars. Several of its shops are boarded up.

The area has been hit by the recent closure of a pharmaceutical factory that once employed 1,200 people and by redundancies at a nearby steel plant.

Hopes are now pinned on attracting new employers to two Welsh devolopment agency owned sites on the edge of town.

Noticeboards in the bright, open-plan jobcentre offices appear to underline the chancellor's contention that there is no shortage of work in 21st century Britain.

But many jobs on offer yesterday were in the low-paid retail, catering and care sectors. And while there is work to be found in nearby Cwmbran or in larger centres such as Newport, many of those looking for work complained that transport costs make it impossible for them to contemplate such a move.

For those forced to stay in the immediate vicinity, the choices included telephone canvassers at £3.60 an hour plus commission for a 16-hour week or work as a seamstress in a Pontypool factory at £3.76 an hour.

"There are jobs out there," said David Bailey, 32, who has been out of work since March last year.

"But you just have to have the transport to get to them and I can't afford to run a car."

Sarah Jennings, a qualified hairdresser, was caught in a similar trap having just been laid off after three months spent de-boning chickens in a nearby factory.

"There are a lot of jobs but not many of them are in Pontypool and I don't drive."

Getting a job in nearby Cwmbran would mean awkward and expensive travel on public transport involving two buses there and back.

Mr Davies, who has been out of work since losing a £250-a-week driving job, relies on £242-a-fortnight hardship allowance to support his wife and children.

The £136-a-week driving job for which he had been sent for interview involved 36 hours a week night-time driving. With three school age children it was, he said, "not a great deal of use".

He was planning to borrow money to pay for diesel to get him to an interview for a driving job in Cardiff that he had seen advertised in the newspaper.

While jobseekers were less than impressed with the chancellor's exhortations, employers in the Pontypool area admitted to mixed fortunes in their search to fill vacancies.

The matron of a care home said she had been advertising in the press and through jobcentres for four weeks in an effort to fill vacancies for part-time kitchen workers and night-time care assistants paying £3.60 an hour.

"It is difficult to find suitable people to do the job," she said.

The personnel manager of an engineering firm who asked not to be identified said it had had a rush of applicants after advertising for machinists in the local press.

Most of those applying for the £8-an-hour jobs were already in employment elsewhere.

Andrew Thomas, a human resources director at Trico, a wiper blades manufacturer which employs 650 people at its factory on the edge of Pontypool, said filling unskilled assembly work jobs was proving tougher than three or four years ago because of improvements in the local economy.

"Although we can recruit unskilled workers we are finding it more difficult to recruit them to the high standards we require."

webTitle: Woman breaks leg as jolt shakes BA jet at 35,000ft

fields.headline: Woman breaks leg as jolt shakes BA jet at 35,000ft
fields.trailText: British Airways yesterday launched an urgent inquiry after a serious technical problem sent a sudden jolt through a packed Boeing 747 at 35,000ft, leaving one woman passenger with a broken leg.
fields.body:
British Airways yesterday launched an urgent inquiry after a serious technical problem sent a sudden jolt through a packed Boeing 747 at 35,000ft, leaving one woman passenger with a broken leg.

Flight BA 179, with 364 passengers and 19 crew, was 30 minutes away from Kennedy airport in New York after leaving Heathrow just before 7pm on Sunday, when the unexplained incident occurred.

No advance warning was given, the seat belt signs were not illuminated, and passengers standing up were thrown about the aircraft.

The woman and four other people, including a steward, were taken to hospital and BA launched an inquiry into what it said was a technical problem.

BA said that the four people all had minor injuries and had left hospital. New York police said seven other passengers had been hurt but had refused treatment.

A BA spokesperson said: "The flight appears to have experienced a technical problem which caused the aircraft to jolt suddenly and without warning. The plane did not fall. It was more of a shudder. The jolt was the only problem the crew faced."

The company said that the aircraft landed safely. "We are doing everything we can to look after those affected. Safety is always a top priority. We are looking at the cause of this problem, but we believe this was just an isolated incident."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Nuclear chief loses job
John Taylor, the chief executive of British Nuclear Fuels, left the company yesterday, taking the blame for the critical safety reports from the nuclear installations inspectorate nine days ago.

So far only five production workers and Mr Taylor have lost their jobs over the scandal of falsified documents for nuclear fuel exported to Japan and Germany from the Sellafield nuclear plant in Cumbria. Paul Brown

Couple on girl murder charge
A couple appeared in court yesterday charged with the murder of eight-year-old Anna Kouao, who died of hypothermia at St Mary's hospital in Paddington, west London, on Saturday.

Marie Therese Kouao, 43, unemployed and her partner Carl Manning, 27, a bus driver, of Tottenham, north London, were remanded in custody for seven days after appearing at Highgate magistrates court.

RSPCA wins terrier ruling
The RSPCA yesterday won a high court ruling, which it says will help curtail the use of terriers to hunt wild mammals, when two judges upheld the conviction and jailing of two men who were found guilty of cruelly ill-treating a lakeland terrier which was injured after being put into a badgers' set.

Footballer calls for Guinness ban
Liverpool and England footballer Robbie Fowler yesterday called for a boycott of Guinness and Bell's whisky products in support of Thalidomide drug victims. The Thalidomide UK group believes Guinness has a "moral obligation" to put more money into the Thalidomide Trust, set up by Distillers, which marketed the drug and was later bought by Guinness.

Student jailed for cocaine plot
A Colombian studying in London who was swept off her feet by a businessman twice her age was jailed for two and a half years at the Old Bailey yesterday after admitting money laundering in a £800m cocaine smuggling plot. Liliana Uribe, 23, was said to have helped German Posada,45, who is now in Columbia.

Morphine doses 'irresponsible'
A hospital consultant yesterday admitted "irresponsibly" prescribing doubled doses of morphine and a sedative to a dying cancer victim, Elizabeth Ann Parbury, 67, on the Isle of Man, in November 1996.

Jonathan Henry Brooks told a General Medical Council hearing where he is accused of serious professional misconduct that his motive had been to relieve pain.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Journalist on hunger strike
fields.body:
Journalist on hunger strike

The Russian-American journalist Andrei Babitsky has gone on hunger strike in protest at his detention by Russia, his lawyer said yesterday,

The acting president, Vladimir Putin, tried to defuse the row yesterday by saying he should be freed.

Mr Babitsky, whose reporting of Chechnya angered Moscow, was detained in January and handed to alleged rebels in exchange for Russian soldiers.
AP, Makhachkala, Russia

Crowds greet freed mayors

A rapturous crowd of about 4,000 people greeted three Kurdish mayors released yesterday from prison on bail after being arrested in south-eastern Turkey for alleged links to armed rebels. The arrests had raised concern in the US and the EU.
Reuters, Diyarbakir

Internet 'virgin' has last laugh

A Hungarian prankster offered to sell a fictitious young woman's virginity to the highest bidder over the internet- and then published 13 bidders' names, email addresses and messages to her on his website.

"Those who didn't realise that it was a joke should suffer," he wrote.
Reuters, Budapest

webTitle: US snubs Germany by rejecting IMF candidate

fields.headline: US snubs Germany by rejecting IMF candidate
fields.trailText: A diplomatic row erupted yesterday over attempts to find a new chief for the International Monetary Fund, after the United States vetoed the European Union's candidate for the job, German deputy finance minister Caio Koch-Weser.
fields.byline: Charlotte Denny and Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
A diplomatic row erupted yesterday over attempts to find a new chief for the International Monetary Fund, after the United States vetoed the European Union's candidate for the job, German deputy finance minister Caio Koch-Weser.

In what will be seen as calculated snub to Berlin, a White House spokesman revealed yesterday that President Clinton had telephoned the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, over the weekend and told him that Mr Koch-Weser did not meet the US requirement for a "strong candidate of maximum stature who would be able to command broad support around the world".

The post of IMF managing director traditionally goes to a European. Earlier yesterday all 15 European Union finance ministers rallied behind Mr Koch-Weser's candidacy.

He faces competition from the IMF's chief economist, Stanley Fischer, who has been acting head since Michel Camdessus left last week, and former Japanese finance ministry official Eisuke Sakakibara.

Despite Mr Fischer's presence in the race, the White House said it believed the IMF post should, in keeping with tradition, go to a European.

"Our objective remains to work with Europe to find a strong European candidate who is able to command broad support, including that of the emerging market countries," Joe Lockhart, the White House spokesman, said.

As Washington and Berlin clashed over the directorship, a leaked US Congress report described the IMF as "high cost and low effectiveness". The report is likely to fuel US calls for a slimmed-down IMF and World Bank, which it also criticised.

The congressional report, written by a commission headed by Professor Allan Meltzer of Carnegie Mellon University, is set to be released within the next month.

A draft copy leaked to Reuters yesterday concludes: "The IMF has given too little attention to improving financial structures in developing countries and too much to expensive rescue operations. Its system of short-term crisis management is too costly, its responses too slow, its advice often incorrect and its efforts to influence policy and practice too intrusive."

Conservative politicians in the US have long held the IMF and World Bank in contempt as too costly and overly bureaucratic. The Meltzer report echoes US treasury secretary Larry Summer's call last year for a far smaller IMF which would only provide short-term loans.

 Keith Vaz, the Europe minister, will today oppose suggestions that Britain could abandon its membership of the European Union in favour of joining a free trade pact with the United States. Speaking in Washington, Mr Vaz will describe suggestions being promoted by the Conservative MP Michael Fabricant that Britain should join the North American Free Trade Area as "far-fetched".

webTitle: Bosnian Serbs on trial for prison camp atrocities

fields.headline: Bosnian Serbs on trial for prison camp atrocities
fields.trailText: The war crimes tribunal in The Hague yesterday began the trial of three Bosnian Serbs accused of the torture, rape, and murder, of thousands of Muslim and Croatian civilians at the Omarska prison camp, where western pictures of inmates in 1992 provoked international outrage.
fields.body:
The war crimes tribunal in The Hague yesterday began the trial of three Bosnian Serbs accused of the torture, rape, and murder, of thousands of Muslim and Croatian civilians at the Omarska prison camp, where western pictures of inmates in 1992 provoked international outrage.

In what prosecutors described as the first case to deal directly with "a system of concentration camps", Miroslav Kvocka, Milojica Kos and Mlado Radic were charged with war crimes and crimes against humanity for presiding over the atrocities at Omarska and other sites.

A fourth defendant, Zoran Zigic, a Bosnian Serb taxi driver, is accused of torturing and murdering prisoners.

The Australian prosecutor, Grant Niemann, told the Hague trbunal judges that "the images of skeletal malnutrition . . . sent shock waves around the world", when they were first broadcast.

Omarska was, he alleged, an integral part of the ethnic cleansing policy of the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic: "This is about a government policy of persecution and ethnic cleansing. It was a crime committed on a massive scale," he said.

"The evidence will prove that thousands of Muslim and Croat detainees suffered and died because of their ethnicity, either directly at the hands of these accused or people under their authority," he said.

Serb forces swept through the Prijedor region of northern Bosnia, herding more than 6,000 Muslims and Croats into Omarska and the nearby Keraterm and Trnopolje camps, the tribunal was told.

Pointing to a replica of the Omarska camp, Mr Niemann described how new arrivals were beaten with batons and rifle butts and crowded into stiflingly hot rooms with no beds and meagre sanitary facilities.

Although the prison was predominantly male, several dozen women were held in the administration building. They worked as cleaners and were raped nightly by camp staff, he said.

Corpses accumulated out side an interrogation centre known as the White House and were dumped in graves in a meadow beside a razed mosque.

"We dug up those graves," said Mr Niemann, showing slides of exhumed bodies with what he called "blunt object injuries and bullet wounds to the head".

The prosecution say Mr Kvocka, 43, was responsible for much of what happened at Omarska as commander in June 1992 and later deputy commander. Mr Kos, 36, and Mr Radic, 47, said to be shift commanders, ordered guards to beat prisoners and sometimes participated themselves, prosecutors maintain.

Mr Zigic, 41, is accused of going on torture and murder rampages, forcing male prisoners to perform sexual acts with each other and to lie down on broken glass.

Of the 50,000 Muslims who lived in Prijedor before the ethnic war in Bosnia, only 6,000 remained after the conflict. The rest either fled or were killed, Mr Niemann told the tribunal. The Croatian population of 6,000 was cut by half. Those who remained have lived "in permanent fear and uncertainty".

In an opening statement, Mr Niemann told the tribunal that the evidence would prove "that the accused and others under their authority confined, beat, tortured, sexually assaulted and murdered many of the Bosnian and Croat detainees ... solely because of the victims' ethnicity".

He added: "It [ethnic cleansing] was certainly committed by more people than you see here today, by a large number of politicians, military police and loyal followers in the puppet entity . . . dangling on the strings of Slobodan Milosevic for the purpose of creating an ethnically pure greater Serbia."

Defence lawyers are expected to argue that their clients are scapegoats for the tribunal's inability to apprehend the alleged architects of that strategy higher up the military and political leadership.

Despite repeated calls from the Hague tribunal for their arrest, the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, and his military commander, Ratko Mladic, remain free.

fields.headline: Zapped
fields.standfirst: Computer game sales slump
fields.trailText: Sega and Eidos underlined the fragility of the global computer games market yesterday by confirming that future sales will fall below original forecasts.
fields.body:
Sega and Eidos underlined the fragility of the global computer games market yesterday by confirming that future sales will fall below original forecasts.

Console manufacturer Sega warned that poor sales in Japan of its new Dreamcast games machine will mean heavy losses while Eidos produced revised third-quarter figures in line with a profits warning made last month.

Both companies emphasised that the computer games industry is in a transitory phase as the old generation of video games platforms such as Sony PlayStation and Nintendo 64 are phased out for newer ones such as PlayStation 2 and a heavily rumoured Microsoft offering.

Nick Gibson, computer games analyst at Durlacher, said it could be 12 to 18 months before sales at publishers such as Eidos recover to levels that made their shares one of the stock market's strongest performers last year.

Eidos, creator of the best-selling Tomb Raider series, announced an operating loss of £11m in the nine months to the end of December compared with a profit of £36.2m a year ago. Turnover fell from £169m to £142.6m.

Chief financial officer Jeremy Lewis admitted 2000 is likely to be a testing year for Eidos with analysts predicting sluggish games sales. "The gamers who have had PlayStation 1 for nearly five years now will be gagging for the launch of PlayStation 2," he said.

Mr Gibson believes the key test for Eidos now is how well it can milk its existing brands and, in the longer term, how it can transfer key titles such as Tomb Raider and Championship Manager on to new platforms. Tomb Raider, traditionally a PlayStation and PC title, has been put on to Dreamcast and Nintendo's Game Boy Color.

Alex Davies, technology analyst at Teather & Greenwood, says the confusion over the capability of new platforms and the timing of their launches is adding to investor uncertainty in the sector. "No one is entirely sure at the moment which of the new platforms will emerge as winners."

Mr Davies believes the picture is likely to become far clearer over the next two months. Sony's PlayStation 2 launches in Japan on Saturday and is expected to increase the pressure on Dreamcast sales.

Sega said yesterday that, after a blistering early start, Dreamcast sales in Japan in the coming half-year are likely to be only half the original estimates of 1.1m.

Speculation is also mounting that Microsoft will finally admit the existence of its much hinted at X-Box at a Games Developers Conference in San Jose on March 10.

Eidos shares fell by almost a half after a warning on January 18 that sales would be significantly below expectation due to delayed product releases and under-performance in key markets, particularly France and Germany.

Last night they closed up 8.5p at 749p, having traded off almost 14% in early dealing.

Eidos, creator of the best-selling Tomb Raider series, announced an operating loss of £11m in the nine months to the end of December compared with a profit of £36.2m a year ago. Turnover fell from £169m to £142.6m. Chief financial officer Jeremy Lewis admitted 2000 is likely to be a testing year for Eidos with analysts predicting sluggish games sales. "The gamers who have had PlayStation 1 for nearly five years now will be gagging for the launch of PlayStation 2," he said. Mr Gibson believes the key test for Eidos now is how well it can milk its existing brands and, in the longer term, how it can transfer key titles such as Tomb Raider and Championship Manager on to new platforms. Tomb Raider, traditionally a PlayStation and PC title, has been put on to Dreamcast and Nintendo's Game Boy Color. Alex Davies, technology analyst at Teather & Greenwood, says the confusion over the capability of new platforms and the timing of their launches is adding to investor uncertainty in the sector. "No one is entirely sure at the moment which of the new platforms will emerge as winners." Mr Davies believes the picture is likely to become far clearer over the next two months. Sony's PlayStation 2 launches in Japan on Saturday and is expected to increase the pressure on Dreamcast sales. Sega said yesterday that, after a blistering early start, Dreamcast sales in Japan in the coming half-year are likely to be only half the original estimates of 1.1m. Speculation is also mounting that Microsoft will finally admit the existence of its much hinted at X-Box at a Games Developers Conference in San Jose on March 10. Eidos shares fell by almost a half after a warning on January 18 that sales would be significantly below expectation due to delayed product releases and under-performance in key markets, particularly France and Germany. Last night they closed up 8.5p at 749p, having traded off almost 14% in early dealing.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: The lunacy of London's indices was illustrated once again yesterday. In the morning, the telecoms sector went up, driving the FTSE 100 index to a high of 6,271 points; in the afternoon, the telecoms sector went into reverse, leaving the index a net 98.4 points adrift at 6,099.6.
fields.body:
The lunacy of London's indices was illustrated once again yesterday. In the morning, the telecoms sector went up, driving the FTSE 100 index to a high of 6,271 points; in the afternoon, the telecoms sector went into reverse, leaving the index a net 98.4 points adrift at 6,099.6.

In fact, the decline in Vodafone - Britain's biggest company, which ended the day 19p lower at 343p - shaved 46 points off the Footsie.

But there was plenty of news to keep investors busy. While in the background the debate over the so-called split market continued - with "old" economy stocks plummeting and tech issues soaring - there were some old-fashioned results statements to deal with.

South African mining group Billiton produced profits in line with expectations, but watched its share price drop from 286p to 267p. Fellow sector member Rio Tinto met with the same market reaction when it issued its own results last week.

In the banking sector, there was a wave of buying in the wake of the sector sector-wide sell-off. Royal Bank of Scotland , for example, ended the day 56p higher at 760p, NatWest (in the process of being bought by RBS) gained 59p to £11.29 and Lloyds TSB firmed 21p to 540p.

Analysts at Warburg Dillon Read joined the list of Baltimore Technology fans, adding the Irish software group to its 30-strong European Focus list. The shares, which were trading below 500p last year, surged 450p to £107.

ITnet was another high-technology advancer. The outsourcing specialist climbed 152p to £11.40 following Friday's news that it had agreed a joint venture with Infobank to build an online procurement service for local government.

There was some profit-taking in internet investment specialist Durlacher , which lost 235p to £33.25 despite confirmation that it is backing a new pop-on-the-web venture run by artist manager Simon Fuller.

Other tech fallers included JSB Software , down 500p at £29.75, London Bridge Software , losing 245p to £61.50, BATM Advanced Communications , 220p lower at £56.75, and Psion , which fell from £54.95 to £53.24.

Yet there was still heavy demand for yesterday's crop of new issues on the Aim market. Griff-Tech.com , the unlikely internet acquisition vehicle spun off by Griffin Mining, jumped from an offer price of 3p to 16p.

Stockbroker Peel Hunt also had an exceptional first day out. Although not quite in the dot.com arena, the stock jumped from a sale price of 300p to 520p.

fields.headline: Burmah Castrol gets blend right
fields.trailText: It is not often that Britannia Group finds itself in the spotlight but yesterday the Cheltenham-based construction materials company was one of of the few outstanding features in the smaller companies sector.
fields.body:
It is not often that Britannia Group finds itself in the spotlight but yesterday the Cheltenham-based construction materials company was one of of the few outstanding features in the smaller companies sector.

The shares rattled up almost a quarter, rising 16p to 65.5p after the group disclosed that it had received an approach which could lead to a full bid. In its official announcement Britannia did not disclose details of the identity of its suitor but the news pushed its market value up to around £15m.

The approach comes as the construction and building materials sectors - Britannia also manufactures concrete products - undergoes consolidation including such high profile ventures as the Lafarge offer for Blue Circle and St Gobain's move for Meyer International.

But the sector in general remains under pressure. Despite the surge in house prices, which has yet to impact on the share prices of house builders, let alone the rest of the sector, investors' eyes are elsewhere.

One concern is the impact of higher interest rates. Despite yesterday's broad hint from a senior Bank of England figure, the City is expecting rates to carry on rising for a while.

The sector is suffering its full share of the dot.com effect, too, with investors apparently little inclined to look beyond the lure of the hi-tech, neglecting even large cap stocks in traditional industries - let alone the smaller end of the corporate spectrum.

But if Britannia dovetails neatly enough into the smaller end of the scale - it is tipped to make pre-tax profits of £1.9m this year - it is at least providing some much needed excitement.

webTitle: Power group breaks into US for £2bn

fields.headline: Power group breaks into US for £2bn
fields.trailText: PowerGen yesterday renewed its attempt to break into the US energy market with a £2bn agreed bid for the Kentucky-based LG&E electricity and gas group.
fields.body:
PowerGen yesterday renewed its attempt to break into the US energy market with a £2bn agreed bid for the Kentucky-based LG&E electricity and gas group.

In the past two years Britain's third-largest generator has tried and failed twice to enter the US market. But PowerGen said it would now control a company with access to growing markets in the US midwest, which accounts for about a quarter of the country's total energy market. Electricity consumption in the area was greater than that of France and Germany combined.

Ed Wallis, PowerGen's chairman, said he was confident that this time he had the right company, in the right market and with the right management. He said LG&E would provide a base for further US acquisitions as increasing deregulation led to more consolidation of the industry.

PowerGen is offering $24.85 cash for each LG&E share which it will fund through a $4bn debt facility it has arranged with five banks.

Despite having to pay a 58% premium for the shares, PowerGen is acquiring LG&E on an exit multiple of 13.7, which Mr Wallis described as "one of the lowest multiples seen in our sector".

PowerGen said that its debt would rise from £2bn last year to about £5bn.Its shares closed 17p down at 419p as Standard & Poor's marked down the group's credit rating in view of the new debt levels.

LG&E has extra capacity under construction and investments in Argentina. The company believes that with PowerGen's backing it can expand from its Kentucky base into deregulated markets nearby. About 90% of its business is regulated, most of it in Kentucky.

PowerGen reported an 11% rise in profits before tax, exceptional items and goodwill during 1999, and an 8.1% rise in the dividend for the year. The company said the LG&E deal would be earnings enhancing and enable it to continue its "progressive" dividend policy.

webTitle: Still time to go with the flow

fields.headline: Still time to go with the flow
fields.standfirst: Share prices are bearing up
fields.trailText: The purest investment theory says that a bull market will come to an end and markets will crash only when the last bear has capitulated and become fully invested. The logic is simple: once everyone believes the market is going up and has bet all their money on the event, then no one will be left to buy any stock and prices will drop.
fields.body:
The purest investment theory says that a bull market will come to an end and markets will crash only when the last bear has capitulated and become fully invested. The logic is simple: once everyone believes the market is going up and has bet all their money on the event, then no one will be left to buy any stock and prices will drop.

Tony Dye, the investment chief at pension manager Phillips & Drew who is expected to hang up his proverbial boots this week, has been a proponent of this theory for many years. However, he never seemed to grasp the internal contradiction.

Four years ago he and his team took a view that stock markets were overblown and inflation was about to explode. So, of the £50bn under P&D's management at the time, some £15bn was placed on the equivalent of cash deposit and another few billion was diverted into index-linked gilts. But instead of financial assets crashing and high street prices soaring, the opposite happened. Prospective pensioners in the numerous funds managed by P&D were left to pay the unquantified "opportunity cost" of being left largely outside the most dramatic stock market boom this century.

When Mr Dye took this extraordinary bet he was not alone in his thinking. Rival pension funds - Mercury Asset Management, Schroders, Gartmore - all thought the market had run ahead of itself. Yet they did not match his stake- laying and they did not suffer from his rigid investment thinking. They capitulated early and, in terms of the British investment scene, Mr Dye was left as the sole significant market sceptic. Suddenly, he looked like the last bear who had to capitulate before his own prediction of something close to financial meltdown came true.

Now that he is on the way out, should the rest of us be heading for the hills?

It's a tricky one. Only a rash commentator would predict armageddon, because even if the call is right you never get the credit. But every day we get fresh evidence that says what is going on cannot go on much longer. The statistics and stories just get ever more fantastical: revenue-to-price ratios that would have looked stretched as price/earnings multiples; cash sitting in incubator funds being valued at a hundred-fold premium; and so on.

At the same time, if and when the crash happens much of the population might not notice. It could well be a "slow crash", as happened in the US last year, when internet stocks fell 40% from their highs in the space of four months before rebounding. And, given the skew-whiff nature of the major indices, such as the FTSE 100, there is a good chance that the traditional barometers of the market's health will actually go up if tech stocks crash, since the money that escapes will have to go somewhere.

But the most comforting factor lies elsewhere. It is a fact that as Britain has witnessed the extraordinary growth of amateur stock market punting over the past six months - with hundreds of thousands online, on credit and in the money - there has been a parallel explosion in amateur punditry.

John Humphries was in the Sunday Times two weeks ago informing us that he had a friend in the City who said it just could not go on. Dominic Lawson burnt two-thirds of the Sunday Telegraph's leader column telling us it could not go on. And London's taxi drivers will tell you about the coming crash in no uncertain terms (if you can get one in soaraway UK plc).

So if you fancy a punt, be assured that Tony Dye is not the last of the bears. And, if you want a tip, try medical diagnostics group Medisys. The price is going up and no one in this office owns a share.

Phone message

If Prudential can hope to get a market valuation of as much as £3bn for Egg, its internet bank, wonder then what First Direct is worth to HSBC.

Launched 10 years ago, First Direct, a pioneer in telephone banking set up by the same man to create Egg, would never work, the naysayers said. It took five years to break even but last year made profits of close to £50m. It has close to 1m current accounts, attracting 117,000 new ones last year, arguably more valuable than the "hot money" savings customers attracted to Egg. Already armed with a popular online offering, First Direct is poised to boost its dot.com credibility with the launch of new internet products tomorrow.

On First Direct's past form - matching technological innovation with mundane but important things like top quality staff training - this move might be expected to unnerve HSBC's rivals, all of whom are racing to get their own internet banks online. There is even a touch of arrogance to the launch invite, which sports a suit-clad cyber-generated baby teasing "hi, I'm a little fella with a big message".

And rivals will already know from last time around that one message here is that First Direct should not be ignored this time around.

fields.headline: Murdoch in talks with Yahoo
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report

Media group tries to counter Time Warner's domination of US cable networks
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch's News Corp and internet portal Yahoo have started talks about an alliance that would see the web company taking a stake in the media group's satellite operations, which are soon to be de-merged .
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's News Corp and internet portal Yahoo have started talks about an alliance that would see the web company taking a stake in the media group's satellite operations, which are soon to be de-merged .

News Corp is also understood to have held preliminary talks with Microsoft about working together in the wake of the merger announced between America Online and Time Warner. Microsoft is also keen to provide the software for the next generation of set-top boxes for satellite televisions.

The activity at News Corp is being conducted by Peter Chernin, Mr Murdoch's deputy - an indication of how important the net is now considered by the media mogul. A senior News Corp executive confirmed the talks with Yahoo yesterday, which were reported in the latest New Yorker, but said that they stopped far short of a merger.

News Corp's satellite assets - including Star TV in Asia and a 40% stake in British Sky Broadcasting - are to be spun off in a new company which some analysts have valued at between $35bn (£22bn) and $40bn. Any deal, which could see Yahoo taking a stake of up to 10% in the new satellite company, is likely to take several weeks to complete.

A company executive said that, although shares were likely to be used to pay for any deal, "a stock swap is way off". Both Mr Murdoch and senior executives at Yahoo have recently made it clear that they want to remain independent.

Sources said that News Corp is likely to provide access to Yahoo sites through its satellite network, while Yahoo would use News Corp's print and television content. The deal would provide Yahoo with access to areas of the world which the California-based company has failed to dominate, such as Asia and Europe.

The two companies already share some resources through News Corp's digital media arm and Mr Murdoch's two sons, Lachlan and James, are friendly with the two young founders of Yahoo. But the latest deal, largely forged in talks between Mr Chernin and one of those founders, Jerry Yang, is expected to lead to a far broader partnership.

News Corp believes that its future lies in distributing news and entertainment around the world through satellite and wireless services. It has also held preliminary talks with Nokia, the mobile phone company, about possible partnerships.

In many ways, News Corp's stance reflects its relatively weak position in the cable industry. Cable networks, which Time Warner dominates, are expected to provide the main broadband access to American homes for internet providers. Mr Murdoch has built up his satellite operations largely outside the US.

In a recent interview Mr Murdoch described his company as an industry "minnow". "I have to work harder than ever to have my values recognised by the market, so that we don't become a breakfast snack for these other big companies," he said.

fields.headline: Britannia
fields.trailText: Shares in Burmah Castrol have been stuck in the pits since year end, underperforming the FTSE all-share index by 4% and the specialist chemicals index by 5%.
fields.body:
Shares in Burmah Castrol have been stuck in the pits since year end, underperforming the FTSE all-share index by 4% and the specialist chemicals index by 5%.

But yesterday the shares climbed 3% in early trading as City analysts adjusted upwards future profit forecasts and "buy" recommendations were repeated.

Record pre-tax profits of £259m, up 5%, and ahead of market expectations, were the immediate cause for celebration and these were coupled with a bullish outlook for future trading prospects and a 10% rise to 47.3p in the dividend for the year.

Underlying enthusiasm stems from a feeling that Tim Stevenson, the new chief executive really has got a han dle on this under-performing business both in terms of costs and growth.

The company has struggled against tough trading environments in Asia and eastern Europe but these markets are now bouncing back strongly.

"Given a relatively benign trading environment, we expect to deliver another strong performance," said Mr Stevenson, who has masterminded a £150m shake-up which will cost 1,500 out of 18,500 jobs over four years.

Five plants have been closed and a couple more are expected to follow in India and Europe but the lubricants and services group is also interested in acquisitions, buying £60m worth of businesses in 1999.

Mr Stevenson played down worries about the 300% rise in crude oil prices, saying the base price of oil had risen much more slowly and had been masked by its own prices rises and cost cutting.

A partnership with Hyundai, mirroring a similar alliance with BMW signed last year, means Burmah Castrol will become the pre ferred brand for the Korean automobile manufacturer which makes 75% of all cars on the road in Seoul.

The agreement also involves sponsoring the Hyundai rally team from 2000 to 2002 and allows Castrol to break into the relatively closed but potentially lucrative Korean consumer market.

Mr Stevenson is keen to exploit the Castrol brand globally through the internet. The company bought web specialist CompanyNet two years ago but now says it is fine-tuning its future strategy for e-commerce.

"Castrol is a great brand with global recognition. It is one that people trust and represents premium quality. Some of these internet start-up companies would die for that," said Mr Stevenson.

Phillip Morrish, an analyst with Albert E Sharp, believes that Burmah Castrol is a future growth stock with plenty of hidden value. He thinks it is set for a hefty re-rating - and all this without the once-touted bid from BP Amoco in sight.

A partnership with Hyundai, mirroring a similar alliance with BMW signed last year, means Burmah Castrol will become the pre ferred brand for the Korean automobile manufacturer which makes 75% of all cars on the road in Seoul. The agreement also involves sponsoring the Hyundai rally team from 2000 to 2002 and allows Castrol to break into the relatively closed but potentially lucrative Korean consumer market. Mr Stevenson is keen to exploit the Castrol brand globally through the internet. The company bought web specialist CompanyNet two years ago but now says it is fine-tuning its future strategy for e-commerce. "Castrol is a great brand with global recognition. It is one that people trust and represents premium quality. Some of these internet start-up companies would die for that," said Mr Stevenson. Phillip Morrish, an analyst with Albert E Sharp, believes that Burmah Castrol is a future growth stock with plenty of hidden value. He thinks it is set for a hefty re-rating - and all this without the once-touted bid from BP Amoco in sight.

webTitle: Austin Reed shares rise as predator moves in

fields.headline: Austin Reed shares rise as predator moves in
fields.trailText: Austin Reed, the tailor favoured by Winston Churchill and Prince Charles, risks celebrating a centenary by losing its independence following a hostile bid yesterday which sent its shares rocketing 29%.
fields.body:
Austin Reed, the tailor favoured by Winston Churchill and Prince Charles, risks celebrating a centenary by losing its independence following a hostile bid yesterday which sent its shares rocketing 29%.

The very British store said it was "exploring options" for the future after an unnamed bidder made an offer which was immediately rejected as insufficient by the board.

Austin Reed is the third UK retailer in a week to be in the firing line as high street names fall victim to rock bottom stock market ratings. The shares ended the day up 24.5p at 107p but far short of their estimated 142p net asset value which would value the company at around £45m.

Analysts believe bidders could come from foreign groups such as Malayan United Industries, which holds a 40% stake in Laura Ashley, or a Japanese firm. But it might appeal for help from a UK rival such as Moss Bros.

Austin Reed has struggled as a maker of formal clothes in an era of more casual designer gear. It moved into womenswear with the acquisition of Country Casuals in 1998 but pre-tax profits have remained modest at £6m.

Churchill fell in love with Austin Reed tailoring during the second world war; he wanted a one-piece suit that he could put on in 10 seconds in the dark.

The zip-up "siren suit" was so successful that he asked for a replica - in velvet.

fields.headline: Schrempp fuels merger talk
fields.trailText: Jürgen Schrempp, DaimlerChrysler's chairman, yesterday fuelled speculation that the German-American carmaker is in active negotiations to take over or merge with another European group.
fields.body:
Jürgen Schrempp, DaimlerChrysler's chairman, yesterday fuelled speculation that the German-American carmaker is in active negotiations to take over or merge with another European group.

Reporting record profits of €11bn (£6.7bn) on €150bn sales, he admitted for the first time talks were taking place. "I can imagine that some time during this year there could be a transaction of some kind."

Sparkling sales figures for last year showed Daimler sold more than 1m Mercedes cars - an increase of 158,000 on 1998. The firm hopes to sell more than 100,000 of its 2m long Smart city car this year.

With Peugeot firmly ruled out, including yesterday by Mr Schrempp, Daimler is increasingly linked with Fiat, the Italian car maker, seen as the most vulnerable European player in a rapidly consolidating market.

Daimler has also been linked to Honda of Japan, a prospect given added force yesterday when Robert Eaton outgoing co-chairman, said DaimlerChrysler hoped to get 25% of its sales in Asia within 10 years. "This is where the most growth will be and our strategy is to pursue this either by acquisition or organic expansion," he told a news conference.

Renewed speculation that Daimler would drive forward the restructuring of the car industry boosted shares which had already gained ground after the company last week said that it would start an internet supply business with General Motors and Ford. Until then Daimler's shares had fallen 15% this year.

The group is seeking permission at its annual meeting on April 19 to buy back up to 10% of its stock - the maximum permitted.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
FSA targets top-up plans
An investigation launched yesterday into possible mis-selling of top-up pension plans over an 11-year period could trigger tax-free compensation payments of more than £200m, regulators said.
fields.body:
FSA targets top-up plans
An investigation launched yesterday into possible mis-selling of top-up pension plans over an 11-year period could trigger tax-free compensation payments of more than £200m, regulators said.

The financial services authority is appealing to past and present members of the armed forces, among others, to come forward if they think they were given bad advice.

The FSA added that material gathered during its review of the sale of free-standing additional voluntary contribution plans could provide the basis for disciplinary action against companies and advisers.

Welcoming details of the review, the industry said it was a "considered response". The Association of British Insurers said at present there was no evidence of mis-selling but the industry was co-operating fully.

Citigroup chief plans to retire

John Reed, the co-head of Citigroup, announced his plans to retire yesterday after a spate of management changes at the financial services company. Shares in Citigroup rose yesterday as analysts welcomed the long-expected announcement.

The share price was also boosted by the firm's plans to look for a successor to Sandy Weill, who is set to retire as chief executive in two years. The company's senior management structure, with joint heads of most divisions, has concerned analysts since Citigroup was formed by the combination of Citibank and Travelers, the financial services company headed by Mr Weill, in 1998.

Lloyd's court battle begins

The high court showdown between Lloyd's, the insurance market, and more than 200 diehard "names" - the private investors who backed the business - opened in London yesterday, but barristers' arguments will not be heard for another week.

Lloyd's is suing the names for losses of more than £51m, and the names are counter-claiming with accusations of fraud.

Mr Justice Cresswell yesterday held a pre-trial hearing to discuss administrative matters. The case will be heard at the courthouse in Chichester Rents.

webTitle: News Corp pumps $1bn into SingTel bid war

fields.headline: News Corp pumps $1bn into SingTel bid war
fields.trailText: News Corp said yesterday it had invested $1bn (£629m) cash in Singapore Telecom which may prove vital in the telecommunication group's bid for Cable & Wireless HKT.
fields.body:
News Corp said yesterday it had invested $1bn (£629m) cash in Singapore Telecom which may prove vital in the telecommunication group's bid for Cable & Wireless HKT.

The investment - in return for a 4% stake in SingTel - was said to be immediately available for investment, but may prove too late to satisfy HKT. Richard Li's 10-month old internet group Pacific Century Cyberworks has reputedly tabled a cash and share offer to HKT of £22.3bn or an all-share offer valued at £24.2bn.

The board of Cable & Wireless announced last month that it intended to merge its 54%-owned Hong Kong subsidiary with SingTel, allowing it to strip out cash from the operation and retain a one-third stake in the newly created group.

However, the emergence of PCCW as a serious bid der forced the CWC board to meet late yesterday afternoon to consider the internet group's offer.

The board is likely to favour the offer that comes with the highest level of cash in order to strengthen its own expansion as an internet access provider

webTitle: A listening cure for the NHS

fields.headline: A listening cure for the NHS
fields.standfirst:
The future of the NHS: special report

The advertising and market research industries could restore the health of the health service
fields.trailText: Why is the National Health Service - one of our undisputed national icons - so constantly sickly, so ill understood? Good news rarely makes good headlines, so most of the big news about the NHS will be bad news. There will always be lots of bad news: that is inherent in a massive medical service. And because the NHS is seen as a limb of government there will always be opposition politicians - whoever is in opposition - ready, willing and only too able to draw blood. Anyone who hopes the media will counter the bad news with good news is just chronically naive.
fields.body:
Why is the National Health Service - one of our undisputed national icons - so constantly sickly, so ill understood? Good news rarely makes good headlines, so most of the big news about the NHS will be bad news. There will always be lots of bad news: that is inherent in a massive medical service. And because the NHS is seen as a limb of government there will always be opposition politicians - whoever is in opposition - ready, willing and only too able to draw blood. Anyone who hopes the media will counter the bad news with good news is just chronically naive.

Could money solve all the problems? Manifestly the NHS has been starved of funds by successive governments, and shedloads more cash are acutely needed. But something else is needed, too. Like the Bank of England before it, the NHS needs to be severed from politics to a far greater extent than it ever has been. This is not a plea for privatisation: far from it. It is a plea for state-funded independence.

Put simply, the NHS needs a clear identity of its own. To build an identity that is sympathetic, rather than authoritarian, it will need to involve its customers - that means all of us - much more closely in its decision making processes. If it were a company, one would say it must switch from being production-led to being customer-led.

Almost every major economic organisation in the country now engages its customers, directly or indirectly, in decisions about the nature of the goods and services it offers, and thence about the deployment of its resources. The NHS does not.

In the NHS the medical establishment and its advisers still make all the key decisions. Patients' opinions hardly get a look in. Communication is a two-way process, and many hospitals, surgeries, doctors and nurses communicate with their local patients wonderfully. But the NHS doesn't communicate with its patients at all. Why not? There are a couple of plausible explanations. First, involving customers will cost money. In a cash-stretched NHS, surely every penny should go on medicine rather than communication?

Second, and more fundamentally, the apportionment of medical resources within the NHS is fiendishly complicated. Results can take years to achieve, the cost-effectiveness benefits are usually unquantifiable, and they can be disputed ad infinitum. How could ignorant patients contribute to such sophisticated debates? Would they not, almost inevitably, make the wrong diagnoses?

If those are the objections to the NHS becoming customer-led, allowing the situation to continue as it is will surely be lethal. The unremitting popular belief that things are going from bad to worse staunches recruitment like a tourniquet. Public discontent demoralises all those working in the NHS - doctors, nurses, therapists, administrators, everyone. Governments respond in panic to media flak, which hinders objective analysis, long-term planning and wise investment.

Governments, of all persuasions, lurch from side to side on a plethora of issues: the importance of hospital waiting lists, the primacy of life-threatening diseases, the price of drugs, the cost of treating the terminally ill, the acceptability of spending money on services - from cosmetic surgery to Viagra, from infertility to obesity, from pychoanalysis to regular screening - which maybe should not come within the NHS's bailiwick. What do the public think? Or don't their views matter?

To provide the NHS with greater independence and more public involvement would call for strong political will, and considerable managerial reorganisation. And to make it work, three key areas would need to be explored.

First, market research. Lacking a consumer market mechanism based on price, the NHS needs to develop its own research systems for investigating consumers' (the public's) views and opinions about needs and priorities. This will obviously not be easy. Respondents will need to have alternatives explained simply, the implications spelled out, and the issues brought out honestly. It will no doubt take time to develop researchers and techniques with the necessary diagnostic skills. There will doubtless be teething problems. But other industries have faced similar difficulties. They are not incurable.

Nor should it be assumed that the findings of such research would need to be followed slavishly by the medical profession. Far from it. Contrary to conventional opinion, neither businessmen nor politicians invariably follow market research findings. But it must always be right to know the public's views about important issues, especially when it is necessary to override them.

Second, identity. For the public to develop a greater trust in the NHS it is essential for it to have a clear and engaging identity. In crude terms this means a brand, a logo, a corporate design scheme. Without a clear visual identity the NHS will remain a nebulous entity. The NHS is a complicated concept with, as we have seen, fuzzy edges. It asks altogether too much of people to expect them to feel good about an abstract institution with no visible image, no public face.

Third, communication. Once the first two steps have been taken, there will be a strong case for communicating the whys and wherefores of the NHS to the public, by way of informative advertising, which would aim to redress the constant flow of bad news in the media. This will raise hackles, but would bolster public understanding, and simultaneously boost staff morale and recruitment - a standard task for corporate advertising of this kind. The campaign could incorporate a hotline, to generate interactive response. (Naturally it would be essential to divert personal medical enquiries to NHS Direct, but that again would not be impossible.)

The advertising (and other) communications should be both national and local. The aim would be to ensure the public appreciates and accepts the way its money is being spent on its health. And it would force the NHS to explain publicly what it was up to, which would be no bad thing. As medicine grows ever more intricate, and expensive, it will be increasingly vital for the medical profession to counter bad publicity and carry the public with them.

As everyone knows, by international standards expenditure on health and medical services in Britain is appallingly low, and the poorer income groups within the population suffer disproportionately. Discovering what the public wants, packaging it identifiably, and communicating what is being offered will, together, give the NHS more independence than it has ever had before. By NHS standards the costs would be minimal. And the treatment would improve the NHS's health and strength immeasurably.

Winston Fletcher was until recently chairman of the advertising agency Bozell UK

fields.headline: Rivals buy United Biscuits for £1.26bn
fields.trailText: United Biscuits last night fell into foreign hands with a £1.26bn offer from Finalrealm, the group that includes Danone of France, and Burlington Biscuits, which includes US food maker Nabisco.
fields.body:
United Biscuits last night fell into foreign hands with a £1.26bn offer from Finalrealm, the group that includes Danone of France, and Burlington Biscuits, which includes US food maker Nabisco.

UB is now set to be broken up by the French- and American-led consortiums - which had earlier fought each other to buy the snack food firm - after three months of uncertainty.

The Britishcompany had seen its share price plummet from 270p in May 1998 to less than 180p last year as surplus capacity in its factories eroded pricing clout with major food retailers.

Yesterday its shares ended 3p lower at 262p as investors worried that last-minute obstacles might prevent the takeover.

Finalrealm and Burlington Biscuits earlier won approval from the takeover panel for the combined offer.

The new offer was pitched at a 265p per share price that had earlier been submitted by Finalrealm and won acceptance from UB's board. Burlington had bought a 29% stake in UB and made its own 254p per share offer, while admitting it might raise this by yesterday's deadline.

The two former rivals will share out the UB empire, with Danone taking some parts of the British and south-east Asian operations in addition to everything in eastern Eu rope and Scandinavia. The French company will not have any financial interest in the bid vehicle.

Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, the Texas-based private equity group that is part of Burlington Biscuits, is expected to put together its assets from UB with those of Premier Brands, a food business it acquired with the takeover of Hillsdown Holdings.

This would produce a British foods business with a combined sales of nearly £1.2bn.

webTitle: Women get ready to pop the question

fields.headline: Women get ready to pop the question
fields.trailText: Nearly 80% of single women say they are prepared to pop the question and ask their partners to marry them on Leap Year's Day today, according to a survey.
fields.body:
Nearly 80% of single women say they are prepared to pop the question and ask their partners to marry them on Leap Year's Day today, according to a survey.

February 29 is traditionally the date when women can reverse the gender roles and ask for a man's hand in marriage. Of the 550 single women surveyed, 78% said they would happily take up the "hunter" mantle and do the asking.

Marriage counsellors Relate said fewer women are popping the question because marriage is more of a decision that couples reach jointly. A Relate spokeswoman warned women against forcing their lovers into a corner. "By proposing out of the blue, you are manipulating them into saying yes by putting them under pressure."

According to some theories, the tradition dates back to a Scottish law passed in 1288 allowing "maiden ladies of both high and low estate... the liberty to bespeke the man they like."

Any man refusing a Leap Year's Day proposal was fined £1 or less according to his means unless he could prove he was already betrothed to another.

The survey was conducted by the supermarket chain Somerfield.

fields.headline: Keep on running
fields.standfirst: You don't have to be a TV trivia addict to recall that the classic 60s show, The Fugitive, was inspired by the true story of Dr Sam Sheppard. But amazingly, it's a saga that's still working its way through the courts.  Lucy Barrick on a drama that just won't end
fields.trailText: You don't have to be a TV trivia addict to recall that the classic 60s show, The Fugitive, was inspired by the true story of Dr Sam Sheppard. But amazingly, it's a saga that's still working its way through the courts. Lucy Barrick on a drama that just won't end
fields.body:
A doctor accused of murdering his wife claims to be innocent, maintaining that a one-armed man he saw fleeing the crime scene is the real killer. The doctor later escapes from prison and dedicates his life to tracking down the murderer. That's the plot of The Fugitive, the 60s TV show, in which David Janssen starred as the ill-fated Dr Richard Kimble; the same premise was later recycled for a movie featuring Harrison Ford. All a little far-fetched, perhaps, but it pales in comparison with the real life events which inspired it, as detailed in The Fugitive: The Final Chapter (tonight, 9.30pm, BBC1).

"I didn't know The Fugitive was based on a true story," admits producer/director Mike Robinson. "I had no idea." That changed, however, when "the assistant producer Paul Dwyer saw a two-line story on the net about a new case involving Sam Sheppard, and it just went from there."

In a tale with all the elements of a classic thriller, Dr Sam Sheppard was accused of murdering his wife, Marilyn, on Independence Day 1954. His subsequent trial and conviction included accusations of adultery, the discovery his wife had been pregnant at the time of her death, and the doctor's mother committing suicide. The current court case, as documented tonight, is being brought by Sam Reese Sheppard, the couple's son - seven years old at the time of his mother's murder - for damages against the state of Ohio for the wrongful incarceration of his father.

Predictably, the new action has caused a huge resurgence of interest in the Sheppard case but, claims Robinson, "I rather imagined we'd be telling a mundane story about the few parallels between the real and fictional cases. What I didn't realise is just how many similarities there were." And, rather than simply re-stating the facts, the programme focuses on his discovery that "when real life departed from fiction, it was actually better than fiction".

It was this blurring of fantasy and reality which, Robinson explains, drew him to the story. "To be honest, it fascinates me," he says, "the whole idea of truth being stranger than fiction. Because if you took this story to a Hollywood producer, they'd say it was too unbelievable." Yet for the younger Sheppard - carefully described as "brittle" by Robinson - the consequences of summer 1954 were only too tangible.

From the very beginning, the Sheppard case has been conducted in the full glare of the spotlight. During the original trial, for instance, the newspaper bloodlust for the defend ent wasn't even concealed from the jury; equally, just as negative media attention helped to convict him, the positive influence of The Fugitive -first aired in 1963 - is now credited with inspiring Sheppard's release a year later, when his conviction was deemed unsound.

"The only reason we're interested now", Robinson admits, "is because of The Fugitive." For Sam Reese Sheppard, meanwhile, "it was very difficult, knowing that part of our history was being used as a device in the public field of public entertainment to make money. But it did keep interest in the Sheppard case alive, and it has done so to this very day. It's very powerful."

After his release, Sheppard's life began to take on a very different complexion from the the placid, studious life of a Cleveland, Ohio neuro-surgeon. "He was not the middle-class physician healer that he was before," his son recalls. This, you sense, is his way of explaining his father's increasingly vociferous addictions to drugs and alcohol. Following which, Robinson says, he was flabbergasted by the way "art appeared to mirror life - and then life became far, far stranger than the art it had inspired."

As he researched Sheppard's life after his release - which saw him marry a German woman, Ariane - Robinson discovered a number of seemingly outlandish details. Firmly maintaining his matter-of-fact manner, he remembers his discovery that Ariane's half sister had been married to Joseph Goebbels (yes, that Joseph Goebbels). "It was one of those things referred to as 'a fact too good to check'," he laughs. "I mean, we couldn't believe it. But we just had to keep checking. And yes, she did marry him. Yes, Hitler really was the best man." In terms of presenting the story to the viewer, Robinson calls this revelation (along with the doctor having later turned to pro wrestling under the name Killer Sheppard) "absolutely priceless".

Yet, while the facts that are known about Sheppard are astounding, it's the search for a potentially unknowable truth that keeps the case open. Does Robinson think Sheppard was guilty? "I don't know", he ponders, despite the amount of time he's spent on the case. "When you talk to people, you hear the arguments both ways. What we tried to do with the film was portray the strengths and weakness of each side." And, he's at pains to point out, while Sheppard Jr is hardly the most congenial of subjects, "you don't know what he went through at the time, and what he still goes through. The danger is people judging his father's innocence by judging the son."

After his release, Sheppard was tried again in 1966 and found not guilty. In his film Robinson places two jurors, one from each trial, together to discuss their different verdicts. The juror from 1954 appears convinced the guilty verdict was correct but, Robinson reveals, "this is something like his 100th interview on the case" - which may have given him the chance to hone his vehemence. Still, if two juries couldn't agree, what does Sam Reese Sheppard stand to gain from bringing this new case now? "On one level," Robinson says, "you have to question him doing this so long after his father's death. On another, he was a seven-year-old boy who lost both his parents, and was then caught in this unholy spectacle because of The Fugitive connection."

After all, most of his life has been spent watching his father's story filtered back to him as entertainment; now, whatever the outcome, Robinson believes that "this is, at heart, the story of how in one night an entirely ordinary family became public property".
