fields.headline: Minister accuses Blair aides minister
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair came under renewed attack last night for alienating Labour's grassroots when a home office minister and the newly-elected leader of Britain's largest trade union waded into the row over the leadership's treatment of heartland supporters.
fields.body:
Tony Blair came under renewed attack last night for alienating Labour's grassroots when a home office minister and the newly-elected leader of Britain's largest trade union waded into the row over the leadership's treatment of heartland supporters.

Less than 24 hours after John Prescott admitted that the Labour leadership was failing to inspire its core voters, the home office minister, Charles Clarke, accused Downing Street of deliberately provoking rows with traditional supporters.

His remarks came as Dave Prentis, the new leader of the public service union Unison, warned that voters would desert Labour because of the government's failure to improve services.

Downing Street is likely to brush off the criticisms from Mr Prentis, who was yesterday elected as general secretary of Unison, as the usual trade union whingeing.

But the concerns of Mr Clarke, who used to be one of Labour's most powerful figures when he served as Neil Kinnock's chief of staff, will be more difficult to dismiss.

In an interview with BBC Online, Mr Clarke said that Downing Street appeared to take delight in distancing itself from the party's heartlands.

"I think sometimes there have been points at which the group around Tony, with or without his agreement I don't know, have sometimes sought to distinguish themselves from certain elements within Labour," he said. Mr Clarke said that figures in Downing Street - dismissed last year by Mr Prescott as the "faceless wonders" - appeared to go out of their way to provoke leftwingers such as the foreign office minister, Peter Hain, who claimed last year that New Labour was being "gratuitously offensive" to its own supporters.

"I think there were some people around Tony at some points who thought there was political advantage to be gained from sparking such a reaction," said Mr Clarke, who refuses to describe himself as "New Labour".

His remarks were echoed by Mr Prentis who warned the prime minister of the dangers of failing to listen to public sector workers.

Mr Prentis, who revealed that Unison planned to seek a judicial review of government proposals to give priority to private contractors in local government services, said: "As far as public service workers are concerned, the government hasn't delivered on its promises. There is a serious danger of a substantial part of the electorate deserting Labour."

Mr Prentis warned that Downing Street's failure to de liver on its commitments would not just dent Labour's support among core voters.

"It is not just about traditional voters - middle England wants its hospitals and its schools and if the government doesn't deal with the underfunding crisis, they will walk away," he said.

Such criticism from an official who is regarded as middle-of the road reflects the fright Unison's leadership had last month, when early feedback from its leadership campaign pointed to a possible victory for Roger Bannister, Mr Prentis' main leftist opponent.

In the event, Mr Prentis - who takes over from Rodney Bickerstaffe next January - won 125,584 votes, compared to 71,021 for Mr Bannister on a 17% turnout.

Mr Prentis yesterday called for a more serious dialogue with the government, attacking the "bias towards the private sector" in the government's best value and private finance initiative policies.

The criticisms from Mr Clarke and Mr Prentis came after the prime minister warned, in his Labour party anniversary speech on Sunday, that he would not bow to pressure from disillusioned activists.

webTitle: Hopefuls buy their way into California's front rooms

fields.headline: Hopefuls buy their way into California's front rooms
fields.standfirst:
The US elections: special report

Super Tuesday - a week to go TV ads swamp the west coast, while Christian rows hit the Republicans
fields.trailText: The bombardment has started. All four main US presidential candidates are investing millions of dollars in commercials to win hearts and minds in California before America's "super Tuesday" primary on March 7.
fields.body:
The bombardment has started. All four main US presidential candidates are investing millions of dollars in commercials to win hearts and minds in California before America's "super Tuesday" primary on March 7.

As befits a contest where "character" is, at the moment, deemed more important than policy, almost all the ads are emphasising their candidate's steely resolve, individuality and sense of purpose.

Character comes into it too in the other, role-playing, sense of the word as the presidential hopefuls parade endlessly across the small screens in the living rooms of California: the war hero, the sports star, the man braving the elements. All with scripts hammering home the metaphors, on the remote chance anybody has missed the point.

For the Republican frontrunner, George W Bush, the sky is the limit. Because he decided not to take the federal funding available during the primary polls, he is not subject to the $40m (£25m) spending ceiling imposed by law.

No previous candidate has ever spent so much by this point in the campaign calendar - $60m in all, around four times that raised by his rival for the Republican nomination, John McCain.

Mr Bush, the Texas governor, has also spent more than any other candidate on direct sales and telemarketing.

The McCain team is going for an image of courage and patriotism. In its ad, a grainy black and white photo shows a handsome young fighter pilot. He could be any of Hollywood's brat pack auditioning for a war movie but he is, of course, John McCain before he was shot down over North Vietnam in 1967.

The ad's voice-over tells viewers: "A young navy pilot who volunteered for duty in Vietnam, John McCain, was shot down over Hanoi. McCain refused early release from prison where he suffered repeated beatings and was held for 5 years. He returned home just as devoted to his country, taking on the establishment."

Mr McCain then goes on to assure people that he will "give the government back to you". The voice-over picks up and declares that he is "ready to be president and leader of the free world".

Mr Bush goes on far outspending all those who stand in his path, including the two main contenders as Democratic presidential nominee: California is seen as the best place to put the money because of the prizes involved. In and outside the state he is currently spending at the rate of $400,000 (£250,000) a day.

The Republican victor in this state will take 162 delegates out of a national total of 2,066 who will vote at the party's convention later this year on who becomes their candidate for president. The Democrat stands to win 434 in California out of a national 4,336.

More important is the psychological effect in the pre-election primaries of winning the country's most populous state of 33m people.

Mr Bush answers the McCain claim to the high ground in a commercial where he talks straight to camera: "Disagree with me - fine - but do not challenge my integrity." He ads: "I fight for what I believe in and I get results."

Bill Bradley, contending for the Democratic party's nomination, also has a past - as a basketball star. He has used it to bring an all-American hero and basketball star of recent years, Michael Jordan, into his campaign.

In the Bradley commercial that features him, Jordan says: "I know the kind of America I want for my children. It's a place where every family has health and no family suffers the tragedy of gun violence, [where] every American has the opportunity to succeed and be viewed equally."

There is a shot of Mr Bradley and his wife, Ernestine, standing by a shoreline looking wistful. The closing line is, "It could happen."

This week came a more upbeat message - "What makes Bill Bradley a winner?" - showing him as a young Rhodes scholar and as a basketball star. This leads to the ad's conclusion: "When Bill Bradley wins, you win. But first, you've got to give him the ball."

Mr Bradley's team has also decided to try to undermine the Democrat frontrunner, Al Gore. A 60-second ad campaign on radio urges people to look at a website set up to pose questions about the vice-president - moreaboutgore.com - and deliver what are intended to be damning answers.

In the website ad, a female voice says: "As a conservative congressman from Tennessee, Al Gore voted against a woman's right to choose 84% of the time ... Al Gore voted against strengthening an assault weapons ban and against gun control so often that the National Rifle Association said 'We could have made Al Gore NRA man of the year'."

The vice-president hits back with a commercial in which James Brady, the aide paralysed by a bullet aimed at President Reagan in 1981, praises Mr Gore: "He's taken on the gun lobby."

In another commercial, Mr Gore is shown as a mountaineer, the belief being that health-conscious Californians like an outdoor man. He is seen with his son climbing the 14,000ft Mt Rainier in Washington state. In the voice-over, the president of the American alpine club, Jim Frush, compliments Mr Gore for not turning back despite bad conditions.

"Strength of character, perseverance, grace under pressure - these are qualities you look for in a mountaineer; they're even better in a president."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.body:
Once Upon A Time... When We Were Coloured (Tim Reid, 1996) 6pm, Sky MovieMax

Likeable, intermittently powerful adaptation of the book that Nelson Mandela requested on his release from prison. Despite an inexperienced director and emotive subject matter - the lives of four generations of an African-American ghetto in pre-desegregation 50s Mississippi - the movie generally steers clear of the pitfalls of didacticism and manipulativeness, and any schmaltz that does creep in is quickly forgiven.

Mad City (Costa-Gavras, 1997) 10pm, Sky Premier

Like any good newshound, Dustin Hoffman's TV reporter Max is in the city museum the very day John Travolta's sacked security man Sam (pictured) blows a gasket, shooting a colleague and barricading himself in with a class of schoolkids as hostages. Max, his career on hold, sees a chance to use the siege to his advantage, just like Kirk Douglas in Ace In The Hole. This isn't as compelling but it's brilliantly acted.

Merry Xmas, Mr Lawrence (Nagisa Oshima, 1982) 10.05pm, UK Arena

Bridge On The River Kwai as pop video, with West and East rock icons David Bowie and Ryuichi Sakamoto clashing as PoW and Japanese officer in a second world war prison camp: a confrontation that lands Bowie up to his neck in trouble. More convincing are Tom Conti as a sensitive, suffering soul, and cult hardman-come-auteur Takeshi Kitano's brutal sergeant. Adapted from Laurens Van Der Post's novel.

Shanghai Triad (Yimou Zhang, 1995) 3.10am, Sky Premier

Full of the sumptuous imagery of the likes of Raise The Red Lantern and Ju Dou, this is a hard-edged tale of Shanghai's gangsters. Viewed through the innocent eyes of a teenager (Wang Xiaoxiao), it has rival gangsters in bloody conflict while Gong Li, as mistress of one of them and celebrated music hall singer, attempts to get free of the mess. It's not one of Zhang Yimou's best, but frankly if Gong Li was in Police Academy 28, she'd make it worth watching.

webTitle: Marguerite was Margot Fonteyn's role. No one else has performed it. Until now

fields.headline: Marguerite was Margot Fonteyn's role. No one else has performed it. Until now
fields.standfirst: Sylvie Guillem talks to  Judith Mackrell about following in Fonteyn's footsteps
fields.trailText: Sylvie Guillem talks to Judith Mackrell about following in Fonteyn's footsteps
fields.body:
In 1963, Frederick Ashton turned Alexandre Dumas's play La Dame aux Camélias into a ballet called Marguerite and Armand for Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev. The buzz surrounding the ballet, which charted the affair between a fiery youth and a consumptive courtesan, was extraordinary. After Nureyev's defection in 1961, the world had become transfixed by the chemistry between him and Britain's greatest ballerina, a woman nearly twice his age. The public avidly speculated that their on-stage electricity was generated by a secret love affair. Given Nureyev's homosexuality and Fonteyn's saintly commitment to her husband this was unlikely. But it was a story everyone wanted to believe.

Fifty photographers attended its dress rehearsal, and the first-night audience reacted so enthusiastically that the stars took 21 curtain calls. The ballet became known as Nureyev and Fonteyn's signature piece, and so infused was it with their personalities that no one else has ever performed it. After their deaths (hers in 1991, his, prematurely, in 1993), it was assumed the ballet had died also. Yet this season the Royal Ballet has, unexpectedly, brought Marguerite and Armand back to the stage.

The woman chosen to dance the legendary Fonteyn role is Sylvie Guillem. It is easy to see why Anthony Dowell, the Royal's director, should turn to her. She's one of the few ballerinas who can match Fonteyn's starry eminence, and she has the artistic clout to perform the role. Yet when Dowell first approached her three years ago, she turned him down, feeling that it was too soon after the deaths of the original stars.

When I asked her last week why she'd finally agreed to risk it, Guillem was lying on a couch with her left leg wired up by her physiotherapist to a pain-relieving Tens machine. She was trying to limit the damage from a kick inadvertently delivered by her partner, Johnny Cope, during rehearsal. The fact that she was captive for at least 30 minutes may have explained her unusually relaxed manner. When she talked about her readiness to dance Marguerite, there was a gleam of mischief in her grey-blue eyes. "I said, why not? It's a ballet, I'm a ballerina - and it's a beautiful part. It's not going to please a lot of people but you know, this is not a ballet called Rudolf and Margot. It is called Marguerite and Armand."

Guillem's English is good but she enunciates the ballet's title with a strong French accent and it's clear that she regards it as equal parts Dumas and Ashton, equal parts French and English. It's also clear, when I watch her rehearsing, that she intends to have her own way with the role. She's not portraying Marguerite as an older woman, as Fonteyn had to, but as the original 23-year-old heroine. Nor is she imitating Fonteyn's style. Guillem's extravagantly supple body and long, lean lines inevitably shape the steps differently from Fonteyn's decorously proportioned physique and she is able to match Armand's feral emotion with muscular attack.

Cope, who is partnering her at some performances, enthusiastically approves of Guillem's approach. "Sylvie does it very much in her own style. She is more worldly than Margot, much less proper. She comes across almost as herself. The role suits her character the way Manon does. I think she'll have a hit with this."

Manon, ballet's other famous courtesan created by Kenneth MacMillan in 1974, is a role in which Guillem scintillates. Interestingly, Marguerite and Armand, in its visceral body language and the torrid dynamics of its pas de deux, resembles MacMillan's style more closely than anything else Ashton choreographed. Yet Guillem feels that the ballet retains the subtlety and compression for which Ashton was noted. "It's really concentrated. The more I do the choreography the more I see all its nuances. In 30 minutes Marguerite goes through the whole of her life, so I have to understand all the musicality of the choreography, all the tiny bits that make everything clear."

In 1963 some dissenters complained that the ballet was no more than a kitsch vehicle for its star personalities. Guillem, who has a fastidious nose for weak or illogical choreography, disagrees. "It's a beautiful ballet, very well made, very refined. The more I work on it, the more I see in it."

Certainly she's gone deep into the background of her role, studying both the play and the earlier novel from which Dumas adapted his work, and analysing the lovers' relationship with her guest partner Nicholas Le Riche. But the role needs charisma as well as intelligence - and this Guillem has in spades.

Even in rehearsal, with her hair bundled into a straggling plait and her long, clever face looking pale with fatigue, she simply makes you stare. Her body can move with the singing precision of a fine blade, but it can also look frail. She will look gorgeous in Marguerite's finery. She will probably die with heroic piteousness.

The fact that Guillem has been honoured with this precious scrap of the Royal Ballet's heritage perhaps signals that relations have grown warmer between the company and its starry guest. When Guillem first started dancing in London many thought she was arrogant. "There is a false idea that I am stubborn and do only what I want, but really I am like a sponge. I have learned a lot from this company," she says, but admits that "it is in my nature to be a little shy. It takes time for me to talk to people and trust them."

She also says there is a world of difference between working freelance (as she does) and being a company member. "I can't have friends in every port. I have to work very hard and be very clear about what I want to do. I cannot just swallow everything I am told. I have to decide what I want to become part of my lug gage, and what I don't." Guillem uses travel metaphors a lot (she performs extensively in London, Paris, Italy, Japan and the US) and while she cherishes her freedom she says it consumes much of her energy. "Everything I do is my own choice. A performance is like a boat. You really want it to arrive at port. So when something goes wrong and it doesn't get there, that touches me a lot." She finds it bizarre that some dancers become so institutionalised they lose their urgency. "You see a few like that in companies everywhere. They come to the theatre as if they were going to a market to buy leeks. They don't care if they perform or not. I find it strange not to be a little bit proud of what you do."

Despite her nomadic spirit Guillem is pleased to be spending more time in London this year. She loves the new Royal Opera House and insists several times that she likes "this company very much. I travel a lot, and it makes me appreciate the quality that is here."

There was some speculation that she might even direct the Royal after Dowell leaves, particularly given her recent success in staging Giselle for Finnish National Ballet. But while she loved that experience it made her aware of how time-consuming running a company would be, given that at 35 she still has much dancing to do. "One day, though," she muses, "why not?" She raises her hand to her eyes as if scanning this distant possibility, then shrugs. "But I never make plans that far ahead."

fields.headline: Blood, saints and tears
fields.standfirst: An exhibition devoted to images of Christ brings out the doubting Thomas in  Adrian Searle
fields.trailText: An exhibition devoted to images of Christ brings out the doubting Thomas in Adrian Searle
fields.body:
Walking into Seeing Salvation, the National Gallery exhibition devoted to the image of Christ, is a bit of a shock. We are taken from third- or fourth-century Roman tomb inscriptions to William Holman Hunt's 1904 painting The Light of the World within a couple of steps: from the tomb to the pits with a turn of the head. Hunt's painting, with its sickly, spooky light, was so popular he painted it three times. This largest version was sent on a world tour by its owner and drew crowds wherever it went.

There were those who claimed to have been profoundly affected by it. This is difficult to imagine today, not simply because we live in a secular age but because it is impossible to empathise with this work as a painting, much less as an object of devotion. While it was attracting the crowds in Melbourne, I remind myself, Picasso was painting the Demoiselles d'Avignon. Somehow, those roughly engraved fish and good shepherds on the stones from the Roman catacombs seem more alive, have more urgency and vitality than the Light of the World.

Recoiling from Hunt, you turn to face Francisco de Zurbaran's The Bound Lamb, painted in the 1630s. If the show continues like this, you think, Damien Hirst's lamb in formaldehyde will be around the next corner. Thankfully, Seeing Salvation isn't quite that corny. Nor is the National Gallery's director, Neil MacGregor, trying to do a hip vicar act. But the exhibition, and the TV series that accompanies it (to be broadcast on BBC2 in the run-up to Easter), as well as MacGregor's forthcoming lecture tour, must take into account that artists, and the church, have always tried to bring Christ up to date.

MacGregor believes the works in the exhibition "explore truths not just for Christians, but for everybody". For a non-believer, or those who belong to other faiths, this may at times be hard to take. European, Christian art is filled with pain and death, as well as the miraculous and redemptive. Somehow, the pain is more believable. What is the truth of a wound? There are some grim and appalling things in the exhibition: a German devotional booklet from 1330-40, with its illustrations of pincers, scourges, the paraphernalia of torture and death, which look all the more chilling for their plain, coloured-in, picture-book drawing. A 17th-century German prayer sheet, replete with close-ups of weeping wounds and bloody nails rimed with flesh. A sculpted Florentine terracotta Christ, from the 15th century, holding open the gaping hole in his side, to show us all the better. Ribalta's painting of Saint Thomas, embracing Christ on the cross, about to lick the bloody spear-wound slit, with an almost erotic fervour. Green-pallored depositions, sallow entombments, roseated, whipped, blood-gushing and spurting Christs, cowed, miserable Men of Sorrows - if one had no inkling what all this was about, and its historical and religious context, one would find it all bizarre and terrible.

And full of pathos. There is something piteous about a tiny cradle, made for a nun to keep in her cell as an object of devotion. Or the late- 15th-century papier-mache mask of Christ's face, crowned with thorns, a ruined little thing, to be hung from a thread. Its survival alone is miraculous. Dirk Bouts's Entombment, from the National Gallery, hangs near a sculpture, Christ on the Cold Stone, from a museum in Utrecht. This naked figure, hunched and thin, awaits his destiny. He is just a man on a rock, covering his genitals with one hand, supporting his head with the other. Behind him is his future, where he looks like any other dead man. Both the sculpture and the painted Christ look undernourished and vulnerable. For them, the miracle must wait. Often, it is the things that these artworks and artefacts leave out that gives them their continuing power.

Zurbaran's lamb of God shows us nothing more or less than a lamb like any other, with its feet crossed and bound, laying on a simple slab, awaiting slaughter. It is a wonderful painting. All the light in the painting falls on to the docile creature, which is surrounded by darkness. The drama is so furtive, so dependent on what you know is going to happen to the sheep, but which the sheep doesn't. The light falling on the lamb is austere, common daylight. The light of nature which doesn't care what lives or dies. The painting says everything and nothing; it is its own mystery, its own ritual. It is as close to a universal image as one can find here.

A late-15th-century Netherlandish Nativity at Night, by Geertgen, shows us the Virgin and attendant angels illuminated by the new-born Christ, who is himself luminous - a glow-in-the-dark baby Jesus, as impossible to take seriously as Hunt's Light of the World. Somehow, we know too much for such images to be believable except in the most symbolic way.

Rutilio Manetti's The Stigmatisation of Saint Catherine of Siena, from about 1630, has red laser beams shooting across to the swooning Dominican nun from a medieval painted crucifix, zapping her with Christ's stigmata. This is indeed an extraordinary painting, both compositionally and in terms of the realisation of its subject, yet the illumination in the Zurbaran is so much more convincing, and more moving and miraculous, than all these made-up spiritual evanescences. We're neither astonished nor alarmed by weird auras, glowing halos, and painted otherworldly phenomena. They may speak of a spiritual, rather than an everyday reality, but the painted machinery gets in the way, and their capacity to astound has been lost.

Similarly, Salvador Dali's spectacular painting in which we get a god's eye-view of the crucified Christ, reaching escape velocity over the coast of Catalonia, looks like a cheap trick. The centrepiece of the final room in the show, Dali's painting does at least attempt a kind of cinematic contemporaneity. Stanley Spencer's Cookham Resurrection and his Christ heading for a home counties Calvary speak a language I for one am immune to, as does Graham Sutherland's twitchy, overworked cartoon for his tapestry in Coventry cathedral. It is simply second rate, however devout Sutherland may have been. Spencer's paintings may be authentically visionary (as were Samuel Palmer's or William Blake's) but I find myself unable to enter their worlds.

The problem isn't the required leap of faith itself, so much as my doubts about them as art. The story of the life of Christ endures with far more power in contemporary literature and film. Nobel prize- winning Portuguese novelist Jose Saramago and Norman Mailer have both penned fictive gospels according to Jesus himself; Pier Paolo Pasolini's The Gospel According to St Matthew, Martin Scorsese's The Last Temptation of Christ and Dennis Potter's 60s TV play, Son of Man, have more power than almost all contemporary Christian art.

Images of Christ have long been in decline (even before Gauguin's Yellow Christ, one of the better 19th-century paintings of the crucifixion), but we haven't entirely left the spiritual in art behind. Those works which address the spiritual often speak of its lack, or absence, rather than of spiritual presence. The reasons for this parallel the absence of shared spiritual values, a shared mythology and visual language for such things. There is no prohibition on images of gods, prophets, heaven and hell, or even of Jesus himself, but it is difficult to know how to depict him.

One of the last images in the exhibition is a photograph of Mark Wallinger's Ecce Homo, his sculpture for the fourth plinth in Trafalgar Square, which has lately been removed to make way for a sculpture by Bill Woodrow. Wallinger's figure is about to be temporarily installed beside the Duomo in Milan. I've driven in a car with Wallinger's model for his everyman Christ. He's just like you or me, and you wouldn't pick him out in a crowd. The figure on the plinth proclaimed nothing more than its life-sized presence, standing in the light, to be measured against the world about him, and the distance we've come in our depictions of the Son of God, whoever he might be.

 Seeing Salvation: The Image of Christ is at the National Gallery, London WC2, till May 7. Details: 0171-747 2885.

fields.headline: Side lines
fields.trailText: The return of Randy Andy | Picketing since '95
fields.body:
Hooray for golf. He met her at the Ryder cup; he's a golf fanatic, so is she. All the signs are that dear Prince Andrew has met his perfect match in the "French beauty" Audrey Rimbaud (aside from the fact that she is also too posh for her own good). The only baffling thing about this otherwise fullproof match is that last week "Randy Andy" was apparently "entertaining" the model and presenter Caprice. Sidelines is sure the sudden rush of young blondes in this ageing royal's life are mutually fulfilling relationships... rather than cynical attempts to make him interesting in the cheapest way possible.

 Congratulations to the 25 domestic women workers at Hillingdon Hospital in west London, the UK's longest strikers, who are celebrating after their employers agreed to negotiate over a return to their old jobs. They have been on the picket line since 1995, protesting about erosion of their terms and conditions.

 If ducks are anything to go by, a handsome man is worth his weight in gold. Research by the University of Cambridge has found that female mallards lay larger, heavier eggs when partnered with attractive males. The findings could cause problems if females are investing more in preferred males in other species. A word of advice for the beautiful men out there: when it comes to birds and eggs, the old question about which came first still stands.

 Women's minister Baroness Jay spoke last week at an Institute of Public Policy Research lecture on Women and Financial Independence, urging women to upgrade their computer skills ("Women will need to be confident users of new technologies" blah blah). Why, then, has the Guardian had 13 calls from people searching for info on the Women's Incomes report, having checked the Women's Unit website and found it was last updated in October?

 For all those of you out there eager to join the National Women's Register featured on yesterday's women's page, call 01603 406767.

Sidelines is sure the sudden rush of young blondes in this ageing royal's life are mutually fulfilling relationships... rather than cynical attempts to make him interesting in the cheapest way possible.  Congratulations to the 25 domestic women workers at Hillingdon Hospital in west London, the UK's longest strikers, who are celebrating after their employers agreed to negotiate over a return to their old jobs. They have been on the picket line since 1995, protesting about erosion of their terms and conditions.  If ducks are anything to go by, a handsome man is worth his weight in gold. Research by the University of Cambridge has found that female mallards lay larger, heavier eggs when partnered with attractive males. The findings could cause problems if females are investing more in preferred males in other species. A word of advice for the beautiful men out there: when it comes to birds and eggs, the old question about which came first still stands.  Women's minister Baroness Jay spoke last week at an Institute of Public Policy Research lecture on Women and Financial Independence, urging women to upgrade their computer skills ("Women will need to be confident users of new technologies" blah blah). fields.headline: Seduced by Miss Julie
fields.standfirst: Strindberg wrote 60 startling plays - but only a couple are seen in British theatres.  Michael Billington investigates
fields.trailText: Strindberg wrote 60 startling plays - but only a couple are seen in British theatres. Michael Billington investigates
fields.body:
Miss Julie is back: a new production, starring Christopher Eccleston and Aisling O'Sullivan, opens in London tonight. But it sometimes seems as if August Strindberg's aristocratic, seductive heroine is never away. Of the Swedish dramatist's 60 plays this remains the most popular in Britain, partly because it is short, realistic and combines the sex and class wars in a way we can recog nise. One just wishes our theatre would range more widely over the work of this uncomfortable genius.

Strindberg, who died in 1912, is the father of modern drama for many playwrights. Shaw dubbed him "among the greatest of the great." O'Neill called him "the most modern of moderns". O'Casey said "he shakes flame from the living planets: Ibsen can sit serenely in his Doll's House while Strindberg is battling with his heaven and his hell." You can see his fingerprint on many modern writers, from John Osborne and Harold Pinter to Tennessee Williams and Edward Albee.

It is easy to see why Strindberg attracts such admiration. He writes about sex, in particular the indivisibility of love and loathing, with candour. He understands the inconsistencies of the human character - in his preface to Miss Julie, written in 1888, he talks of "the multiplicity of motives which is typical of our times". In his Chamber plays he cuts straight to the dramatic bone. And in those weird late works, such as Storm and The Ghost Sonata, he attempts to imitate the inconsequential logic of dreams. Above all, he accords with our appetite for the extreme. In the words of the novelist, Knut Hamsun, he flung himself at everything "with a kind of jubilant rage".

But Strindberg presents problems. Having started out as a vehement socialist, republican and freethinker, he became increasingly anti-feminist, reactionary and pious. He seemed to embrace endless opposites: radical and fascistic, atheistic and religious, scientific and occultist, sane and insane. In his demented later phase, he could be found doing a dance of exorcism round restaurant pots and pans to chase away evil spirits. Yet he was also a shrewd theatrical pioneer who uncannily foresaw the possibilities of intimate theatres and fluid dramatic form.

If we are to understand Strindberg properly, we have to understand that his neurosis and his genius were inextricably intertwined. Robert Brustein pointed out in Who Needs Theatre that in the US Strindberg's plays are rarely staged lest they arouse the ire of feminists. Thankfully we have not reached that degree of intellectual panic in this country. What I would like to see is more Strindberg staged in Britain. Not just the big three - The Father, Miss Julie and The Dance of Death - but some of the rarer works such as To Damascus, There Are Crimes and Crimes and The Pelican. But we also need to tackle Strindberg with a greater awareness of his essential impurity: of his ability to mix the tragic and the comic, the naturalistic and the symbolic with a furious disregard for academic categories.

Looking back over the great Strindberg productions I have seen, I am struck by their tonic mixture of opposites. Of the Miss Julies, the one that sticks in my mind is Ingmar Bergman's Swedish version that came to the 1986 Edinburgh festival. Bergman showed that this is a three-character play rather than an erotic pas de deux: that the valet's fiancée, Kristin, is a vibrant, sensual rival to Miss Julie. Bergman also endowed this supposedly naturalistic tragedy with a rich scenic symbolism, conjuring a Swedish summer night with a violent access of dawn sunlight finally exposing the characters in all their flaws.

Giorgio Strehler's Piccolo Teatro production of Storm - translated in English by Eivor Martinus as Thunder in the Air - similarly turned this late chamber play into a vividly realistic theatrical dream with a complex design and soundtrack. As the aged hero sat awaiting death in a prickly heat we saw fragments of his past life in subliminal lightning flashes. And one of the landmark Strindberg productions remains the National's 1967 Dance of Death: Olivier and Geraldine McEwan showed that this portrait of a doomed, disastrous 25-year-long marriage was shot through with wild, sardonic comedy.

By the time Miss Julie opens in London I shall be en route for Adelaide where The Dance of Death is among the works on offer. It will be fascinating to see whether Australians find Strindberg funny. I wish that we could all range over the Strindberg canon and embrace the febrile contradictions of his work. Just as he seems a prototype modern man, in that his instincts were constantly at war with themselves, so his plays speak to us precisely because they offer a fierce contest of opposites.

 Miss Julie opens at the Theatre Royal Haymarket, London SW1 (0171-930 8800), tonight.

fields.headline: Vintage YSL
fields.standfirst: Gossip as compelling as clothes at Paris show
fields.trailText: A web of intrigue surrounded yesterday's Yves Saint Laurent Rive Gauche presentation at Paris fashion week, where the gossip was as compelling as the clothes. Since Tom Ford, the creative director of Gucci, took control of Saint Laurent on January 1, the fashion world has been placing bets on when YSL's head designer, Alber Elbaz, would be dethroned. Elbaz has completed only two seasons of his three year contract with YSL, but it is assumed that Ford will buy him out. For why purchase one of the world's most prestigious labels if you can't design it yourself?
fields.body:
A web of intrigue surrounded yesterday's Yves Saint Laurent Rive Gauche presentation at Paris fashion week, where the gossip was as compelling as the clothes. Since Tom Ford, the creative director of Gucci, took control of Saint Laurent on January 1, the fashion world has been placing bets on when YSL's head designer, Alber Elbaz, would be dethroned. Elbaz has completed only two seasons of his three year contract with YSL, but it is assumed that Ford will buy him out. For why purchase one of the world's most prestigious labels if you can't design it yourself?

At 64, Yves Saint Laurent is in frail health, but he still designs his haute couture collections twice a year. He is regarded as one of the greats: his mannish tuxedos, safari suits and blazers redefined the modern woman's wardrobe. Yet Elbaz was often seen to get the balance wrong. Last season, he was criticised for not being true to the label's original spirit.

For autumn/winter 2000, Elbaz responded with a collection that was vintage YSL, reworked in autumn's favourite fabric, leather. Calf-length leather coats with high collars came belted at the waist, while lean leather dresses had full blouson sleeves and drop-waists. Saint Laurent's trademark pinstripe trouser suits were here, as were his voluminous, high-necked chiffon blouses and tailored pencil skirts.

This was an elegant, sensual and refined collection, in sophisticated colours such as cream, gold, russet and black. But it won't be enough to stop the onslaught of the Gucci machine. In the front row at the show was a relaxed Ford, tanned and in an expensive cashmere coat, waving to friends.

The question is: will Ford continue to head Gucci as well as take over at YSL? With the twice-yearly fashion schedule becoming tighter, it is a tall order for anyone to design four collections a year. Designers including Stella McCartney, Jeremy Scott and Hedi Slimane have been in talks with Ford recently, but speculation surrounds the nature of their liaisons. The man who hasn't made a wrong move yet is making no rash decisions.

webTitle: Mitsubishi says Britain must join euro soon

fields.headline: Mitsubishi says Britain must join euro soon
fields.standfirst: Electronics giant says it may quit UK if single currency is ruled out
fields.trailText: The UK head of the Japanese electronics giant Mitsubishi yesterday urged Britain to join the single currency "as soon as possible", and warned that, if membership was ruled out, his company would find it "difficult" to keep its European base in the country.
fields.body:
The UK head of the Japanese electronics giant Mitsubishi yesterday urged Britain to join the single currency "as soon as possible", and warned that, if membership was ruled out, his company would find it "difficult" to keep its European base in the country.

Hiroshi Nemichi stopped short of issuing an open threat to withdraw from the UK if it did not move to euro entry, but made clear that his company's loyalty depended on Britain's links with its European neighbours being "as strong as possible".

The warnings, which mark the latest stage in the pro-euro Britain in Europe campaign to sell the single currency to a reluctant electorate, were dismissed by the anti-euro Business for Sterling pressure group as "scare stories".

Nick Herbert, the group's chief executive, said: "Inward investment is pouring into the UK despite being out of the euro zone, due to our competitive advantages of low taxation and low regulation - advantages that would be destroyed if we sign up to economic and monetary union."

Mr Nemichi's warning came as the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, marked the second week of Britain in Europe's Out of Europe, Out of Work Campaign, with a prediction that the British would eventually vote in favour of joining the single European currency, once the time was right. A referendum on the issue could be held early in the next parliament - providing the five economic tests were met. "If we have come to the conclusion that the tests have been met and Britain will be better off inside then I do think the British people will join in supporting the euro," he said.

Ministers are seeking to re cruit big business to endorse the pro-euro campaign amid allegations that Downing Street has repeatedly pulled punches on the issue for fear of running directly counter to prevailing public opinion.

Over 3m Britons depend for their living on the UK's economic links to Europe, Mr Cook said, pointing to 4,000 of his own constituents in Livingston who work for Japanese companies.

But he added: "If Britain weakens its ties with Europe, investors would weaken their ties with Britain."

In a pamphlet published yesterday by Britain in Europe, Mr Nemichi warned: "If Britain were to rule out membership of the single currency, as the anti-Europeans seem to want, Britain would be less attractive to inward investors."

He said later: "Obviously, if you think of a situation where you are in [the single currency] or out, the operation in the case of not in is definitely more difficult."

Mitsubishi is not the first major Japanese company to warn Britain of the consequences of staying out of the euro, though it is the first to do so from a campaigning platform.

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, said last month that the government was being pressed by inward investors to hold its planned euro referendum soon after the next election.

Senior Japanese business leaders, alarmed at apparent coolness from Tony Blair over their calls for early euro membership, expressed their concerns at a meeting with the prime minister last November. Norio Ohga, chairman of Sony, is understood to have issued the strongest warning that the UK was losing its competitive edge against continental Europe.

fields.headline: Will you marry me?
fields.standfirst: She had seen the future (a fast car, no cooking or cleaning) and having a husband certainly wasn't part of it. But then... On the day a woman can traditionally pop the question,  Charlotte Higgins explains why she did just that
fields.trailText: She had seen the future (a fast car, no cooking or cleaning) and having a husband certainly wasn't part of it. But then... On the day a woman can traditionally pop the question,  Charlotte Higgins explains why she did just that
fields.body:
I never wanted to get married. I really didn't. So the fact that last year I actually proposed to my boyfriend, without even having the decency to wait till Leap Year, is possibly the most grossly inconsistent thing I've ever done. It is such a grandiose u-turn, in fact, that I would hardly be surprised now if I started voting Tory, tucking into large steaks or wearing strings of pearls and living in Kensington (though I'd like to hope that someone would have the heart to restrain me).

But there it is. I did it, unromantically, one drizzly Monday night outside the pub at closing time. I hadn't planned it. It just sort of came out. It's strange how simple it was to say, though it took me days to get over the shock of having done it. For my voting preferences, vegetarianism and irrational dislike of those parts of the capital that lie west of Hyde Park are flashes in the pan compared with my antipathy to marriage, which dates back almost as far as the cradle, way before the bubbling up of any feminist consciousness.

In the early days, it was quite simple: like many sensible five-year-old girls, I hated boys. They were rough, uncivilised creatures and, frankly, they smelled. My favourite childhood game was pretending to be a witch. In that world, I was Circe, the all-powerful enchantress, and boys got turned into pigs, pronto.

Later, things got more angst-ridden. As a young teenager, from my limited and hugely oversimplified perspective, I saw two types of women: those who'd stayed at home and raised kids, and those who'd invested in a pinstripe suit with shoulderpads and lots of red lipstick, and were Doing It For Themselves. (It was the 80s, OK?) I'm afraid to say I most certainly wanted to be in the second camp, at least partly because my mother was a member of the first and, in my straightforwardly unpleasant teenage way, I was truly horrified by almost everything my parents did.

In those days, I envisioned a future in which I did no cooking or cleaning (activities with which my mother seemed to be ceaselessly occupied) and owned a fast car. Having a husband to iron shirts for certainly wasn't a part of the plan. Men held you back. (I'm afraid that to this day I can't bear cleaning and cheered when I read Simone de Beauvoir's description in The Second Sex: "Few tasks are more like the torture of Sisyphus than housework with its endless repetition: the clean becomes soiled, the soiled becomes clean, over and over, day after day.")

By the time I read The Second Sex I was at university. De Beauvoir called marriage a woman's "destiny", but by my 20s I was even more sure that I would reject that particular fate. At the place where I studied, for every one woman student there were three men. I was taught by men. The portraits in the dining hall were of prime ministers and kings and great thinkers, and they were all men. It seemed absolutely clear to me that life was going to be a fight against the dark forces of patriarchy and marriage was an outmoded patriarchal institution which, as we learnt from speakers at our women's lunches in the crepuscular and odiferous college bar, bred domestic violence and fostered organised slavery.

Furthermore, I asked, just what exactly was the point? What was the point of dressing up in white tulle (particularly when white can be so damaging to someone with hips the size of mine) and walking down the aisle on the arm of your father to be presented like a sacrificial lamb at the altar? What was the point of all that consumption and crippling excess and top-hats-and-tails and patronising best men's speeches when the whole enterprise would, in an alarming number of cases, end in tears, disaster and divorce a few years down the line? What was the point when the best relationship I know, that of my brother and his partner of now nearly 20 years, wanted no institutional carapace to bind it?

So what happened? It goes without saying that Charlie and I love each other and want to grow old together. Our commitment is already made. In a sense, there is no reason to get married at all. Which meant that I was taken aback when he first suggested it to me. In fact, I pooh-poohed the idea. But then I began to think about it and to take on board his arguments. I re-examined my objections. I began to suspect that by getting married, I wouldn't actually, really, be endorsing (still less exposing myself to) marital rape, domestic violence and female servitude.

Once I began to think of marriage as a possible choice out of many possible choices, and not a destiny imposed on me, it didn't seem quite so awful after all (and I was very glad when Gordon Brown got rid of married people's tax breaks). I considered the idea that it would be the quality of our relationship rather than its legal status that would define it, and the chances of my subsuming my individuality into a Borg-like collective consisting of me and Charlie are frankly slender. Plus, even if cold-light-of-day statistics said that we had as much chance of failing as making it work till death us do part, so what? Why bother at all, if you refuse to try things you might fail at?

Once I had chucked out the objections, I started to be able to see certain advantages. That a wedding really needn't be a ghastly tribute to self-satisfied coupledom, but could be a celebration of partnership, friendship and family ties (admittedly putting two sets of families and a bunch of our friends in the same room could be a huge disaster, but we'll go with it anyway). That we actually do, really do, have a strange urge to tell everybody that we love each other and it might be nice to give our family and friends a good party while we're at it.

It sounds a bit Tory and possibly carnivorous and Kensingtonian to say this, but we want to do the ritual thing. We want to do as our forefathers did before us, in a place hallowed by time. As you will by now be grasping, I also started to think how immensely romantic it would be to get married. And I know that romance is a pernicious literary invention, but sod it.

So we're getting married in a church near my parents' home and doing everything "properly". Well, mostly everything. I'm not going for white tulle, but green chiffon. I have not darkened the door of a single store's bridal department (in fact the word "bridal" still makes me shudder). I'm not wearing a veil or having bridesmaids, but I shall be making a speech. There won't be any wedding cake, or morning suits, or formal photographs, or a Daimler (my eldest brother is polishing up his 50s Citroën DX).

I shan't be going up the aisle to the Wedding March but to something postmodern by my oldest friend, a composer. I certainly hope there won't be any pomposity or smugness. It's not exactly revolutionary, but it's a way of making it ours. Which is kind of what we're hoping for in our marriage, too.

 In 1288, Queen Margaret of Scotland decreed that on Leap Year's Day, a woman could propose. It was beholden on the man to accept, unless he was already married or betrothed, or pay a "swingeing £1 fine".

 It is said questions of rank dictated the Queen had to intimate to Philip that he'd get Royal assent.

 Queen Victoria lost weight with nerves before asking Albert to marry her on October 15 1839. She wrote in her diary: "I said... that it would make me too happy if he would consent; we embraced each other over and over... he said he would be very happy."

 Zsa Zsa Gabor once said she proposed to all nine husbands: "A woman has to make up a man's mind."

 7,000 women propose each Leap Year. But while they may be comfortable asking, men may be reticent to let go of their traditional role. In an online AOL poll, 44% of men said they'd refuse.

It seemed absolutely clear to me that life was going to be a fight against the dark forces of patriarchy and marriage was an outmoded patriarchal institution which, as we learnt from speakers at our women's lunches in the crepuscular and odiferous college bar, bred domestic violence and fostered organised slavery. Furthermore, I asked, just what exactly was the point? What was the point of dressing up in white tulle (particularly when white can be so damaging to someone with hips the size of mine) and walking down the aisle on the arm of your father to be presented like a sacrificial lamb at the altar? What was the point of all that consumption and crippling excess and top-hats-and-tails and patronising best men's speeches when the whole enterprise would, in an alarming number of cases, end in tears, disaster and divorce a few years down the line? What was the point when the best relationship I know, that of my brother and his partner of now nearly 20 years, wanted no institutional carapace to bind it? So what happened? It goes without saying that Charlie and I love each other and want to grow old together. Our commitment is already made. In a sense, there is no reason to get married at all. Which meant that I was taken aback when he first suggested it to me. In fact, I pooh-poohed the idea. But then I began to think about it and to take on board his arguments. I re-examined my objections. I began to suspect that by getting married, I wouldn't actually, really, be endorsing (still less exposing myself to) marital rape, domestic violence and female servitude. Once I began to think of marriage as a possible choice out of many possible choices, and not a destiny imposed on me, it didn't seem quite so awful after all (and I was very glad when Gordon Brown got rid of married people's tax breaks). I considered the idea that it would be the quality of our relationship rather than its legal status that would define it, and the chances of my subsuming my individuality into a Borg-like collective consisting of me and Charlie are frankly slender. Plus, even if cold-light-of-day statistics said that we had as much chance of failing as making it work till death us do part, so what? Why bother at all, if you refuse to try things you might fail at? Once I had chucked out the objections, I started to be able to see certain advantages. That a wedding really needn't be a ghastly tribute to self-satisfied coupledom, but could be a celebration of partnership, friendship and family ties (admittedly putting two sets of families and a bunch of our friends in the same room could be a huge disaster, but we'll go with it anyway). That we actually do, really do, have a strange urge to tell everybody that we love each other and it might be nice to give our family and friends a good party while we're at it. It sounds a bit Tory and possibly carnivorous and Kensingtonian to say this, but we want to do the ritual thing. We want to do as our forefathers did before us, in a place hallowed by time. As you will by now be grasping, I also started to think how immensely romantic it would be to get married. And I know that romance is a pernicious literary invention, but sod it. So we're getting married in a church near my parents' home and doing everything "properly". Well, mostly everything. I'm not going for white tulle, but green chiffon. I have not darkened the door of a single store's bridal department (in fact the word "bridal" still makes me shudder). I'm not wearing a veil or having bridesmaids, but I shall be making a speech. There won't be any wedding cake, or morning suits, or formal photographs, or a Daimler (my eldest brother is polishing up his 50s Citroën DX). I shan't be going up the aisle to the Wedding March but to something postmodern by my oldest friend, a composer. I certainly hope there won't be any pomposity or smugness. It's not exactly revolutionary, but it's a way of making it ours. Which is kind of what we're hoping for in our marriage, too.  In 1288, Queen Margaret of Scotland decreed that on Leap Year's Day, a woman could propose. It was beholden on the man to accept, unless he was already married or betrothed, or pay a "swingeing £1 fine".  It is said questions of rank dictated the Queen had to intimate to Philip that he'd get Royal assent.  Queen Victoria lost weight with nerves before asking Albert to marry her on October 15 1839. She wrote in her diary: "I said... that it would make me too happy if he would consent; we embraced each other over and over... he said he would be very happy."  Zsa Zsa Gabor once said she proposed to all nine husbands: "A woman has to make up a man's mind."  7,000 women propose each Leap Year. But while they may be comfortable asking, men may be reticent to let go of their traditional role. In an online AOL poll, 44% of men said they'd refuse.

webTitle: Forgive me, Bush asks Catholic voters

fields.headline: Forgive me, Bush asks Catholic voters
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Arizona senator John McCain went for the jugular yesterday in his bitter race with George W Bush for the Republican presidential nomination, accusing his opponent of being too close to the party's anti-Catholic conservatives.
fields.body:
Arizona senator John McCain went for the jugular yesterday in his bitter race with George W Bush for the Republican presidential nomination, accusing his opponent of being too close to the party's anti-Catholic conservatives.

The day before Virginia and Washington state's primaries, Mr McCain tried to tie Mr Bush to the Christian conservative Pat Robertson.

"I am a Reagan Republican who will defeat Al Gore," Mr McCain told an audience in Virginia Beach. "Unfortunately, Governor Bush is a Pat Robertson Republican who will lose to Al Gore." The remarks come as the furore caused by Mr Bush's visit to the fundamentalist Bob Jones university in South Carolina a month ago shows no sign of abating.

Although, Mr Bush has admitted that his appearance there was an error, his change of heart may have come too late to help him shake off a reputation for being hostile, or at least insensitive, to the feelings of America's 60m Catholic voters.

The college bans inter-racial dating, gave an honorary degree to Ian Paisley and teaches that Catholicism is a "satanic cult".

On Sunday, Mr Bush wrote to the head of the archdiocese of New York, Cardinal John O'Connor, saying: "On reflection, I should have been more clear in disassociating myself from anti-Catholic sentiments and racial prejudice. It was a missed opportunity causing needless offence, which I deeply regret."

Voters go to the polls in a crucial primary on March 7 in New York, where some 41% of voters are Catholic. Opinion polls show Mr Bush and Mr McCain running neck and neck.

The significance of Mr Bush's mishandling of the Catholic vote is potentially enormous.

The Catholic church is easily the largest Christian denomination in the US, with 22% of the population. It represents the kind of support he cannot afford to alienate.

fields.headline: Brown faces protest over pledges
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown, the chancellor, is facing all-party protests today over proposals to ban independent scrutiny by parliament of Labour's key pledges to cut hospital waiting lists and curb benefit fraud.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown, the chancellor, is facing all-party protests today over proposals to ban independent scrutiny by parliament of Labour's key pledges to cut hospital waiting lists and curb benefit fraud.

David Davis, Conservative chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, is combining with Labour deputy chairman, Alan Williams, and David Rendel, Liberal Democrat MP on the committee, to demand sweeping changes to treasury legislation being debated today.

The committee is fighting the treasury over the government's refusal to open up the BBC, some 300 government agencies and £70bn of government business to automatic parliamentary inspection.

MPs are angry over ministers refusing parliament's senior financial officer, Sir John Bourn, the right to check performance targets set by Labour. One example is Alastair Darling's pledge as social security secretary to cut benefit fraud among income support and jobseekers' allowance claimants by 10% by 2002 and by 30% by 2007. Ministers are proposing that the benefits agency and the ministry validate their own figures. Similar systems are proposed for the NHS and other services.

The MPs have also demanded scrutiny of £70bn of public money paid to private companies to build hospitals, prisons, social security offices and computer systems under the government's private finance initiative.

Mr Rendel has asked for the BBC to open its accounts to scrutiny by parliament. Chris Smith, the culture secretary, has been overruled by Mr Brown who wants the BBC to present accounts to ministers, not MPs. Mr Williams and Mr Davis also want automatic scrutiny of about 300 quangos, including the housing corporation, environment agency, football licensing authority, gas consumers' council, and historic buildings and monuments commission.

They are also furious that Sir John - whom Labour has made one of the few people that whistleblowers can contact to disclose government fraud, incompetence and corruption - has been excluded from investigating complaints about private companies providing public services. Mr Williams said yesterday: "We cannot have the executive telling parliament what it should be looking at, it should be the other way round."

fields.headline: Shy scientist's accidental good fortune
fields.standfirst: News Analysis Business break led academic to create £350m biotech kingdom
fields.trailText: A publicity-shy Malaysian-born academic has emerged as the king of Britain's booming biotechnology industry, with a paper wealth of well over £350m. Kim Tan, 44, is founder and managing director of KS Biomedix, a Surrey company that has come up with a way of using antibodies from sheep to fight cancer.
fields.body:
A publicity-shy Malaysian-born academic has emerged as the king of Britain's booming biotechnology industry, with a paper wealth of well over £350m. Kim Tan, 44, is founder and managing director of KS Biomedix, a Surrey company that has come up with a way of using antibodies from sheep to fight cancer.

Until recently, KS toiled at the obscure end of the drug development sector.

However, since November it has emerged as a hot favourite in the rush for hi-tech shares. Its market value has jumped from £160m to £360m and Dr Tan owns a hefty 60%.

He also chairs an Ofex-listed firm, Gene Medix, where his shares are worth more than £150m, making him one of the richest entrepreneurs in the industry.

Dr Tan insists he has amassed his fortune almost by accident - he went into business after becoming frustrated with studying for a series of post-doctoral qualifications at Surrey university: "I decided I wasn't good enough to do first division science so I thought I'd try my hand at running a business."

His first venture was a diagnostics company, Guildhay, which he sold for around £500,000.

He used this, together with a £250,000 grant from the department of trade, to set up KS Biomedix.

The company capitalised on his research into pancreatic cancer. His team first tried attacking tumours by injecting cancer antigens - which stimulate the production of antibodies - into mice and capturing the immune antibodies produced by the animals. However, mouse antibodies were not powerful enough, so Dr Tan decided to try sheep. That was successful almost immediately.

KS now has its own flock of sheep which produce a regular supply of antibodies. Analysts believe that by licensing these on to other drug development firms the company could be making profits of £100m within 10 years.

Dr Tan says: "It will be business to business. We've no ambition to be in drugs sales ourselves - there are plenty of good, good companies out there who can distribute our drugs to doctors."

From the start KS had a frugal culture. Despite his paper wealth, Dr Tan is on a salary of £70,000 and, like his fellow directors, has no company car or corporate pension scheme.

He says: "When we came to the market, the model for drug development companies really was British Biotech - expansive offices, expensive sales forces and all the rest of it.

"We set our stall out, saying we believe that when we raise funds we want to use the money to fund science rather than directors' lifestyles."

His lifestyle is modest - he still drives an eight-year-old Volkswagen Golf.

In its first five years on the market, KS raised just £10m. Then yesterday the company placed another 2.27m shares to boost its bank balance by £15.4m.

The company employs just 20 people, with offices in Guildford and laboratories in Farnborough. Much of its development work is contracted out to third parties.

Dr Tan has business in his blood - his father runs a food wholesale business distributing rice and sugar throughout Malaysia.

"My father came to Malaysia [from China] aged 18 with nothing. He built up his own business and supported my whole family."

Dr Tan now sends money back to help his nine siblings: "It's a very Asian thing - you feel responsible for supporting each other."

A committed Christian, he is also involved in a number of charities in the developing world, including the Tear Fund, an evangelical relief organisation. "I have a Christian faith and my background biases me towards the developing world," he says.

The only hitch so far has been an embarrassing incident two years ago when KS recruited a senior manager who failed to disclose a rape conviction. The press found out and Dr Tan, who was obliged to sack him, felt bruised by the whole affair. Colleagues say this turned him against the media.

KS yesterday said its half-year losses had increased from £536,000 to £925,000 before tax, due to the cost of clinical trials of two arthritis drugs. Both are likely to enter phase three clinical trials this year, and a partnering deal with a big pharmaceuticals company should get milestone payments rolling in, pushing KS into the black.

Dr Tan insists: "We don't have big egos at this company. A number of biotech companies have been run by cult figures, and I don't think that's good for the long term."

However, he heads a list of biotech entrepreneurs who have suddenly found themselves sitting on a fortune.

For example, Galen Holdings' chairman Allen McClay has shares worth £200m and Powderject's Paul Drayson has a stake worth £40m.

Despite their low profiles, the biotech millionaires are beginning to rival Britain's much-hyped "dot.com" entrepreneurs. The race is on to be the drugs world's Bill Gates.

webTitle: South African board drops media writs

fields.headline: South African board drops media writs
fields.trailText: South Africa's human rights commission has withdrawn the summonses issued to more than 40 editors demanding that they testify at hearings this week into alleged racism in the media.
fields.body:
South Africa's human rights commission has withdrawn the summonses issued to more than 40 editors demanding that they testify at hearings this week into alleged racism in the media.

The commission yesterday said it could still revive the subpoenas if the editors failed to cooperate with the inquiry, which opens tomorrow. But its last-minute climbdown amid accusations that the summonses were a breach of constitutional guarantees of press freedom, and that the probe was tainted by bad research and political manipulation, leaves the commission embarrassed and divided.

The commission chairman, Barney Pityana, said he did not regret issuing the summonses. "The commission is anxious that the central purpose of the inquiry into racism in the media should not be lost sight of," he said.

He added that "five black editors and about three white editors" would still be urged to cooperate with the hearings. They are believed to include Phillip van Niekerk, the editor of Johannesburg's Mail and Guardian, in which the Guardian Media Group has a majority holding.

"The pressure on the human rights commission has been enormous," Mr Van Niekerk said "This is a sign that they didn't know what they were doing."

The Mail and Guardianand the Johannesburg Sunday Times were the subject of the original allegations, which led to the inquiry. The two papers were accused of "subliminal racism" for exposing corruption by black officials. But the probe was swiftly undermined by a commission report that was widely derided for its unconventional interpretations of racism and blatant inaccuracies.

Nonetheless, the commission pressed ahead with the investigation by announcing public hearings, at which the editor of any publication mentioned in the report was required to account for the alleged racism.

Many editors said they would refuse to comply with the subpoenas because they were not only a breach of constitutional guarantees of free speech, but the planned conduct of the hearings amounted to an "inquisition", at which guilt was virtually presumed.

The summonses mostly failed to lay out the specific accusations the editors would face, and required them to provide any documentation from their offices which might deal with the issue of race in the news, including all minutes of editorial meetings.

The commission was also embarrassed when it tries to summons the editor of the Financial Times. It discovered he lived in London, beyond the inquiry's jurisdiction, and the subpoena was quietly dropped.

A delegation of 10 editors is meeting the commission today to urge that the hearings be amended to drop the "adversarial" approach in favour of dialogue.

webTitle: LA's deportees send murder rate soaring in El Salvador

fields.headline: LA's deportees send murder rate soaring in El Salvador
fields.standfirst: US accused of exporting gang warfare to central America
fields.trailText: Baggy jeans bought with stolen necklaces. An attitude, a tattoo and a supply of crack cocaine. Malvin Antario looks like a gang leader from Los Angeles.
fields.body:
Baggy jeans bought with stolen necklaces. An attitude, a tattoo and a supply of crack cocaine. Malvin Antario looks like a gang leader from Los Angeles.

But home in Soyapango, El Salvador, is a far cry from even the most deprived LA housing estate. The corrugated iron shacks have no running water.

There are flies and rats. Sewage runs through the streets of this slum, which is separated from slightly better-off neighbourhoods by a graffiti-covered wall.

"I wanted to be able to get money for drugs and clothes. I wanted to fit in, I wanted something to do, so I joined the 18th Street," says Malvin.

The 18th Street is one of several gangs in El Salvador with roots in LA, introduced when the US started deporting legal and illegal Salvadorean immigrants with US criminal records, following the end of El Salvador's 12-year civil war in 1992.

In the last fiscal year, the US deported 62,359 criminals, up from 37,000 three years earlier. But while the deportations are marginally lowering crime rates, freeing up prison space and saving taxpayers' money in the US, they are leading to a proliferation of US gang habits in El Salvador and other countries in central America.

"Kids see deported gang members from LA who have nice clothes, who do things for money, like sell drugs and do tattoos, and they want to be like them. They don't want to be like their dad working in the fields or their mother washing clothes," says William Huezo, an LA deportee living in the capital, San Salvador.

The two main gangs in El Salvador are the 18th Street and Mara Salvatrucha, both exported from LA. The cities and even rural areas have been divided between these well-armed rival factions, who mark their territories with graffiti. As a result of their activity, crime has soared.

Gang members are thought to be responsible for 10% of El Salvador's annual murder rate of 120 per 100,000 people (the UK has a rate of less than two per 100,000, the US eight per 100,000). Not only do they kill each other, but also passers-by caught in the crossfire. They rob backpackers, kidnap, steal cars, deal drugs and extort money from businesses.

"More than 300 deported Salvadoreans arrive in the country from the US every month. These are people who have not just been in jail but have often committed crimes after they have left jail. They are having a huge impact on the country," says Eduardo Alfonso Linares, head of San Salvador's police force.

But psychologists say the damage done by El Salvador's civil war is also responsible for the rise in membership of gangs. The war took the lives of more than 75,000 people.

As a result, many family units have been destroyed, leaving children in the care of people to whom they are only loosely related. Often these relatives cannot afford to send their children to school.

Meanwhile, gang life gives young people something to do and a sense of belonging.

"The war has made people much more tolerant of violence. People tend to solve everyday disputes with violence. This has been passed down to the next generation," says Marcela Smutt, a consultant on gangs for a UN research project Violence in a Society in Transition.

El Salvador's congress is debating whether to try children as young as 14 in adult courts and has agreed to fund more jails for juveniles.

But organisations working with children say these are not the right answers.

"Gangs in big numbers are an expression of social exclusion. But what is the government doing? They're constructing more jails instead of providing schools and asking for more family responsibility," says Karla Hanania de Varela, child rights officer at Unicef.

Some government members say the heart of the problem lies with Washington's policy and have complained to the US president, Bill Clinton.

"Many violent offences, like murder and kidnapping, are committed by young people who have been in the US and are sent back here with no warning. As these deportations increase, so do crime rates," says Milagro Hernandez, of the government's justice department.

But the US only shows signs of stepping up its policy of deporting immigrants with criminal records.

Meanwhile, gang life gives young people something to do and a sense of belonging. "The war has made people much more tolerant of violence. People tend to solve everyday disputes with violence. This has been passed down to the next generation," says Marcela Smutt, a consultant on gangs for a UN research project Violence in a Society in Transition. El Salvador's congress is debating whether to try children as young as 14 in adult courts and has agreed to fund more jails for juveniles. But organisations working with children say these are not the right answers. "Gangs in big numbers are an expression of social exclusion. But what is the government doing? They're constructing more jails instead of providing schools and asking for more family responsibility," says Karla Hanania de Varela, child rights officer at Unicef. Some government members say the heart of the problem lies with Washington's policy and have complained to the US president, Bill Clinton. "Many violent offences, like murder and kidnapping, are committed by young people who have been in the US and are sent back here with no warning. As these deportations increase, so do crime rates," says Milagro Hernandez, of the government's justice department. But the US only shows signs of stepping up its policy of deporting immigrants with criminal records.

fields.headline: Anti-bully course for BBC staff
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC is sending about 200 journalists on a training programme to help staff "understand better what is - and what is not - bullying".
fields.body:
The BBC is sending about 200 journalists on a training programme to help staff "understand better what is - and what is not - bullying".

The staff from the BBC's monitoring headquarters at Caversham, near Reading, will be expected to take part in a two-hour session.

A spokeswoman said: "It's just a training scheme they have decided is appropriate for staff at monitoring. There's nothing specific that has sparked this off."

In a memo, the purpose of the course was outlined for the journalists as a way "to help all of us to understand better what is - and what is not - bullying and harassment, how to avoid it in our own behaviour and how to deal with it when we encounter it in others.

"The aim is to influence behaviour positively and to eliminate undesirable behaviour from our workplace."

A recent survey showed that one in four employees said they had been bullied in the past five years, and that almost half had experienced or seen bullying.

The study of 5,300 workers by Manchester university's institute of science and technology (Umist) found that victims were spread across all levels but that 75% of bullies were managers.

Cary Cooper, a professor of organisation psychology and health at Umist and one of the authors of the study, said that training could be useful as a way to gauge how much bullying took place.

Steve Lee, a National Union of Journalists' representative, said: "People tend to be suspicious but initiatives like this can help focus people's minds. I have heard of a number of cases of bullying or harassment, but they tend to be confidential and difficult to prove."
