webTitle: Police chief shot dead in setback for drugs war

fields.headline: Police chief shot dead in setback for drugs war
fields.trailText: The chief of police in the Mexican border town of Tijuana was shot dead at the weekend as he drove to his office after attending Mass. The killing comes as a blow to the Mexican government's attempts to show it is winning the war against drugs barons.
fields.body:
The chief of police in the Mexican border town of Tijuana was shot dead at the weekend as he drove to his office after attending Mass. The killing comes as a blow to the Mexican government's attempts to show it is winning the war against drugs barons.

Alfredo de la Torre Marquez, 49, had attended his local church on Sunday and was alone in his car when three vehicles boxed him in and unknown assailants opened fire. The heavily armed gunmen sprayed the car with more than 100 bullets. De la Torre's car crashed into a palm tree at the side of the road.

Police in Tijuana said yesterday that they had no immediate suspects, but two vehicles which had been stolen in California and driven across the border had been seized and were being examined. One had bloodstains on a seat, which might indicate that De la Torre had managed to fire back.

"He was well known and well liked," said Enrique Tellaeche, a spokesman for the Baja Californian state attorney general's office. "We did not know that he was having trouble with anyone."

Local media saw the shooting as a response by drug traffickers to a recent warning from the Mexican president, Ernesto Zedillo, of a govern ment crackdown on their activities. De la Torre was usually accompanied by his bodyguards, but on this occasion he left his home without telling them.

In 1998 De la Torre took over the running of a force of 1,800 officers with responsibility for a population of around 1.5m in a city where murders are a daily occurrence.

De la Torre, who joined the police in 1976 and had been the director of the state penitentiary, pledged to try to reduce violence in the border city, but warned in an interview last year: "I'm not God and I'm not Superman."

Tijuana, home to perhaps the busiest border crossing on Earth, has long been a byword for crime and vice. The "Tijuana cartel" is thought to be one of the wealthiest and most ruthless drug-trafficking operations in the world, smuggling cocaine from Colombia into the US. Nearly 40m visitors cross the border each year, making searches difficult. The shooting came soon after the Mexican government responded angrily to a claim by the US ambassador that the country was a world centre in drug-trafficking.

Jeffrey Davidow said last week: "The fact is that the headquarters of the drug-trafficking world are now in Mexico. Just as the headquarters - the main base - of the Mafia was in Sicily, now the main bases of drug traffickers are in other countries and Mexico is one of them."

The acting Mexican foreign minister, Carmen Moreno, said in a statement that "such behaviour undermines mutual confidence and therefore tends to benefit our common enemy, which is international organised-crime drug groups".

Mexico has been making public efforts to demonstrate that the government is fighting both drug traffickers and corruption within the police and military, which has allowed drug cartels to flourish.

The US drugs tsar, Barry McCaffrey, recently praised Mexico's efforts to curtail drugs traffic. Crime and the government's failure to contain it will feature heavily in political campaigns for the presidential electionin July, at which the Institutional Revolutionary party is hoping to maintain its 70-year grip on power.

fields.headline: Ralph Usherwood
fields.trailText: When, in 1955, Ralph Usherwood, who has died aged 88, reached the halfway mark of his stint as art editor of Radio Times, the magazine had reached its peak circulation of more than 8m.
fields.body:
When, in 1955, Ralph Usherwood, who has died aged 88, reached the halfway mark of his stint as art editor of Radio Times, the magazine had reached its peak circulation of more than 8m.

It was the journal to which all illustrators aspired, illustration being the perfect partner for radio - a medium which drew on the listener's imagination counterpointed by an image which was imaginatively drawn. But in that year ITV was launched, the broadcasting monopoly was broken, the ratings battle between the BBC and commercial television became reality, and radio swiftly became the junior partner.

Usherwood had inherited a healthy tradition. In the 1920s and early 30s, Radio Times Christmas covers had been created by the two most brilliant poster artists of the period, the Frenchman AM Cassandre and the American E McKnight Kauffer. Edward Ardizzone began work for the magazine before the war; so did Victor Reinganum, Heath Robinson and Nicolas Bentley. Eric Fraser was beginning a 50-year career. But the great period was Usherwood's, spanning the 1950s, particularly before 1957, when television subjects started to take precedence on the cover.

Usherwood was born in West Wickham, Kent, went to school at St Dunstan's College, London, where his father was headmaster, and read classics at Worcester College, Oxford. Here he designed the scenery for Tamburlaine, one of the magical summer evening productions in the college gardens, drew caricatures for the student magazine Isis, and captained the university lacrosse team. During the war, he served in the RAF.

His ability as an artist informed his perception as an art editor, and his charm - and rising circulation figures - persuaded people to work for insufficient pay. He carefully fitted the artist to the task. Usherwood was said to have read the scripts or books of every broadcast work that he wanted illustrated, and he hoped that his artists would be familiar with them as well.

Quite often they were. They usually received their commissions on a Thursday or Friday of the week before publication. Leonard Rosoman recalled receiving one for Somerset Maugham's Cakes And Ale, and reading the book overnight before starting work and delivering on Monday - although a BBC committee threw out the work because it showed a barmaid and her lover in the same bedroom.

Anthony Gross illustrated Anouilh and Chekhov; Robin Jacques did The Tempest (with Gielgud as Prospero), Julius Caesar and John Whiting's A Penny For A Song; John Minton did Ibsen's The Lady From The Sea in dramatic black and white; Lynton Lamb did Tartuffe (starring Donald Wolfit); and Ronald Searle illustrated O'Neill's The Emperor Jones.

After Usherwood, artists as fine as Peter Brookes, Ralph Steadman, Adrian George and Peter Till carried the torch into the 1970s and 80s, but the magazine, under pressure, ceased to be the major showcase of fine illustration. The garish colours of sets and costumes from soap operas like Coronation Street have their apotheosis in the photographs of the current listings magazines, among which the Radio Times is now just another player.

Usherwood's wife, Hilda, died in 1979. His two sons survive him.

Ralph Dean Usherwood, art editor, born October 27 1911; died January 2 2000

fields.headline: Crime and punishment
fields.standfirst:
Crisis in Chechnya: special report

Chechnya atrocities must be investigated
fields.trailText: Nobody knows how many people have been killed since the Russian onslaught on Chechnya began last September. The number of Chechens, civilians as well as combatants, who have been maimed, tortured, raped, incarcerated in "filtration centres" (Putin-speak for concentration camps), bombed into incoherence or madness, terrorised, beaten, and otherwise abused is an even darker secret. This ignorance is the result of a deliberate Russian policy which has barred access to Chechnya to international institutions and relief and human rights organisations, as well as (until relatively recently) the mass media.
fields.body:
Nobody knows how many people have been killed since the Russian onslaught on Chechnya began last September. The number of Chechens, civilians as well as combatants, who have been maimed, tortured, raped, incarcerated in "filtration centres" (Putin-speak for concentration camps), bombed into incoherence or madness, terrorised, beaten, and otherwise abused is an even darker secret. This ignorance is the result of a deliberate Russian policy which has barred access to Chechnya to international institutions and relief and human rights organisations, as well as (until relatively recently) the mass media.

Western politicians, travelling to Moscow to voice their concerns, have been effectively coopted into this continuing cover-up. President-to-be Vladimir Putin and his advisers well understand the need of their democratically challenged visitors to be seen to be reflecting public outrage at home. They have learnt to keep cool while Madeleine Albright, Robin Cook, Joschka Fischer, Nato's George Robertson, the EU's Chris Patten, that well-meaning OSCE chap, and all the hand-wringing rest complain to camera. Unlike bolshie Boris Yeltsin, the Putinistas listen politely, then make plausible but essentially empty gestures. They know the pressure and pontification will make no real difference on the ground. The more worldly among their VIP guests know that, too. As the limos leave the Kremlin and head for the airport, it is back to the business of Chechen eradication - with smiles all round and minimal damage done to western loans and all the other bilateral issues deemed to matter more in the long run.

Now that the war is almost over, and the damage mostly done, Moscow's information embargo is less strictly enforced. Alvaro Gil-Robles, from the Council of Europe, yesterday became the first senior western official to be allowed into Grozny, the ruined Chechen capital. He, too, gained a promise of dubious worth: the Russians agreed (in principle) to let a human rights group open a Grozny mission. But much, much more is needed by way of investigation. There is accumulating, persuasive, eyewitness evidence that Russian forces have committed war crimes and crimes against humanity. The horrors of the Chernokozovo camp, north of Grozny, may yet become as infamous as Omarska in the Bosnian war. Full, independent inquiries must now proceed urgently and unimpeded.

fields.headline: Letter
fields.standfirst: Cynthia Kee writes
fields.trailText: Cynthia Kee writes: Informed by the insights of psychoanalysis, Robert Gosling (Obituary, February 14) led an integrated life in which he acted as he thought, worked and taught. This made him a lovely person to be around: safe, constant, open and engaging - as well as truly egalitarian.
fields.body:
Informed by the insights of psychoanalysis, Robert Gosling (Obituary, February 14) led an integrated life in which he acted as he thought, worked and taught. This made him a lovely person to be around: safe, constant, open and engaging - as well as truly egalitarian.

When he retired as chairman of the Tavistock clinic in 1979, Bob entered with awareness into a quite different way of living. Already an excellent carpenter (his father had been one), he set about draining Hay Farm, the wonderful, but waterlogged, property he and his wife Veronica bought on a Gloucestershire hillside.

He rebuilt the tumble-down farm buildings, built a writing house in the woods for his wife, and, later, a dark room; made vegetable patches, a flower garden, conservatory and a trout-cum-swimming-and-boating pond. Bit by bit he took over the shopping and cooking, and learned bottling, preserving, jam-making and freezing. He catered for multitudes without fuss, allowing Veronica to shed her housewife's skin and launch out on a highly successful career as sculptor and photographer.

My family and I spent innumerable Christmases and many Easters with the Goslings. They are an integral part of my life, with Bob at the quiet heart.

fields.headline: Antonio Arguedas
fields.standfirst: Maverick Bolivian linked to the represssion of Che Guevara's guerrillas and publication of his diaries
fields.trailText: Antonio Arguedas, the Bolivian minister of the interior during Che Guevara's guerrilla campaign of 1967, has died in La Paz aged 71, after the home-made bomb he was carrying exploded. He sprang briefly to world attention in 1968 after arranging for copies of Guevara's captured diaries to be smuggled to Havana, and then spent a week in a safe house in London being interviewed by the CIA and British intelligence.
fields.body:
Antonio Arguedas, the Bolivian minister of the interior during Che Guevara's guerrilla campaign of 1967, has died in La Paz aged 71, after the home-made bomb he was carrying exploded. He sprang briefly to world attention in 1968 after arranging for copies of Guevara's captured diaries to be smuggled to Havana, and then spent a week in a safe house in London being interviewed by the CIA and British intelligence.

CIA agent, communist sympathiser, turncoat and opportunist, Antonio Arguedas Mendieta began his political life as a member of the Partido de la Izquierda Revolucionaria, the original Moscow-line communist party, and always remained on friendly terms with Bolivia's leading communists. As a teenage radio operator for the Bolivian air force, one of his tasks was to distribute party pamphlets at military airfields.

In 1950, he studied law and became the favoured lawyer of junior officers, befriending an air force pilot, René Barrientos, who took over as president in 1964 after a coup d'etat. Transferring his loyalties to the Movimiento Nacional Revolucionario, Bolivia's mainstream political movement, Arguedas joined the Barrientos government as a junior official in the ministry of the interior.

The US air attaché in the La Paz embassy, Colonel Edward Fox, knowing of Arguedas's leftist background, threatened Barrientos with the suspension of US economic assistance if Arguedas was not sacked, but the CIA station chief, Larry Sternfield, argued that it might be possible to recruit this intelligent and talented man. As he anticipated, Arguedas accepted their offer of recruitment. He did so, he told me in 1968, "partly out of opportunism and partly out of curiosity". He was promoted to be minister of the interior.

When Guevara's Bolivian campaign became common knowledge early in 1967, the CIA arranged with Arguedas for several Cuban exile agents to be seconded to his ministry, "to put some professionalism" into its intelligence efforts, according to a former CIA officer. One of the agents, Gabriel García García, became Arguedas's personal intelligence adviser.

Arguedas and his CIA advisers were to be responsible for the arrest of Loyola Guzmán, Guevara's chief urban contact, and for rounding up the guerrillas' entire urban support network. They also authorised an attack on the tin mines in June 1967, which led to a massacre of more than 80 miners and their families, effectively preventing the guerrillas from opening up a new front in the politicised mountainous region of the country.

Arguedas eventually grew disenchanted with his Cuban exile advisers, particularly after he discovered that they had opened their own detention centre, quite out of the control of his ministry. Subsequently, he claimed that he had gone out of his way to protect prominent leftists.

After Guevara was shot in October 1967, Arguedas was given a copy of his campaign diary by one of the Cuban exile agents, which he passed to his friend Ricardo Aneiba, head of the ministry's technical division, to be photographed. In January 1968, he resolved to send it to Cuba, and arranged for another friend, Víctor Zannier, to visit Santiago de Chile, to make the necessary contacts at the offices of Prensa Latina, the Cuban news agency. The microfilmed document was then sent to Havana, to be published in July 1968 both locally and by Ramparts magazine in the United States.

The publication was seen as a political coup for Fidel Castro, and a disaster for Barrientos, who declared a state of emergency and closed down the Bolivian Congress. Arguedas also ensured that Guevara's death mask and his severed hands, cut off by the Bolivian military for identification purposes, were dispatched to Havana in the same way.

When it transpired that the published diary had a number of pages missing, Ricardo Aneiba told Arguedas: "I think it was you who sent the diary to Cuba. The missing pages correspond exactly to the missing pages in the diary that you gave me to copy." Arguedas replied: "Oh, I thought it was you, because when we captured Guevara's address book, the first name on the page was yours."

Realising that he was in danger of being exposed, Argueda escaped to Chile. Prevented by the Chileans from returning to Bolivia, and by the CIA from going to Argentina, he flew to London, where he disappeared. Fearing that he might be assassinated, Cuban embassy officials enlisted the support of the Labour MP, Stan Newens, who discovered that he had been staying at the Richmond Hill Hotel under his maternal name. When Newens asked in the House of Commons why Arguedas was being held incommunicado, the then home secretary, Merlyn Rees, replied that nothing could be done since he had already left the country.

Arguedas and his CIA escort had travelled to New York, and eventually returned to Bolivia after Barrientos promised him a fair trial. He argued in court that, since his copy of Che's diary had come from a CIA agent, it could not be regarded as a Bolivian state secret. He was freed on bail at Christmas 1968, but after his house was bombed, and he was shot at in the street, he asked for asylum in Mexico in 1970.

In more recent decades, Arguedas's life oscillated between his erstwhile CIA patrons, old acquaintances in the Bolivian left, and his newfound friends in Havana. After several years in Cuba, he returned to Bolivia in disguise, promising to lead a new revolution. Later, he spent eight years in prison in La Paz on charges of kidnapping. Two years ago, he was accused of belonging to an organisation that kidnapped and ransomed wealthy citizens - and went into hiding. After his death, police claimed he was behind a recent bombing campaign by C-4, a hitherto unknown anti-communist terrorist group.

The strange twists of Arguedas's life may be illuminated by the publication of his memoirs, the manuscript of which is in the hands of the La Paz police.

He was promoted to be minister of the interior. When Guevara's Bolivian campaign became common knowledge early in 1967, the CIA arranged with Arguedas for several Cuban exile agents to be seconded to his ministry, "to put some professionalism" into its intelligence efforts, according to a former CIA officer. One of the agents, Gabriel García García, became Arguedas's personal intelligence adviser. Arguedas and his CIA advisers were to be responsible for the arrest of Loyola Guzmán, Guevara's chief urban contact, and for rounding up the guerrillas' entire urban support network. They also authorised an attack on the tin mines in June 1967, which led to a massacre of more than 80 miners and their families, effectively preventing the guerrillas from opening up a new front in the politicised mountainous region of the country. Arguedas eventually grew disenchanted with his Cuban exile advisers, particularly after he discovered that they had opened their own detention centre, quite out of the control of his ministry. Subsequently, he claimed that he had gone out of his way to protect prominent leftists. After Guevara was shot in October 1967, Arguedas was given a copy of his campaign diary by one of the Cuban exile agents, which he passed to his friend Ricardo Aneiba, head of the ministry's technical division, to be photographed. In January 1968, he resolved to send it to Cuba, and arranged for another friend, Víctor Zannier, to visit Santiago de Chile, to make the necessary contacts at the offices of Prensa Latina, the Cuban news agency. The microfilmed document was then sent to Havana, to be published in July 1968 both locally and by Ramparts magazine in the United States. The publication was seen as a political coup for Fidel Castro, and a disaster for Barrientos, who declared a state of emergency and closed down the Bolivian Congress. Arguedas also ensured that Guevara's death mask and his severed hands, cut off by the Bolivian military for identification purposes, were dispatched to Havana in the same way. When it transpired that the published diary had a number of pages missing, Ricardo Aneiba told Arguedas: "I think it was you who sent the diary to Cuba. The missing pages correspond exactly to the missing pages in the diary that you gave me to copy." Arguedas replied: "Oh, I thought it was you, because when we captured Guevara's address book, the first name on the page was yours." Realising that he was in danger of being exposed, Argueda escaped to Chile. Prevented by the Chileans from returning to Bolivia, and by the CIA from going to Argentina, he flew to London, where he disappeared. Fearing that he might be assassinated, Cuban embassy officials enlisted the support of the Labour MP, Stan Newens, who discovered that he had been staying at the Richmond Hill Hotel under his maternal name. When Newens asked in the House of Commons why Arguedas was being held incommunicado, the then home secretary, Merlyn Rees, replied that nothing could be done since he had already left the country. Arguedas and his CIA escort had travelled to New York, and eventually returned to Bolivia after Barrientos promised him a fair trial. He argued in court that, since his copy of Che's diary had come from a CIA agent, it could not be regarded as a Bolivian state secret. He was freed on bail at Christmas 1968, but after his house was bombed, and he was shot at in the street, he asked for asylum in Mexico in 1970. In more recent decades, Arguedas's life oscillated between his erstwhile CIA patrons, old acquaintances in the Bolivian left, and his newfound friends in Havana. After several years in Cuba, he returned to Bolivia in disguise, promising to lead a new revolution. Later, he spent eight years in prison in La Paz on charges of kidnapping. Two years ago, he was accused of belonging to an organisation that kidnapped and ransomed wealthy citizens - and went into hiding. After his death, police claimed he was behind a recent bombing campaign by C-4, a hitherto unknown anti-communist terrorist group. The strange twists of Arguedas's life may be illuminated by the publication of his memoirs, the manuscript of which is in the hands of the La Paz police. Antonio Arguedas Mendieta, politician, born c1930; died February 16 2000

fields.headline: £225,000 for Shipman drug error
fields.standfirst: Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: A man who was left a mental wreck after an overdose of drugs prescribed by the serial killer Harold Shipman yesterday received £225,000 compensation.
fields.body:
A man who was left a mental wreck after an overdose of drugs prescribed by the serial killer Harold Shipman yesterday received £225,000 compensation.

Lawyers for the Medical Defence Union, representing Shipman who was jailed for life last month for the murder of 15 women patients, admitted he had been negligent in prescribing Derek Webb 2 times the amount of Epilim he needed to control his epilepsy.

Mr Justice Penry-Davy, sitting at the high court in Manchester, heard that Mr Webb, 58, who had epilepsy from infancy and a psychotic illness, could have died after taking the equivalent of 76 tablets in 7 days.

Michael Redfern QC said Mr Webb had lived in a semi-independent state with his partner, who was also mentally handicapped, in Hyde, Greater Manchester. He had been a patient of Shipman's and was on a repeat prescription of 200mg of Epilim. In November 1989 Shipman increased this to 500mg.

Four weeks later Mr Webb's sister, Jean Wood, who cared for him, arrived back from holiday to find him in a "disastrous condition", Mr Redfern said. Mr Webb was covered in excreta, had pressure sores and broken skin on his abdomen, was unable to walk, and was having seizures.

On admission to hospital, he was found to be dehydrated and malnourished and had paranoid delusions.

Mr Webb was left with additional brain damage and increased cognitive impairment. He was placed in a nursing home but when an investigation was launched into the death of Shipman's patients, Mrs Wood reported the matter to the police.

Mr Redfern said: There was no evidence other than that this was a one-off act of negligence."

webTitle: Beware of happy faces in Yorkshire

fields.headline: Beware of happy faces in Yorkshire
fields.trailText: A new hazard was laid in the path of foreign visitors yesterday in the form of a guide to the regional subtleties which divide, for example, an Essex girl from a Yorkshireman.
fields.body:
A new hazard was laid in the path of foreign visitors yesterday in the form of a guide to the regional subtleties which divide, for example, an Essex girl from a Yorkshireman.

As part of really getting to know "a confusing and often confused people", the Tourist's Guide to the British offers a range of risky ways of catching locals' attention. Geordies, for example, are said to enjoy a pat on their oversize stomachs after sharing a brown ale, while the retired community in Eastbourne and Hastings appreciates acknowledgement of its "uniform of plastic headscarves, defiantly unfashionable nylon and support tights".

The £2.99 handbook is designed to help visitors understand a national subtext of insults and jibes, according to author Simon Henry, a 29-year-old journalist who has reserved his coarsest quips for his native region.

A rare smile on the face of a fellow Yorkshireman, he says, will be a sign only of impending breaking wind. Key words for visitors to try in the region include "can't, won't and no".

Mr Henry said: "Visiting another region can feel like being a foreigner in your own country, so you can imagine how baffling it is to tourists."

Luke Chaput, of the guide's publishers Nightingale - based in London, close to Essex where "people are noted for their wealth, whether hard-earned or stolen" - said: "The book should help the naive foreigner to understand the startling divisions between us all."

webTitle: Puerto Ricans to join Scottish US fight

fields.headline: Puerto Ricans to join Scottish US fight
fields.trailText: It is an unlikely venue for the latest round of a protest war between the US navy and Puerto Rican fishermen. But next week the tranquillity of Cape Wrath will be shattered by the dissenting voices of Caribbean islanders.
fields.body:
It is an unlikely venue for the latest round of a protest war between the US navy and Puerto Rican fishermen. But next week the tranquillity of Cape Wrath will be shattered by the dissenting voices of Caribbean islanders.

The coastline on the north western tip of Scotland will be the scene of a fresh battle between the groups as the fishermen try to stop US ships, led by the USS Dwight D Eisenhower, from using Cape Wrath for firing practice.

The Americans are using the ministry of defence's designated bombing area in Caithness after being forced off Puerto Rica by an outcry which began last April when an F-18 jet dropped two bombs off target and killed a civilian guard on the island of Vieques.

In protest at the killing, the renowned environmental activist Alberto de Jesus led the fishermen in their kayaks on to Vieques. His protest was phenomenally successful, not only pushing the US navy off the island, but reawakening the Puerto Rican independence movement.

Now Mr de Jesus plans to travel to Scotland to continue his fight against the US navy. He is liaising with Scottish environmental groups, who have long opposed the bombing of the isolated beauty spot.

What began as a low-key protest has gained enormous momentum in Puerto Rica. The US navy was forced to admit it had, in violation of federal rules, fired ammunition tipped with depleted uranium on Vieques.

A further investigation by the Puerto Rican government uncovered more accidents at the training ground and the fishermen's protests have now a become a full-scale civil disobedience protest, orchestrated by those who no longer want the country to be a protectorate of the US.

A spokesman for the ministry of defence said allowing the Americans to bombard Cape Wrath was part of the routine co-operation between Nato member states.

webTitle: Pit museum faces axe in council cuts

fields.headline: Pit museum faces axe in council cuts
fields.trailText: The only mining museum in the north-west is facing closure because of a council's financial crisis.
fields.body:
The only mining museum in the north-west is facing closure because of a council's financial crisis.

The Lancashire Mining Museum, in Salford, attracts 28,000 visitors a year but the city council needs to make £13m cuts, so it is likely to be turned into a training centre for council staff.

The museum is set in Buille Hill, a Georgian mansion built in 1825 for Thomas Potter, one of the founders of the Manchester Guardian.

It was first used as a museum in 1904 and became a dedicated mining museum 52 years later.

Alan Davis, the museum's curator, said: "Modern children don't even know what coal is because they have been brought up with central heating. They come here and learn all about an industry which ran from 1296 to 1996. This country owes so much to the miners and it is important that future generations learn about the industry."

He said the campaign to save the museum had received messages of support - via the internet - from America, Canada, New Zealand and Australia. Former miners are also backing the campaign.

But Keith Mann, a city councillor, said there were other mining museums in Britain where people could learn about the coal industry.

A decision about the museum's future will be made tomorrow by the council.

fields.headline: Open day on the mayor
fields.trailText: I am glad to see Frank Dobson opening up the over-simplified debate over the funding of the Tube (Dobson turns on Blair prats, February 25). The two questions which need to be answered are how much will the borrowing cost? And who will pay? Neither question has been answered. Therefore no judgment can yet be made.
fields.body:
I am glad to see Frank Dobson opening up the over-simplified debate over the funding of the Tube (Dobson turns on Blair prats, February 25). The two questions which need to be answered are how much will the borrowing cost? And who will pay? Neither question has been answered. Therefore no judgment can yet be made.

Government borrowing would be the cheapest because it can achieve the lowest interest. Bonds may also be low-cost, but I doubt whether the full cost could be raised in this way. The cost and terms of any private borrowing is as yet unknown.

The options for who will eventually pay are the national taxpayer, the council taxpayer or the passenger. The mayor and assembly will need to negotiate the best terms and make a judgement when the terms are known. In the end, I expect a balance to be struck and the costs to be shared.

Cllr Maggie Mansell Labour GLA candidate, Croydon and Sutton

 Matthew Norman is right that Cities of London and Westminster Labour party's annual meeting voted unanimously on a resolution criticising Labour's mayoral selection process (Diary, February 25). He is also correct that I am a supporter of Frank Dobson. So were many others at the meeting. But regardless of who they wanted to win, everyone agreed with what all the candidates have already said, that the process had much-discussed flaws.

And those present at the meeting would also agree on the key issue - no one wants to see a Tory elected as the first mayor of London. That really would be an outrage. All London Labour members and MPs should pull together behind Frank now to make sure that doesn't happen.

Kate Green London

 If Livingstone leaves the party now and stands as an independent mayoral candidate he will be an easy scapegoat and will have all the blame thrown at him so that the current leadership can duck their responsibilities and cling to power. If however he holds his nerve now and continues to play the long game, then his reputation and influence can only increase after the next general election.

Syd Hancock, St Connec, France

 My mum says she would vote for Ken. As she is an out and out Tory, that's enough reason for me to back Dobbo. Let Ken run as an independent and Londoners decide. My experience of a Livingstone London suggests he is all mouth and no trousers.

Mark Sadler Bangor

fields.headline: Life and Liberty
fields.standfirst: Brady and Hindley deserve a hearing
fields.trailText: The Moors murderers are back in the headlines - one wants to die; the other continues to fight for her freedom. Ian Brady made his first court appearance for 30 years yesterday for the right to starve himself to death. The hearing is expected to last for four days but the main arguments are already clear. Myra Hindley has written over 150 letters about her life, which form the basis of a BBC documentary tomorrow evening about the Moors murderers that explores whether a life sentence should mean life. In G2 today, we publish a background report on this programme, extracts of the letters, and a review of them by the psychiatrist who concluded Brady had become mentally ill and should be transferred to a secure hospital.
fields.body:
The Moors murderers are back in the headlines - one wants to die; the other continues to fight for her freedom. Ian Brady made his first court appearance for 30 years yesterday for the right to starve himself to death. The hearing is expected to last for four days but the main arguments are already clear. Myra Hindley has written over 150 letters about her life, which form the basis of a BBC documentary tomorrow evening about the Moors murderers that explores whether a life sentence should mean life. In G2 today, we publish a background report on this programme, extracts of the letters, and a review of them by the psychiatrist who concluded Brady had become mentally ill and should be transferred to a secure hospital.

Ian Brady is not seeking release from the life sentenced imposed in 1966 for the torture and cold-blooded murder of three young people. He subsequently admitted to two further murders. He was transferred to Ashworth maximum security hospital in 1988 following a deterioration of his psychiatric condition after two decades of solitary confinement. And that is the cause of his problem.

If he was still in prison, he would be allowed to starve himself to death. For most of the last century, forced feeding was part of prison policy following a 1909 landmark judgment in a suffragette case. But slowly, with the help of the European Convention on Human Rights, prisoners' rights expanded including the right to die. The British Medical Association's position became unequivocal: there should be no attempt to force feed if a doctor in charge of a hunger striker was satisfied that the prisoner had been rational at the time of the decision and was aware of the consequences. The old prison policy was changed in the 1970s and upheld in a 1994 court judgment.

Where it becomes complicated for Brady is that he is now restrained under the mental health act. The hospital will seek to justify the forced feeding (through a tube passing through his nose into his stomach) on the grounds his refusal to eat is related to his illness. It is all part of his treatment. But there are three problems with this argument: his diagnosis as a psychopath, a disorder which half the psychiatric profession believe is untreatable; earlier rulings by the courts which have established that a mental illness does not automatically preclude a prisoner from taking his own decisions on medical treatment; and the sanity of his own plan. Who can blame him for not wanting to spend another 20 years behind bars? He would rather die now than "rot slowly". He should be given that right. Keeping people alive so that they can be punished is barbaric.

Similarly, a civilised society would have released Hindley by now. Of course no home secretary will take on the tabloids - with their determination to maintain Hindley as Britain's most evil woman - but hopefully the European Court of Human Rights will interfere. The 1990 decision to impose a "whole life" sentence was wrong. She is not being imprisoned for the danger she poses, but for the gravity of her crime. No one can deny the gravity, but she is the only person to be serving a "whole life" tariff - meaning she should expect to die in prison - who was not an actual killer. Lord Chief Justice Lane, no softie, only recommended 25 years. She has already served 34 years and is still only aged 57. Is she expected to serve another 23? Her lawyers rightly took her case to the Law Lords last month. Let them take note: the parole board, which scrutinised her minutely, has already recommended an open prison - a pre-step to release.

fields.headline: Getting and spending
fields.standfirst: We may need a leap year holiday to do it
fields.trailText: Today is a rare kind of day: a 29th day of February, something that turns up only once in four years. Even Christmas comes once a year. And yet it is hardly commemorated, except in one sense: women, by convention, may decently propose marriage to men in a leap year, and especially on February 29. Men are not required to accept, but not to do so has always been thought caddish. At a time when in all other contexts sex discrimination is on the retreat, that convention looks ridiculous. In a truly equal society, women would propose to men as regularly as men to women. But that would leave February 29 devoid of any obvious difference from all other days.
fields.body:
Today is a rare kind of day: a 29th day of February, something that turns up only once in four years. Even Christmas comes once a year. And yet it is hardly commemorated, except in one sense: women, by convention, may decently propose marriage to men in a leap year, and especially on February 29. Men are not required to accept, but not to do so has always been thought caddish. At a time when in all other contexts sex discrimination is on the retreat, that convention looks ridiculous. In a truly equal society, women would propose to men as regularly as men to women. But that would leave February 29 devoid of any obvious difference from all other days.

Since we British have fewer public holidays than most of our neighbours, as well as working longer hours, even a government which preaches the work ethic might decently allow us an extra holiday when a February 29 trundles round. Treasury statisticians will confirm that this would add a mere 0.25% of a day to the annual quota. To have it fall in February - when it could be tacked on to school half-terms - might seem appropriate: this is a month when people need cheering up. It would give the south of Britain an opportunity to enjoy the country in early spring: thanks to climate change, gardens in the south-west which used to open in March are this year in business already. In bleaker regions one could still go to see the snowdrops and aconites. But a leap year holiday might also be a moment for quadrennial stocktaking, a day to look back on the past four years and reflect on those to come: a time to ask the question: should we change or stay as we are? It is tempting to say that on leap year holidays shops be closed: "getting and spending we lay waste our powers" Wordsworth wrote, and it is even true now everything opens on Sundays. But that is too prescriptive. If people would rather spend the day at Ikea or watching Carlisle United, let them do so. It's is a free country, mostly.

fields.headline: More in the breech ...
fields.trailText: The members of my battalion are in one mind on the SA80: ditch it and purchase the American M16 (Army rifles which jam, February 26). At almost half the weight of a loaded SA80, the M16 wins on comfort factor alone. Some of my colleagues were part of the 10-year trials which have thrown this up, in Alaska and Kuwait. The preliminary report stated that "L85/L86 (the rifle and LSW) not be deployed operationally anywhere in the world". Not encouraging, with my regiment deploying to the former Yugoslavia next winter. Now all we need are some radios that work; I've sorted out a mobile phone, just in case!

 The prototype SA80 was unveiled in 1976 on Salisbury Plain. Defence correspondents drooled over the new weapon, designed to fire a tiny 4.85mm round. Pressure was reportedly exerted by the US defence establishment for the SA80 to be developed to chamber the Nato 5.56mm round, in common with the American M16 assault rifle. Luckily it did not come into service until after the Falklands war when it would undoubtedly have joined the catalogue of other kit which fell down on the job. Drowned out for two decades has been the opinion of the people who actually have to use the wretched SA80; the PBI (Poor Bleedin' Infantry). From the outset, soldiers dubbed the SA80 "the Palitoy gun", which indicates the level of their faith in it to perform as what is bluntly called "a manstopper".

The British soldier would far rather fight using the Kalashnikov AK-47. But that would mean undermining the military myth clung to in Washington and London that the west has the best.

Mike Starke Chale Green, Isle of Wight

webTitle: His murder wasn't racist, the court was

fields.headline: His murder wasn't racist, the court was
fields.trailText: Reading the interview with Doreen Lawrence (I think about Stephen all the time, February 24) I feel her pain. Eighteen months ago my partner's son was killed by a thug who was burgling his home. Scott was a young man of mixed race with a warm, caring nature and an enjoyment of his mixed heritage. When asked why he had cheered for England, Scotland and Jamaica in the World Cup he replied "because I can".
fields.body:
Reading the interview with Doreen Lawrence (I think about Stephen all the time, February 24) I feel her pain. Eighteen months ago my partner's son was killed by a thug who was burgling his home. Scott was a young man of mixed race with a warm, caring nature and an enjoyment of his mixed heritage. When asked why he had cheered for England, Scotland and Jamaica in the World Cup he replied "because I can".

Our experience of institutional racism wasn't with the police but with the judicial system. The police behaved impeccably throughout, our family liaison officer was excellent and they worked hard to secure a murder conviction. However, Macpherson would do well to look at the judiciary. With all the publicity given to the use of racist and sexist terms, how can a prosecution barrister refer to someone of mixed race as "half caste"? Why, when talking to my partner's nephew (also of mixed race), did the judge explain very slowly and carefully that he was not to discuss the case with anyone, and then repeat himself and ask slowly and deliberately if he understood?

In the public gallery were members of the family, black and white, but in the courtroom itself, apart from one solitary black person on the jury, it was a sea of white. Although the accused, who would be seen as white despite being the product of a white and a mixed-race parent, admitted stabbing Scott three times through the heart, the jury believed his account that he had been attacked first and had lashed out blindly in panic. They returned a verdict of manslaughter.

As a white person, I found the anti-racism of many white lefty liberals to be a sham. When they heard of what had happened I would be asked, "was it a racist attack?" When I answered not as far as we knew they would look very disappointed and walk away or change the subject. They were only interested in a campaign to notch on their belt. Black people would ask about myself, my partner and ask about Scott as a person and only much later was the motive for the attack mentioned.

What should never be lost sight of is that it is not only the police that suffer from institutionalised racism. They are merely one part of society and that is what has to change.

London

fields.headline: Book value
fields.trailText: After 25 years working in public libraries I am unable to dispute the sentiments expressed about Manchester Central Library (The other dome of discovery, February 26). There is an alternative to the "best value" public library service of which Jane Rogers and other readers are probably unaware. Manchester, like Newcastle, is blessed with an independent library (The Portico) where the ideals of Thackeray and Smiles thrive.
fields.body:
After 25 years working in public libraries I am unable to dispute the sentiments expressed about Manchester Central Library (The other dome of discovery, February 26). There is an alternative to the "best value" public library service of which Jane Rogers and other readers are probably unaware. Manchester, like Newcastle, is blessed with an independent library (The Portico) where the ideals of Thackeray and Smiles thrive.

The Newcastle Literary and Philosophical Society was one of the founders of the 24-strong Association of Independent Libraries, and here you can find obscure Jacobean poems and original 19th-century travel accounts, as well as the latest Jane Rule, Jacqueline Wilson, and Colin Dexter. Yes, there is an annual subscription, but this is far less that your TV licence (£65 pa).

Newcastle-upon-Tyne

fields.headline: Maths on the web
fields.trailText:
Maths Year 2000
Star rating **
Aimed at: everyone
fields.body:
Maths Year 2000
Star rating **
Aimed at: everyone

The department for education's new maths site is good - but could do better, given the resources available and the importance of the DfEE's new Maths = Top Jobs campaign. But it has some entertaining mathematical games and an online museum of instruments (the warfare section is a missed opportunity to engage young minds). If you want to take your child or class to one of the five remaining Maths Fests, look here for details.

GCSE Bitesize revision
Star rating ***
Aimed at: everyone

Useful revision exercises and tips for algebra, data handling, number work and shape, space and measure at GCSE level. Students can also email a team of teachers with questions about difficult subject content and exam techniques, although there is no guarantee of a reply.

Number Generator
Star rating ***
Aimed at: parents

The National Lottery's Random Number Generator is a fun way to introduce children to the concept of probability, as long as you don't object to the commercial element of the site. Playing the lottery is, of course, illegal for under-16s and a more obviously mathematical (but less entertaining) random number generator can be found at: http://lottery.merseyworld.com/Winning_index.html

Maths Net
Star rating ****
Aimed at: everyone

Exciting, thoroughly interactive and full of resources, games and puzzles. Could be better organised, and you'll need to switch on Java in your browser (by going to Edit/Preferences) and possibly download the Shockwave plug-in too. The lively collection of articles will also interest maths teachers.

History of Maths
Star rating ***
Aimed at: teachers

An engrossing site from St Andrews University, the archive delves into the history of mathematicians and mathematical concepts. Whether you want to flesh out your teaching with, say, the history of pi through the ages, consult the Famous Curves Index or learn more about Arabic and Greek mathematicians, this is worth a visit.

NRICH Maths
Star rating ****
Aimed at: teachers

NRICH is an online maths club run by Cambridge University, providing an Ask a Mathematician bulletin board service, a large archive of games and problems, teaching ideas and a section on LOGO.

Fibonacci Numbers
Aimed at: everyone
Star rating ***

Surrey University's Dr Ron Knott has compiled this small, fascinating guide to the Fibonacci phenomenon in nature - found in petals, seed heads, leaves and breeding patterns - and its mathematical implications.

Weisstein's World
Aimed at: teachers
Star rating ***

A US site that claims to be the world's largest online maths resource. It's not designed for our national curriculum, so should be used selectively. Has a fun random topic feature, and an encyclopaedic approach makes it dry but authoritative.

 You can find dozens of other useful maths links at Net class or contact Ros Taylor.

Next week: literacy websites

fields.headline: Internet know-how
fields.trailText: Six months ago the web carried about 9.5m sites. Now it's probably 11m. Most are dross, miscellania or just irrelevant; but more and more are informed, fascinating and probably just what you need to engage children and students.
fields.body:
Six months ago the web carried about 9.5m sites. Now it's probably 11m. Most are dross, miscellania or just irrelevant; but more and more are informed, fascinating and probably just what you need to engage children and students.

It may be giving pupils access to information they couldn't get otherwise, such as the US National Drought Mitigation Centre; the means to draw graphs and diagrams more easily, building on coursebook work, or offering fresh revision materials.

Even basic key stage 1 (four- to seven-year-olds) listening and music skills, as well as mouse control, can be practised at the Little Animals Activity Centre.

Many of these sites are just as useful for homework and project research. With a web connection, you can share the task of looking for resources and information with your child - and help ensure they don't plagiarise!

Philip Milner, who teaches French at Leeds Grammar School, has taken pupils on a virtual journey to a specific destination. "I gave them all the name of a provincial city in France, and they had to use the French national railway website to find out how to get there, and locate the Museum of Fine Arts - these towns all have their own sites. They've also visited ski resorts and checked the weather conditions online."

The worksheet, he says, was particularly important. "Some got there and some didn't, but they all knew what they had to do. You've got to keep wandering around and specifically point them to things." At GCSE level, classes mailed their exchange school about the millennium celebrations.

On the web, it's important to make tasks very clear and maybe impose a time limit, thus deterring a few faster, web-literate pupils from using spare class time to look at off-topic sites.

If you're helping with homework, know precisely what your child is seeking. "Castles" is too vague; "Welsh castles" or "13th-century castles" or "keeps" is better. Try a searchable directory like the family-vetted www.ukplus.co.uk rather than a vast engine like Altavista. Education Unlimited's Netclass section is also useful. Bookmark any good sites and make sure your child acknowledges the source in any project or essay.

fields.headline: Covert education
fields.standfirst: John Crace discovers how private investigators learn their trade
fields.trailText: John Crace discovers how private investigators learn their trade
fields.body:
Marlowe, Magnum, Colombo and Easy Rawlins; the US has done us proud with private dicks. Chiselled, maverick loners in raincoats and trilbys with one eye on the case and the other on the bottle of bourbon. We Brits have sometimes been a little more restrained with our Peter Wimseys and Mr Parkises, but even on this side of the pond the private eye has a certain frisson. Edge, glamour, insight...

Typically, the reality for Britain's estimated 10,000 private investigators is more Boon than Sam Spade. Most of the work involves the serving of legal documents, tracing witnesses, taking statements, measuring up after car accidents, and generally doing all the donkey work that solicitors can't be bothered to do for themselves. But one feature of their fictional counterparts remains. Anyone can be one.

"You can come out of prison one day, and set yourself up as an investigator the next," says Peter Heims, past president of the Association of British Investigators (ABI).

Not surprisingly, most people within the industry are none too happy about this, and the government is expected to close this anomaly in its new security bill to be introduced later this year. There are some who would like the government to go a great deal further than this and insist that all investigators have a minimum level of qualifications and training.

However, these voices are almost all coming from the two professional bodies, the ABI and the Institute of Professional Investigators (IPI), both of which expect a certain standard of competence from their members.

As these bodies only have about 4-500 members each, with some investigators belonging to both, you might gather there is still a certain resistance to training out there.

"It's our entry exam that's the problem," says Heims. "For example, former serving police and security officers often take the view that they already know everything they need to know and there's no need for an exam. But the work is actually very different when you don't have a badge to back up your authority. I suspect that even though the exam isn't too demanding, the real reason so many don't want to take it is fear of failure."

Most of those who enter the industry learn their trade on the hoof, and experience counts for a great deal. But there are some formal training options for those who want them.

There are two correspondence courses, about which Heims is a little sniffy (he takes issue with some of the content), and centres in Leeds, Derby, Manchester and London where you can do NVQ levels 3 and 4 in investigation.

The IPI also offers its own training courses. Sarah Martin, who cleaned up at the ABI's oscars last year by winning the accolade of "Investigator of the Year", has completed both the NVQs and the IPI courses and freely admits she is something of a training junky.

"The work we do can be extremely stressful," she says. "We deal with everything from debt to death, and the results of our investigations can send people to prison, make them divorce, bankrupt them, lose them their job and deprive them of custody of their children. We owe it to our clients to make sure that the job is done properly and that we don't make any errors which could jeopardise any court proceedings."

Martin believes training should concentrate on an understanding of the legal processes in which the investigator is liable to be involved. She is big on continuity of evidence and often attends conferences to update herself on changes in the law.

If this sounds fearfully dull for those who were looking for more cloak and dagger action, there is plenty of that to be had, too. Private investigators are often called upon to do surveillance work, though, as Martin will tell you, that can pall after eight hours hiding out in a bush waiting for a suspect to appear.

If that doesn't excite you, try this. A top investigator with the right qualifications can rake in well over £100K per year. That NVQ is looking more attractive by the minute.

 For details of NVQs in investigation call SITO on 01905 20004 or Edexcel on 0207 393 4580.

fields.headline: Massage
fields.trailText: Massage
fields.body:
Ow! Oof! Go easy there! Look, you must try to relax. You're very tense.

But I thought massage was - aargh! - supposed to be soothing. It should be, but you need a lot of work on these muscles - they're so knotted.

So what is massage exactly? Massage is a method of kneading and rubbing the body that can create a sense of relaxation, relieve aches and tone muscles. It's the scientific manipulation of the soft tissues for a curative effect, one of the oldest forms of healing. Hippocrates...

Ow! Blast Hippocrates! Hippocrates said: "Hard rubbing binds, much rubbing causes parts to waste and moderate rubbing makes them grow." The ancient Chinese and Indians used massage, too.

And the ancient Swedes, nudge nudge. Oouf! Yaroo! Sorry, but we're very firm about protecting the distinction between our massage and the seedy stuff you are hinting at. In fact, Swedish massage, established in the early 19th century by Professor Peter Ling, has a very distinguished history, although these days we prefer the terms "remedial massage" for the therapeutic approach, and "body massage" for the invigorating and toning effects.

Are there other varieties? Yes. Specialities include neuro, muscular, connective tissue, shiatsu, aromatherapy, Indian head, and facial.

OK! What would I need to learn? Apart from being able to use your hands skilfully, a good knowledge of anatomy and physiology. Masseurs use their weight to knead and rub the body, and they need to be strong, physically.

Any courses in massage will include biology and anatomy. You will also need a knowledge of hygiene, safety precautions, first aid and general health care. Only then can the therapist appreciate the value of massage on the body's systems in, for instance, aiding circulation, respiration and digestion. And only then will the therapist know the situations in which massage is definitely not advisable.

Finally, you will need to understand, and conform to, a code of ethics.

Count me in. Where do I get this? Courses are available for those wanting a general introduction and for those who want to reach a professional level. Massage can only be picked up by a training that offers meticulous instruction and individual guidance.

Ay, there's the rub - Ouch! Are there letters to be had? Some diploma courses are approved, by the Institute of Complementary Medicine, for instance. Successful students who fulfil all ICM criteria can register with the British Register for Complementary Practitioners.

The Association of Reflexology is another recognising body that accredits courses.

fields.headline: Qaahili for beginners
fields.standfirst: The QAA is to do more in colleges.  Michele Hanson gives a taste of things to come
fields.trailText: The QAA is to do more in colleges. Michele Hanson gives a taste of things to come
fields.body:
Our art schools are being inspected, by the Quality Assurance Agency (QAA). But don't worry, they'll probably all get top marks: while the inspectors are visiting, pupils and teachers will be behaving perfectly, because all colleges will have spent a fortune making sure they do. All part-time staff are paid £120 a day to come in and learn how to stand, dress, move around and teach. Oops! Sorry. They won't be teaching, they'll be "facilitating learning outcomes". They know how to do this because they've been taught by visitors paid to talk gobbledygook.

I hear all this from my friend Roberto, who teaches at a London art school, but has been banned from Inspection Week for being stroppy in class. No wonder he is in a strop: it is infuriating, when one is a grown-up teacher, to be taught something you consider ridiculous by someone you know to be more stupid than yourself.

Roberto had difficulty reading the big, glossy and rather costly Self-Assessment Document produced by his college. This set out the college's aims and objectives, is sent to the inspectors and is written in Qaahili. It describes a Personal and Professional Development course.

"PPD is a mandatory course component comprising a unit of 10 credits per level," it read. Roberto waded on, through reams of rubbish, and came to a section on Learning Outcomes. Perhaps that would help.

"Avoid using general terms such as: comprehend, understand... appreciate," said the document. Roberto may use "criticise, describe, recognise, summarise and generalise", which are presumably not general terms.

Roberto was no wiser. He studied his sheet on Observation Dos and Don'ts.

"Do: stand in a relaxed, alert position/ use your hands to enliven your presentation/ speak clearly and slightly slower than normal voice/ ask latecomers if they have had difficulty with transport... but in a non-judgemental way/ be yourself - calm and confident. Don't: pace about the room/ flap your hands about/ appear overly laid-back or casual. Remember to: enjoy your teaching and learning."

Teaching? Someone has forgotten their QAA instructions. Teaching isn't allowed any more, only facilitating learning outcomes.

Not that Roberto's college is perfect. There are a few objections he would like to make, but there's no point in voicing his concerns to the QAA because they can't change anything. They can't improve things or do anything constructive. All they can do is give you a low mark. Then no one will come to your college and you'll be out of a job. Naturally, teachers (sorry, facilitators), with proper full-time jobs are, sensibly, keeping their mouths shut.

The Royal College of Art got top marks when it was inspected. So it can probably speak Qaahili quite well. Here are some examples:

Qaahili: Initiatives to enhance the quality of teaching are represented in the recently introduced voluntary scheme of peer observation and the management observation of new staff.

English: You are surrounded by Gestapo.

Happy times.

fields.headline: Local solutions
fields.standfirst: How should the Conservative party react to the new learning and skills bill? Beware tidy mindedness, warns  Tim Boswell
fields.trailText: How should the Conservative party react to the new learning and skills bill? Beware tidy mindedness, warns Tim Boswell
fields.body:
Only once in a while does further education get the attention and support it deserves. John Major's Conservative government made a breakthrough in 1992 by freeing colleges from local authority control, creating an independent further education sector and embarking on a (successful) programme of expanding enrolments. Together with the creation of a new framework for vocational qualifications centred on GNVQs and NVQs, the scene was set for a higher profile.

I was lucky to be the further education minister at that time - and I will always remember the excitement of the first gathering of principals and chairs of governors at the Queen Elizabeth II Centre as the sector was launched - it felt as near as I shall ever feel to running down the tunnel at Wembley for a cup final.

And since then further education has played a blinder. Enrolments have exploded, new courses have flourished and a start has been made on upskilling all levels of the work force, as well as, crucially, delivering more A levels even than school sixth forms and preparing students for progression to higher education.

Of course, there have been problems - some to be anticipated once colleges were given their head, and their independent status led to greater transparency and accountability.

I do not seek to minimise problems of governance or control of franchised operations, nor those derived from over-rapid expansion. I am conscious also of the considerable strains of transition on staff, whose position needs better recognition. But few in the sector would want to put the clock back and I believe the "pluses" far outweigh the "minuses".

One particularly helpful development as the sector has settled to its new role has been the growth of partnership arrangements. Healthy competition between institutions need not preclude co-operation between them, say on admissions, course provision or common services.

All providers, further education, local education authority and private sector alike, are in one sense offering a public service and it is the overall quality of provision that matters most. I believe that this local cooperation from the "bottom up" would offer the best approach for all learning requirements, at all levels of ability; and with good impartial guidance available to all, can point young people and adult learners (including those who missed out on basic skills) in the direction they ought to go.

This is the context in which Conservatives should approach the government's current proposals in the learning and skills bill. Of course, the post-16 scene has always contained anomalies of funding and organisation, but beware an excess of tidy mindedness.

Government proposals pose a number of important threats: to school sixth forms, whose basis for continuing funding is precarious; to the training budget and modern apprenticeships, as Training and Enterprise Councils are wound up and the active business voice is attenuated; and to the local authorities' continuing role in financing and conducting informal education post-16 and for adults.

Proposals for a new Youth Support Service will depend on packets of funding from many sources. Emphasis on social exclusion, however commendable in principle, may be bought at the cost of diluting guidance for all young people.

Finally, proposals for the new inspection schemes are an "unprincipled" mess.

We hope that detailed scrutiny and further details of departmental thinking will help to allay these fears. But we feel that the emphasis on process, largely driven from the centre, and "top down" is likely to impose extra bureaucracy and frustration on further education.

It would be a tragedy if the sector became demotivated and weakened in its unique ability to serve all age groups and almost every need in the learning society we all want to see.

 Tim Boswell is shadow minister for further education.

fields.headline: A day at the Dome
fields.standfirst: Your chance to take pupils to the Dome free of charge
fields.trailText: Your chance to take pupils to the Dome free of charge
fields.body:
The Dome at Greenwich opened its doors to visitors on January 1 and has featured constantly in the news headlines ever since. Love it or loathe it, you can't afford to miss it, particularly as it will only remain open in its current format - with a unique range of exhibitions and contents - for a year.

Youngsters are important visitors and the organisers are keen to attract visits from school parties.

Packed with educational materials, as well as featuring a self-contained Learning zone, the Dome makes an ideal venue for a school trip that children will enjoy and always remember. In conjunction with Tesco, the Official Education Sponsor of the Millennium Experience, the Guardian is delighted to have organised a prize draw offering 100 free tickets to the lucky school which correctly answers the following question.

How to enter

Answer the following question:

Name two of the curriculum investigations that children can carry out on the Tesco SchoolNet 2000 website (for a clue, have a look at www.tesco.schoolnet2000.com)

Send your answer by Friday, March 31 in an envelope marked "Dome Competition" to Amanda Roper, Guardian Education, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

Terms and conditions:

The competition is open to all schools - primary and secondary - in both the state and independent sector. The Guardian will accept only one application per school, which must be submitted by the head or deputy headteacher. Please state how many pupils attend the school.

The Guardian reserves the right to split the tickets between one or more winners where the agreed winner is a small school with less than 100 pupils. The final decision will rest with the judges.

The prize covers only the cost of admission to the Dome, and will be valid for any date until December 31, 2000, subject to availability. Full terms and conditions available on request.

 Promoter: Tesco Stores Ltd, New Tesco House, Delamare Road, Cheshunt, Herts EN8 9SL.

About the Learning zone

The Learning zone was devised to show visitors why we should embrace learning throughout our lives. It emphasises that the learning of the future will bear little resemblance to that of the past.

Visitors begin their journey by being taken "back to school" with an imaginary school setting - based on a real school - featuring the smell of cooked cabbage wafting through corridors! They then see a film, Lily and the Magic Seed, which tells the story of a little girl whose life is transformed after she is handed "The Seed of Learning". She then invites visitors to join her in the "Learning Orchard".

At the heart of the Learning zone is the Tesco SchoolNet 2000 project - created by thousands of schools, which have put a huge volume of work onto a specially designed website. Since September 1998, over 131,000 pupils from more than 16,000 schools have created the tome of work - in effect an electronic Domesday Book for the 21st century.

Youngsters have submitted contributions using their own words, drawings and photographs to describe their communities - past, present and future. The work consists of more than 43,000 web pages - equivalent to over 30 editions of The Oxford Edition of the Complete Works of William Shakespeare. Visitors can view the web pages on a bank of computers displayed at the entrance to the zone. Teachers can register their schools and receive free teaching resource packs at www.tesco.schoolnet2000.com or by calling 0845 6011423.

 Tesco SchoolNet 2000 was borne out of the success of the Tesco Computers for Schools scheme, now running until April 9. Schools were forwarded catalogues in January, but if you would like to register, call 0870 0100708.

fields.headline: Blunkett's reluctant hero
fields.standfirst: Simon Midgley goes in search of the Merseyside miracle-worker, who must now rescue Sheffield College
fields.trailText: Simon Midgley goes in search of the Merseyside miracle-worker, who must now rescue Sheffield College
fields.body:
George Sweeney, the acting principal of Sheffield College, squirmed with discomfort. The Guardian, the photographer said enthusiastically, wanted to use a really big photograph of him to accompany this article.

Now Mr Sweeney, aged 54, does not like having his picture taken. He is, at the best of times, extremely backward about coming forward to blow his own trumpet. So you can equally imagine his embarrassment when no less a figure than David Blunkett, the Secretary of State for Education and Employment, started extolling his virtues to the assembled throng gathered for the Further Education Funding Council's conference in Birmingham.

Mr Sweeney, who is on secondment from his own college in Merseyside, claims not to have heard what Blunkett said because he was hiding under his seat at the time. In fact Blunkett singled out Sweeney as a Merseyside miracle worker.

While working in an area with socio-economic conditions far worse than in Tower Hamlets and Hackney, Mr Sweeney and his college have boosted their GCSE pass-rate at grades A-C to 67% and the A-level pass rate to 90%.

Now Mr Sweeney has been parachuted in to Sheffield to try to work some of his magic with that city's financially troubled tertiary college, the second largest college in England.

The college has overstretched itself with distance (off-site) franchising and is classified by the Further Education Funding Council as being in category C, which means it is in precarious financial health.

For three years the college, which has 44,000 students, a budget of £40m, five main sites and 1,800 staff, has failed to achieve its targets, despite being the sole further education provider in a city with relatively few sixth forms and little competition for 16- to 19-year-olds.

Late last year the funding council decided to get tough. In December, after the college's previous principal, Ken Ruddiman, retired at the age of 60, it asked Mr Sweeney to lead a six-month review of the city's further education provision with the help of Terry Melia, the chair of the Further Education Development Agency and former funding council chief inspector.

The funding council also imposed two new governors on the college, one of whom is Professor Bob Fryer, a director of learndirect (formerly the University for Industry).

It is thought that a suggestion that one of the college's main sites, Parson Cross, which just happened to be in Mr Blunkett's Sheffield Brightside constituency, might have to be closed down if more funding were not forthcoming, had not gone down terribly well with the Secretary of State or the funding council. Ruddiman says there were too many campuses to support with the level of funding coming in and Parson Cross was the most expensive.

Mr Sweeney, who has spent his working life teaching in further education colleges, was appointed principal designate of Knowsley College in 1990. It was his job to oversee the merger of two small colleges, Kirkby College and Knowsley Central Tertiary College. Having been born and brought up in Huyton, Harold Wilson's former constituency, he knew the area already.

Knowsley College is situated in what Sweeney describes as an "economically challenging environment" where the levels of attainment at 16 are very low. When he arrived he told staff the goal was to make the college the best in the north-west. The initial target was to achieve national average pass rates in all areas of work.

The trick, he said, is in doing simple things a step at a time. Targets should be ambitious, but achievable. The principal should also have some idea of how the college can get from situation A to target B. The other key task, he added, is to give people the confidence not to fear blame if things do not work.

"It's about teamwork," Mr Sweeney said. "It's about engaging people's enthusiasm. You only engage people's enthusiasm if they feel that what they say matters, is listened to and acted upon.

"It's a sound commonsense appreciation of how organisations work," he said. "And the political processes involved. One of the very salutary lessons you learn when you become a principal is that saying something should happen does not necessarily mean that it will happen.

"If you are going to be effective, you very quickly learn that things tend to be achieved by teams of good people. It is not the individual coming in and saying: 'This is how you do it. Here is the way, the truth and the light.'

"And you do not actually reach a stage where you say: 'Well that is it. We have done it.' It is about how you develop a culture of continuous improvement."

Knowsley College is now funding council accredited so that it enjoys a less interventionist inspection regime. It also has Beacon College and Investors in People status.

At Sheffield the review continues. "I have spoken and listened to a lot of people. I have tried to identify the college's extraordinary strengths and the things that need to be done.

"It has got a clear local focus but I think it needs to be sharper. The college is also drawing back from national franchising.

"I am trying to come to a view about what the normal level of activity within Sheffield and its surrounding areas should be. I think that there are clear avenues that need developing. We have a really good higher education programme. Our A-level programme is very impressive. I think we need more development in level one and two work."

And the million dollar question - what is the key to college success? "It's about leadership which discovers and harnesses staff enthusiasm and turns it to a constructive purpose. It's about being a conductor. I try to be as inclusive as possible in the way I do things, which can be misconstrued by people. No, it is not a democracy. It is about having an intelligent discussion and an intelligent discussion requires people to know what is going on.

"It is about trying to give people a sense of perspective about where the institution should be going and giving them the belief that you can get there. I guess that sounds like motherhood and apple pie. It's not. That is what I do and in my experience it works."
