In December, after the college's previous principal, Ken Ruddiman, retired at the age of 60, it asked Mr Sweeney to lead a six-month review of the city's further education provision with the help of Terry Melia, the chair of the Further Education Development Agency and former funding council chief inspector. The funding council also imposed two new governors on the college, one of whom is Professor Bob Fryer, a director of learndirect (formerly the University for Industry). It is thought that a suggestion that one of the college's main sites, Parson Cross, which just happened to be in Mr Blunkett's Sheffield Brightside constituency, might have to be closed down if more funding were not forthcoming, had not gone down terribly well with the Secretary of State or the funding council. Ruddiman says there were too many campuses to support with the level of funding coming in and Parson Cross was the most expensive. Mr Sweeney, who has spent his working life teaching in further education colleges, was appointed principal designate of Knowsley College in 1990. It was his job to oversee the merger of two small colleges, Kirkby College and Knowsley Central Tertiary College. Having been born and brought up in Huyton, Harold Wilson's former constituency, he knew the area already. Knowsley College is situated in what Sweeney describes as an "economically challenging environment" where the levels of attainment at 16 are very low. When he arrived he told staff the goal was to make the college the best in the north-west. The initial target was to achieve national average pass rates in all areas of work. The trick, he said, is in doing simple things a step at a time. Targets should be ambitious, but achievable. The principal should also have some idea of how the college can get from situation A to target B. The other key task, he added, is to give people the confidence not to fear blame if things do not work. "It's about teamwork," Mr Sweeney said. "It's about engaging people's enthusiasm. You only engage people's enthusiasm if they feel that what they say matters, is listened to and acted upon. "It's a sound commonsense appreciation of how organisations work," he said. "And the political processes involved. One of the very salutary lessons you learn when you become a principal is that saying something should happen does not necessarily mean that it will happen. "If you are going to be effective, you very quickly learn that things tend to be achieved by teams of good people. It is not the individual coming in and saying: 'This is how you do it. Here is the way, the truth and the light.' "And you do not actually reach a stage where you say: 'Well that is it. We have done it.' It is about how you develop a culture of continuous improvement." Knowsley College is now funding council accredited so that it enjoys a less interventionist inspection regime. It also has Beacon College and Investors in People status. At Sheffield the review continues. "I have spoken and listened to a lot of people. I have tried to identify the college's extraordinary strengths and the things that need to be done. "It has got a clear local focus but I think it needs to be sharper. The college is also drawing back from national franchising. "I am trying to come to a view about what the normal level of activity within Sheffield and its surrounding areas should be. I think that there are clear avenues that need developing. We have a really good higher education programme. Our A-level programme is very impressive. I think we need more development in level one and two work." And the million dollar question - what is the key to college success? "It's about leadership which discovers and harnesses staff enthusiasm and turns it to a constructive purpose. It's about being a conductor. I try to be as inclusive as possible in the way I do things, which can be misconstrued by people. No, it is not a democracy. It is about having an intelligent discussion and an intelligent discussion requires people to know what is going on. "It is about trying to give people a sense of perspective about where the institution should be going and giving them the belief that you can get there. I guess that sounds like motherhood and apple pie. It's not. That is what I do and in my experience it works."

fields.headline: After the storm
fields.standfirst: David Cohen reports on resurgent higher education in the nations of the Pacific Rim
fields.trailText: David Cohen reports on resurgent higher education in the nations of the Pacific Rim
fields.body:
Government officials looking at new strategies to attract fresh Asian blood into British institutions of higher learning will discover a very different mood in the region from the one that has enveloped the Asia-Pacific area for the past three years.

From Singapore and Kuala Lumpur to north Asia, there is a feeling that the worst of the recent economic crisis has passed. The region's stock markets are rising and currencies getting stronger.

"The region has moved out of the pit, no question," says Lim Pin, vice-chancellor of the National University of Singapore. "The question now is how fast countries can get back to the starting point, and how well they can begin to move again."

South Korea is trying to solidify its reputation as one of the region's "knowledge economies". The government is pushing Brain Korea 21, a $1bn project intended to push the republic's 83 universities up into the ranks of the world's best by 2005.

The aim is to improve graduate schools at the top universities, strengthen regional institutions and upgrade academic research. The last goal is to be achieved by a benchmarking project that measures local institutions against foreign, mainly Anglo-American, counterparts, and by a new fund that will bring in up to 140 science lecturers from abroad each year.

At South Korea's dominant university, Seoul National, undergraduate enrolment will be cut by 30%, with entry standards raised to the level of some US institutions. In engineering, administrators hope a successful Seoul National applicant will have the same potential as one at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Seoul National will also be expanding foreign enrolments, conducting more lectures in English and establishing hostels for foreign students.

Malaysia is aggressively reviving earlier strategies to halt the flood of young people leaving to study abroad. The blueprint for a Multimedia Super Corridor, a 10-by-30-mile strip dedicated to the information technology industry, is back on track. A new wave of private institutions are training nearly 150,000 students, roughly as many as those in the eight state universities, which are themselves now run like corporations - more than half operate in the black.

"The crisis has hastened the initiative for foreign investments," says Leonard Yong, a professor of psychology at the University of Malaysia, referring to efforts to lure foreign corporations and universities into campus life.

Educators in Singapore have still more reason to feel pleased. Although faculty members, like all working Singaporeans, were forced in 1998 to accept a 10% salary cut, overall support for higher education has been stable in the past two-and-a-half years. Singapore lacks resources, and government officials saw the vitality of their two universities as a crucial factor in surviving the economic crisis.

University research and development in the sciences and engineering have long been key to the government's vision of global competitiveness. Since 1997, Singapore has tried to fashion the National University and the Nanyang Technological University into what the government calls "world-class" institutions. The National recently decided to install thousands of sockets to give students easy internet access at the Kent Ridge Road campus.

Yet the downturn has not been without its lessons. "The great thing about the crisis - if I can put it that way - is that it's shown our vulnerabilities," says Tsui Kai Chong, a dean of business at Singapore Management University, due to open in July. "It has challenged us to adapt."

fields.headline: Politics free, finances in chains
fields.trailText: While the stories of other Asian countries are taking new turns, some pessimistic themes keep recurring in Indonesia.
fields.body:
While the stories of other Asian countries are taking new turns, some pessimistic themes keep recurring in Indonesia. "You see those buses out there," says Dr Felix Lengkong, an assistant rector at Atma Jaya University, pointing out of his office window at the ageing streetcars that clatter along the city's main arteries. "That's what a lot of lecturers here arrive to school in." He motions in the other direction, to the university's parking lot, where late-model vehicles sit baking under theequatorial sun. "Those cars, many of them anyway, are owned by some of our richer students." Lengkong is highlighting the problem faced by Indonesian educators in the past decade: a shortage of money.

Nothing much has changed. Indonesia's strides in higher education have been huge, moving it from just a couple of small colleges at independence, in 1945, to today's 1,078 institutions. Of those, which enrol more than two million students, 264 are universities and 30 of them are financed by the state.

Atma Jaya, in the heart of the capital's business district, is one of the country's handful of private universities that are not overshadowed by the prestigious and more prosperous state institutions. Yet even here, a professor can expect to take home only the equivalent of $100 a month, far less than a bellboy at a five-star hotel downtown.

Both the economy and democracy are on shaky legs in Indonesia. The country suffered 77% inflation in 1998, and rioting and looting ended the 32-year authoritarian regime of President Suharto. The first democratic transfer of power to a new president, Abdurrahman Wahid, took place in October.

"In my opinion," says Lengkong, "the worst of the political troubles here are probably over. Students, as well as many rectors, have great hope for the new president. But on a day-to-day level, we're still trying to get back on our feet."

The challenge goes beyond financing new classrooms and textbooks. At Atma Jaya, a long-standing plan in the early 1990s was to build a 31-storey tower to house the university's swelling campus population, but fiscal realities restrained building to a modest gymnasium.

Acquiring new books, especially the English-language ones required for economics and technology courses, is also financially vexing, especially when the books have to be paid for in scarce American dollars.

Lengkong says the new political freedoms have ended the government censorship of unpopular books. But the persistent lack of money means that few students can now afford to purchase any.

Many potential students cannot even afford higher education. For years, government planners counted on higher education to bring affluence to the lower classes, which make up most of Indonesia's 210 million inhabitants, who spread over some 7,500 inhabited islands.

"The overall effect of the crisis on higher education has not been quite as bad as it could have been," says Suprodjo Pusposutardjo, director of academic affairs at the Ministry of Education and Culture.

"But it has re-emphasised the problems universities have always grappled with: lack of technology, lack of expertise, lack of money and resources."

fields.headline: Clever talkers
fields.standfirst: It's a myth that today's language graduates can't find jobs, and  Keith Marshall  can provide the statistics to prove his point
fields.trailText: It's a myth that today's language graduates can't find jobs, and Keith Marshall can provide the statistics to prove his point
fields.body:
There is a myth abroad that language graduates find it hard to get jobs. It is not only pervasive among the general public, but even among many in the language-teaching world. And it is driving potential students of languages away from A-level in the 6th form and away from degree courses in universities.

In fact, however, it is simply untrue. Language graduates are not more likely to be unemployed than specialists in other subjects. Research I have done over recent years has established beyond doubt that, statistically, year after year, language graduates have lower rates of unemployment than graduates in the great majority of other subjects.

Their rates, for example, are consistently lower than for engineering, business studies, psychology, even computing studies, much lower than for the humanities, and the biological and social sciences. Only graduates in medicine, dentistry, veterinary science, law and education have lower employment rates than those in, say, French and German.

The Oxford linguist who complained to the Guardian that nobody on his course had found a job within six months deserves sympathy, but is certainly not typical. Linguists do very well in the competition for jobs in the graduate employment market. The figures (below) speak for themselves.

A further myth, discouraging to many, says that the only jobs for language graduates are teaching and translating. Again, the facts prove this to be wrong - monumentally wrong. First-destination statistics from the Higher Education Statistics Agency (HESA) show that for those who go directly into employment, only a tiny proportion (about 1%) become translators and only 5% go into education - many teaching English as a foreign language.

Many language graduates, like those in most university subjects, go on to further training, including a Postgraduate Certificate in Education. Taking account of this post-grad training, around 16% annually have been going into teaching. But this leaves some 84% who go into other jobs.

The truth, therefore, is that the vast majority of language graduates go into the private sector. They take up jobs where their general intellectual and personal skills are in more everyday use then their language expertise. Surprised that linguists do not make regular use of their degree subject expertise in their professional lives? Why? Do English graduates expect to discuss Shelley or Dickens, do history graduates discourse on Magna Carta in the office?

Much of the UK graduate jobs market (30-40% by most estimates) is open to graduates from all subjects. Here employers are looking for generic graduate qualities. Ability in communication, personal organisation, numeracy, flexibility, analysis, autonomy, teamworking and originality are among those mentioned in Skills Development in Higher Education, the Coopers and Lybrand Report (1998) for the CVCP, DfEE and HEQE. The knowledge and specific additional skills needed for each post in that broad sector are acquired on the job or through employer training.

Those with lower unemployment rates than linguists are nearly all going into earmarked professions, not into a competition for the 30-40% of jobs open to graduates of all disciplines. Here the linguists have the edge over those in other disciplines. Their mix of specialist knowledge and generic abilities is making them more employable than all the rest in that open competition.

The UK needs professionals in all sorts of jobs with developed language skills and high-grade generic graduate abilities. Whether you look at the macrocosm of national statistics or the microcosm of individual universities, our language graduates are in demand.

If anything, we need more: more A-level candidates, more language degree entrants, more language expertise in every area of the economy.

fields.headline: Local authorities to go?
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston reports on plans to redraw the map of education
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston reports on plans to redraw the map of education
fields.body:
Radical plans to abolish local education authorities and hand their functions and powers to the new Local Learning and Skills Councils are being explored at the request of an influential Labour think tank.

A trio of former or current chief education officers, headed by Margaret Maden, ex-head of Warwickshire local education authority, has been commissioned by the Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) to take a hard look at the future of the 150 English authorities.

Their conclusions are due to be released in September and - should they gather support - would be comfortably in time for any consideration for Labour's election manifesto.

News of their project prompted a quick salvo from the Local Government Association.

"Anybody who thinks we want more quangos, rather than local democracy, is not reading the public mood," said Neil Fletcher, the association's head of education.

The role of local education authorities is on the political agenda at the moment. Another think tank, the New Local Government Network, is including it in a review of new models of local education, which is due to be published in June.

Labour has made it clear that as its first term has concentrated on educational standards, so a second term would focus on structures, said Joe Hallgarten, the IPPR's education researcher.

"We commissioned Margaret Maden to think about the role of local education authorities."

To join her inquiry, Maden brought in David Mallen, former chief education officer for East Sussex, and another education director who is still in post.

A source close to the project stressed that Maden, who took over as professor of education at Keele university from Professor Michael Barber, currently heading the government's standards and effectiveness unit, was a long way off producing a final report.

"The question is: how best to organise the functions which are at present administered by local education authorities," said the source.

"The experience coming out of Ofsted inspection of local authorities is that it's the small ones which are running into trouble.

"They don't have the strength and depth of expertise to handle problems."

Their functions - including opening and closing schools, ensuring sufficient places, operating budgets, running special needs - couldn't be done nationally, or regionally.

"These are functions which somebody's got to do sub-regionally and surprise, surprise, suddenly these 47 Local Learning and Skills Councils pop up.

"They are about the right size. What would happen if they took over the local education authorities' functions."

One advantage in transfering powers and responsibilities to the new bodies, which are due to begin operations in April next year, is that it would reestablish the connection between pre- and post-16 education, now that the majority of youngsters were staying in education until 18.

"There's a very strong argument that your education system should be adminstered as a whole."

It mustn't mean bureaucratic appointment, but "proper educationalists. And at least half the Council would have to be elected."

webTitle: Modern visions and the old school of thought

fields.headline: Modern visions and the old school of thought
fields.standfirst: Simon Bowers meets two rising new-media stars
fields.trailText: Simon Bowers meets two rising new-media stars
fields.body:
Chris Beer, 30, is managing director of his own design firm, Splinter, which uses computers to develop a range of products from shelving units to educational programmes.

At Shebbear College, a Methodist secondary school in Devon, he received a very traditional public school education. "I was taught Latin but could see no relevance to it, even then. And I couldn't decline a single verb for you now."

He discovered a talent for arts subjects and, having passed nine O levels, went on to do geography, history and art at A level. He then went to Stoke, to do a BA in art and design. It was not until he got to Stoke, aged 21, that he came into contact with computers. "They were just sitting in the corner of the art room gathering dust. As an artist I was very suspicious of them at first. But when I saw the kind of artwork that was being produced on computers around that time, I became interested.

"I taught myself by trial and error and very quickly saw the potential of this new design tool for my image and print artwork."

After graduating, he was keen to develop his interest in digital art and went to Dundee to do an MA in electronic imaging at the Duncan of Jordanstone College of Art. He then found employment in various computer design companies, before setting up his own firm, Splinter. "It started with three people working in a broom cupboard in Liverpool, and we now employ 13 designers."

The company won three prizes at the Liverpool design awards last year. Beer now hopes to develop an educational computer programme for schools on the London Eye ferris wheel and the problems it posed engineers. He said: "I don't think new technology needs to be understood in great depth for it to be a valuable tool. Most of what we do at Splinter boils down to common sense.

"People who work with computers are often thought of as geeks and that's really unhelpful. There is a big gap at the moment between specialist programmers and the rest of us. Schools ought to be teaching the kind of skills that can fill that gap."

Iain Arnison, 27, is a lecturer in multimedia and internet applications at John Moores University in Liverpool, where he develops learning tools for schools and universities across the country.

He was diagnosed with severe dyslexia at junior school, but his parents fought hard to keep him in main-stream education.

Arnison got 7 GCSEs and an A level in design after negotiating limited exam concessions at Bishop Wilson school in Burton, the Wirral.

Before he took his A levels, however, he was sent an educational psychologist's report which said: "Iain has not yet developed a realistic attitude to his disability. He needs all his parents' support to accept the reality of his handicap."

He nevertheless went on to do an art foundation course and then a degree in Electronic Media at Staffordshire University where he graduated with first-class honours.

"What really changed my life was getting a disability grant of £3,000 to buy a Macintosh computer with speech technology that could convert text into a voice for me. I had always been intrigued by computers since my parents got me a Sinclair ZX 81 when I was 10. And I found that typing on a keyboard helped with common dyslexic problems like mixing up bs and ds. I later bought a BBC B and taught myself some basic programming, just to amuse myself."

Before graduating from Stafford, Arnison had already secured a job at the John Moores University, where he now develops educational computer programmes for LEAs. His latest project is a space adventure game for GCSE students, to help them with applied maths.

"For me school was a nice place to meet people, but I think they should concentrate more on teaching people what they are good at. I always thought it was bizarre that I had to learn French when I clearly couldn't even master English.

"My attitude is: why do we need to be taught mental arithmetic when we have calculators? Why do we need to read text when computers can read it for us? Why do we even need to write when the latest dictation software can take down our words as we speak?"

fields.headline: Changing places
fields.standfirst: Do you have a problem with your child's education? Is something bothering you about your school? Can you help other readers from your experience? This week we are launching an interactive advice column - each week we pose a reader's problem and invite answers from the public along with an expert view.
fields.trailText: This week we are launching an interactive advice column - each week we pose a reader's problem and invite answers from the public along with an expert view. This week: moving house
fields.body:
This week's query

I am about to move house and I have a child in year 6. Should I only be looking at places where the catchment area is good? The problem is that all those houses seem so much more expensive than the rest.

The expert view

"One of the curious side effects of school league tables is their benefit to estate agents rather than to parents trying to educate their children. League tables of exam results were introduced by the Conservatives as a way of making schools more accountable. The idea was that parents would be able to see at a glance which were the good and bad schools in their area.

In fact, they tell you far more about the quality of the intake. Research at King's College, London showed how certain parents played the education market far more effectively than others and schools began to polarise. More recent research at Exeter University has shown that a school's performance has more to do with the postcode of the children attending than almost any other factor. This also means that good results can disguise a school that is coasting.

A better way of understanding the actual quality of education in the school is to find their value added rating. The fact that one school has 60% of pupils getting five A*-C grades doesn't make it better than one getting 39%. Research by the Institute of Education and Edinburgh University also shows the greater the mix of intake, the more all pupils benefit.

Both these studies indicate that, provided around a third of the pupils are well motivated, all pupils will do well.

The problem with value added tables is that they do little to help the schools that still have a very difficult intake, even if they are doing well by those pupils - parents are, understandably, reluctant to send their children there. Nor do they provide much incentive for high-flying schools to alter their entrance policy as exam results are still the main currency by which schools are judged.

We do need a much broader measure of schools' performance if we are to stop the polarisation caused by league tables and to start to give all parents a genuine choice of good schools.

In the meantime, what are parents to do? It is essential to visit schools and capture the atmosphere for yourself. Meeting the teachers and the head should give you a sense of a school's ethos and, if at all possible, go during the school day rather than just a parents' evening."

Bethan Marshall's tip

"Lesson breaks are especially revealing. Do pupils respond to their teachers with friendly formality as they come out of lessons and in the corridors? Noise and jostling are normal but worry if there are signs of aggression. And remember, although your child is now a sweet 11-year-old, he or she will soon turn into one of those huge, shambling adolescents who look so alarming en masse in corridors."

 Bethan Marshall is a lecturer in education at King's College, London and a former classroom teacher.

Next week's query

My seven-year-old is getting anxious about SATs. I have tried to reassure him that it is not the end of the world but he still seems to be feeling the pressure. What do I do?

fields.headline: Dreaming in colour
fields.standfirst: Britain's reputation for new-media creativity is being held back by the Victorian values of its education system
fields.trailText: Britain's reputation for new-media creativity is being held back by the Victorian values of its education system
fields.body:
Since 1991 I've been running a multimedia unit (started by just two of us) at the Liverpool John Moores University - first working on laser disk titles, then CD-roms and now on hybrids of Internet sites, CDs and DVD materials.

Recently a local journalist asked me how many jobs we had created in the region, and I quickly listed two companies - one, Amaze, employing over 100 and another 15 - as well as a smaller group of sole traders, and people working in twos or threes. And there are 30 people still working in the university unit, of whom I expect a dozen to split off soon to form more companies.

As I ran through this list, 200 jobs seemed a conservative figure; one that, in today's economic climate, is more than likely to grow exponentially. Nor is this in any real sense exceptional - in the city in which I work the older university, the University of Liverpool, could point to similar statistics from their Connect unit, an Internet centre with a more than impressive record.

At one level, I look at the people we have reared here and cannot believe their earning potential, far outstripping anything I could have dreamed of in my education career. Many who have left have realistic ambitions of becoming millionaires; many now in the unit are coming up with Internet ideas more than capable of attracting venture capital.

In my unit, those who are doing well are overwhelmingly young - in their twenties. Most are from Art and Design backgrounds, often with poorish conventional academic skills (a staggeringly high percentage have forms of dyslexia, some profound). They are prepared to work all hours, are completely engaged in their work to the extent that the line between work and leisure is often blurred, and are at ease working in teams and in accepting the need for continual upskilling.

That they are with us at all is interesting, since many of them would have failed in other circumstances. A few years ago, when our own work reached its take-off moment (triggered by large contracts from commercial publishers), we found it hard to find people with the skills we knew were central - the combination of a design sensibility with competence in the relevant software packages (like, at that time, scripting in Macromedia's Director).

Our first work had been successful precisely because we had decided, somewhat impulsively, not to employ computer programmers, but to approach the development of computer materials from the twin angles of design and pedagogy.

The problem we quickly had was obvious - we were unable to find designers with the appropriate skills. We solved this, in Liverpool, by beginning an MA in Multimedia Design programme (in 1995) which we reinforced by starting a six-month intensive postgraduate vocational certificate programme, which we run with Connect at the University of Liverpool.

It is aimed at art and design graduates and our first run of the programme, in 1998, attracted more than 1,000 applicants. The two courses have largely solved the problem we were facing and, of the 20 designers working in my unit at the moment, 13 are from these programmes. More, the companies we have spun out all employ people who have completed these courses.

Yet there is no connection between what we are doing and the rest of the education system. Those we employ, and those who, as a result, are succeeding so brilliantly, were rarely "discovered" during their conventional schooling.

One of our brightest was told by an educational psychologist at 16 that he should think of applying for a job in the local supermarket. His schools had only seen his hopelessness at literacy and missed his outstanding grasp of the visual; and he was only saved by an LEA support teacher who realised that he seemed to be rather good at making things.

Similarly, we have several stars who did a degree in Fine Art where they were actively discouraged from thinking at all about computers. "All you need for Fine Art," said one tutor, "is a pair of hands." The course he was running was (and is) betraying the opportunities that are so dramatically opening for those with an understanding of the processes and conceptual bases of Fine Art when allied to the new media.

The non-alignment between the accidental success of those who have worked for us, and the educational system as a whole is alarming. Here we have a bunch of kids, a world of wealth and fun before them, who almost certainly would do no better in school today than when they were there.

Or even worse: their skills, so critical to the information age, lie in creating easily navigable, understandable, electronically delivered materials. They are the designers and the architects and, in partnership with the content experts, the keyholders in the new digital content industry. They think visually, spatially and laterally; they work with flair, with abandon and panache, creatively brainstorming design solutions to enable users to access vast amounts of material.

Exactly where are these skills in the national curriculum? Aren't these skills now more important than the 19th-century core curriculum? It it right for the creative skills, for which Britain has a reputation, to be marginalised to late afternoon sessions?

Hundreds of thousands of kids in schools would be liberated by an acknowledgement that we are living in different times. The Third Way is not simply a more efficient means of producing a new generation of clerks whose usefulness will be swept aside by the new communications technologies.

These technologies will have been used in schools, for the most part, as a new means of teaching redundant skills: often in drills in those hours decreed obligatory to raise standards, ensuring that those who leave at 16 will be perfectly prepared for work. In the last century.

 Peter Fowler is head of the International Centre for Digital Content at the Liverpool John Moores University. The ICDC is a partnership between the JMU and Phil Redmond, chair of Mersey Television and part-funded by the European Union.

webTitle: Be a survivor, not a victim

fields.headline: Be a survivor, not a victim
fields.standfirst: As bullying escalates, a new initiative aims to teach children how to cope in violent situations
fields.trailText: As bullying escalates, a new initiative aims to teach children how to cope in violent situations
fields.body:
Schools are being urged to use the personal safety strategies that have been successful in the workplace to help youngsters acquire the assertiveness that will help them resist dangerous situations such as bullying and violence.

A resource pack produced this month by the National Confederation of Parent Teacher Associations with the Suzy Lamplugh Trust is aimed at parents, teachers and children. The NCPTA says that parents' three main safety concerns about their children are abduction, bullying and safety travelling to and from school. The material in SafeWise, which includes a video and handbook, covers many more situations in detail, including "date-rape", work experience and the dangers of clubbing for an older age-group.

It also tackles the dilemma of allowing children to develop a sense of independence without exposing them to danger. Getting the balance right between protecting and stifling children seems to be more difficult than ever before.

Reducing car use to make it safer for children to walk to school is impossible, for example, as long as parents regard it as the safest way for their children to travel to and from home. Yet it is the growing number of cars on the school run that has made the roads near schools more dangerous.

The launch of the initiative this week coincided with a spate of news stories about bullying. These included the story of a Nottingham comprehensive that appointed a bodyguard to 13-year-old Amie Salmon, the victim of persistent bullying - a decision that seemed to single her out without dealing with the perpetrators of the abuse.

The media also reported that St George's School in Maida Vale, London - the Roman Catholic secondary where the headteacher, Philip Lawrence, was murdered nearly four years ago - faces closure after further outbreaks of violence, which included attacks on staff. Mr Lawrence's successor, Margaret Ryan, left abruptly, announcing that she was taking "early retirement" after police were called in to break up a fight between two pupils that led to one of them being hospitalised. Mrs Ryan was known to be less keen than Mr Lawrence on excluding troublesome pupils.

Diana Lamplugh, who has worked to promote personal safety in the workplace since her estate agent daughter Suzy disappeared, believes the government could be doing more to help schools draw up anti-bullying policies. She would like to see the idea of specially trained mediators among pupils, with whom children can discuss their problems, more heavily promoted.

"No one deserves to be bullied, and if they are, they should not suffer in silence," she says. "Trained mediators are extremely effective and are proven to have reduced bullying dramatically."

Mrs Lamplugh stressed the importance of learning how to be assertive early in life. "Introducing the concept of personal safety skills and ideas throughout education is incredibly important. If children can learn to avoid violence and diffuse aggression, they are less likely to become victims."

She says the SafeWise strategy is designed to help children practise safety strategies well before they start to seek a greater measure of independence. It would be equally relevant for older teenagers when independence brings further fears faced during work experience or a gap year.

 The SafeWise pack is available from the trust, price £27.50 plus £2 p&p. Send a cheque made out to SLT Training & Resources to: SafeWise, Suzy Lamplugh Trust, 14 East Sheen Avenue, London SW14 8AS.

fields.headline: Clatter of tiny feet
fields.standfirst: Clog dancers are alive and well and living in Stockport
fields.trailText: Clog dancers are alive and well and living in Stockport
fields.body:
Liza Austin-Strange is hurriedly downing micro-waved curry, closely followed by yoghurt. Conventional teaching is over for the day, but she has a long evening ahead. Twice a week, she's here until 8pm to pass on expert instruction to the enthusiastic clog dancers of Banks Lane Juniors.

We are in Stockport, which is part of Greater Manchester in modern, local government terms. In terms of folk tradition, it's very much part of Lancashire, once a hotbed of clog-dancing - its competitive, masculine traditions immortalised by Bill Tidy's late-lamented strip cartoon in Private Eye. Lancashire "cloggies" danced on everything from canal barges to the stages of music halls. Styles varied according to location.

The children of Banks Lane can do any number of styles, plus a few more dances with less localised pedigree. Almost a quarter of the 400 pupils take part, giving up lunchtimes and evenings to hone their skills. They perform at folk festivals from Sidmouth to Whitby. They've given demonstrations in France and Sweden. They have been captured on video and CD, and they were recently visited by barefoot dancers from The Mighty Zulu Nation. "The Zulus were fascinated by the clogs and surprised how skilled the children were," says Austin-Strange.

Collectively, her troupe are known as Fosbrooks after one Jack Fosbrook, a fleet-footed stalwart of Stockport who, rather reluctantly, trained women dancers in the 1920s. The first world war had left the town somewhat short of men. Fosbrook might have been surprised to learn that the vast majority of those who have carried his name into the 21st century are female. "My brother found it hard," confides Samantha Cheetham, 11, one of several girls who has moved on to the local comprehensive but still comes back to clatter her clogs in the Banks Lane gym on Monday and Thursday evenings. "I don't think boys have the same co-ordination."

Austin-Strange is more diplomatic. "I could have as many boys as girls if I ran a separate, male-only class," she says. "But there aren't enough hours in the week."

As it is, there are three or four brave lads out there hammering the parquet floor with around 70 girls. The noise is deafening, but the discipline and co-ordination hugely impressive. Even more so when you consider that some of these youngsters are beginners. "We usually start them at seven because it's quite rigorous for the little ones," says Austin-Strange, before clambering between the straps of an accordion.

"Not everybody has the capability," she goes on, "but every child gets the chance to learn to read music at an early stage. Many of them can sight-read to sing in our community choir or to play the violin for the dancing. I never say to them 'you're no good; give it up'. Eventually, the strugglers tend to drop out. I've just had a letter written 'with great sorrow' from the mother of a year-five girl who's giving up after struggling for three years. Our parents are very supportive. They want their kids to be part of this."

And many of the children take to it as though they've been born with clogs on. Take Nicola Lyons, 11, who started younger than most and can now perform the most extraordinary steps while playing the fiddle at the same time. It's almost as though she's suspended by strings. Her socks are a white blur and her heels click together six inches or so above the ground. Afterwards, she tells me: "It's quite easy when you get used to it." And when I look sceptical, she admits that "it does take a lot of practice". She's had new clogs for Christmas. "You have to wear them in," she says. "The leather can be dead hard at first."

While Nicola's performing, headteacher Jane Caygill points out the rapt expressions of the children watching. "There's no jealousy or rancour there," she observes. She took over the school two years ago, by which time the clog-dancing tradition had been established for two decades. "Wasn't I a lucky bunny," she says. How so?

fields.headline: The Guv'nor
fields.trailText: Who would be a school governor? Why do 360,000 people offer time, energy and expertise for no financial recompense and, on the face of it, little other reward? School governors form the largest volunteer force in this country - what do they get in return?
fields.body:
Who would be a school governor? Why do 360,000 people offer time, energy and expertise for no financial recompense and, on the face of it, little other reward? School governors form the largest volunteer force in this country - what do they get in return?

Last summer, at the National Association of Governors and Managers, we conducted a survey. We were enormously encouraged that, despite the undoubted challenges governors face, they showed tremendous commitment to their schools and the well-being of future generations.

They told us what motivated them; providing support for schools, forging community links, working in a team with staff, helping children and offering community service. Overwhelmingly they mentioned "a sense of achievement".

And they recognised that being a governor had added to their own learning. They wrote of learning new skills, increasing their knowledge of education and "getting the best management experience I've ever had".

Of course, they also told us about the downside. They expressed frustration about bureaucracy and interference from central government. They railed against the constraints, particularly financial, and complained of their work being undervalued. And, if hell is other people, it can also be other governors!

Despite the challenges, they believed they had found a cause worth fighting for. This suggests not only a rational desire to play their part in improving children's education, but also an emotional attachment to their schools.

My experience as a governor of two schools certainly bears this out. But, for those of you thinking of taking the plunge, a word of caution. Beware - governorship can become addictive.

 Jane Phillips is a member of the NAGM national executive committee. NAGM can be contacted on 0121 643 5787.

fields.headline: Stay cool in hot water
fields.standfirst: Your child has been accused of unruly behaviour - or been the victim of it. What happens next?
fields.trailText: Your child has been accused of unruly behaviour - or been the victim of it. What happens next?
fields.body:
At first, when seven-year-old pupil Stefanie Stewart came home from school saying another child had "strangled" her, her parents took it with a pinch of salt. "I asked Stefanie to show me what had happened, and she put her hands round her neck and pressed on her Adam's apple," says her father, Des Stewart. "Then I realised maybe she wasn't exaggerating."

Stewart, a director of a golfing company, and his wife Lorna, an account manager for a high-street bank, telephoned the school, King's Lodge primary in Chippenham, Wiltshire, and arranged a meeting with the head, Jane Ratcliff, and Stefanie's class teacher. The Stewarts left happy that the matter would be resolved and that there would be no more incidents.

That was several months, and many more alleged incidents and meetings, ago. At the beginning of this term, the school offered Stefanie a daily, 10-minute "quiet time" when she could talk to a teacher "to build her confidence in dealing with any conflicts that arose", Ratcliff says. The Stewarts considered this entirely inappropriate. They referred the case to the Secretary of State for Education, who failed to intervene by the deadline set by the lawyer. The Stewarts will now apply for a judicial review.

Ratcliff says she has dealt with the matter in line with her school's behaviour policy. "There have been lots of meetings, and I have offered Mr Stewart more since the beginning of January, but he has chosen not to take that up." Last summer, Ofsted inspectors rated relationships in the school as very good and behaviour as good. Improvements to the bullying policy were implemented in September, and published in January.

Physical attacks on Stefanie have stopped, although Stewart claims she is still being verbally abused. Ten days ago, 13-year-old Amie Salmon was withdrawn from Glaisdale School in Nottingham because her mother believed it was failing to deal with bullies. Have the Stewarts thought of removing Stefanie?

"We did discuss that with her as a last resort," says Stewart, who has been happy with his daughter's educational progress at the King's Lodge. "She said: 'Why should I leave when I haven't done anything wrong?' "

Disagreements between parents and schools over what used to be called discipline, and is now called "behaviour management", happen in all schools. But what can parents expect of schools, and vice-versa? These are questions the government is keen to address. Schools are required to draw up home-school agreements and publish their policies on bullying and behaviour management. Some £500m is being invested over three years in schemes to cut exclusion rates (12,300 permanent cases in 1998) and truancy.

Many teachers have received little training in behaviour management, although a review of the curriculum is under way.

It may comfort teachers that parents whose children are persistent truants will have to pay higher fines, up to £2,500 per parent, and that "reasonable force" may now be used to restrain pupils. There are policies galore. They are worthless, however, if everyone doesn't benefit from them. Schools must have a clear idea of how to do this and, crucially, of how parents can cooperate. Many do, and old methods - parents notified that a child has spent playtime outside the head's office, or a simple system of "black" and "merit" marks" - prevail. But schools at the cutting edge may use more sophisticated programmes, in which buzzwords raise self-esteem and help children help themselves.

High exclusion rates, graffiti, stressed teachers are all signs of a school with behaviour problems. All are familiar to John Bayley, a former teacher who is now a trainer in assertive discipline, brainchild of the American psychologist Lee Kanter. For pupils and parents, it offers a system of progressive warnings, sanctions and rewards. Children know exactly where their bad behaviour is going to lead them, and can draw back. Letters may be sent home to parents, praising good behaviour as well as condemning bad. Schools adapt the framework - in some the children are involved, expressing views on which sanctions and rewards work.

For teachers, it stresses positive thinking, says Bayley: "Instead of telling them what not to do - 'Will you shut up' - you say: 'I'd like your mouths shut, I'd like your hands on your desk, I'd like you facing this way, thank you very much.' "

For the school as a whole, consistency is a key factor, from playground supervisors to the head. Basic training is one all-day session plus two twilight sessions, costing from £2,800. "But you have to leave a team behind to steer the programme and review it," says Bayley. "It's not an instant solution, more like painting the Forth Bridge."

It is Circle Time at Eagle House, an independent prep school in Berkshire. This is a far cry from the schools in which Bayley works, but its approach to behaviour management has common themes: accentuating the positive and involving parents. A group of 10- and 11-year-olds is sitting in a circle, discussing a class rule. "Treat others as you would wish to be treated yourself." One girl expresses difficulty with that. "What does it feel like if somebody is unkind to you? How does it feel inside?" a classmate asks her. "Well, it's horrible," the girl replies. "What you are doing is inflicting that on somebody else. Have you thought about that?" says another.

"What you need to do," someone else chips in, "is count to 10 and walk away before you start to say something that you know is unpleasant." The girl agrees to try.

Even four-year-olds have Circle Time every week, taking it in turns to speak up about anything bothering them. "Younger children come to school more isolated than ever because they no longer play on the street in groups," says Diane Gardiner, head of pre-prep at Eagle House. "They can be quite self-centred, so you have to help them learn to be part of a group. That is a new thing that schools are having to deal with. If a four-year-old is having difficulty sitting in a circle, you congratulate those sitting comfortably and the others will follow suit. We involve the parents in everything, and if issues arise out of Circle Time, such as bullying, we bring them in. If parents feel part of the process, they are less likely to be aggressive. We might get them involved by a system of stars and stickers for their child getting dressed in the morning, or being nice to other children."

Jenny Mosley, founder of Circle Time, works with schools at all levels in the public and private sector. The mother of three teenagers, she advises against showing disloyalty to the teacher. "If you immediately say, 'That bloody teacher', you are causing an emotional split for your child." So what is the right approach for parents of children in hot water? Dorit Braun of Parentline Plus, a charity that offers support to parents and which has produced a new leaflet, Families Working With Schools, says the important thing is to listen to your child without taking sides, discuss issues that arise with the teacher, and come up jointly with a solution.

Most parents want to put things right. To do that they must work with the school, not against it, but they can only do this if they understand the school's approach. "It is perfectly reasonable for schools to expect parents to support their work," says Braun. "But unless the school communicates what it is trying to achieve, a partnership can't develop."

Tips for parents

 When visiting a prospective school, look out for simple class rules that emphasise do's rather than don'ts, and noticeboards that indicate how much communication is going on between home and school.

 Ask to see the home-school agreement and behaviour policy, which should include a clear strategy on dealing with bullies.

 Speak to other parents to see whether they are happy with the procedures for discussing problems.

 Once your child is at school, try to attend some social events as well as parent evenings. Feeling part of the school will help if something goes wrong.

 When a problem arises, listen to your child, but try to reserve judgment. If you are unhappy, ask to speak to the class teacher, or head of year at secondary level, and take someone along if you feel anxious. Stay calm.

 Before the meeting, clarify your points and the outcome you would like. Use wording from the home-school agreement, such as: "I feel Sam's self-esteem is suffering because of this."

 Work out a strategy with the teacher for dealing with the problem, and back it up at home.

 If you are not satisfied, ask to see the head. The governors and the local education authority are the next ports of call.

 For further information about Assertive Discipline, contact Behaviour Management on 0181 944 6161. Jenny Mosley Consultancies is on 01225 767157.

fields.headline: French connection
fields.trailText: At the Howard School in Rainham, a calculated risk has paid off spectacularly, paving the way for an award-winning website and underpinning the school's strategy for raising achievement. The gamble centred on a 26-year-old Frenchman, Stéphane Derne, who came to the school as part of his PGCE training, made a good impression and was offered a job.
fields.body:
At the Howard School in Rainham, a calculated risk has paid off spectacularly, paving the way for an award-winning website and underpinning the school's strategy for raising achievement. The gamble centred on a 26-year-old Frenchman, Stéphane Derne, who came to the school as part of his PGCE training, made a good impression and was offered a job.

"Things went badly wrong at my main teaching practice school in Dover," explains Derne. "My classes were some of the toughest and the support was minimal. I still feel that I was set up to fail." And fail he did. When it was clear that he had little hope of passing his PGCE, he wrote to Maurice Barry, the head of the Howard School, and suggested he should turn down the post he was due to take up in September 1999.

Barry had other ideas. "We knew he could teach because we had seen him in action and when he suggested we needed a French website, we let him get on with it."

In October 1999, Bonjour was born. It quickly established a good reputation and picked up a number of internet awards. "The site philosophy is that it should be steeped in French culture as this is something that is often sidelined in textbooks," says Derne. "It is having a big impact on the school, particularly with some of the younger boys, who can be so hostile to modern languages - once online they seem to forget that it's lesson time."

Derne has also become the school's resident cover-teacher - an essential role given that every department head is guaranteed 32 periods in which to carry out lesson visits and feedback sessions with colleagues. "This programme of professional development is crucial to my five-year plan to turn this school around," says Barry.

The Howard School is in the Medway area of Kent. "It is a prosperous area but there are pockets of deprivation," says Barry. "And as one of the last of a vanishing breed - a bilateral school for boys [part high school, part grammar] - our 1,750-plus roll is truly comprehensive. With only 20% here achieving five or more A-C grades at GCSE our focus is on improving achievement across the board. What is important is having a culture of applause and reward. All children respond to praise - even if, with the older boys, it has to be done rather discreetly."

fields.headline: Literacy 2, sport 0
fields.standfirst: Exercise is on the way out. That is the depressing conclusion of a new report
fields.trailText: Exercise is on the way out. That is the depressing conclusion of a new report
fields.body:
The fat cats of the junk food industry will be feeling just a little fatter this morning. A report published by Sport England confirms what many of us have suspected for years. Our tuberous schools really are turning the nation's children into couch potatoes. In the five years since the previous survey, the proportion of six- to eight-year-olds spending two hours or more per week taking part in PE declined from 32% to 11%. The figures for nine- and 10-year-olds make similarly bleak reading: a decline from 46% to 21%.

Throughout his England career, Trevor Brooking was known as the gentleman footballer, the player who never stood out of line, but in his current role as chairman of Sport England he is sufficiently worried by the findings to have no intention of allowing governmental apparatchiks to spin the implications of the report with a more favourable gloss.

"Children are at their most impressionable between the ages of five and 10," he says, "and they aren't being given the time or opportunity to find out whether they enjoy sport or are good at it. PE teachers at secondary schools tell me they are now working on basic skills with 11- and 12-year-olds that used to be expected of six-year-olds. We're running the risk of losing our next generation of sportsmen and women."

Understandably, Sport England has more interest in elite performers than the rest of us, whose only involvement with top-level sport is the ritual humiliation of watching our national teams on the TV. But the findings don't just affect the best. There is plenty of research, most recently from Germany, to indicate that children who exercise regularly achieve higher attainment levels in core curricular subjects.

Brooking also maintains that sport and exercise have a part to play in stemming student disaffection. "We have a massive problem with youngsters becoming involved in drugs and other anti-social behaviour patterns at an earlier and earlier age," he says. "Sport is hugely overlooked as a means of encouraging more positive attitudes."

Sport England's findings have come as no surprise to David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, whose own survey of PE and sport in schools last year produced almost identical findings. "It is nothing short of a scandal that PE and sports facilities in too many schools are not much better than those in a banana republic," he said. "The fitness levels of a significant number of youngsters and their sedentary lifestyles are already a cause for concern.

It's not hard to identify the causes of the decline. Many urban schools no longer have their own facilities, and despite various pledges from the government about its commitment to preserving school playing-fields, it has also designated brownfield sites as prime development areas. And, yes, school playing fields are brownfield sites.

As the situation stands, these schools have little choice but to abandon any pretence of offering a comprehensive sport programme and to get by as best they can. This often means hiring a coach some distance away and getting pupils back to school in time for the next lesson. Small wonder, then, that many children spend a large part of their allocated two hours of PE in transit. One London primary teacher said that many schools in her local education authority had just about given up making any pretence at maintaining a PE presence on the curriculum.

The other prime culprits are the government's literacy and numeracy strategies, both of which are praiseworthy in themselves but divert energy and attention from elsewhere. "When I started teaching in the early 70s, I used to take sports practices in breaks and at lunchtime," says Chris Thatcher, headteacher of Potters Green primary school in Coventry. "None of us have time for that any more. Teaching has become immensely bureaucratic and most staff have to spend at least a further 90 minutes in the classroom at the end of the day just to keep up. The problem we have is that the government keeps dreaming up new initiatives without considering how they will affect the existing ones. It's time the different departments started talking to one another."

But most parents do care about sport, which is why so many of them get involved with their children's sporting activities outside school. Just listen to some of the dads shouting from the touchline.

Believe it or not, the government likes to take the credit for some of these extra-curricular activities. The curriculum, we are told, should be viewed more fluidly to include activities outside the classroom and classroom hours. So that presumably includes sleeping, which appears to be our youngsters' most popular pursuit.

fields.headline: A good report
fields.standfirst: Parents are happy with the quality of education, but fearful of its pressures.  John Carvel analyses our poll
fields.trailText: Parents are happy with the quality of education, but fearful of its pressures. John Carvel analyses our poll
fields.body:
David Blunkett's cabinet colleagues will be envious of the results of our ICM opinion poll of parents about his handling of education. He gets a glowing half-term report for improving standards, as promised by Tony Blair when he made education a priority in his election manifesto.

Nine out of 10 parents with children at state schools say they are happy with the quality of education, and seven out of 10 think Blunkett is doing a good job.

These ratings give the lie to suggestions that the middle classes are despairing of the standard of state education. Even much-maligned inner-city secondary schools get a satisfaction rating of 89%.

But scratching below the surface, a series of focus groups run for us by ICM to supplement the poll finds parents are becoming nervous about the increasing pace and pressure of education, particularly at nursery and primary stages.

Mothers and fathers were anxious that the regime of homework, testing and league tables was taking something precious away from their children, depriving them of the more relaxed childhood experience that they themselves had enjoyed.

As Blunkett prepares the next stage of his standards crusade, he should pause to reflect that parental anxiety about childhood stress may be the backlash waiting to happen.

The poll was based on interviews of 500 parents, 500 teachers and 100 university lecturers across England. Teachers and lecturers' views will be reported here next week.

Blunkett will take comfort from his personal satisfaction rating, with 62% of parents saying he is doing a fairly good job and 7% saying very good, compared with 19% rating his performance as poor.

This positive response stretched across every boundary of age, sex, gender, region and type of school. It is more pronounced in the inner cities, where parents might have been expected to be more anxious about reports of disadvantage.

Some 91% said they were happy with the quality of their children's schooling. There was no difference in rating between primary and secondary education. In the inner cities the positive response was 96%.

Blunkett will also celebrate results showing 96% of primary parents think he is right to give priority to literacy and numeracy, although 40% think the artistic and creative side is being neglected as a result.

The majority of primary parents think their children's teachers are competent (54%) or highly competent (39%). Only 4% say the teachers are not very competent and 1% not at all competent - a more generous assessment than is usually given by Chris Woodhead, whose parental approval rating lags slightly behind Blunkett's. Asked about Woodhead's conduct of the inspection system, 12% of parents approve strongly and 45% slightly.

These are strikingly good figures. Of course, parents tend to be more appreciative than voters in general when asked to rate their children's state schools, in the same way that patients comment more favourably about NHS hospitals when they have recently undergone treatment. But our sampling suggests the prime minister will continue to gain political mileage from beating his education drum.

The poll gives ministers some areas for concern. Half the parents thought education standards had improved over the past 10 years, but only 38% saw improvement over the past two years, since Labour came to power. The implication is that standards rose under the Conservatives but stopped rising under Labour.

When parents were asked about their own children's schools, 51% with children at the primary stage saw improvement over the past two years, compared with 40% at secondary. In both cases, only 7% thought standards had fallen, but the secondary parents were more likely to see no change. Blunkett's promise to give more attention to secondary education over the next few years may change this perception.

He must also reflect on the policies he pinched from the Tories. His homework initiative is popular: a fifth of parents want it set for four-year-olds and a majority for six-year-olds. But there is scepticism about league tables and an even split of opinion on whether the government is too hard or too soft on teachers.

League table results were a surprise. Although 58% of parents said they were helpful in understanding a school's performance, 39% said they were not. Four out of five parents (81%) said they had not used league tables to select their child's school, and 38% said they should be scrapped. The figures were almost identical for primary and secondary parents. Blunkett might regard these figures as a green light for change.

Some 22% of parents said the government was too tough on teachers, 24% too soft and 38% about right. Middle-aged parents were more inclined to think ministers too soft, but the overall result suggests the government will not gain mileage from teacher-bashing.

Concern about the harshness of the education system emerged more strongly from our focus groups, conducted on the fringes of Birmingham and London with a view to avoiding specifically inner-city or rural concerns.

Primary parents were strongly motivated to do the best for their offspring, but worried about competitiveness among other parents.

Ten years ago, "children were still children. Now they grow up so quickly - they've got to," said a parent from Datchet, Berkshire.

The group of six mothers and two fathers accepted the need for homework, but disliked it. One spoke of five-year-olds coming home with worksheets and three books a night. Others commented: "Even the one in nursery comes back with homework on a Friday", "I don't want my five-year-old stressed out. School's a big enough step without pressure at an early age", "You don't expect little ones to dread going to school. It didn't occur to me to dread it."

Home-school contracts were seen as ridiculous: "How can you get a four-year-old to say: 'Yes I will go to school and I will not kick.' " Punctuality rules were too strict: "If the child's 30 seconds late through the door, they get a late slip. If they get seven late slips, the parent gets called in to see the head or social services."

Asked about discipline problems in school, the parents did not mention indiscipline. Responses were: "It's a bit strict", "My daughter thought I was going to prison because she was late for school."

Despite these problems, the primary parents thought headteachers were more approachable than they used to be, and they were full of praise for teachers, speaking of them as committed, almost martyr-like figures who gave a lot. Teachers' pay was "too low". They got long holidays, "but they earn it". Teachers were more stressed and got less enjoyment from their jobs than previously. Asked to give a single word to describe the profession, the parents offered: "brave", "impressive", "capable", "respect", "heroes", "underestimated", "martyrs".

Asked to describe the ideal primary school, they said it would be state-funded, with about 300 pupils in classes of 15. Each would have "a teacher and a helper", "extra help for special needs children", "no SATs" and "all the equipment they needed". Nobody thought that was likely to happen in 10 years, if ever. "If anything, classes are going to get bigger and teachers' pay will get worse."

Secondary parents were more positive about changes in the past 10 years. A group of four mothers and four fathers with children in Sutton Coldfield comprehensives said schools were "more caring" and pupils were "treated as adults", with more respect from teachers.

They also talked about increased demands on children. "There's more pressure on kids to deliver", "It's a bit of a shock to the system going into GCSEs and A levels." But the general view was that children had to cope with such pressures in the modern world. All said that they would rather be at school now than when they were teenagers.

They were "very pleased" with the standard of teaching, but thought parents' evenings were a waste of time. "You only get one or two minutes with each teacher in a large hall."

Asked about the ideal secondary school, they said it should have smaller classes - 20 rather than 30. Some felt every child should be provided with a laptop computer. Others wanted better sports and technology facilities. Most said secondary schools needed to get better, but expectations of change by the government were minimal.

Sutton Coldfield parents valued the information about local schools in Ofsted reports and thought that inspection was not disruptive.

Most parents in the focus groups did not know who Blunkett was. Three of the eight secondary parents recalled that he was education secretary. The primary group did not recognise the name until one father recalled he was "the MP who tried to get the manager of Sheffield Wednesday sacked". That was a salutary reminder for Blunkett that he still needs to try harder.

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 505 parents of primary and secondary schoolchildren, 501 primary and secondary schoolteachers and 101 university lecturers drawn from nationally representative samples. All interviewing was conducted by telephone from February 8-15 2000. Focus groups were conducted at Sunbury on Thames and Sutton Coldfield on February 15-16 2000. Next week: What the teachers think

webTitle: Bank chief drops hint of loan rates standstill

fields.headline: Bank chief drops hint of loan rates standstill
fields.trailText: The Bank of England hinted yesterday that it might give homeowners and business a respite from dearer borrowing costs, despite new figures showing that domestic demand is growing at its fastest rate since the tail end of the Lawson boom 10 years ago.
fields.body:
The Bank of England hinted yesterday that it might give homeowners and business a respite from dearer borrowing costs, despite new figures showing that domestic demand is growing at its fastest rate since the tail end of the Lawson boom 10 years ago.

David Clementi, one of the Bank's two deputy governors, said last night that there was a chance for a pause in the cycle of interest rates rises which began last September.

"It may well be that there is now an opportunity to wait and see for a period how the economy develops; and this need not damage our prospects of meeting the inflation target," he told an audience in Cardiff.

"This might improve the chances of continued sustainable growth in output and employment and, perhaps, of a return of sterling to a more realistic level."

The Bank's monetary policy committee, which meets to consider interest rates again next week, has worried that its attempts to restrain household spending with higher borrowing costs are pushing sterling to levels which are damaging exporters.

"Within the MPC we are very conscious of the resulting sectoral imbalances within the economy," Mr Clementi said.

The strength of domestic demand was revealed by figures yesterday from the office for national statistics showing that household spending grew by 4.5% between the final quarter of 1998 and 1999. This was the fastest growth since the second quarter of 1989, boosted by the largest increase in pay packets for 10 years.

However, the pace of growth slackened in the final quarter of last year, which some analysts said was a sign that higher borrowing costs were already causing consumers to tighten their belts.

The ONS has revised upward its initial estimate of growth in between the final quarters of 1998 and 1999, to nearly 3%. Its initial estimate of 2.7% was boosted by revisions to industrial production, hotels and restaurants, and distribution, which raised last year's third quarter growth to 1%.

Some analysts think this may be the peak in the cycle, because higher interest rates since last autumn put the brakes on output.

The trade gap sliced a record 1.2% off growth in the final quarter of last year. Without it, the economy would have been expanding at an annualised rate of nearly 8%.

webTitle: Barclays plan for retailers to load cash machines

fields.headline: Barclays plan for retailers to load cash machines
fields.trailText: Barclays could encourage shop keepers to load cash machines with their own takings in an attempt to take banking services back into rural areas.
fields.body:
Barclays could encourage shop keepers to load cash machines with their own takings in an attempt to take banking services back into rural areas.

The idea is one of many that might be considered by the bank if Link, which connects the country's cash machines, can today resolve the deadlock over whether "surcharges" to customers should go ahead.

Barclays wants to charge rival bank customers £1 to use its cash machines while keeping the network free for its own customers. Other banks and building societies either offer the service free or charge a "disloyalty" fee for cash machine withdrawals.

Today's Link board meeting, called to decide on whether surcharges will be introduced, follows an independent treasury-backed investigation that suggests the fees charged by banks for cash machine withdrawals should be capped at 30p.

While that could involve big reductions for some customers who might pay up to £2.50 to withdraw cash, the main banks are expected to argue fiercely that the 29p cost which Don Cruickshank's investigation insists applies to each cash machine transaction, seriously underestimates the real cost to them.

Mr Cruickshank threatened the banks with an investigation if they do not cut costs while the office of fair trading has warned Link it is awaiting the outcome of the meeting to decide whether further investigation is warranted.

The big banks insist they do not make profits on their cash machine networks. HSBC said it cost nearly £70m to run its network while Barclays, the main proponent of "surcharging" rival customers for using is machines, insists it spends £100m a year on its network. The bank says the planned £1 surcharge would allow it to recover 25% of the cost.

Barclays remained convinced of the merits of surcharging - or direct charging - in the hours before today's board meeting. "A direct charging environment [surcharging] would provide creative thinking to solve social banking problems such as those faced by rural communities. For example we might consider allowing a shopkeeper in a rural community to host a smaller cash machine on our behalf in their own shop," a spokesman said.

While Barclays has given its customers free access to the Link network, it is yet to introduce the "surcharge" after the threat of legal action by Nationwide building society. Nationwide, which remains opposed to the surcharging concept, said yesterday that it could continue to offer free access to Link if the surcharge was restricted to 30p.

Nationwide yesterday put an amendment forward for the meeting, calling for a 30p cap. The building society's chief executive, Brian Davis, said: "If surcharging is agreed and our amendments fail, we will call on the government to take direct action."

The agenda for today's meeting shows that if surcharging is agreed to, Barclays will call for a freeze on charging until banks and building societies are able to notify their customers of the charge they face.

Nationwide yesterday put an amendment forward for the meeting, calling for a 30p cap. The building society's chief executive, Brian Davis, said: "If surcharging is agreed and our amendments fail, we will call on the government to take direct action." The agenda for today's meeting shows that if surcharging is agreed to, Barclays will call for a freeze on charging until banks and building societies are able to notify their customers of the charge they face.

webTitle: Success on a plate with takeaways for the over-worked office worker

fields.headline: Success on a plate with takeaways for the over-worked office worker
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: There was a time when grabbing a furtive evening meal in the staff canteen was a sure sign of being overworked and in need of a life. But now it seems the put-upon worker does not even have time to sit down and eat, so a leading catering group has begun experimenting with a new service for employees: takeaway food from the canteen.
fields.body:
There was a time when grabbing a furtive evening meal in the staff canteen was a sure sign of being overworked and in need of a life. But now it seems the put-upon worker does not even have time to sit down and eat, so a leading catering group has begun experimenting with a new service for employees: takeaway food from the canteen.

The service, which allows staff to order frozen meals which they cook at home, has so far proved a success, adding further weight to the argument that in the 21st century work will further encroach on home life.

A range of ready meals is available, including the curry-house staples chicken tikka massala and lamb biriani, to save employees the bother of stopping off on the way home.

Sodexho, formerly the catering group Gardner Merchant, has started trials of its Now for Later service at four blue chip companies in London and Edinburgh, and is delighted at the take-up so far.

Surprisingly the scheme has proved popular on Fridays, with singletons with no plans heading home with a TV dinner in their briefcase.

Spending on food is increasingly moving away from the home and towards restaurants, ready-meals and takeaways. According to figures released by Datamonitor, a market-research company, away-from-home eating accounts for 29% of the British food market.

"We did a lot of research to look at the services people want at work, and they said they wanted the service because it saves them valuable time," said a spokeswoman for Sodexho.

"People also like it because it allows them some spontaneity. If you're due to go out and the other person cancels, then you are able to take some food home with you at the last minute. If you don't have time to cook then it is a positive benefit."

Others are less certain the move will be welcomed by a workforce already spending longer at the office than ever. "If this scheme is being introduced because companies expect that people should be at their desks 60 hours a week then it's poor," said Angela Baron, an adviser at the Institute of Personnel and Development.

"There are many other similar time-saving schemes offered by firms such as ironing services and in-house gyms, which are a cost-effective perk to staff as long as companies don't expect people to work longer as a result.

"There's clear evidence that longer hours lead to high levels of stress, poor performance, more mistakes and lower levels of health in general."
