fields.headline: Zoltan Kocsis
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall, London
Rating: * * * *
fields.trailText: Zoltan Kocsis playing Bartok is one of those rare matches between pianist and composer where the performer's gifts seem perfectly attuned to the demands of the music.
fields.body:
Zoltan Kocsis playing Bartok is one of those rare matches between pianist and composer where the performer's gifts seem perfectly attuned to the demands of the music.

In the Allegro Barbaro, Kocsis launched maniacally into the music's unrelenting rhythms. The boldness of his performance and the monothematic intensity of the music fused in a vivid flash of cubist colour. Meanwhile, Ten Slovakian Folk Tunes, from the For Children set, and the Romanian Folk Dances demonstrated the apparently humble origins of Bartok's musical language in the coolly circling melodies of eastern Europe. But Nine Old Dance Tunes showed how he assimilated the earthy realism of this material into his own idiom, creating music that is by turns exotic and exhilarating.

But it was in Bartok's Piano Sonata that Kocsis revealed the true heights of the composer's creativity - and his own electrifying technique. His energy and rigour turned the work into a motoric tour de force: like a sonic impression of a mechanised, teeming Hungarian forest.

Kocsis's first half presented the apotheosis of the classical, developmental sonata - Beethoven's Opus 111 - and his performance of it was defined by the same violently contrasting tones and colours that he had brought to Bartok. However, as in an earlier account of Mozart's C Minor Fantasy, he sacrificed niceties of phrasing and subtleties of dynamics for rhetorical histrionics. Compared with the alchemical synthesis of Kocsis and Bartok, his relationship with the classical masters seemed strained.

webTitle: HSBC joins global net banking race

fields.headline: HSBC joins global net banking race
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: HSBC yesterday unveiled hsbc.com, its global internet bank, ahead of tomorrow's launch of hugely discounted products by the new internet arm of First Direct, HSBC's profitable telephone bank in the UK.
fields.body:
HSBC yesterday unveiled hsbc.com, its global internet bank, ahead of tomorrow's launch of hugely discounted products by the new internet arm of First Direct, HSBC's profitable telephone bank in the UK.

The London-based bank with operations in 82 countries refused to put a figure on the cost of launching hsbc.com but said it would spend $2bn (£1.25bn) on technology this year, a rise of £187m on last year.

It also said it had set aside £200m to cover bad debts in Korea, the majority of which analysts believe are connected to Daewoo, the car company.

Overall, however, HSBC's bad debt charges fell £355m to £1.25bn in 1999 as economies in Asia, where 38% of its business is based, regained some stability. The group's pre-tax profits rose by 21% to £5bn although profits in the UK banking business, formerly known as Midland, rose less quickly.

The UK bank reported operating profits of £1.3bn, up 1%, restrained by the dollar-sterling exchange rate, the provision against the Korean debtor and another £15m to cover pensions misselling.

Costs in the UK bank operation also rose, mainly because of bonus payments to the traders in its treasury operation. Up to 5% of the UK bank's administration is now handled in China.

Within the UK bank, First Direct, launched 11 years ago as a pioneering telephone operation, reported an £18m rise in profits to £25.8m. First Direct broke even in 1994 after amassing start-up costs of £124m.

Sir John Bond, chairman of HSBC, said First Direct would announce its new, "fiercely competitive" internet products tomorrow. The City believes the products could represent moves by First Direct to offer market-beating rates.

Sir John insisted HSBC's strategy was different to its rivals, all of which announced internet banks during the past fortnight's annual bank reporting season. HSBC already has 400,000 internet customers. "The opportunities of e-commerce change the fabric of the way business is done in financial services," Sir John said.

HSBC, which plans more advertising based on its red hexagonal brand, has already spent the past 18 months developing hsbc.com with IBM. Together, they have created a computer package called IFS to link all its operations.

Sir John said the strategy also involved forming partnerships such as the one with Identrus, an electronic signature company, as well as taking direct stakes in internet firms.

In the UK, HSBC already has 55,000 of its customers signed up to Open, the Sky-led digital television consortium in which HSBC has a stake. It is aiming for 1m hsbc.com customers in a year.

Sir John said the group was not just chasing retail customers. "One of the most exciting markets in the e-age is the commercial market, the small and medium sized enterprises that form a vital part of our strategy and long-standing core business," he said.

The group, which bought the private banking business of billionaire Edmond Safra, who died in a house fire last year, said it would take a £100m restructuring charge in 1999 to cover the cost of the purchase.

The bank's shares, listed in London and Hong Kong where 8% are owned by the Hong Kong monetary authority, fell 3p to 720p in London. It announced a second interim dividend of $0.207per share, taking the total to $0.34.

fields.headline: Mastery of the middle
fields.standfirst:
Andreas Johnson
Manchester University
Rating: * *
fields.trailText: Sporting carefully bedraggled locks and a slinky demeanour, Sweden's latest pop export, Andreas Johnson, strutted on stage with the guile of someone who's been through it all before. Having already fronted two bands at home, the 28-year-old is now attracting as much attention for his rugged jaw line and coy grin as he is for his music. Indeed, his recent radio-friendly single, Glorious, crept into the top five on the strength of a big string arrangement, an impeccable production, and a lot of pretty-boy publicity.
fields.body:
Sporting carefully bedraggled locks and a slinky demeanour, Sweden's latest pop export, Andreas Johnson, strutted on stage with the guile of someone who's been through it all before. Having already fronted two bands at home, the 28-year-old is now attracting as much attention for his rugged jaw line and coy grin as he is for his music. Indeed, his recent radio-friendly single, Glorious, crept into the top five on the strength of a big string arrangement, an impeccable production, and a lot of pretty-boy publicity.

In front of a half-capacity crowd, Johnson eased himself into a set of meticulously orchestrated pop songs, his accomplished mid-range vocals ably accompanied by four backing musicians. Johnson also played guitar, but in endeavouring to appear on the moody side of mellow, his light-fingered strumming came across as merely indifferent. Unfortunately, the same can be said of most of his tunes.

It's not that there's anything drastically wrong with the grandiose melodies, or even with the insipid romanticism of the lyrics - it is only disposable pop, after all - but after half an hour of solid riffs, orchestral keyboards, and an unerring bistro-bar tempo, it was beginning to sound drearily formulaic.

Cruising through tracks from his new album, Liebling, the dark and diminutive Johnson affected Brian Adams's lovelorn croak for The Games We Play, while for Should Have Been Me his voice assumed a Gallagher roughness over strings which threatened to put the song (and the audience) to sleep. Through it all, his expression alternated between a sultry pout and a slightly embarrassed smile. Weren't they supposed to like Swedish pop music over here?

When Johnson shrugged off his jacket to reveal a black sleeveless top and a suntan, his skinny muscularity prompted half a dozen wolf-whistles. Perhaps spurred on by this, the band rocked out a little in Safe From Harm, even incorporating a few changes in pace and a measure of quirky effects. Meanwhile, ever the indolent star, Johnson made sure he sweated just enough for his skin to glisten in the lights.

Of course, everyone had turned up to hear Glorious and they weren't disappointed by a version which dutifully reproduced the epic grandeur of the single. Overall, though, this was perfectly executed mid-tempo pop and, for that very reason, it lacked both spontaneity and edge.

 Andreas Johnson plays Lomax, Liverpool, tomorrow, (0151-707 9977), then tours.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Hungary for more
fields.standfirst:
London Symphony Orchestra/Pierre Boulez
Barbican, London
Rating: * * * * *
fields.trailText: When Boulez was chief conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra in the early 70s, he initiated a ground-breaking series of 20th-century concerts at the Roundhouse in north London. Each programme consisted of a new work, a modern masterpiece and one of the classics of modernism. On Sunday, for the third concert in Boulez 2000, the LSO's celebration of the composer-conductor's 75th birthday, the formula was revived with spectacular success.
fields.body:
When Boulez was chief conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra in the early 70s, he initiated a ground-breaking series of 20th-century concerts at the Roundhouse in north London. Each programme consisted of a new work, a modern masterpiece and one of the classics of modernism. On Sunday, for the third concert in Boulez 2000, the LSO's celebration of the composer-conductor's 75th birthday, the formula was revived with spectacular success.

It was an all-Hungarian affair: the premiere came from Peter Eotvos, the contemporary masterwork was Ligeti's Violin Concert and the modernist classic Bartok's ballet score, The Wooden Prince. The programme was beautifully balanced, full of telling connections: Eotvos's zeroPoints ends with a xylophone flourish that sounded like a homage to The Wooden Prince, while its moments of sensuous wind writing recall Ligeti's textural miracles. The folk melodies that motivate the violin lines in parts of the concerto could not have been so unselfconsciously integrated without Bartok's example.

But neither work is remotely derivative. zeroPoints is a dazzling quarter hour of orchestral virtuosity that repeatedly prefers to start again with new material rather than develop what is already there. It creates a structure that's as quirkily original as it is satisfying. After his distinguished career as a conductor Eotvos's ear for what works in the orchestra is so instinctive - glinting toccatas for strings and percussion, an interlude with saxophones and bluesy muted trumpets, swirling tremolos right across the orchestra - that the images are totally compelling.

There's no shortage of arresting material in Ligeti's violin concerto either. The five movements are concerned with musical uncertainty, whether of pitch (in the retuned strings that blur the solo violin's opening line, or the ocarinas and recorder that destabilise the wind tuning in the later movements) or of tempo, with fast music that sounds slow and vice versa. It's a violinistic piece, indebted to the great concerto literature, and as Christian Tetzlaff demonstrated, a showpiece for a player with the necessary technical equipment.

The LSO made a brilliant showpiece out of Bartok's ballet too, though even Boulez could not disguise the fact that the later scenes are too protracted. But he brought all its colour and rhythmic variety unfailingly to life in music that veers between Wagner, early Stravinsky and what within a few years would become the authentic Bartokian style - there are pre-echoes of works right up to the Concerto for Orchestra, 30 years in the future.

 BBC Radio 3 will broadcast a recording of the concert on March 6.

fields.headline: Accident damages sums to double
fields.standfirst: Appeal court expected to raise test case awards by up to 100%
fields.trailText: Compensation awarded to victims of work, road and medical accidents for their pain and suffering could double following an unprecedented five-judge hearing which began in the court of appeal yesterday.
fields.body:
Compensation awarded to victims of work, road and medical accidents for their pain and suffering could double following an unprecedented five-judge hearing which began in the court of appeal yesterday.

The judges, headed by the master of the rolls, Lord Woolf, are expected to substantially raise the sums awarded by the lower courts in eight test cases, increasing some by as much as 100%. Their judgment will lay down guidelines which will boost awards in future cases.

The appeal court judges normally sit in threes, but five judges will sit for the first time because of the implications for thousands of cases each year. The judges are taking the step after a report by the law commission, the government's official law reform body, recommended a 50-100% rise in damages.

The outcome will not affect damages for loss of earnings and the cost of long-term care, which make up the bulk of £1m-plus compensation awards for the most disabled accident victims.

The judges will look only at the element which is hardest to compensate in financial terms - the effect of the victim's injury in terms of pain, limitations on bodily capacity and inability to enjoy leisure activities.

Damages for the most severe disability, such as permanent paralysis of all four limbs, are currently around £150,000 under informal tariffs set by judges. This could rise to £300,000.

Insurers say the result will inevitably be higher premiums for motorists and employers. The NHS litigation authority believes it could add hundreds of millions of pounds to the health service bill for outstanding liabilities, plus tens of millions a year.

Since the NHS is not insured, the money will have to come from resources which could otherwise be spent on patient care. Christopher Purchas QC, representing John Heil, one of the test case claimants, told the court at the start of the four-day hearing it was "irrelevant" that increases in damages would lead to much higher claims on insurance companies and the health service.

Mr Heil, a former police officer, suffered from post traumatic stress disorder after an incident with an uninsured driver and is unemployed after taking medical retirement from the force.

Mr Purchas said: "The amount of compensation that a claimant is entitled to receive does not depend on the financial standing of the defendant. It does not make any difference whether the defendant is a pauper or a millionaire, whether it makes him bankrupt or puts him into liquidation."

A claimant was entitled to have "full compensation" for losses caused by personal injury, Mr Purchas added.

He said: "We submit the reason why awards have fallen below the appropriate level is that no or insufficient allowances have been made for the change in economic circumstances and increases in living standards during the past 30 to 40 years."

The other test case claimants include two children who suffer from cerebral palsy because their births were negligently managed, and Tracy Kent, who was left brain-damaged after an ambulance took too long to answer a 999 call.

webTitle: I have to leave my brain at home when I go to the office

fields.headline: I have to leave my brain at home when I go to the office
fields.trailText: The problem
fields.body:
The problem

I work for a large airline and although I love my job, I hate the company. The money is below par and the work, though never the same, can be moronic.

I want to find a new job, but am scared to leave as I have forgotten what the world of work is like outside the airport and was forced to switch off my brain some time ago due to it not being required.

This was my first job after university - should I break free and start again from the beginning? I don't know what to do with a modern languages degree.

The solution

Should you break free? Well, if you don't do it now, when will you? And if you don't, you are condemning yourself to a lifetime of boredom. Having said that, you love your job, just hate the company. The solution might be to get a similar job with a different airline. That would solve your worries about leaving your cosy and familiar airport world.

However, I think that you should take a good long look at yourself and career aspirations. You really need to sit down and figure out what you want out of a job. From what you say in your letter, it would seem that you want to be challenged - or at least use your brain - and be paid a decent whack. How important is it for you to use your languages degree? Do you want a job with responsibility, travel, flexibility, prestige etc? And which of these qualities is the most important to you?

It is only when you have really analysed what kind of job would make you happy that you can start trying to get it. I would advise a visit to your university careers centre (you should be able to use any centre free of charge since you are a graduate) where you can take a computerised test that helps match your personal qualities, skills and aspirations with a suitable career.

It might take time and effort to plan a career, but the investment will be well worth it when you land that dream job.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work
(Purple House, £9.99) and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't (Element, £9.99)

fields.headline: A third way budget
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair's favourite guru has some advice for his Downing Street neighbour: cut taxes next month

fields.body:
The idea of the third way has been much derided since Tony Blair introduced, or resurrected, the term in 1997. An unending strew of articles, many of them in this newspaper, proclaim that third way politics is soft Thatcherism - Mrs Thatcher without her handbag. In opting for a third way philosophy, the critics say, New Labour has abandoned the main values of the left - the promotion of public institutions services, protection of the vulnerable and economic redistribution. For such critics, the remedy for these failures is clear. Better funding for public goods is necessary and hence we must put up taxes. In particular, income tax rates should be raised, since penalising the better off directly advances the cause of social justice.

If the government doesn't increase taxes, it is said it is because it is too timid to do so. New Labour is still running in fear of what happened prior to the 1992 election. The Tories hammered home the theme that Labour were about to raise taxes sharply, thus precipitating Labour's defeat. But the party no longer needs to be diffident about the issue, the critics continue. Surveys show people are prepared to see income tax go up in exchange for more well-funded public services. Labour needs to get back to catering for its basic constituency, the poor and the deprived.

No doubt the Labour leadership does worry about the electoral consequences that might follow from tax hikes. But this isn't, or shouldn't be, the major reason why they are to be avoided. The real reason is that the third way proposes a quite different approach to the achievement of social goals from the more tradi tional left. It is one no longer based on the splitting of social and economic policy into separate compartments. As Tony Blair has often pointed out, in the past the right has concerned itself with economic development, the left with social justice. But it won't do to consider either in separation from the other.

Taxation is complex, especially in terms of its consequences for human behaviour. These consequences need to be weighed up when considering changes in tax politics. Such changes normally have effects upon economic activity and hence the overall health of the economy. They can sometimes lead to the opposite effects from those desired. One cannot assume, for example, that higher tax rates always result in higher tax revenues.

It is a mistake for the left to concentrate too much upon high rates of income tax. Steeply graduated, income tax can act as a disincentive, penalising effort and hence job creation. It can also increase levels of tax evasion. Moreover research suggests that the overall level of the tax base, when combined with effective public spending, is more important for social justice than the progressiveness of tax.

The Australian income tax system in the 1980's was very progressive, but the degree of economic inequality in the country was marked. The Swedish tax system, by contrast, had a lower degree of progressiveness, but generated higher relative tax revenue. The level of economic inequality in Sweden was well below that of Australia.

The left must rid itself of the idea that social problems can be solved by increasing tax rates to the greatest extent possible. In some situations, tax cuts can make economic sense and contribute to social justice - as is true of the working families tax credit, introduced by the current government. According to studies done at the London School of Economics, combined with other measures the tax credit should lift 2m children out of poverty by the end of the first term of the Labour government.

The left has traditionally assumed that if deficit spending is reduced public investment will have to decline, while poorer groups will be most adversely affected. Experience from the US in recent years shows that each of these assumptions, while seemingly obvious, is false. Combined with appropriate macroeconomic measures, deficit reduction can foster high labour market participation and economic expansion. Seeking to build up the tax base through fiscal policies that maximise employment possibilities is a fundamental emphasis of third way politics.

It is one that has paid off. Political commentators seem amazed that the chancellor has at his disposal such a large public surplus. The critics seem wilfully to fail to see that this situation is the direct result of policies of fiscal discipline and capital investment, which have generated far more disposable income than would have been true if old left strategies had been adopted. It is not an accident that levels of payment of income tax, VAT and corporation tax are so high Economic progress and social justice can indeed go together. In preparing his budget for March 21, Mr Brown should not deviate from the path he has so ably charted in previous years. For instance, he should implement the planned reduction in the rate of income tax from 23% to 22%, not increase it. He should offer greater tax credits for small business start-ups, provide further incentives for the IT sector, and make further cuts in capital gains tax. Such innovations will help Tony Blair reach his stated objectives for health and education, not inhibit them.

Anthony Giddens is director of the LSE. His book The Third Way And Its Critics is published this week by Polity Press

fields.headline: Mediocrity's rich friends
fields.standfirst:
Snowdon
National Portrait Gallery, London
Rating: *
fields.trailText: There's nothing like a great photographer, and Lord Snowdon is nothing like a great photographer. He's no Cartier-Bresson, just someone who knows how to light a nice piece of Cartier, so it's a bit of a mystery that he has a lavish retrospective at the National Portrait Gallery. One thing's for sure - he's paid his dues in sucking up to the royal and the rich for over 40 years.
fields.body:
There's nothing like a great photographer, and Lord Snowdon is nothing like a great photographer. He's no Cartier-Bresson, just someone who knows how to light a nice piece of Cartier, so it's a bit of a mystery that he has a lavish retrospective at the National Portrait Gallery. One thing's for sure - he's paid his dues in sucking up to the royal and the rich for over 40 years.

Great portrait photographers catch people off guard; Snowdon (as the exhibition deferentially calls him) just encourages them to show off. There are no real personalities here, just pictures of famous people - Stephen Fry, the Queen - that are contrived, gimmicky attempts to dramatise their "personalities". Not once does he make you feel intimate with anyone. What would you do if you were commissioned to take a "lively" picture of Damien Hirst? Snowdon posed his in a fish tank. The gallery is so stunned by this image, it's on the exhibition poster.

Lord Snowdon unfailingly resorts to visual cliche in a glib attempt to capture "character". He is also a master of flattery: when commissioned to photograph Tony Blair for Vanity Fair he made him look resolute in black and white.

And so it goes on, as Snowdon remorselessly exposes the public face of public people. His failure to get beneath the skin of his subjects is sometimes highly ironic. Here's Peter Mandelson relaxing by the minimalist fireplace in his Notting Hill pad, a few months before it caused his resignation. There's Charles and Diana playing happy families.

The only subjects treated with any sensitivity are actors. Laurence Olivier in The Entertainer is haunting. But that's theatre, and the emotion is ready made. Snowdon seems unable to get as excited by real life, instead tricking it out in off-the-peg glamour, as you notice seeing two photographs of different celebrities taken at different times in the same Dorchester suite. In the end the celebs become interchangeable. Was that old man in the beret Igor Stravinsky or Groucho Marx?

On the way out, after all the celebrity happy snaps, you pass through a toe-curling display of social-problem photographs taken for Sunday supplements in the 60s. It's grotesque to see hungry children and the mentally ill - phoney, exploitative pictures when first published 30 years ago - wheeled out again to justify this puffing of a minor talent.

 Until June 4. 0171-306 0055.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible
